ROBINSON CRUSOE,

in an un-inhabited Ifland -on the Coall of A;;crarda
near the Mouth of the Great River Oroonrqzie; having been call on Shore by Shipwreck, wiherein all
the Men perillied but himdfelf.

iL I F E
AND
ADVEN TU RES
O F
Robinon Crufoe, &c.
Was born in the Year 1622, in the City
of Trk, of a good Family, tho' not of
that Country, my Father being a'        oreigner of Bremen, who fettled firf at
R Hull: He got a good Eftlate by Merchandize, and leaving off his Trade, lived
afterwards at Tork, from whence he had married my
Mother, whofe Relations Were named Robinfn,   a very
good Family in that Cotry, and from whom I was
called Robinfon Kreuttner; but by the uftial Corruption of Words in England, we are now call'd, nay, we
call our telves, and write our Name Crufce, and fo my
Companions always call'd me.        -
B                     I




( 2 )
I had two elder Brothers, one of which was Lieu
tenant Colonel to an Englijb Regiment of Foot in F1a
4ers, formerlycommanded by the famous Col. Lockb-t
4tid was killed at the Battle near Dunkirk againfi the
Spanardnis: What became of my Second Brother I never knew, any more than my Father or Mother did.
know what was become of me.
Being the third Son of the Family, and not bred to
any Trade, my Head began to be Iill'd very early with
rambling Thoughts: My Father, who was very ancient, had given me a competent Share of Learning, as far
as Houfe-Education, and a CountryFree-School generally
goes, and defign'd me for the Law; but I would be
iatisfy'd with nothing but going to Sea; and my Incli
nation to this led me fo flrongly againft the Will, nay
the Commands of my Father, and againfi all the En.
treaties and Perfwafions of my Mvother and other
Friends, that there feemed to be tbmething fatal in that
Propenfion of Nature tending diretly to the Life-of
M4ilery which was to befal me.
My Father, a wife and grave Man, gave me ferious
and excellent Counfel againit what he fobre-faw was my
Defign. He called me one Morning into his Chamber,
where he was confined by the Gout, and expoftllated
very warmly with me upon this Subjet: He ask'd me
what Reafons more than a meer wandring Inclination
I had for leaving my Father's Houfe and my native
Country, where I might be well introduced, and had
a Profpe& of raifing my Fortune by Application and
Induftry, with a Life of Ea(e and Pleaftre: He told me
it was. for Men ofdefperate Fortunes on one Hand, or of
afpiring, faperiourFortunes on the other, and who went
abroad upon Adventures, to rife by Enterprize, and
make themfelves famous in Undertakings of a Nature
out of the common Road i that thefe things were all ei
ther too far above me, or too far below me; that nine
was the middle State, or what might be called the upper Station of 06W Zife, which be had fQund by long
Experince was th        e hell State in the World; the mot
uitecd to human Happinefs, not expofec to the Miferies
and Hardlfhiip the Labour and Suffrrings,of the mevhanickPart of Mankind, and not embarafi'd with the
Prido




( 3 )
Pride, Luxury, Ambition and Envy of the upper Part
of Mankind. He told me, I might judge of the Happi;
nefs of this State, by this one thing, sit. That this
was the State of Life which all other People envied;
that Kings have frequently lamented the miferable
Confequencesof being born to great Things, and wilh'd
they had been placed in the middle of the two Extremes,
between the Mean and the Great; that the wife Maa
gave his Tcftimony to this as the juft Standard of true
Felicity, when he prayed to have neither Poverty oC
Riches.
He bid me obferve it, and I fbould always find, that
the Calamities of Life were Ihar'd among the upper and
lower Part of Mankind; but that. the middle Station
had the feweft Difafters, and was not expos'd to fo
many Viciffitudes as the higher or lower Part of Man.
kind; nay, they were not fubjeaed to fo many Diflem.
pers and Uneafinefes either of Body or Mind, as thofe
were, who by vicious Living, Luxury and Extravagances on one Hand, or by hard Labour, want of Neceffaries, and mean or infuflicient Diet on the other Hand,
bring Diftempers upon themfelves by the natural Confequences of their Way of Living; That the middle Station of Life was calculated for all Kind of Virtues, and
all Kind of Enljoyments; that Peace and Plenty were
the Handmaids of a middle Fortune; that Temperance,
Moderation, Quietnefs, Health, Society, all agreeable
Diverfions, and all defirable Pleafures, were the Blef-'
iings attending the middle Station ofLife;that this way
Men went filently and fmoothly thro' the World, and
comfortably outtf it; not embarafs'd with the Labours
of the Hands or of the Head, not fold to a Life'of Slavery for daily Bread, or harrafs'd with perplexed Cir.
cumfiances, which rob the Soul of Peace, and the Body of
Rell; nor enraged with the Paffion of Envy, orthe fecret
burning Lulf of Ambition for great things; but in eafy Circumftances fiding gently thro' the World, and
fenfibly tailing the Sweets of Living, without the Bitter,
feeling that they are happy, and learning by every day's
Experience to know it more fenfibly.
After this, he prefs'd me earneftly, and in the mot
affe~ionate manner, not to play the young Man, nor t
B z                preci.




(4)
precipitate my felfinto Mileries which Nature and the
tration of Liie I was born in, feem'd to have provided
againl; that I was under no Neceifity of fcekirg my
Lread; that he would do well for me, and endeavour
to enter me fairly into the Station of Life which he had
b)een juft recommending to me; and thatif I was not very ealy and happy in the World, it muft be my meer
late, or Fault that muft hinder it, and that he fhould
have nothing to anDvwer for, having thus ditcharged his
Duty in warning me againft Mealures which he knew
would be to my hurt: In a word, that as he would do
very kind things for me if I would flay and fettle at
Home, as he dire&ed; fo he would not have ib much
hand in my ivi isfortunes, as to give me any Encouragement to go away: And to clol all, he told me, I had
my elder Brother for an Example, to whom he had ufed
the fame earnedt Ferfwafions to keep him frcm going
into the Low Country Wars, but could not prevail,
his young Decfres prompting him to run into the Army,
where he was killed; and tho' he laid he would not ceafe
to pray for me, yet he would venture to fiy to me,that if
1 did take this foolifh Step, God would not bleis me,
and I would have Leifure hereafter to refit& upon having negleced his Counfel, when there might be none
to aflift in my Recovery..I obferved in this lafd part of his Difcourfe, which
was truly Prophetick, tho' I fuppofe my Father did not
know it to be fo himfelt; I fay, 1 obferv'd the Tears
run down his Face very plentifully, efpecially when
he fpoke of my Brother who was killed; and that when
he fpoke of my having Leilure to repent, and none to
aflf me, he was lo mov'd, that he broke off the Ditl
courfe, and told me, his Heart was tb full, he could fay
no more to me.
I was fincerely affe&ed with this Difcourfe, as indeed who could be otherwiie? and I refolv'd not to
think of going Abroad any more, but to fettle at Home
according to my Father's Defire: But alas! a few Days
wore it alloff and in fhort, to prevent any of my Fa,.
ther's farther Importunities, in a fewWeeks afterlrefolv-*
ed to run quite away from him. However, I did not atc
fo haltily neither as the firft heat ofmyRefolution promped




( 5 )
ed, but I took my Mother at a time when I thought
her a little plealanter than ordinary, and told her, that
my Thoughts were fo entirely bent upon feeing the
World, that it hould never fettle to any thing with ReIblution encugh to go through with it, and my Father
had better give me his Conient, than force me to go
without it; that I was now eighteen Years old, which
was too late to go Apprentice to a Trade, or Clerk to
an Attorney; that 1 was lure, if I did, 1 Ihould never
ferve out my Time, but I lhI uld certainly run away
from my Mafter before my Time was out, and go to
Sea; and if fhe would fpeak to my Father to let me go
one Voyage abroad, ifl came home again and did not
like it, I would go no more, and 1 would promife by a
double Diligence to recover the Time that 1 had lott.
This put my Mother into a great PalTon: She told
me, the knew it would be to no purpofe to fpeak to my
Father upon any iuch Subject; that he knew too well
what was my Intereft, to give his Confent to any
thing fo much for my Hurt, and that Ihe wondered how
I could think of any fuch thing, after the Ditcourte
I had had with my Father, and iuhh kind and ten*
der Expreffions as the knew my Father had uled to m 1;
and that in fhort, if f would ruin my felt, there was no
help for me; but 1 might depend I ihould never have
their Confent to it: That for her part ihe would not
have fo much hand in my Deftrufion; and I ihould
never have it to fay, that my Mother was willing when
my Father was not.
Tho' my Mother refufed to move it to my Father,
yet, as I heard afterwards, that fhe reported all the
Ditcourle to him; and that my Father, after fhewvinga
great Concern at it, {aid to ier with a Sigh, That Boy
might be happy if he would flay at Home, but if he
goes Abroad, he will be the moft miterablell Wretch
that ever was born; I can give no Content to it.
It was not till almoft a Year after this that I broke
loofe, tho' in the mean time I continued obftinately
deaf to all Propotals of fettling to Bufinels, and frequently expoltulating with my Father and Mother, about
their being fo poiitively determin'd againft what they
knew my Inclinations prompted me tj. But being one
B 3                  Day'




(6)
Day at Hu/g, where I went cafually, and without any
purpofe of making an Elopement that time; but I fay,
being there, and one of my Companions being going
by `ea to Lindon in his Father's Sllip, and prompting
me to go with them, with the common Allurement of
Seafaring Men, viz That it fhould coil me nothing for
my Paflage, I conifuted neither Father or Mother any
more, nor lb much as lent them word of it; but leaving them to hear of'it asthey might, without asking
God's Bleffing, or my Father's, without any Confide'ration of'Circumnfances or Confequences, and in an ill
Hour, God knows, on the firft of September 1651, I
went on Board a Ship bound for London: Never any
young Adventurer's Misfortunes, I believe, began fooner, or continued longer than mine: The Ship was no
fooner gottenout of the Humber, but the Wind began to
blow, and the Sea to rife in a mol} frightful manner;
and as I had never been at Sea before, I was moll inexpreflibly tick in Body, and terrify'd in Mind: I began
now Ifrioufly to refloe  upon what I had done, and how
jitlly I was overtaken by theJudgment of Heaven for my
wicked leaving my Father's Houfe, and abandoning my
Duty; all the good Counfel of my Parents, my Father's
Tears, and my Mother's Entreaties came now frefh into
my Mind, and my Confcience, which was not yet come
to the Pitch ofHardrefs to which it has been fince, reproach'd me with the Contempt of Advice, and the
Breach of my Duty to God and my Father.
All this while the Storm encreas'd, and the Sea, which
I had never been upon before, went very high, though
nothing like what I have feen many times fince; no,
nor like what I faw a few Days after: Butt it was enough
to affe& me then, who was but a young Sailor and had
never known any thingpf the matter. I expe&ed every
Wave would have fwallowed us up, and that every time
the Ship fell down as I thought it did, in the Trough or
Hollow of the Sea, we ihould never rife more: In this
Agony of Mind, I made many Vows and Refolutions,
that if it would pleafe God to fpare my Life in this
one Voyage, if ever I got once my Foot upon dry Land
again, I would go diredly home to my Father, and newrr fet it into a Ship again while I lived; that I Woaldd'
take




(7)
take his Advice, and never run my felf into fuich Mifre
ries as there any more. Now I faw plaitly the Goodnefs of his Obfervations about the middle Station of Life,
how eafy, how comfortable he had lived all his Days, and
never had been expofed to Tempefts at Sea, or Troubles
on Shore; and in fhort I refolv'd that I would, like a true
penting Prodigal, go home to my Father..Theif wile and fober Thoughts cortinued all the
while the Storm continued, and indeed fome time after;
but the next Day the Wind was abated and the Sea calnier, and  began to be a little inur'd to it: However,
I was very grave for all that Day, being alfo a little Seafick fiill; but towards Night the Weather clear'd up,
the Wind was quite over, and a charming fine Evening
fbllow'd; the Sun went down perfectly clear, and rofe
fo the next Morning, and having little or no Wind, and
a fmooth Sea, the Sun fhining upon it, the Sight was,
as I thought, the moft delightful that ever I faw.
I had flept well in the Night, and was now no more
Sea-fick, but very chearful; looking with wonder upon
the Sea that was fo rough and terrible the Day before,
and could be fo calm and fo pleafant in fo little time after. And now left my good Refolutions flould continue, my Companion, who had indeed enticed me awayE
comes to me, Well Bob, fays he, clapping ire upon the
Shoulder, H iw do you do after it? 1 warrant, you were
frigted, wva'n't you, ladf Nihrt, ruhen it blew but a Ca
full of Wind? A Cap full dyou call it? aid I, 'twas a ter.
rible Stcrm: A Storm, you Fool yu, replies he, do you
tall that a Storm, why- it was nothing at all; give us but
t gbood Ship and Sea-room, and t  hink i nothing of fucb
a guaul of Wind as that; butyoure but a fretl WateSuikrt
L3lb: come let us make a Beol of Punch, and we'll rfet
all that;' dye fee wiat charming Weather 'tis ncwv? To
moke fhorit this fad Part of my Story, we went the way
-of all Sailors, the Punch was made, and I was made half
~drunk with it, and in that one Night's Wickednefs t
drown'd all my Repentance, all my Refle&ions upon my
paft Condu&t, all m  Refolutions for the future. In a
word, as the Sea was return'd to Its fmoothnefs of Surface and fettled Calmnefs by the abatement of that
Storm, fo the Hurry ofy Thoughts being over my
13 4                Fears




(8)
Fears and Apprehenfions ot being fwallow'd up by Sea
being torgotten, and the Current ot my former Defires
rcturn'd, t entirely fbogot the Vows and i-romitis that
I made in my Dilfrefs. 1 found indeed ibmle Intervals
of Rele&ion, and the ferious Thoughts did, as it were,
endeavour to return again fome times; but 1 lhook them
off and rouz'd my ielt'front them as it were from a
Diitemper, and applying my felf to Drinking and Company, foon mailer'd the Return of thofe Fits, (for fo
I call'd them) and I had in five or iix Days got as compleat a Vii&ory over Contcience, as any young Fellow
that refolv'd not to be troubled with it, could defire:
Lut I was to have another Trial for it frill; and Providence, as in luch Cafes generally it does, relblv'd to
leave me entirely without excufe; For if I would not
take this for a Deliverance, the next was to be iich a
one, as the worf and mofl harden'd V\ retch among us
would contefs both the Danger and the Mercy.
The fixth Day of our being at Sea, we came into
Tarmouth Roads; the Wind having been contrary, and
the Weather calm, we had made but little Way fince
the Storm. Here we were oblig'd to come to an Anchor,
and here we lay, the Wind continuing contrary, vi{.
at South-Wefl, for feven or eight Days, during which
time a great many Ships from NewcaJile came into the
time Roads, as the common Harbour where the Ships
might wait for a Wind for the River.
We had not however rid here fo long, but we fhould
have Tided it up the River, but that the Wind blew too
freih; and after we had lain four or five Days, blew
very hard. However, the Roads being reckoned as
good as a Harbour, the A nchorage good, and our GroundI' ackle very ftrong, our Men were unconcerned, and
not in the leat apprehenufie of Danger, but fpent the
Time in Reft and Mirth, after the manner of the Sea;
but the eighth Day in the Morning, the Wind increafed,
and we bad all Hands at work to ftrike our Top-Mafls,
and make every thing fnug and clofe, that the Ship
might ride as eatfy as poffible. By Noon the Sea went
very high indeed, and our Ship rid ForecaJie in, ihipped feveral Seas, and we thought once or twice our Anchor had come Home; upon which our Mailer order'd
out




( 9)
out the Sheet- Anchor; lo that we rode with two Anchors a-head, and the Cables vered out to the better End.
By this Time it blew a terrible Storm indeed, and
now I began to lee Terror and Amazement in the Faces
even of the Seamen themtelves. The Matter, tho' vigilant in the Bufinefs of preferving the Ship, yet as he
went in and out of his Cabin by me, I could hear him
fottly to hinlilf' lay feveral times, Lord be merciful to us,
weJhall be all loft, we Jball be all undone; and the like:
During thefe firft Hurries, I was ilupid, lying ftill in my
Cabin, which was in the Steerage, and cannot defcribe
m) Temper: I could ill refume the firtl Penitence which
I had to apparently trampled upon. and tarden'd my
feltagainif: I thought the Bitterneis of Death had been
pat, and that this would be nothing too, like the firft.
But when the Mailaer himfelf came by me, as I faid jutt
now, and faid we fhould be all loft, I was dreadfully
frighted: I got up out of my Cabin, and look'd out;
but fuch a difinal Sight I never faw: The Sea went
lMountains high, and broke upon us every three or four
Minutes: When I could look about, I could fee nothing but Difirefs round us: Two Ships that rid nearus, we found, had cut their Mails by the Board, being.
deep loaden; and our Men cry'd out, that a Ship which
rid about a Mile a-head of us, was founder'd.  Two
more Ships being driven fronm their Anchors, were run
out of the Roads to Sea, at all Adventures, and that not
with a Mail (landing. The light Ships fared the beflt
as not fo much labouring in the Sea; but two or three
of them drove, and came dole by us, running away with
only their Sprit-ail out, before the Wind.
Towards Evening the Mate and Boatfwain begI'd.
the Mailer of our Ship to let them cut away the ForeMad, which he was very unwilling, to: But the Boatriain protefting to him, that if he did not, the Ship
would founder, he contented; and when they bad cut:
away the Fore-mall, the Main-mal flood fo loofe, and
lhook the Ship, to much, they were obliged to cut her
away alfo, and make a clear Deck.
Any one may judge what a Condition I mall be in
at all this, who was but a young Sailor, and who had
bWn in fuich a Fright before at but a little. But if I
B 5        '        ca




( to )
can exprefs at this diftance the Thoughts I had about
me at that time, I was in tenfold more Horror of Mind
upon accoiut of my former Convitions, and the havhig returned from them to the Refolutions I had wickedly taken at firft, than I was at Death itfelf; and
thefe, added to the Terror of the Storm, put nie in fuch
a Condition, that I can by no Words deferibe it. But
the worif was not come yet; the Storm continued with
fuch Fury, that the Seamen themfelves acknowledged
they had never known a worfe. We had a good Ship,
but fhe was deep loaden, and wallowed in the Sea, that
the Seamen every now and then cried out, the would
founder. It was my Advantage in one refpe&, that I
Aid not know what they meant by founder, till I en.
uir'd. However, the Storm was fo violent, that I faw
what is not often feen, the Mafter, the Boatfwain, and
fome others more fenfible than the reft, at their Prayers, and expe&ing every moment when the Ship would
go to the Bottom. In the middle of the Night, and
under all the reft of our Diffreffes, one of the Men that
had been down on purpofe to fee, cried out we had
fprung a Leak; another faid, there was four Foot Wa.
-ter in the Hold. Then all Hands were called to the
Pump. At that very Word my Heart, as I thought,
-died within me, and I fell backwards upon the fide of
ny Bed where I fat, into the Cabin. However, the
Men rouz'd me, and told me, that I that was able to
ido nothing before, was as well able to pump as another,
at which I ftirr'd up, and went to the Pump, and
vork'd very heartily. While this was doing, the Ma.
Qer ibeing tome light Colliers, who, not able to ride out
the Storm, were oblig'd to flip and run away to Sea,
wnd would come near us, order'd to fire a Gun as a Signal ofDiftrefs. I who knew nothing what that meant,
*ias fo furprized, that I thought the Ship had broke, or
fome dreadful thing happened. In a word, I was fo
furprized, that I fell down in a Swoon. As this was a
time when every body had his own Life to think of, no
body minded me, or what was become of me; but another Man ftept up tothe Pump, and thrufting me afide
with his Foot, let me lie, thinking I had been dead;
ad it was a great while before I came to my fclf.

We worked on, but the Water encreafing in the Hold
it was apparent that the Ship would founder; and thoe
the Storm began to abate a little, yet as it was not poffible lhe could fwimtill we might run into any Port, 6t
the Mafter continued firing Guns for Help; and a light
Ship who had rid it out juit a-head of us, ventured a
Boat out to help us. It was with the utmofft Hazard
the Boat came near us, but it was impoffible for us to
get on Board, or for the Boat to lie near the Ship fide%
till at lald the Men rowing very heartily, and venturing their Lives to fave ours, our Men caft them a Rope
over the Stern with a Buoy to it, and then vered it ouc
& great Length, which they after great Labour and Hazard took hold of, and we haul'd them clofe under our
Stern, and got all into their Boat. It was to no purpofe for them or us, after we were in the Boat, to think
of reaching to their own Ship; fo all agreed to let her
drive, and only to pull her in towards Shore as much
as we could, and our Mafter promired them, That if the
Boat was ftav'd upon Shore, he would make it good
to their Mafter: So partly rowing and partly driving;
our Boat went away to the Northward, (loping to'wards the Shore, almoft as far as Winterten-Nejs.
We were not much more than a Quarter of an Hour
out of our Ship, but we faw her fink: And then l underflood for the firft time, what was meant by a Ship
founderingin the Sea. 1 Muft acknowledge I had hard*
ly Eyes to look up, when the Sea-men told me the was
finking; for trom that Moment they rather put me
into the Boat, than that I might be faid to go in, m/
Heart was as it were dead within' me, partly with
Fright, partly with Horror of Mind, and the Thpughts
Of what was yet before me.
While we were in this Condition, the Men yet lalouring at the Oar to bring the Boat,near the Shore'
we could fee, (when our Boat Imlintihn the Waves,

( I2 )
broke off a little the Violence of the Wind.; Here we
got in, and tho' not without much Difficulty, got all
&afe on Shore, and walk'd afterwards on Foot to 72rmouth, where, as unfortunate Men, we were ufed with
great Humanity, as well by the Magiltrates of the
Town, who ailign'd us good Quarters, as by particular Merchants and Owners of Ships; and had Money
given us fufficient to carry us either to London, or back
to Hall, as we thought fit.
Had I now had the Senfe to have gone back to
Hull, and have gone Home, I had been happy, and my
lather, an Emblem of our bleffed Saviour's Parable,
had even kill'd the fatted Calt for me; for hearing the
Ship I went away in, was caft away in Tarmouth Road,
it was a great while, before he had any Affurance that
I was not drown'd.
But my ill Fate pufli'd me on now, with an Obftinacy that nothing could refill; And tho' I had feveral
times loud Calls from my Reafon, and my more compofed Judgment to go home, ) et I had' no Power to
do it: I know not what to call this, nor will I urge,
that it is a, ecret over-ruling Decree, that hurries us on
to be the Inflrunments of our own Deftru&ion, even
tho' it be before us, and that we pufh upon it with our
Eyes open. Certainly, nothing but fome fuch decreed
unavoidable Mifery attendirig, and which it was impollible for me to efcape, cJuld have pufhli'd me forward
againil the calm Reafonings and Perfwafions of my molt
retired Thoughts, and againft two fuch vifible InftrucLions as I had met with in my firft Attempt.. My Comrade, who bad help'd to harden me be.
oreg and who was the Maifer's Son, was now leis forward than I. The firft time he fpoke to me after we
were at Tarmouth, which was not till two or three
Days; for we were feparated in the Town to feveral
iQuarters: I fay, the firfl time he he law me, it appear'd
his Tone was alter'd; and looking very melancholy, and
4haking his Head, ask'd me how I did: And telling his
lather who I was, and how I had come this Voyage
only for a Tryal, in order to go farther abroad; his
Father turning to me with a very grave and concerned
Toe; T, ung MAan, fays he, you ought never to go to Sea

upon that I told him ibme of my Story; at the End of

was farther than he could have Authority to go: However, he afterwards talk'd very gravely to me, exhorme to go back to my Father, and not tempt Providence
to myt uin; told me I might fee a vifible Hand of

We parted toon after; for I made him little Anfwer,
and I law him no m)re; which way he went I know not:
As for mb having tome Money in my Pocket,I travelled
to London by Land; and there, as well as on the Road, had
many Struggles with my felt, what Courfe of Life I
flould take,and v hether I thould go Home, or go to Sea.
As to going Home, Shame oppofed the beft Motions
that offer'd to my Thoughts; and it. immediately. Ccurr'd to me how I fhould be laugh'd at among the
Neighbours, and fhould be afham'd to fee, not my Father
and Mother only, but even every Body elfe: From
whence I have fince often obferv'd how incongruous and
irrational the common Temper of Mankind is, efpecially' of Youth, to that Reafon which ought to guide
them in fuch Cafes, vii. That they are not afliam'd to
fin, and yet are afham'd to repent; not afham'd of the
Adion for which they ought juftly to be efteem'd Fools;
but are afhamed of the returning, whic. only can make
them eiteem'd wife Men.                        In




( 4)
tn this State of Life however I remain'd fome time;
uncertain what Meafures to take, and what Courfe of
Life to lead. An irrefiflible Relu&ance continued to
going Hote; and as I itay'd a while, the Remembrance
of the Diftrefs I had been in wore off; and as that abated, the little Motion I had in my Defires to a Return, wore off with it, till at laft I quite laid afide the
Thoughts of it, and look'd out for a Voyage.
That evil Influence which carried me firft away
from my Father's Houfe,which hurried me into the wild
atd indigefted Notion of raifing my Fortune; and that
imprefs'd thofe Conceits fo forcibly upon me, as to make
me deaf to all good Advice, and to the Entreaties, and
even the Commands of my Father; I fay, the fame
Influence, whatever it was, prefented the moft unfirtunate of all Enterprizes to my View; and I went on
board a Veffel bound to the Coaft of Africa, or, as our
Sailors valgarly call it, a Voyage to Guiney.
It was my great Misfortune, that in all there Adventures I did not fhip my felf as a Sailor; whereby,
tho' I might indeed have work'd a little harder than
ordinary, yet at the fame time I had learn'd the Duty
and Office of a Foremaft Man; and in time might
have qualified my felf for a Mate or Lieutenant, if not
for a- Mafter. But as it was always my Fate to chute
for the worfe, fo I did here; for having Money in my
Pocket, and good Cloaths upon my Back, I would alays go on board in the Habit ofa Gentleman; and fo t
neither had anyBtfinefs in the ShiP,or learn'd. to do'any.

foys and Trifles as the Captain dire&fed me to buy.
rhis 4u 1. I had mufter'd together by the Affiflance of

This was the only Voyage which I may fay was fuccefsful in all my Adventures, and which I owe to the
pntegrity and Honefly of my Friend the Captain; un-!der whom alfo I got a competent Knowledge ofthe
Mathematicks and the Rules of Navigation, learn'd how
to keep an account of the Ship's Courfe, take an Obfervation, and, in flort, to underftand fome things that: were needful to be underftood by a Sailor: For as he
took delight to introduce me, I took delight to learn;
Iand, in a Word, this Voyage made me both a Sailor
and a Merchant: For I brought home 5 Pound 9 Ounces of Gold-Duft for my Adventure, which yielded me
in London at my Return, almoit 3001. and this filled
me with thofe afpiring Thoughts which have fince fo
compleated my Ruin.
Yet even in this Voyage I had my Misfortunes too;
1 particularly that I was continually fick, being thrown
into a violent Calenture by the excefive Heat ef4he:      Climate; our principal Trading being upon the Coat,
jfrom the Lat. of i5 Degrees N. even to the Line it fel.
I was now fet up for a Guney Trader; and my Friend
to mygreat Misortune, dyiibg foon after his Arrival, j
refolved to go the fame Voyage again, and I embark'd
in the fame Vefiel with one who was his Mate in the
former Voyage and had now got the Command of the
Ship. This was the unhappieft Voyage that ever Man
made; fbr tho' I did not carry quite 10o 1. of my new
gain'dWcalthhfo that I had 2oo0leftanid ewich I lodg'd
with




( I6;)
with my Friend's Widow, who was very juft to me,
yet I fell into terrible Mistortunes in this Voyage; and
the firlt was this, vit. Our Ship making her Courie to.
wards the Canary Iflands, or rather between thole Hiands
and the African Shore, wasiurpriz'd in the Gray of the
vioining by a Mocrijb Rover of Saliee, who gave chace
to us with all the Sail ihe could make. We crowded
aloi as much Canvafs as our Yards would fpread, or our
Mails carry, to have got clear; but finding the Pirate
gain'd upon us, and would certainly come up with us in
a few Hours, we prepared to fight; our Ship having
12 Guns, and the Rogue iS. About three in the Atternoon he came up with us, and bringing to, by miltake,
uit athwart our Quarter, inilead of atnwart our Stern,
ashe intended, we brought 8 of our Guns to bear on that
iide, and pour'd in a broadfide upon him, which made
him fheer off again, after returning our Fire, and pouring
in alib his inall Shot from near 20o Men which he had
on board. However, we had not a Man touch'd, all
9ur Men keeping clofe: He prepar'd to attack us again,
and we to detend our filves; but laying us on Board the
pext time upon our other Quarter, he entered 90 Men
upon our Decks, who immediately tell to cutting and
backing the Decks and Rigging. We ply'd them with
Small-hot, Half-: ikes, Powder-Chells, and fuch like,
iand clear'd our Deck of them twvice. However, to cut
ihort this melancholy part of our Story, our Ship be.
ing difabled, and three of our Men kill'd, and eight
wounded, we were obliged to yield, and were carry'd
all Prilbners into Sallee,.a Port belonging to the Moors.
The Ufage I had there was not fo dreadful as at firft
Ipprehelnded; nor was I carried up the Country to
the Emperor's Court, as the reft of our Men were, but
was kept by the Captain of the Rover, as his proper
Prize, and made his Slave, being young and nimble, and
fit for his Bufinefs. At this furprizing Change of my
Circumitances, from a Merchant to a Milerable Slave,
I was perfe&-ly overwhelmed; and now I look'd back
upon my Father's prophetick Difcourfe to me, that [
iiould be mifcrable, and have none to relieve me, which
I thought was now fo effe&tually brought to pafs, that [
could inot e worfe ithat now the Hand of Heaven had!  *  -ovr




7)
overtaken me, and I was undone without Redemptionm
But alas! this was but a Tafte of the Mifery I was
to go thro', as will appear in the Sequal of this Story.
As my new Patron, or Mafter, had taken me home
to this Houfe, fo I was in Hopes that he would take me
with him when he went to Sea again, believing that it
would fome time or other be his Fate to be taken by a
Spanijh or Portugal Man of War; and that then I fhould
be fet at Liberty. But this Hope of mine was foon ta.
kerl away; for when he went to Sea, he left meon Shore
to look after his little Garden, and do the common
Drudgery of Slaves about his Houfe; and when he came
home again from his Cruife, he ordered me to lie in the
Cabin, to look after the Ship.
Here I mediated nothing but my Eicape, and what
Method I might take to effect it; but found no way that
had the leaft Probability in it: Nothing prefented to
make the Suppofition of it rational; for I had no Body
to communicate it to, that would embark with me, no
Fellow Slave, no EngliJhman, fril/bnn, or Scctfman
there but my felt; ib that for two Years, tho' 1 often
pleafed my felf with the Imagination, yet I never had
the leatf encouraging 2rofpec of putting it in Pra6tice.
i      After about two.Years, an odd Circumfiance prelented it felf, which put 'the old Thoughts of making fome
attempt for my Liberty again in my Head: My Patron
lying at' home longer than ufual, without fitting out
his Ship, which, as I heard was for want of Money,
he ufed conftintly once or twice a Week, fometimes oftner, if the Weather was fair, to take the Ship's Pinnace,
and go out into the R1oad a filhing; and as he always
took me and a young Marefco with him to row the Boat~
we made him very merry, and I prov'd verydexterous in
catchingFifh; infbmch, that fometimes he would fend me
with a ~i[oor, one of his Kinfmen, and the Youth the,V!arejco, as they called him, to catch a Dith of FiIh for him.
It happened one time, that going afifhing with him in
calm lorning, a Fog rote lb thick, that tho' we were
not half a League from' the Shore, we loft fight of it;
ahnd rowing we knew hot whither or which way, we.
labour'd all Day, and all the next Night; and when the:
~lornin cae w    f   d w e d e had pu'd off to Sea, in



ftead of pulling in for the Shore; and that we were at

well in again, tho' with a great deal of Labour, and
fome Danger; for the Wind began to blow pretty frefh in
the Motning; but particularly we were allvery hungry.
But our Patron warn'd by thisDifafter, refolved to
take moreCare of himfelfforthe future; and having lying
by him the Long-Boat of our Engljb Ship which he had

without a Compafs and iobme Provifion; fo he order'd
the Carpenter of his Ship, who alto was an Englifb
Slave, to build a little State-roomn or Cabin in the middie of the Long-Boat, like that of a Barge, with a Place
to ftand behind it to fleer,'and haul home the Main-iheet;
and room before for a hand or two to ftand and work
the Sails. She fail'd with that we call a Shoulder of
Mutton Sail; and the Boom gibed over the Top of the
Cabin, which lay very fnrg and low, and had in it,
toom for hiti to lie, with a Slave or two, and a Table
to eat on, with fnme frmall Lockers to put in fome Bottles of fuch Liquor as he thought fit to drink; particularly his Bread, Rice and Coffee.
We were frequently out with this Boat a fifhing; and
and as I was moft dextrous to catch PFih for him, he
never went without me. It happened oneday, that he
had appointed to go out in this Boat, either for Pleafre.or for Fifh, with two or three Moors of fime
Diffiniion, and for whom he had provided' extraordinarily; and hadl therefore fent on Board the Boat over
Night, a iarger Store of Provifions than ufual; aid
had ordered me to get ready three 'Putees with Powder and Shot, which Were on Board his Ship; for that
theydefign'd fome fpojt of Fowiing as wel as Fifini.
I got all things ready as he had dire&ed, and wiitel
the next Morning with the Boat waffed clean, her An
tlent and Pendants out, and every thing to accommodate his Guefis; when by and by my Patron came on

upon fome BUfinefithat fell out, and order'd meIwith

ifbh, I fhould bring it home to his Houfe: All which
I prepared to do.
This Moment my former Notions of Deliverance
darted into my Thoughts; for now I found I was like
to have a little Ship at my Command; and my Ma.
fler being gone, I prepar'd to furnifli my felf, not for
fifhing Bufinefs, but for a Voyage; tho' I knew not,
neither did I fo much as confider whether I fhould fleer
for any where to get out of that place was my Way.
My firit Contrivance wasto make a Pretence to fpeak
to this Moor, to get fomething for our Subfillence on
board; for I told him we mufl not prefume to eat of
our Patron's Bread; he faid, that was true; fo he
brought a large Basket of Rusk, or Bisket, of their kind,
and three Jarrs with frefh Water into the Boat: I knew
where my Patron's Caie ofBottles flood, which it was
etident by the Make, were taken out of fome Englijf
Prize; and I convey'd them into the Boat while the
M;oor was on Shore, as if they had been there before,
for our Mafter: I convey'd allb a great Lump of BeesWax into the Boat, which weigh'd about half a Hundred Weight, with a parcel of Twine or Thread, a
Hatchet, a Saw, and a Hammer, all which were of
great ufe to us afterwards efpecially the Wax to make
Candles. Another Trick I try'd upon him, which he
innocently came into alfo: His Name waslfmaet,   whom
they call Mildy, or Moloy; fo I call'd to him, Moloy, faid
I, our Patron's Guns are all on Board the Boat, can
you not get a little Powder and Shot, it may be we may
kill fome Alcamies (a Fowl like our Curlieus) for our
felves, for I know he keeps the Gunner's Stores -in the
Ship? Yes, fys he, I'll bring fome; accordingly he
brought a great Leather Pouch, which held about a
'omlud and a half of Powder, or rather more; and another with Shot, that had five or fix Pound, with
fome Bullets, and put all into the Boat: At the fame
Time I had found fome Powder of my Matter's in the
great Cabin, with which I fil'd one of the large Bottles in the Cafe, which was almott empty; pouring what
was in it into another: And thus furnifhed with every
thing needful, we fail'd out of the Port to fifli. The




( 20)
Caftle which is at the Entrance of the Port, knew
who we were, and took no Notice of us; and we
were not above a. Mile out of the Port, before we
'haul'd in our Sail, and fet us down to fiih. The
ind blew from the N. N. E. which was contrary to
my Defire; for had it blown Southerly, I had been
lure to have made the Coatl of Spain, and at leaft
reach'd to the Bay of Cadi; but my Kelolutions were,
blow which way it would, I would be gone from that
horrid Place where I was, and leave the reft to Fate.
After we had fiIh'd fome time, and catch'd nothing,
for when I had Fiih on my Hook I would not pull
them up, that he might not iee them; I faid to the
AMoor, this will not do, our Mafter will not be thus
ferv'd, we muft ifand farther off: He thinking no
h]arm, agreed; and being in the Head of the Boat, fet
the Sails; and as I had the Helm, I run the Boat out
near a League farther, and tlen brought her too, as if
I would fiih.; when giving the Boy the Helm, I ftept
forward to where thev/re  r was, and making asifl floop'd
for fbmething behind him, I took him by Surprize
with my Arm under his Twilt, and tois'd him clear
over-board into the Sea; he rolt immediately, for he
tiam like a Cork, and call'd to me, begg'd to be taken
in, told me he would go all over the World with me:
He fwam fo ftrong after the Boat, that he would have
reach'd mie very quickly, there being but little Wind;
upon which I ftep'd into the Cabin, and fetching one
of the Fowling-Pieces, I prefented it at him, and told
him, I had done him no Hurt, and if he would be quiet, I would do him none: But faid I, you fwim well
enough to reach the Shore, and the Sea is calm, make
the belt of your Way to Shore, and I will do you no
Harm, but if you come near the Boat, I'll flhoot you
thro' the Head; for I am refolv'd to have my Liberty: So he turn'd himfelf about and fwam for the Shore,
and I make no doubt but he reach'd it with Eafe, for
he was an excellent Swimmer.
I could have been content to have taken this Moor
'with me, and have drown'd the Boy, but there was no
venturing rt trit him: When he was gone, 1 turn'd? the Boy, who they calX'd Xury and laid to him, Xu*^              *                  ffrB




ry, if you will be faithful to me, I'll make you a great
Man; but if you will not firoke your face to be
true to me, that is, frear by Mahomet and hbi lather's
Beard, I muft threw you into the Sea too; the Boy
finil'd in my Face, and fpoke fo innocently, that I could
not milruft him; and fwure to be faithful to me, and
go all over the World with me.
While I was in View of the Moor that was fwiming,
I flood out diretly to Sea, with the Boat, rather firetching to Windward, that they might think me gone
towards the Straits-mouth (as indeed any one that had
been in their Wits muaf ha' been fuppos'd to do; ) for
who would ha' fiLppos'd we were lail'd on to the Southward to the truly Barbarian Coaft, where whole Nations of Negroes were fure to furround us with their
Canoes, and deitroy us; where we could never once go
on Shore, but we Ihould be devour'd by favage Beafts,
or more mercilefs Savagts of' human Kind.
But as loon as it grew dusk in the Evening, I changed my Courfe, and iteer'd dirctly South and by Eait,
bending my Courfe a little toward the Eall, that [
might keep in with the Shore; and having a fair frefh
Gale of Wind, and a fmooth quiet Sea, 1 made fuch
Sail, that I believe by the next Day at three a-Clock in
the Afternoon, when I firft made the Land, I could
not be lefs than l 5o Miles South of Sallee, quite beyond
the Emperor of Mlorocco's Dominions, or indeed of any
other King thereabouts tor we iaw no People.
Yet fuch was the Fright 1 had taken at the Moors,
and the dreadful Apprehenfions I had of falling into
their Hands, that I would not flop, or go on Shore, or
come to an Anchor; the Wind continuing Fair, till I
had fail'd in that manner five Days: And then theWind.fifting to the Southward, I concluded alfo, that if any of our Veffels were in Chafe of me, they allb would
now give over; fo I ventur'd to make to the Coatl, and
came to an Anchor in the Mouth of a little River, I
knew not what, or where; neither what Latitude,
what Country, what Nation, or what River:! neither
faw, or defir'd to fee any People, the principal thing I
wanted was frefh Water. We came into this Creek in
the Evening refolving to fwim on Shore as loon as -it
was




(   2 )2
*as dark, and difcover the Country; but as Coon as it
was quite dark, we heard fuch dreadful Noiies of the
Barking, Roaring, and Howling of wild Creatures, of
we knew not what Kinds, that the poor Boy was ready to die with Fear, and begg'd of me not to go on Shore
till Day. Well, Xury, faid I, then I won't; but. it
may be we may fee Men by Day, who will be as bad
to us as thofe Lions; then we may give them the Jhoot
Gun, fays Xury, laughing, make them run wey; fuch
Englbfh Xury fpoke by converting among us Slaves.
However, I was glad to fee the Boy fo cheerful, and I
gave him a Dram (out of our Patron's Cafe of Bottles) to chear him up: After all, Xury's Advice was
good, and I took it, we drop'd our little Anchor, and
lay fill all Night; I fay flill, for we flept none; for
in two or three Hours we faw vafi great Creatures
we knew not what to call them) of many Sorts, came
down to the Sea-fhore, and run into the Water, wallowing and wafhing themfelves for the Pleafure of
cooling themfelves; and they made fuch hideous Howlings and Yellings, that I never indeed heard the like.
Xury was dreadfully frighted, and indeed fo was I
too: But we were both worfe frighted when we heard
one mighty Creature come fwimming towards our Boat:
we could not fee him, but we might hear him by his
blowing, to be a monftrous huge and furious Beaf;
Xury faid it was a Lion, and it might be fo for ought
I know: Poor Xury -cried out to me to Weigh
the Anchor and row away; no lays I, Xury, we can
flip our Cable with a Buoy to it, and go to Sea, they
cannot- follow us far; I had no fooner faid to, but I
perceiv'd the Creature (whatever it was) within two
Oars length, which Something furprized me; however,
I immediately ftept to the Cabin-door, and taking up
my Gun, fir'd at him, upon which he innmmediately
turn'd about, and fwam towards the Shore again.
But it was not poflible to defcribe the horrible Noifes,
and hideous Cries and Howlings, that were raifed as
well upon the Edge of the Shore, as higher within the
Country, upon the Noife or Report of a Gun, a thing I
have Tome Reafon to believe thofe Creatures had never
ca4rdbeforc. This convinyee  me4 that there was no
going




( 23)
going on Shore for us in the Night upon that CoaRt
and how to venture on Shore in the Day, was another
Queftion too; for to have fallen into the Hands of any
of the Savages, had been as bad as to have fallen into
the hands of Lions and Tigers; at leaft we were equally applehenfive of the Danger of it.
Be that as it would, we were obliged to go on Shore
fomewhere or other for Water, for we had not a Pint
left in the Boat; when or where to get to it, was the
Point: Xury faid, If I would let him go on Shore with
one of the Jarrs, he would find if there was any Water,
and bring fome to me. I ask'd him, why he would go?
why I Ihould not go, and he flay in theBoat? The
Boy anfwered with fo much Affetion, that made me
love him ever after. Says he, If wild Alans come, they
eat me, you go vy. Well, Xuy, faid I, we will both
go, and if the wild Mans come, we will kill them, they
Ihall eat neither of us; fo I gave Xury a Piece of Ruskbread to eat, and a Dram out of our Patron's Cafe of
Bottles, which I mentioned before, and we haul'd the
Boat in as near the Shore, as we thought was proper,
and waded on Shore; carrying nothing but our Arms,
and two Jarrs for Water.
I did not care to go out of fight of the Boat, fearing the coming of Canoes with Savages down the River:
But the Boy feeing a low Place, about a Yhile up the
Country, ambled to it, and by-and-by I faw himticome
running towards me: I thought he was purfued by fome
Savage, or frighted with fome Wild Bealf, and I run
forward towards him, to help him; but when I came
nearer to him, I faw fomething hanging over his Shoulders, which was a Creature that he had Ihot, like a Hare,
but different in Colour, and longer Legs; however, we'
were very glad of it, and it was very good Meat but the
great Joy that poor Xury came with, was to tell me he
had found good Water, and feen no wild Mans.
But we found afterwards that we need not take fuch
Pains fr Water, for a little higher up the Creek where
we were, we found the Water frefh when the T'iide was
ouut which flows but a little Way up; fo we filled our
Jarrs and feae4 on the Hare we had killed, and prepar;c4




...              ( C24)
pared to go on our Wayi having feen no Foor-fleps of
any human Creature in that part of the Country.
As I had been one Voyage to this Coaft before, I
knew very Well that tle lflandsof the Canaries, and the
Cape de Yer'd Iflands alfo, lay not far off from the Coatt.
But as I had nolinfiruments to take an Obfervation to
know what Latitude we were in, and did not exaftly
know, or at leaff not remember, whatLatitude they were
in, I knew not where to look for them, or when to fland
off to Sea towards-them, otherwife I might now ealily
have found fome of there Iflands. But my Hope was
that if I flood along this Coatl till I came to that Part
where the Engzifjh traded, I ihould find tome of their
Veffels upon their utiial Defign of Trade, that would
relieve and take us in.
By the beff of my Calculation, that Place where I
now was, muft be that Country, which lying between
the Emperor of Mor(,cco's Dominions and the iegroes,
lies wafle and uninhabited, except by VW ild Beafs; the
Negroes having abandon'd it, and gone farther South,
for fear of the Aloors; and the imoors not thinking it
worth inhabiting, by Reafon of its Barranneis; and
indeed both forfaking it becaufe of the prodigious Numbers of Tygers, Lyons, Leopards, and other furious
Creatures which harbour there; lb that the Aicors uie
it fbr their Hunting only, where they go like an Armny,
two or three thoufand Men at a time; and indeed for
near an hundred Miles together upon this Coaft, we
faw nothing but a wafte uninhabited Country by Day,
and heard nothing but Howlings and Roaring of Wild
Beafts by Night.
Once or twice in the Day-time, I thought I flaw the
Pico of Tenerifl, being the high Top of the Mountain
Tenerife in the Canaries; and had a great- mind to venture out in Hopes of reaching thither; but having tried twice, I was forced in again by contrary Winds, the
Sea alfo going too high for my little Veffel; fo I Iefolv'd to purlue my fihl Defign, and keep along the
$hore.
t         ' Several times we were obliged to land for fielhWater
after we had left this Place; and once in particular, being early in the Morning, we came to an Anchor under




(2    )
a little Point of Land, which was pretty high, and the
Tide beginning to flow, we lay ftill to go farther in.
Xury, whole Eyes were more about him than it feems
mine were, calls foftly to me, and tells me, that we had
beil go farther off the Shore; for, fays lie, look yonder
lies a dreadful Molfter on the Side ok that Hillock, fatt
afleep. I look'd where he pointed, and faw a dreadful
Monfter indeed; for it was a terrible great Lion, that
lay on the fide of the Shore, under the Shade of a piece
of the Hill, that hung as it were a little ovez him. Xury,
fays I, you fhall go on Shore, and kill him: Xutry look'd
frighted, and laid, Me kill! he eat me at one Mcuth;
one Mouthful he meant; however,'I faid no more to the
Boy, but bad him be frill, and took our biggefi Gun,
which was almoft Musket-bore, and loaded it with a
good Charge of Powder, and with two Slugs, and laid
it down; then I loaded another Gun with two Bullets,
and the third ( for we had three Pieces) I loaded with
five finaller Bullets. I took the betl Aim I could with
the firtl Piece to hate fhot him into the Head; but he
lay fo with his Leg rais'd a little above his Nofe, that
the Slugs hit his Leg about the Knee, and broke the
Bone. He ifarted up growling at firft, but, finding his
Leg broke, fell down again, and then got up upon three
Legs, and gave the moft hideous Koar that ever I heard.
I was a little furprized, that I had not hit him on the
Head; however, I took up the iecond Piece immediately; and tho' he began to move off, fir'd again, and fhot
him into the Head, and had the Pleafure to fee him
drop, and making but little Noife, he lay ftruggling
for Life. Then Xury took Heart, and would have me
let him go on Shore. Well, go, faid I. So the Bq
jump'd into the Water, and taking the little Gun in one
Hand, fwam to Shore with the other Hand; and coming clofe to the Creature, put the Muzzle of the Piece
to his Ear, and fhot him into the Head again, which
difpatched him quite.
This was Game indeed to us, but this was no Food;
and I was very forry, to lofe three Charges of Powder
and Shot upon a Creature that was good for nothing to
us. However, Xury faid, he would have fome of him;
fo he comes on board, and ask'd me to give him the
C              Hatchet:




( (26)
Patchet. For what, Xury, faid I? Me cut of his Hetea,
iaid he. However, Xary could not cut off his Head4'
but he cut off a Foot, and brought it with him, and it
was a monftrous great one.
I bethought my felt however, that perhaps the Skin
of him nmight one way or other be of tome Value to us;
and 1 refolv'd to take off his Skin if'I could. So Xory
and I went to work with him; but Xaqy was much the
better Workman at it, for 1 knew very ill how to do it.
Indeed it took us up (both) the wholeDay, but at laft we
got off the Hide ol him, and fpreading it on the top of
our Cabin, the Sun effe&ually dried it in two Days
time, and it afterwards ferv'd me to lie upon.
After this Stop, we made on to the Southward continually for ten or twelve Days, living very fparingly on
our Provifions, which began to abate very much, and
going no oftner in to the Shore than we were obliged
to forfrefi Water. My Defign in this, was to make
the River Gambia or Senegall, that is to fay, any where
about the Cape e TVerd, where I was in hopes to meet
with fome European Ship, and if I did not, I knew not
what Courfe I had to take, but to feek for the Iflands, or
perifi there among the Negrces. I knew that all the
Ships from Eur(pe, which fiil'd either to the Coafi of
Guiney, or to Brafil, or to the Eafi Indies, made this Cape,
or thofe Iflands; and in a word, I put the whole of my
Fortune upon this tingle Point, either that I muRf meet
with bome Ship, or mutt perifh.
When I had purlued this Refoluion about ten Days
longer, as I have faid, I began to fee that the Land
was inhabited, and in two or three Places as we failed
l/ we faw People fiand upon the Shore to look at us;
we could alfo perceive they were quite black and flark
naked I was once inclin'd to have gone on Shore to
to them; but Xi.y was my better Counfellor, and faid
to me, No go, nogo: However, I haul'd in nearer the
Shore, that I might talk to them, and I found they run
along the Shore by me a good way. I obferv'd they
had no Weapons in their Hands, except one, who had
a long (lender Stick, which Xury faid was a Lance, and
that they would throw them a great way with good
Aim; ib I kept ata diflance, but talk'd with them by
Signs




( 27 )
Signs as well as I could, and particularly made Signs for
fomething to eat. They beckon'd to me to tfop my
Boat, and they would fetch me fome Meat. Upon this
I lower'd the Top of my Sail, and lay by; and two of
them run up into the Country, and in lets than half an
Hour came back and brought with them two Pieces of
dry Flefh, and fonle Corn, fuch as is the Produce of
their Country; but we neither knew what the one or
the other was: However, we were willing to accept it.
But how to come at it, was our next Dipure; for I wa*
not tfr venturing on Shore to them, and they were as
much afraid of us; but they took a fafe Way for us all,
for they brought it to the Shore and laid it down, and
went and flood a great way of, till we fetch'd it on
Board, and then came coloe to us again.
We made Signs of Thanks to them, for we bad nothing to make them amends: But an Opportunity offer'd that very Inftant, to oblige them wonderfully; for
while we were lying by the Shcre, came two mighty
Creatures, one purfiing the other ( as we took it) with
great Fury, from the Mountains towards the Sea; whe-'
ther it was the Male purfuing the Famale, or whether
they were in Sport, or in Rage, we could not tell any
more than we could tell whether it was ufual or flrange;
but I believe it was the latter, becaufe in the firil place
thofe ravenous Creatures feldom appear but in the
Night; and in the fecond place, we found the People
terribly frighted, efpecially the Women. The Man that
had the Lance or Dart, did not fly from them, but the
re' did; however, as the two Creatures ran direAly
into the Water, they did not feem to off-r to fall upon
the Negroes, but plung'd themielves into the Sea, ernd
fwam about as if they had come for their Diverfion;
at laft one of them began to come nearer our Boat than
at firfl I expe&ed, but I lay ready for him; for I had
loaded my Gun with all pofible Expedition, and bid
Xury load both the other: As foon as he came fairly
-within my Reach, I fir'd, and fhot him diretly into the
Head: Immediately he fhnk down into the Water, but
rofe inilantly, and plung'd up and down as if he w-s
ftruggling for Life; and fo indeed he was: He immediately made to the Shore, but between the Wound,
C 2                 wviici




(28) 8
which was his mortal Hurt, and the trangling of th
Water, he died juf before he reach'd the Shore.
It is impolilble to exprefs the Aftoniflment of thefe

lome of them were ready even to die for Fear, and
tell down as dead with the very Terror. But when
they law the Creature dead, and funk in the Wateiand that I made Signs to them to come to the Shore,
they took Heart, and came to the Shore, and began to
iearch fbr the Creature, I found him by his Blood
laining the Water, and by the help of a Rope,' which

dragg'd him on Shore, and found that it was a mott
curious Leopard, fpotted and fine, to an admirable degree; and the Negroes held up their Hands with Admi.
ration, to think what it was hlad kill'd him with.
The other Creature, frighted with the Flath of Fire
and the Noife of the Gun, fwam to the Shore, and ran up
dire&lly to the Mountains, from whence they cane,
nor could I at that diltance know what it was. I found
quickly the Negroes were for eating the Flesh of this
Creature, fo I was willing to have them take it as a
Favour from me, which when I made Signs to them
that they might take him, they were very thankful
tor. Immediately they fell to work with him; and
tho' they had no Knife, yet with a flarpened piece of
W'ood, the) took off his Skin as readily, and much more
readily than we would have done with a Knife; they
offer'd me fome of the Flefh, which I declin'd, making as if I would give it them, but made Signs for the
Skin, which they gave me very freely, and brought me
a great deal more of their Provifion, which tho' I did
not underftand, yet I accepted. Then I made Signs to
them for fome Water, and held out one of my Jars to
them, turning it Bottom upward, to fhew that it was
empty, and that I wanted to have it filled: They call'd
immediately to tome of their Friends. and there came
two Women and brought a great Veffel made of larth,
and burnt, as I fppofe, in the Sun; this they fet down
for me, as before, and I fent Xury on Shore with my
Jars, and filled them all three. The Women were as!iark naked as the Men.

I was now furnifh'd with Roots and Corn, fuclh s it

or five Leagues bet-(re me, and the Sea being very calm,
I kept a large Offing to make this Point; at length,
doubling the Point at about two Leagues from the Land,
I faw plainly Land on the other fide to Seaward; then
I concluded, as it was moft certain indeed, that this
was the Cape de Verd, and thofe the Iflands, called fromi
thence Cape de Verd Iflands. Iowever, they were at a

In this Dilemma, as I was verv penfive, I ifept into

when on a fiudden the Boy cry'd out, AafteIe, Maffer, a
Sb/i with a Sail! and the foolilh Boy was friglhted our
of his Wits, thinking it muft needs be tome ot his NMafter's Ships fent to purfue us, when I knew we were gotten far enough out of their Reach. I jump'd out of the

what the was, (viz) that it was a Portuguwej Ship, and as

But when I obftrv'd the Courfe fhe fteer'd, I was foon
convinc'd they were bound tome other Way, and did
not defign to come any nearer the Shore; upon which I
ltretch'd out to Sea as much as I could, refolving to
tpeak with them if poffible.
With all the Sail I could make, I found I fhould not
be able to come in their Way, but that they would lie
gone by, before I could make any Signal to them;
but after I had crowded to the utmolt, and began

Perfpeeive Glaffes, and that it was fbme Eurrpean Boat,

of Ditrefs, and fir'd a Gun, both which they faw, fbr
they told me they faw  the Smoke, tho' they did not

I hey ask'd me what I was, in Portuguefe, and in SpaniJf, and in French, but I underflood none of them; but

It was an iniexpreffible Joy to me, thatany one will believe;that I was thus deliver'd,as 1 efteem'd it, from fuch
ansmierable and almoit hopeles Condition as I was in

As he was charitable in this Propofal, fo he was jui

then he took every thing into his own Pofiffion, and

As to my Boat, it was a very good one, and that he
faw, and told me he would buy it of me for the Ship's
ttie, and ask'd me what 1 would have for it? I told him

could not offtr to make any Price of the Boat, but left

give me a Note of his Hand to pay me So Pieces of
ight for it at Brafil, and when it came there, if any
one offer'd to give more, he would make it )p; he offer'd




( 31 )
fer'd me alfo o0 Pieces of Eight more for my Boy,Xa7y
which I was loth to take; not that I was not willing to

know my Reaoin, he own'd it to be juE, and offcr'd nme

to fet him free in Io Years, if he turn'd Chritlan: Upon

the Captain have him.
We had a very good Voyage to the Brails, and arriv'd
in the Bay, de Tcdos los Santos, orAIl-Saints-Bay, in about
22 Days after. And now I was once more deliver'd from
the mollt miierable of all Conditions of Life, and what
to.do next with my felf, I was to confider.
The generous Treatment the Captain gave me, I can
never enough remember; he would take nothing of me
for my Paffage, gave me 20 Ducats for the Leopard's
Skin, and 40 for the Lion's Skin which I had in the Boat,
and cautfed every Thing I had in the Ship to be pun&ually deliver'd me, and what I was willing to fell, he
bought; fuch as the Cafe of Bottles, two of my Guns,and
a Piece of the Lump of Bees. -wax, for I had made Candies of the reft; in a word, I made about 220 Pieces of'
Eight of all my Cargo, and with this Stock I went on
Sbore in the Brafils.
I had not been long here, but beingrecommended to
the Houfe of a good honeft Man like himfelf, who ha&
an Ingenio, as they call it; that is, a Plantation and x
Sugar-Houfe, 1 liv'd with him fome time, and acquain.
ted my felifby that Means with the Manner of their
Planting and mnaking of Sugar; and leeing how well thPlanters liv'd, and how  they grew rich fiuddainly; I
refolv'd, if I could get Licence to fettle there, I woulc
turn Planter among them reiblving in the mean time to
find out tome Way to get my Money which I had leftia London, remitted to me. To this purpofe, getting,
a kind of a Letter of Naturalization, I purchafed as much
Land that was Uncur'd, as my Money would reach,
a=d form'd a Plan for my Plantation and Settlement,.
and fuch a one as might be fuitable to the Stock which I
rroposd to my fel to receive from E^gla^d.
C 4.                   [




(3     )
I had a Neighbour, a PortugueTe of Lisbon, but born of
EngliJh Parerts, who ieName was Wells; and in much fuch
Circumltances as I was: 1 call him Neighbour, becaufe
his i'lantation lay next to mine, and we went on very
fbciably together. My Stock was but low as well as his;
and we rather planted for Food, than any thing elfe,
fbr about two Years. However, we began to increafe,
and our Land began to come into Order; fo that the
third Year we planted fome Tobacco, and made each of
us a large Piece of Ground ready for planting Canes in
the Year to comne; but vwe both wanted Help; and now
I fourd mGre than bebfre, I had done wrong in parting
tith my Boy Xury.
But alas! for me to do wrong that never did right,
was no great Wonder: I had no Remedy but to go on:
I was gotten into an Employment quite remote to my
Genius, and direaly contrary to the Life I delighted in,
and for which I forbook my Father's Houfe, and broke
thro' all his good Advice; nay, I was coming intothe
very middle Station, or upper Degree of low Life,
which my Father advifed me to before, and which, if
I retblved to go on with, I might as well have flaid at
home, and never have fatigued my felfil the World as I
had done; and I ufed often to fay to my felt, I could
have done this as well in Eng tand among my Friends, as
have gone 5ooo Miles of to do it among Strangers and
Savages in a Wildernefs, and at fuch a Diflance, as never to hear from any-Part of the World that had the leafl
Knowledge of me.
In this manner I ufed to look upon my Condition
with the utmoft Regret. I had no Body to converfe
with but now and then this Neighbour; no Work to
beiWe, but by the Labour of my Hands; and I ufed
to fay, I liv'd juf like a Man cafl away upon Tome defo.
late Ifland, that had no Body there but himfelf. But
how jut has it been, and how fhould all Men reflet,
that, when the) compare their prefent Conditions with
others that are worfe, Heaven may oblige them to make
the Exchange, and be convinced of their former Felicity, by their Experience: I fay, how iulf has it been, that
the truly folitary Life I refle&ed on in an Ifland of meer
Defolation ihould be my Lot, who had fo often unjuftly
comr.




(33 )
compared it with the Life which I then led, in which
had I continued, I had in all probability been exceeding
profperous and rich.
I was in fome Degree fettled in my Mearures for carry.
ing on the Plantation, before my kind Friend the Captain of the Ship, that took me up at Sea, went back;
for the Ship remained there in providing her Loading,
and preparing for herVoyage, near three Months; when
telling him what little Stock I had left behind me in
London, he gave me this fiiendly and fincere Advice:
Seignior Inglefe, fays he, (for fo he always call'd me,) if
you will give me Letters, and a Procuration here in form
to me with Orders to the Perfon who has your Money in London, to fend your Effecls to Lisbon, to fuch
Perfons as I fhall dire&, and in fuch Goods as are proper for this Country, I will bring you the Produce of
them, God willing, at my Return; but fince human
Affairs are all fubje& to Changes and Difafters, I
would have you give Orders but for Ioo 1. Sterl. which
you fay is half your Stock, and let the hazard be run for
the firfl; fo that if it come fafe, you may order the reft
the fame way; and if it mifcarry, you may have the o.
ther half to have Recourfe to for your Supply.
This was fo wholfome Advice, and look'd fo friendly,
that I could not but be convinc'd it was the belt Courfe
I could take; fo I accordingly prepared Letters to the
Gentlewomen with whom I had left my Money, and a
Procuration to the Portuquefe Captain, as he defired.
I wrote the EngliJh Captain's Widow a full Account
ofall my Adventures, my Slavery, Efcape, and how I
had met with the Portugal Captain at Sea, the Humanity of his Behaviour, and in what Condition I.vas
now in, with all other neceflary Directions for my Supply; and when this honeft Capt. came to Lisbon, he found
means by fome oftheEnglijb Merchants there, to fend over not the Order only, but a full Account of my Story
to a Merchant at London, who prefented it effe6tually to
her; whereupon ihe not only delivered the Money, buc
out of her own Pocket fent the Porttual Captain a very
handibme Prefent for his Humanity and Charity to me.
The Merchant in London vefled this ico 1. in En.fih
Goodsfuch as the Captain bad writen for; ent them direAqlv




( 34)
relly to him at Lisbcn, and he brought them all fafe to

When this Cargo arriv'd, I thought my Fortune made,
for I was furpriz'd with thejoy of it; and my goodSteward the Captain had laid out the 51. which my Friend
had fent him for a Prefent for himfelf, to purchafe, and

a little Tobacco, which I would have him accept, being
of nmy own Produce.
Neither was this all; but my Goods being all Engli;h
Manufad&ures, fuch as Cloth, Stuff, Bays, and Things

fiund means to fell them to a very great Advantage; fo
that I may fay, I had more than fbur times the Value
of my firft Cargo, and was now infinitely beyond my
poor Neigbour, I mean in the Advancement of my Plantation; for the firft Thing I did, I bought me a Negroe Slave, and an European Servant alfo; I mean another befides that which the Captain brought me fiom
Lisbon.
But as abufed Profperity is oftentimes made tte very
Means of our greateft Adverfity, fo was it with me. f
wenton the next Year with great Succefs in my Plantation: I raifed o5 great Rolls of Tobacco on my own

of above a Ioo lb. Wt. were well cur'd and laid by, aainrt the Retutrn of the Fleet trom Lisbon. And now
increafing in Bufinefs and Wealth, my Head began to he

fuch as are in deed often the Ruin of the the beft Heads
in Bufinels.

To come then by juft Degrees to the Particulars of

it was to parchafe upon the Coafl, for Trfles (fiach as

Publick Stock; fo that few Negroes were brought, and

It happen'd, being in Company one Day with fome

muh upon what I had difcourlfd of with them the lalf

bad a mind to fit out a Ship to go to Guinev that they
had all Plantations as well as I, and were ftraitned for
nothing fo muzh as Servants; that as it was a Trade
that could not publickly fell the Negroes when they
came home, fo they defired to make but one Voyage,
to bring the Negroes on Shore privately, and divide
them among their own Plantations; and in a Word, the
Queflion was, whether I would go their Super-Cargo in
the Ship, to manage the Trading Part upon the Coaft
-of Guiney? And they off'r'd me that 1 Ihould have my
equal Share of the Negroes, without providing any Part
of the Stock.
This was a fair Propofal, it mull be confefs'd, had it

I lantation of his own to look after, which was in a fair
way of coming to be very confiderable, and with a good
Sto k upon it. But for me that was thus eflablilh'd,
and had nothing to do but go on as I had begun, for

oo I. from Enland, and who in that Time, and with
that little Addition, could fcarce have fail'd of being
worth; or 400o 1. Sterling, and that encreafing too;

be guilty of.
But I that was born to be my own Deftroyer, could
no more refilf the Offer than I could reftrain my firft

after my Plantation in my Abfence, and wctld difpofe
6fit to fuhh as T liould dire&t, if I mifcarried. This,

'                              Cove.




( 37 )
Covenants, to do fo; and I made a formal Will, difpofing of my Plantation and Effe&s, in cafe of my Death,

half of the Produce being to himfelf, and the other to
be fhipp'd to England.
In fhort, I took all pofllble Caution to preferve my
EffeAs, and to keep up my Plantation; had I ufed half
as much Prudence to have look'd into my own Interefl,
and have made a Judgment of what I ought to have
done, and not to have done, I had certainly never gone
away from fo profperous an Undertaking, leaving all the
the probable Views of a thriving Circumftance, and
gone upon a Voyage to Sea, attended with all its common Hazards; to fay nothing of the Reafons I had to
expe& particular Misfortunes to my felf.
But I was hurried on, and obey'd blindly the Dictates of my Fancy rather than my Reafon: And accordingly the Ship being fitted out, and the Cargo furniih'd,
and all things done as by Agreement, by my Partners in
the Voyage, I went on board in an evil Hour again,
the ift ot Sept. I659, being the fame Day eight Years
that I went from my Father and Mother at Ha1,? in order to a& the Rebel to their Authority, and the Fool to
my own Intereft.
Our Ship was about 120 Tun Burthen, carried 6
Guns and 14 Men, betides the Mafter, his Boy, and.
my telf; we had on board no large Cargo of Goods,
except of izuh Toys as were fit for our Trade with the

atif we were bound forthe Ifle Fernandde Niron~a, holding our CGurfe N. E. by N. and leaving thofe talcs on

in about I Degrees North Latitude, but that he was
22 Degrees of Longitude Difference Well from Cape St.

I was pofitively againtl that, and looking over the

With this Defign we chang'd our Comrfc, and fteer'&
