was




( 39 )
was otherwife determined, for being in the Latitude of
12 Deg. i S. Min. a iecond Storm came upon us, which
carry'd us away with the fame Inmptuofity Weftward,
and drove us fo out of the very way of all human Commerce, that had all our Lives been faved, as to the Sea,
we were rather in danger of being devoured by ravages,
than ever returning to our own Country.
In this Dilfrels, the Wind fill blowing very hard,
one of our Mlen, early one Morning crN'd out, )Land
and we had no iboner run out of the Cabin to look out,
in hopes of feeing whereabouts in the World we were,
but the Ship ftruck upon a Sand, ard in a Moment, her
Motion being bo ftopp'd, the Sea broke over her in luch
a manner, that we expeaed we ihould all have perifn'd
immediately; and we were even driven into our
clofe Quarters, to fhelter us from the very Foam and
Sprye of the Sea.
It is not eafy for any one, who has not been in the
like Condition, to defcribe or conceive the Confternation of Men in fuch Circumflances; we knew nothing
where we were, or upon what Land it was we were
driven, whether an Ifland or the Main, whether inhabited or not inhabited; and as the Rage of the Wind
was ftill great, tho' rather lets than at firft, we could
not fo much as hope to have the Ship hold many Minutes without breaking in Pieces, unlefs the Winds by
a kind of Miracle fhould turn immediately about. In
a Word, we fat looking one upon another, and expecting Death every'Moment, and every In a&ing accordingly, as preparing, for another World; for there
was little or nothing more for us to do in this: That
which was our prefent Comfort, and all the Coujfsrt
we had, was, that contrary to our Expe&ation the Ship
did not break yet, and that the Mailer faid the Wind
began to abate.
Now tho' we thought that the Wind did a little
abate, yet the Ship having thus fruck upon the Sand,
and flicking too fail for us to expef her getting off,
we were in a dreadful Condition indeed, and had nothing to do but to think of faving our Lives as well as
we could. We had a Boat at our Stern, juft before the
Storm, bat ihe was firit tav'd by dathing againft the
Ship's




( 40)
Ship's Rudder, and in the next Place fle broke away;
and either funk or was driven oft to Sea, fo there was
no Hope from her: We had another Boat on board,
but how to get her off into the Sea, was a doubtful
thing; however, there was no room to debate, for
we fancied the Ship would break in pieces every
Minute; and forie told us, fhe was actually broken
already.
In this Diftrefs the Mate of our Veffel lays hold of
the Boat, and with the help of the refi of the Men, they
got her flung over the Ship's fide, and getting all into:   r, let go, and committed our felves, being Eleven in
umber, to God's Mercy, and the wild Sea; for tho'
the Storm was abated confiderably, yet the Sea went
dread;ul high upon the Shore, and might well be call'd
Den -tild Zee, as the Dutch call the Sea in a Storm.
And now our Cafe was very difmnal indeed; for we
all faw plainly, that the Sea went fo high, that the
Boat could not live, and that we fhould be inevitably
drowned. As to making Sail, we had none, nor, if we
had, could we have done any thing with it; fo we
work'd at the Oar towards the Land, tho' with heavy
"earts, like Men going to Execution; for we all knew,
that when the Boat came nearer the Shore, the would
be dafh'd in a thoufand Pieces by the Breach of the Sea.
However, we committed our Souls to God in the moff
earneft manner, and the Wind driving us towards the
Shore, we haften'd our Deftrution with our own Hands,
pulling as well as we could towards Land.
What the Shore was, whether Rock or Sand, whether
Steep or Shoal, we knew not; the only Hope that could
rationally give us the leaft Shadow of Expetation, was,
if 'We might happen into tome Bay or Gulph, or the
Mouth offbmne River, where by great Chance we might
have run our Boat in, or got under the Lee of the Land,
and perhaps made finooth Water. But there was nothing of this appeared; but as we made nearer and
nearer the Shore, the Land look'd more frightful than
the Sea.
After we had row'd, or rather driven about a
League and a half, as we reckoned it, a raging Wave,
Mountain-like, came rowling a-ftern ofus, and plainly
bid




( 4' )
bid us expe& the Coup de Grace. In a word, it took us
with fuch a Fury, that it overfet the Boat at once, and
feparating us as well from the Boat, as from one another, gave us not time hardly to fay, O God! for we
were all fwallowed up in a Moment.
Nothing can defcribe the Confufion of Thought
which I felt when I ifnk into the Water; for tho' I
fwam very well, yet I could not deliver nly felf from
the Waves fo as to draw Breath, till that Wave having driven me, or rather carried me a vait Way on towards the Shore, and having fpent it felf, went back,
and left me upon the Land almoft dry, but half dead
with the Water I took in: I had fo much Prefence of
k ind, as well as Breath left, that feeing my felf nearer
the main Land than I expe&ed, I got upon my Feet,
and endeavoured to make on towards the Land as fafi
as I could, before another Wave fhould return, and take
me up again. But 1 foon found it was impoffible to
avoid it; for I faw the Sea come after me as high as a
great Hill, and as furious as an Enemy, which I had
no Means or Strength to contend with; my Bufinefs
was to hold my Breath, and raife my felt upon the
Water, if I could, and fo by fvimming to preferve my
Breathing, and pilot my flel towards the Shore, if poffible; my greateft Concern now being, that the Sea, as
it would carry nme a great Way towards the Shore when
it came on, might not carry me back again with it
when it gave back towards the Sea.
The Wave that came upon me again, buried me at
once 20 or 30 Foot deep in its own Body; and I could
feel my felf carried with a mighty Force and Swiftnefs
towards the Shore a very great Way; but 1 held my
Breath, and affifled my felf to fwim ifill forward witl?
all my Might. I was ready to burfl with holdirg my
Breath, whean, as I felt my felf rifing up, fo, to my
immediate Relief; I found my Head and Hands fhoot
out above the Surface of the Water; and tho' it was
not two Seconds of Time that I could keep my felf fo,
yet it reliev'd me greatly, gave me Breath and new
Courage. I was covered again with Water a good
while, but not fo long but I held it out; and finding the
Water had fpent it felf, and began to return, I firuck
forward




(42 )
forward againft the Return of the Waves, and felt
Ground again with nmy Feet. I flood ftill a few Moments to recover Breath, and till the Water went from
me, and then took to my Heels, and run with what
Strength I had farther towards the Shore. But neither
would this deliver me from the Fury of the Sea, which
came pouring in after me again, and twice more I was.
lifted up by the Waves, and carried forwards as before,
the Shore being very flat.
The laft time of thefe two had well near been fatal
to me; for the Sea having hurried me along as before,
landed me, or rather daih'd me againft a piece of a
Rock, and that with fuch Force, as it left me fenfelefs,
and indeed helplefs, as to my own Deliverance; for the
Blow taking my Side and Breafl, beat the Breath as.
it were quite out of my Body; and had it returned again immediately, I mutl have been firangled in the
Water; but I recover'd a little before the Return of the
Waves; and feeing I fhould be cover'd again with theWater, I refolv'd to hold fall by a piece of the Rock,
and fo to hold my Breath, if poflible, till the Wave
went back. Now as the Waves were not fo high as at
firft, being near Land, I held my Hold, till the Wave,
abatedc, and then fetch'd another Run, which brought
me fo near the Shore, that the next Wave, though it
went over me, yet did not fo fwallow me up, as to carry me away; and t'e next Run f took, I got to the
main Land, where, to my great Comfort, I clambertd
up the Clifts of the Shore, and fat me down upon the
Grafs, free from Danger, and quite out of the Reach
of the Water.
I was now landed, and fafe on Shore, and began to
look up and thank God, that my Life was fav'd in a
Cafe wherein there was fome Minutes before fcarce any
room to hope. I believe it is impoffible to expresl to,
the Life, what the Extafies and Tranfports of the Soul
are, when it is fo faved, as I may fay, out of the very
Grave; and I do not wonder now at that Cuftom, vit.
That when a Malefa&or, who has the Halter about his;
Neck, is tied up. and jufi going to be turn'd off, and,
has a Reprieve brought to him; I fay, I do not wont
der that they bring a Surgeon with it, to let-himlBloo&
that:




( 43)
that very Moment they tell him of it, that the Strprize may not drive the Animal Spirits from the Hearty
and overwhelm him:
For fudrden Yys, like Griefs, confound at firfl.
I walk'd about on the Shore, lifting up my Halds,
and my whole Being, as I may fay, wrapt up in the
Contemplation of my Deliverance, making a thoufarnd
Geftures and Motions, which I cannot deicribe, reflec.
ting upon all my Comrades that were drown'd, and
that there fiould not he one Soul ibv'd but my felf;
for as for them, I never faw them afterwards, or any
Sign of them, except three of their Hats, one Cap, and
two Shoes, that were not Fellows.
I caft my Eyes to the ftranded Veffel, when the
Breach and Froth of the Sea being fo big, I could hardly fee it, it lay fo far off, and confidered, Lord! how
was it poffible [ could get on Shore!
After I had folac'd my Mind with the comfortable
part of my Condition, I began to look round me, to
lee what kind of Place I was in, and what was next to
be done; and I loon found my Comforts abate, and that,
in a Word, I had a dreadful Deliverance; for I was
wet. had no Cloaths to ihitt me, nor any thing either
to eat or drink to comfort me; neither did 1 fee any
Profpe& before me, but that of perifhing with Hunger,.
or being devour'd by wild Beafts And that which was
particularly affli&ing to me, was, that I had no Weapon
either to hunt and kill any Creature for my Suflenanee,
or to defend my felf againft any other Creature that
might defire to kill me for theirs: In a Word, I had
nothing about me but a Knife, a Tobacco-pipe, anAi,
little Tobacco in a Box: This was all my Provifion, and,
this threw me into terrible Agonies of Mind, that for a
while I run about like a Mad-man. Night coming upon me, I began with a heavy Heart to confider what
would be my Lot, if there were any ravenous Beafts in
that Country, feeing at Night they always come abroad
for their Prey.
All the Remedy that offer'd to my Thoughts at that
time, was, to get up into a thick buhy Tree like a Fir,
but.




(44)
but thorny, which grew near me, and where I refolv'd
to fit all Night, and confider the next Day what Death
I Ihould die, for as yet I faw no Profpe& of Life. I
walk'd about a Furlong from the Shore, to fee if I could
-find any frefli Water to drink, which I did, to my
great Joy; and having drank, and put a little Tobacco
in my Mouth to prevent Hunger, I went to the Tree,
and getting up into it, endeavour'd to place my felfl'o,
as that if I Ihould feep, I might not fall; and having
cut me a fhort Stick, like a Truncheon, for my Defence, I took up my Lodging, and having been exceffively fatigu'd, 1 fell fail aileep, and flept as comfor.
tably, as I believe few could t ave done in my Condition, and found my felfthe moft re!rieihed with it, that
I think 1 ever was on fiiuh an Occafion.
When I wak'd, it was broad Day, the Weather clear,
and the Storm abated, fo that the Sea did not rage
and fwell as before: But that which furpriz'd me
moft, was, that the Ship was lifted off in the Night
from the Sand where fhe lay, by the Swelling of the
Tide, and was driven up almofi as far as the Rock,
which I firft mention'd, where I had been fo bruis'd by
the dafling me againft it; this being within about
a Mile from the Shore where I was, and the -hip feeining to fland upright iill, I wiih'd my felf on board,
that, at leaft, I might fave fome neceirary Things for
my Ufe.
W hen I came down from my Apartment in the
Tree, I look'd about me again, and the firft thing I
found, was the Boat, which lay as the VMind and the
Sea had tofs'd her  up un the O and, about two Miles
on my Right Hand: I walk'd as far as I could upon
tlkeShore to have got to her, but found a Neck or Inlet
of Water between ne and the Boat, which was about
halfa Mile broad; fo I came back for the prefent, being more intent upon getting at the Ship, where I hop'd
to find fomething for my prefent Subfiilence.
A little after Noon I found the Sea very calm, and
the I ide ebb'd fo far out, that I could come within
a Quarter of a Mile of the Ship: And here I found a
fre h renewing of my Grief; for I faw evidently, that
if we had kept on board, we had been all fafe, that is
to




(45 )


to fay, we had all got fafe on Shore, and I had not
been fo miferable as to be left entirely deftitute of all

Tears from my Eyes again, but as there was little Relief in that, I refolv'd, it'poflible, to get to the Ship;
fo I pull'd off my Cloaths, for the Weather was hot
to Extremity, and took the Water; but when I came to
the Ship, my Difficulty was fill greater to know how
to get on board, for as fie lay a-ground, and high out of

as with great Difficulty I got hold of it, and by the

Ship. Here I found that the Ship was bulg'd, and
had a great deal of Water in her Hold, but that file lay
fb on the Side of a Bank of hard Sand, or rather Earth,
that her Stern lay lifted up upon the Bank, a'nd herHead
low almoft to the Water; by this means all her Q.(arter
Nwas free, and all that was in that Part was dry; for
you miay be fure my Work was to fearch and to fee
what was fpoil'd, and what was free; and firfl I found,
that all the Ship's Provilions were dry, and untouch'd
by the Water, and being very well difpoied to eat, I
wvent to the Bread-room and filPd my Pockets with
Bisket, and eat it as I went about other things, for I
had no Time to lofe. I alfo found liome Rum in the
great Cabin, of which I took a large Dram, and which
1 had indeed need enough of, to fpirit me for what was
before me. Now I wanted nothing but a Boat to furnifli my felf with many things which I forefaw ould
be very neceffary to me.
It was in vain to fit ftill and wvifh for what was not to
be had, and this Extremity rcuz'd my Application.
We had feveral fpare Yards, and two or three large

Weight, tying every one with a Rope that they might
not drive away; when this was done, I went down the

(46)

My Raft was now ftrong enough to bear any reafonable Weight; my next Care was what to load it with,

was after long fearching that I found out the Carpen;

2. The Tide riling and letting into the Shore. 3. What

before, by which I perceiv'd that there was fome Indraught of the Water, and confequently I hop ' to find
fome Creek cr River there, which I might make uti of
as a Port to get to Land with my Cargo.
As I imagin'd, fo it was; there appear'd before me
a little opening of the Land, and I found a ftrong Current of the Tide fet into it, fo I guided my Raft as
well as I could to keep in the Middle of the Stream:
But here I had like to have fuffcr'd a fecond Shipwreck, which, if I had, I think verily would have broke
my Heart; for knowing nothing of the Coaft, my Raft
run a-ground at one End of it upon a Shoal, and not being a-ground at the other End, it Wasted but a little
that all my Cargo had flipp'd off towards that End that
w~as




(48 )
was afloat, and Co fallen into the Water: I did my ut;.moft by fetting my Back againft the Chefis, to keep

little River, with Land on both Sides, and a ftrong Current or Tide running up. I look'd on both Sides for a
proper Place to get to Shore, for I was not willing to
be driven too high up the River, hoping in time to
fee fome Ship at Sea, and therefore refolv'd to place my
felf as near the Coaft as I could.
At length I fpy'd a little Cove on the right Shore of
the Creek, to which with great Pain and Difficulty I
guided my Raft, and at lait got fo near, as that, reaching Ground with my Oar, I could thruft her direlly
in; but here I had like to have dipt all my Cargo in

is to fay, floping, there was no Place to land, but
where one End of the Float, if it run on Shore, would
lie fo high, and the other fink lower as before, that it
would endanger my Cargo again: All that I could
do, was to wait till the Tide was at the higheft, keeping the Raft with my Oar, like an Anchor to hold the
Side of it faft to the Shore, near a flat Piece of Ground,
which I expeted the Water would flow over; and fo
it did: As foon as I found Water enough, (for my
Raft drew about a Foot of Water) I thruil her upon
hat flat Piece of Ground, and there faften'd, or
muoor'd her, by fticking my two broken Oars into the
Ground; one on oneSide near one End, and one on the
other Side near the other End; and thus I lay till the
Water ebb'd away, and left my Raft and all my Cargo
fife on Shore.
My next Work was to view the Country, and feek
a proper Place for my Habitation, and where to ftow
my Goods, to fecure them from whatever miglt happen,

pen. Where I was, I yet knew not; whether on the

rofe up very fteep and high, and which feem'd to overtop tbme other Hills which lay as in a Ridge from it

I found alfo that the fland I was in, was barren, and,

large Wood; I believe it was the firft Gun that had
been fir'd there fince the Creation of the World. I had
no fooner fir'd, but from all the Parts of the Wood
there arofe an innumerable Number of Fowls of many
forts, making a confus'd Screaming, and crying, every
one according to his urual Note; but not one of then
of any Kind that I knew; As for that Creature I'kill'd,
I took it to be a kind of a Hawk, its Colour and Beak
resembling it, but it had no Talons or Claws more that.common, its Flelh was Carrion, and fit for nothing.
Contented with this Difcovery, I came back to my
Raft, and fell to work to bring my Cargo on Shore,
wvhich took me up the reft of that Day; what to do
with my flf at Night, I knew not, nor indeed where
to reft; for I was afraid to lie down on the Grourd,:
not knowing but tome wild Beaft might devour me,
tho', as I afterwards found, there was reaIly no need
for thofe Fears.

Creatures like Hares, run out of the Wood where I thot

I foon foind the Place I was in was not for my Seilement, particubrly becaufe it was upon a low moorilh Ground near the Sea, and I believed would not be

Water near it; fo I refolv'd to find a more healthy and

I was not willing to banifh my ExpeRation yet.

Top; on the fide of this Rock there was a hollow Place
worn a little way in, like the Entrance or Door of a
Cave, but there was not really any Cave or Way into
the Rock at all.
On the Flat of the Green, jufl before this hollow
Place, I refolved to pitch my Tent. This Plain was
not above an hundred Yards broad, and about twice as
long, and lay like a Green before the Door, and at the
End of it defcended irregularly every way down into
the low Grounds by the Sea-fide,. It was on the N. N.
W. fide of the Hill, fo that it was flhelter'd from the
Heat every Day, till it came to a W. and by S. Sun, or
thereabouts, which in thofe Countries is near the flt.
ting.
Before I Let up my Tent, I drew a half Circle before
the hollow Place, which took in about ten Yards in its
Semi-diameter, from the Rock, and twenty Yards in its
Diameter, from its Beginning and Ending.
In this half Circle I pitch'd two Rows of ftrong
Stakes, driving them into the Ground till they flood
very firm like Piles, the biggefl End being cut of the
Ground about five Foot and a half; and lharp n'd on
theTop; the two Rows did not ftand above fix Inches
from one another.
Then I took the Pieces of Cable which I had cut in the
Ship,and'laid them in Rows upon one anotherwithin the
Circle between thefe two Rows of Stakes, up to theTop,
placing other Stakes in the infide, leaning againfl them,
about two Foot anda half high, like a Spur toa P'olit
and this Fence vas fr frong, that neither Man or Bearf
could get into it or over it. This coil me a great deal
of Time and Labour, efpecially to cut the Piles in tI
Woods, ring-them to the Place, and drive them into
the Earth.
The Entrance into thisPlace I made to be, not by a
Door, but, by a fhort Ladder, to go over the Top,
which Lad4er, when I was in, I lifted over after me,
and rfI was compleatly fenzed in, and fortified, as I
thouit, fromalt the World, and Qonfcquently flept
ferei   the Jight, which oiherwile I could not have
d0le dtho' as it appear'd afterward, there was no need of
D 4                                all




(56)
a11 this Caution from the Enemies I apprehended Dan.
ger from.
Into this Fence, or Fortrefs, with infinite Labour,
I carry'd all my Riches, all my Provifions, Ammunition
and ~tores, ot which you have the Account above; and
I made me a large Tent alto, to preferve me fromthe Rains, that in one Part of the Year are very violent
there, I made double, vit. one fmaller Tent within,
and on, larger Tent above it, and cover'd the uppermiol part of it with a large Tarpaulin which I had
iav'd among the Sails.
And now I lay no more for a while in the Bed- which
I had brought on Shore, but in a Hammock, which was
indeed a very good one, and belong'd to the Mate of the
Ship.
into this Tent I brought all my Provifions, and every
Thing that would 1poil by the Wet; and having thus
enclos'd all my Goods, I made up the Entrance, which
till now I had left open, and fo pafs'd and repafs'd, as
I faid, by a fhort Ladder.
When I had done this, I began to work my Way into the Rock, and bringing all the Earth and Stones that
I dug down, out thro' my Tent, I laid them up within
my Fence in the Nature of a Terrace, fb-that it rais'd
the Ground within about a Foot and a Half'; and thus
I made a Cave juft behind my Tent, which ferv'd me
like a Cellar to my Houfe.
It cofi me much Labour, and many Days, before all
thefe Things were brought to Perfetion, and therefore
rlmuft go back to rome other Things which took up
~0me of my Thoughts. At the fame Time it happen'd
afr i: had laid my Scheme for the fetting up my Tent,
and making the Cave, that a Storm of Rain fallingfrom
a thick dark Cloud, a fudden Flafl of Lightning happen'd, and after that, a great Clap of Thunder, as is
naturally the Effet of it: I was not fo much furpriz'd
ioith the Lightning, as I was with a Thought which
darted into my Miind as fwift as the Lightning it felf:
0 my Powder! my very Heart funk within me, when
1l thought, that at one Blaft all. my Powder might be
deftroy'd j on which, not my Defence only, but the, 0 5  ".  1  v  s  ".  '  '  -  1  pro '

providing me Fool, as I thought, entirely depended;
I was nothing near fo anxious about mny own Danger,
tho' had the Powder took Fire, I had never known who
had hurt me.
Such Impieffion did this make upon me, that after
the Storm was over, I laid afide all my Works, my
Building and Fortifying. and apply'd my felf to make
Bags and Boxes to feparate the Powder, and to keep
it a little and a little in a Parcel, in hope, that whatever might come, it might not all take Fire at once, and
to keep it fo apart, that it fliould not be pollible to make
one part fire another. I finifhed this Work in about a
Fortnight, and I think my Powder, which in all was
about 14o lb. WItt. was divided in no lefs than a hundred
Parcels. As to the Barrel that had been wet, I did not
apprehend any Danger from that, fo I plac'd it in my
new Cave, which in my Fancy I call'd my Kitchin;
and the reft I hid up and down in Holes among the
Rocks, fo that no Wet might come to it, marking very
carefully where I laid it.
In the interval of Time while this was doing, I went
out at leaft once every Day with my Gun, as well to divert my felf, as to fee if I could kill any thing fit for
Food, a nd as niear as I could, to acquaint my felt with
what the Ifland produc'd. The firil Time I went out,
I prefently difcover'd that there were Goats in the Ifland, which was a great SatisfaAion to me; but then it
was attended with this Misfortune to me, vi.. That
they were fo fhy, o fiubtle, and fo fwift of Foot, that
it was the difficalteft Thirng in the World to come at
them: But I was not difoourag'd at this, not doubting.
but I might now and then hoot one, as itoion happened;
for after 1 had found their Haunts a little, I laid wait
in this Manner for them: I obferved, if they faw
me in t   Valleys, tho' they were upon the Rocks,
they wvotr run away as in a terrible Frght;, but
if they  fiefe feedining the Valleys, and I was upon the Rocks, they took no Notice of me from whence
[ coicluded, that by the Pofitiou of their Opticksf their

dily fee Objes: that were above them:. So afterwards I: '.....      S       *        tooke

took this Method, I always climb'd the Rocks firf, t6

4lhe firfi Shot I made among thefe Creatures, I kill'd
a She-Goat which had a litte Kid by her, which fhe
gave Suck to, which grieved me heartily; but when the
Old one fell, the Kid flood Rlock ftill by her till I came
and took her up; and not only fo, but when I carried
the Old one with me upon my Shoulders, the Kid follow'd me quite to my Enclolfre; upon which I laid
down the Damtand took the Kid in my Arms, and carried it over my Pale, in Hopes to have bred it up tame;
but it would not eat, fo I was forc'd to kill it and eat
it my felf; thefe two filpply'd me with Fleih a great
while, for I eat fparingly; and fav'd my Provifions (my
Bread eplecially) as much as paffibly I could.
Having now fix'd my Habitation, I found it abfolutely neceffary to provide a Place to make a Fire in, and
Fuel to burn  and what I did for that, as alfo how I

fliall give a full Account of'in its Place: But I muft firft

about Living, which it may well be ftppos'd were not
a few.
I had a difial Profpe& of my Condition; for as I
nas not caft away upon that Ifland without being driten, as is faid, by a violent Storm quite out of the Courfe
ffur intendedVoyage, and a great Way, viw. ome Hun.
dreds ofLeagues out of the ordinary Courfe of the Trade
f Mankind, I 'had great Reafon to confider it as a Determination ofHeaven, that in this defilate Place, and
in this defolate Manner lIhould end my Life: the Tears
wwild run plentifully down my 'Face when I made thefe

without Help, abaiddned, and fo entirely deprefs'd that

After I had been there about Ten or Twelve Days,
it came intainy Thoughts, that I Ihould lote my Reckoning ofTTime for want of Books, and Pen and Ink,
and Ihould even forget the Sabbath Days frointhe wori
king Days: But to prevent this, I cut it with my Knife
upon a large Poll, in Capital Letters, and making it
into a great Crofs, I fetit up on the Shore where I hrt[
landed, vii. I came on Shbre here the 30ot of Sept. 1659.
Upon the Sides of this fquare Poft, I cut every Day a
Notch with my Knife, and every feventh Notch was
as long again as the reft, and every firft Day of the
JAlonth as long again as that long one; and thus I kept
my Kalendar, or weekly, monthly, and yearly Reekoning of Time.
-n the next place we are to obferve, that among the
many things which I brought off the Ship iri the ieveral Voyage, which, as abovemention'd, I made to it, I
got feveral things of lefs value, but not at all lefs ufeul to me, which I omitted fetting down before; as in
particular, Pens, Ink, and Paper, leveral Parcels in the
Captain'sj Mate's, Gunner's, and Carpenter's keeping,
three or:four Compaffes, tme Mathematical Inftru*
ttnts,, Dials, Perfpe&ives, Charts, and Books of Navigation all which I huddled together, whethter I might

which came to me in my Cargo from ErSgland, and
which I had pack'd up among my things; fome Pcrtuutet Books alfo, and among them two or three Pepilh
Prayer-Books, and feveral other Books, all which I careutlly fecur'd. And I mnft not forget that we had in
the Ship a Dog and two Cats, of whofe enminent Hittory I may have occafion to fay fomething in its Place;
for I carried both'the Cats with me; and as for the
Dog, he jump'd outof the Ship of himfelg and fwam
on Shore to me the Day after I went on Shore with my
fifu Cargo, and was a trufty Servant to me many
yoars: I wanted nothing that he could fetch me, nor
any




( 6i )
aty Company that he could make up to me; I only

that while my Ink lailed, I kept things very exa&f; but
after that was gone, I, could not; for I could not make
any Ink, by any Means that I could devile.
And this put me in mind that I wanted many things,
notwithftandiiig all that I had amafs'd together; and of
thele, this of Ink was one, as alfo a Spade, Pick-Axe and
Shovel, to dig or remove the Earth; Needles, Pins and,
Thread; as fbr Linnen I foon learn'd to want that without much Difficulty.
This Want of' Tools made every Work I did go on
heavily, and it was near a whole Year before I had entirely finified my little Pale,' or furrounded Habitation:: The Piles, or Stakes, which were as heavy as I
could well lift, were a long time in cutting and preparing in the W'cods, and more by tar in bringing
home; fob that I fpent fometines two Days irin- utting

in 4driving it into the Ground; for which purpofe f

But what need I ha' been concerned at theTedioufnefs 4ny thing I had to do, feeing I had time encugh

I now began to confider ferioufly my Condition, and

as a Direcion from the Experience of the moll miferable

Having now brought my Mind a little to reliih my
Condition, and given over looking out to Sea, to iee if
I could Ipy a Ship; I fay, giving over thefe Things, I
began to apply myfelf to accommodate my way of Living, and to make things as eafy to me as I could.
I have already defcribed my Habitation, which was
a Tent under the fide of a Rock, furrounded with a
ftrong Pale of Pofts and Cables, but  mnight now rather call it a Wall; for I raifed a kind of Wall up againft
it of Turfs, about two Foot thick on the Outfide; and
after fome time, (1 think it was a Year and half) I
raired Rafters from it, leaning to the Rock, and thatch'd
or cover'd it with Boughs of Trees, and fitch things as
I could get, to keep out the Rain, which I found at
fome times of the Year very violent.
I have already obferv'd how I brought all my
Goods into this Pale, and into the Cave which I had
made behind me: But I mull obferve too, that at firtt
this was a confused Heap of Goods, which as they lay
in no Order, fo they took up all my Place, I had no
room to turn my llt fo I fet myfelf to enlarge my Cave,
and work'd farther into the Earth; for it was a loofe
fandy Rock, which yielded eafily to the Labour I beftowed on it: And fo when 1I found I was pretty fafe
as to Beafs of Prey, I work'd fideways to the Right
Hand into the Rock; and then turning to the Right again, work'd quite out, and made me Door to conm
out on the Outfide of my Pale or Fortification.
This gave me not only Egrefs and Regrefs, asit were
a Back-Way to my Tent, and to my Store-houfe, but
gave me-oom to flow my Goods.
And now I began to apply myfelf to make filch
telary;things as I found I moft wanted, particularly a
Chair and a Table; for without thefe I was not able to
enjoy the few Comfirtst lad in the World; I could
not write or eat, or feveral things, with ib much Pleafure wih.Outia -Table,, I. $o




'( 64    )
So I went to work: and here I nmuf needs obferve
that as Reafon is the Subflance and Original of the Mathematicks, fo by flating and iqularing every thing by
Reafon, and by making the molt rational Judgnment of
things, every Man may be in time,. after of every Me.
chanick Art. I had never handled a Tool in my Litt,
and yet in time, by Labour, Application and Contrivance, I found at laft that I wanted nothing but I cculd
have made it, efpecially if I had had Tools; however,
I made abundance of things even without Tools, and
fome with no more Tools thin an Adz and a Hatchet,
which perhaps were never made that way before, and
that with infinite Labour. For Example, If I wanted
a Board, I had no other way but to cut down a Tree,
fet it on an edge before me, and hew it flat on either
Side with my Axe, till I had brought it to be as thin
as a Plank, and then dubb it finooth with my Adz:
It is true, by this Method I could make but one Board
out of a whole Tree, but this I had no Remedy for but
Patience, any more than I had for the prodigious deal
of Time and Labour which it took me up to make a
Plank or Board: But my, Time or Labour was little
worth, and foit was as well employ'd one may as a.
nother., However, I made me a Table and a Chair, as I obferv'd above, in the firft Place, and this I did out ot
the ihort Pieces of Boards that I brought on my Raft
from the Ship: But when I had wrought out fome
Boards, as above, I made large Shelves of the breadth
of a Foot and a half, one over another, all along one
fide of my Cave, to lay all my Tools, Nails and Iron'work, and in a Word, to feparate every thing at large
in their Places, that I might eafily come at them; allb
I knoak'd Pieces into the Wall of the Rock to hang my
Guis*,'and all hings that wotuld.hang -up...
So that had my Cave, been to be feen, it look, like a
general Magazinebof all neceffary things; and  I had
every thing fo ready at iny Hand, that it wass a great
Pleatlreto men to fee all my Goids in fuch Order, and
efpecially;to find my Stock of all NecefCarits fo great.
And now it waswhen I hegan to keep a Journal of
every Day's Employment, for indeed at firit I was i
too




( 65)
too much Hurry, and not only a Hurry as to Labour,
but in too much Difcompofure of Mind, and my Journal would ha' been full of many dull things. For Example, I muft have faid thus: Self. the 3oth. After I
got to Shore, and had efcap'd drowning, inflead of being thankful to God for my Deliverance, having firft
vomited, with the great Quantity of Ialt Water which
was gotten into my Stomach, and recovering my felf a
little, I ran about the Shore, wringing my Hands and
beating my Head and Face, exclaiming at my Mifery,
and crying out, I was undone, undone, till tir'd and faint,
I was forc'd to lye down on the Ground to Repofe, but
durft not fleep, for fear of being devoured.
Some Days after this and after I had been on board
the Ship, and had got all I could out of her, yet I could
not forbear gettirg up to the Top of a little Mountain,
and looking out to Sea, in hopes of feeing a Ship, then
fancy at a vaft Diftance I fpy'd a Sail, pleafe my felt
with the Hopes of it, and then after looking fteadily till
I was almoft blind, lofe it quite, and fit down and weep
like a Child, and thus encreafe my Mifery by my Folly.
But having gotten over there thingf in tobme meafure, and -having fettled my Houlhold Stuff and Ha.
bitation, made me w Table and a Chair, and all -as
handrfome about me as could, I began, fay, to keep my
Journal, of which I fhall here give you the Copy,
(tho' in it will be told all thefe Particulars over again)
as long as it lafied; for at lafi having no more Ink,
I was forced to leave it off.
The J           OUR iA L.
Eptember 30, T659. I, poor miferable Ro.
binfon Crufoe, being thipwreck'd, during a
dreadful Storm in the Ojfing, came on Shore
on this difmal unfortunate Ifland, which I
call'd the fland of Defairw, all the reft of
the Ship's Company being drown'd, and my felf almoil dead..
Ah




( 66)
AIl the reftof th Day I fpent in affliing my felf at
the. difmal Circumitances I was brought to, vit. I haad
neither Food, Houfe, Cloaths, Weapon, or Place to
fly to, and in Defpair of any Relief, faw nothing but
Death before me, either that I Ihould be devour'd by
wild Beafs, murder'd by Savages, or flarv'd to Death
fpr want of Food. At the Approach of Night, I flept
in a Tree for fear of wild Creatures, but flept foundly, tho' it rain'd all Night.
Oihcber i. In the Morning I faw, to my great Surprize, the Ship had floated with the high Tide, and
was driven on Shore again much nearer the Ifland,
which, as it was fome Comfort on one hand (for feeing hpr fit upright, and not broken to pieces, I hoped,
if the Wind abated, I might get on board, and get fme
Food and Neceffaries out of her for my Relief) fo on
the other hand, it renew'd my Grief at the Lofs of imy
Comrades, who, I imagined, if we had all (taid on
board, might have faved the Ship, or at leaf that they
would not have been all drowned, as they were; and
that had the Men been rived, we might perhaps have
built us a Boat out of the Rins of the Ship, to have
carried us 'to frome ther Part of the World. I fpen
great Part of this Day in perplqing my felfon thefe
tiigs?  bt at length fecing t~r$hip almot p dry, I
went pon,the Sand 7as near as I coul4 and then fiwam
on board: This Day alfo continued raining, tho' with
no Wind at all.
From the if of Oober to the 4th. All thefe pays
entirely tpent in many feveral Voyages to get all I could
out of the Ship, which I brought on Shore every Tide
of Flood upon Rafts. Much Rain alfo in there Days,
tho' with fome Intervals of fair Weather:!$ut, it feems,
this was the rainy SeaCfoln
O. 2c. I overfet my Raft, and all the Goods I had
got upon it; but being in thoal Water, and the things
being chiefly heavy, I recover'd many of them when
the Tide was out.
0*..   It raind all Night and all.Day, with fome
GutEs of Wini,   during which Tile the Ship broke in
Piect, the W iud bloving a little ehardr than beforet
and was no more to be feen, except the Wrec of her.and




C 67 )
and that only at low'Water. I fpeot -this Day in cow
vering and fecuring the Goods which I had faved, that
the Rain might not fpoil them.
OL. 26. 1 walk'd about the Shore almoft all Day to
find out a Place to fix my Habitation, greatly concern'd
to fecure my fel from any Attacs in the Night, either
from wild Beals or Men. Towards Night i fix'd upon
a proper Place under a Rock, and mark'd out a SemiCircle for my Encampment,   which I reoblv'd to
ftrengthen with a Work, Wall, or Fortification, made
of double Piles, lined within with Cable, and without
with Turf. ''
From the 26th to the 30th, I work'd very hard in
carrying all my Goods to my new Habitation, though
foie Part of the T'in  it rain'd exceeding hard.
The 3 0i in t:e i ning I went out into the Jflan
with my Gun to bfor fome Food, and difcover thc
Country, when i ktfl'd a She-Goat, and her Kid follow'd me Home, which I afterwards kill'd alfo, becaufe
it would not feed.
November i. I fet up my Tent under a Rock, and lay
there for the firft Night, -making it as large as I could
with Stakes driven in to fwing my Hammock upon..Nv, 2. I,ft up all my Chefts and Boards, ard the
Iitees of Timber whiec made my Rafts, and with them
form'd a Fence round me, a little within the Place I
had mark'd out for my Fortification.
Nov. 3. I went sut with my Gun, and kill'd two
Powss like Dacks, which were very good Food. In the
Afternoon went to work to make me a Table.
%v. 4. This Morning I began to order my Times
of Work, of going 'out with my (Gun, Time of Sleejp
and Time of Diverfion, viz. Every Morning I walk'd
cut with my Gun for two or three Hours, if it did not
rain, then employ'd my felf to work ill about eleven
a Clock, then eat what I had to live on, and from
twelve to two I lay down to fleep, the Weather being
excefive hot, and then in the Evening to Ixork.gain:
The working Part of this Day and the next were whol
ly employed in making my Table, for. I was yet but a
very Ibrry Workman, tho' Time and Neceffity made

(68'
me a compleat natural Mechanick oon after, as I believe

Nov. A. This Day I went abroal with my Gun and

but her FleIlj good for nothing: Every Creature. I kill'd,
I took 'off the Skins and preferv'd them. Coming
ba4*by the Sea Shore, I faw many Sorts of Sea-Fowls

Nov. 7. Now it began to ber Weather.

Nl1 3. This Day it rained, which refrefhed me
exceedingly, and cooled the Earth, but it was accompany'd with terrible Thunder and Lightning, which frighted me dreadfully, for fear of my Powder: As foon as
it was over, I refolved to feparate my Stock of Powder
into as many little Parcels as poffible, that it might not
be in Danger.
Nv. 14, 1 5, 6. Thefe three Days I fpent in making
little fiuare Chefis or Boxes, which might hold about
A Pound, or two Pound, at mof, of Powder; and fo
putting the Powder in, I ftowed it in Places as fecure
and remote from one another as poflible. On one of
thefe three Days I kill'd a large Bird that was good to
eat, but I knew not what to call it.:N^ 2. 17. This Day I began to dig behind my Tent
into the Rock, to make room for my farther Conveniency. Note, Three Things I wanted exceedingly for
this Work, vT. a Pick-axe, a Shovel, and a Waeelbarrow or Basket, fo I defifed from my Work, and began




( 69 )
gan to confider how to fupply that Wanlt, and make me

but the next Thing was a Shovel or Spade; this was fo
abSolutely necefilry, that indeed I could do nothing effeftually without it; but what kind of one to make I
knew not.
Nov. t8. The next Day in fearching the Woods, I
found a Tree of that Wood, or like it, which in the Brafils they call the Iron Tree, for its exceeding Hardnefs;
of this, with great Labour, and almoft ipoiling my Ax,
I cut a Piece, and brought it Home too with Dlfficulty enough, for it was exceeding heavy.
The exceffive Hardnefs of the Wood, and having no
other Way, made me a long while upon this Machine,
for I work'd it effectually, by little and little, into the
Form of a Shovel or Spade, the Handle exafly fhap'd
like ours in England, only that the broad Part having
no Iron fhod upon it at Bottom, it would not laft me
fo long; however it ferv'd well enough for the Ufes
which i had Occafion to put it to; but never was a
Shovel,. I believe, made after that Faihion, or fo long
a making.
I was Hill deficient, for I wanted a Basket or a Wheelb
barrow; a Basket I could not make by any means, having no fuch Things as Twigs that would bend to make
VWicker Ware, at leaft none yet found out; and as to
the Wheel-barrow, I fancy'd I could make all but the
Wheel, but that I had no Notion of, neither did I
know how to go about it; befides, I had no poflible
Way to make Iron Gudgeons for, the Spindle or Axis of
theW heel to run in, fo I gave it over; and fo for carrying
away the Earth which I dug out of the Cave, I made
me a thing like a Hoad which! the Labourers carryMortar in when they ferve the Brick-la) ers.
This was not fo difficult to me as the making the
Shovel; and yet this, and the Shovel, and the Attempt,
which I made in vain, to make a Wheel-barrow, took,me up no lefs than four Days; I mean always, excepting my Mornings Walk with my Gun; which I feldom
fail'd, and very feldom fail'd alfo of bringing home
fbmething fit to eat.
Av. 23.




(70 )
iou. 23. My other Work having now flood Rill, be.
caufe of my making thefe Tools; when they were finifhed, I went on; and working every Day, as my Strength
and Time allow'd, I fpent eighteen Days entirely in
widening and deepening my Cave, that it might hold
lmy Goods eommiodioufly.
Nate, During all this Time, I work'd to make this
Room or Cave fpacioas enough to accommodate me as a
Ware-houfe or Magazine, a Kitchen, a Dining-room,
and a Cellar; as for a Lodging, I kept to the Tent, except that obmetimes in the wet Seafbn of the Year, it
rain'd fo hard that I could not keep my felf dry, which
caus'd me afterwards to cover all my Place within my
Pale with long Poles in the form of Rafters, leaning againft the Rock, and load them with Flags, and large
Leaves of Trees like a Thatch.
December Io. I began nowto think my Cave or Vault
finiihed, when on a iuddain (it eelms I had made it too
large) a great Quantity of Earth fell down from the
Top and one Side, fo much, that in ihort it frighted me,
and not without Reafon too, for if' had been under it,
I had never wanted a Grave-digger: Upon this Difafter
I had a great deal of Work to do over again; for I had
the loofe Earth to carry ott, and, which was of more
Importance, I had the Cieling to prop up, fo that I
might be fure no more would come down.
Dec. ix. This Day I went to work with it accord.
ingly, and got two Shoars, or Pofts pitch'd upright to
the Top, with two Pieces of Boards a-crofs over each
Poll: This I finifh'd the next Day; and letting more
Pofts up with Boards, in about a Week more I had the
Roof fecured; and the Pofts ftanding in Rows, ferved
me for artitions to part off my Houle.
Dec. 17. From this Day to the 20th,'l placed Shelves,
and knock'd up Nails on the Pofts to hang every thing
tip that could be hung up, and now I began to be in
fome Order within Doors.
Dec. 20. Now I carried every thing into the Cave,
and began toTurnilh my Houfe, and fet up fome Pleees
of Boards like a Dreffer, to order my Vi&ualst pon;
but Boards began to be very fcarce with me: Alfo I
made me another Table.
Dec. 24.




( 7I )
Dec. 24. Much Rain all Night and all Day; no ftirl
ring out.
Dec. 25. Rain all. Day.
Dec. 26. No lain, and the Earth niucd cooler than
before, and pleafanter.
Dec. 27. Kill'd a young Goat, and lam'd artother,
fo that I catch'd it, and led it Hone in a String; when
I had it Home, I bound and fplinter'd up its Leg which
was broke. 2V. B. I took fuch care of it that it lived,
and the Leg grew well, and as 1trong as ever; but 1by
nurfing it fo long it grew tame, and fei upon the little
Green at my Door, and would not go away. This
was the flrft time that I entertained a Thought of breeding up fortt tame Creatures, that I might have Food
when my Powder and Shot was all fpent.
Dec. 28, 29, 30. Great Heats ard no Breeze; fo that
there was no ftirring abroad, except in the Evening tor
Food   This Time i fpent in putting all my Things in
Order within Doors.
January t. Very hot Hfill but I went abroad early
and late with my Gun, and lay fill in tihe middle of
the Day: This' Evenirg going fartler into the Valleys,
which lay towards the Center of the Ifland, I found
there was plenty of Goats, tho' exceeding fhie and hard
to come at; however, I refolv'd to try if I could not
bring my Dog to hunt them down.
7an. 2. Accordingly, the next Day I ivernt out with
my Dog, and fet him upon the Goats; but I wis  inilaken, for they all faced about upon the Dog, and he
knew his Danger too well, for he wouldl not cohle near
them.:
Yan. 3. I began my Fence or Wall, which, being finl
jealous of my being attack'd by fomre Body, I reiblv'd to
to make very thick and ftrong.
N. B. This Wal beirg eef,lribed beJfre, I p  rfeIy

All this.time I work'd very hard, the Rains hindering me many Days, ray, fometines Weeks together;
but I thought I ihould never be perfe&ly lecure till this
Wall was finifh'd; and it is fcarce credible what inex.
preflible Labour every thing was done with, efpecially
the bringing Piles out of the Woods, and driving them
into the Ground; for I made them much bigger than 1
needed to have done.
When this Wall was finifl'd, and the Outlide double
fenced with a Turf-Wall raifed up clofe to it, I per.
fwaded myfelf; that if any People were come on ihore
there, they would not perceive any thing like a Habitation: And it was very well I did fo, as may be obferv'd hereafter, upon a very remarkable Occafion.
During this time, I made my Rounds in the Woods
for Game every Day when the Rain admitted me, and
made frequent Difcoverics in thefe Walks of fomething
or other to my Advantage; particularly I found a kind
of wild Pidgeons, who built not as Wood-Pidgeons in
a Tree, but rather as Houfe-Pidgeons, in the Holes of,
the Rocks; and taking fome young ones, I endeavoured
to breed them up tame, and did fo; but when they
grew older, they flew all away, which perhaps was at
firft want of feeding them, for I had nothing to give
them   however I frequently found their Nefts, and got
their young ones, which were very good Meat.
And now in the managing my Houihold Affairs, I
found my felf wanting in many things, which I thought
at firtt it was inmpoffible for me to make, as indeed  s
to fome of them it was: For inflance, I could never
make a Cask to be hoop'd; I had a fmall Runlet or,
two, as I cbferv'd befre, but I could never arrive to the
Capacity of making one by them, tlho I fpent many
Weeks about it; I could neither put in the Heads, or
join the Staves fo true to one another, as to make themn
hold Water; fo I gave that alfo over.
In th. next Place, I was at a great lofs for Candle;
fo that as foon as ever it was dark, which was generally
by Seven o' Clock, I was oblied to go to Bed. I remenlber




( 73 )
member'd the Lump of Bees-Wax, with which I made
Candles in my African Adventure; but I had none of
that now: The only Remedy I had, was, that when I
had kil'd a Goat, I faved the Tallow, and with a little
Dilh made of Clay, which I baked in   the Sun, to
which I added a Wick of 'ome Oakuml, I made me a
Lamlp; and this gaye me Light, tho' not a clear ftea.
dy Light like a Cahdle. In the middle of all my Labours it happen'd, that rummaging my Things, 1 found
a little Bag, whichi as I hinted before, had been fill'd
with Corn for the feeding of Poultry, not for this Voyage, but before, as I fuppofe, when the Ship camln from
Lisbon; what little Remainder of Corn had been in the
Bag, was all devoured with the Rats, and I fhw nothing
in the Bag but Husks and Dull; and being willing to have the Bag for fome other Ufe, (I think it
was to put Powder in, when I divided it for tear of
the Lightening, or fome fuch Uie,) I flook the Husks
of Corn out of it on one fide of my Fortification unde r
the Rock.
It was a little before the great Rains, juff now men.
tioned, that I threw this Stuff away, taking no Notice
of' any thing, and not fo tmuch as remembring that I
had thrown any thing there; when about a Month after, or thereabouts, I faw fome few Stalks of fomething
*green flooting out of the Ground, which I fancied
might be fome Plant I had not feen; but I was furprized and perfe&ly aflonifh'd, when after a little longer time I law about ten or twelve Ears come out, which
were perfet green Barley of the fame Kind as our Elar
pean, nay, as our Englijb Barley.
It is impofible to exprefs the Aftonifhment and Confufion of my Thoughts on this Occafion; I had hitherto a&ted upon no religious Foundation at all; indeed I had very few Notions of Religion in my Head,
nor had entertained any Senfe of any Thing that had
befallen me, otherwife than as a Chance, or, as we
lightly fay, what pleafes Go&; without fo much as enquiring into the End of Providence in thefe Things,
or his Order in governing Events in, the World: But
after I faw Barley grow there, in a Climate which I
knew was not proper for Corn, and efpecially that I
E                  knew




( 74):1new not how it came there, it ftartled me firangly, atna
I began to fuggeft, that God had miraculoufly caus'd
this Grain to grow without any Help of Seed fown, and.that it was fo direded purely for my Suftenance in that
xwild miterable Place.
This touch'd my Heart a little, and, brought Tears
o-mt of my Eyes, and I began to blefis my felf that fuch
a Prodigy of Nature fhould happen upon my Account;.and this was the more ftrange to me, becault I faw near
it till, all along by the Side of the Rock, fome other
tlraggling Stalks, which prov'd to be Stalks of Rice,
ard which I knew, becaufe I had feen it grow in Africa
when I was afhore there.
I not only thought thefe the pure Produfions of
Providence for my Support, but nor doubting, but that
there was more in thle Place, I went all over that Part
of the ifland, where I had been before, peering in every Corner, and-under every Rock, to fee for more of it,
hut I could not find any; at laft it occur'd to my
Thoughts, that I had flouk the Bag of Chickens Meat,cut, in that Place, and then the Wonder began to ceafe;
land I muft confefs, my religious Thankfulnefs to God's
'Providence began to abate too, upon the discovering that
all this was nothing but what wascommon; tho' I ought
to have been as thankful tor fo ftrange and unfbrefeen
Provideuce, as if' it had been miraculous; for it was
' eally the Work of Providence as to me, that fhould orIder or appoint, that io or 12 Grains of Corn flould remXnan unfpoil'd (when the Rats had deftroy'd all the
xeft) asit it had been droptfr'im Heaven: As allb that
I fhould throw it out in tlhat particular Place where,
it being in the Shade of a high Rock, it fprang up immnediately; whereas, if I had thrown it any where elfe
it that T'ime, it had been burnt up and deftroy'd.
I carefully fav'd the Ears of this Corn, you may be
fure in their Seafon, Which was. about the fEnd of June,
aund laying tip every Corn, I refolv''d to fow themi all

Year that I could allow- my felfthe leaft Grarin ofthis
Corn to eat, and even tben but f:paringly, as fiall fay
fter.wardsin its Order  for I.od.all that I fow'd the,,                                  ft

frfl Seaforn, not by not obferving the proper Titie,-for

Belides this Barley, there was, as above, 2 or 30

I work'd exceflive hard this three or four Months, to

contriving to gointo it, not by a Door, but over a Wall
by a Ladder, that there might beno Sign on the Outfide

April 16. I finifh'd the Ladder, fo I went up with
the Ladder to the Top, and then pull'd it up after me,
and let it doxwn on the Infide: This was a compleat
Enclofijre to me; for within I had room enough, and
oothing could come at me from without, unlefs it could
firft iutint my7 Wall.
The very next Day after this Wall was finilh'd, I had
almoft had all nay Labour overthrown at once, and my
Jelf kill'd; the Cafe was thus: As I was buay in the
Infide of it. behind my Tent, julf in the Entrance into my Cav;  I was terribly frighted with a moft dreadful furprizing tiing indeed; for all on a fudden I foun;l
the Earth came tumbling down frtno the Roof ~ my
Gave, and from the Edge of the Hill over my  aead,
and two of:the Ports I had fet up in the Cave, crack'd
in a frightful manner: I was heartily flared, but thought
nothing of what really was the Catfe; only thinking
that the Top of my Cave was falling in, as Tome of it
-hadone before, and for fear I ihould be buried in it,
I ranr/forw4rdto my Ladder, and not thinking my felt
fafe there neither, I got over my7Wall for fear of the
Pieces f the 4ill which I expe&ed might roll down upon me    I was no fooner fteptdown upon the firm.Ground, buht i:plainly faw it wis a.terrillle Earthqtake,
for the Ground I flood on fhook three Times, at about
4ight Minutes Diltnce, with three fich Shocks as..                   2               'wouil




( 76 )
would have overturned the itrongetl Building that
could be fuppofed to have ftood on the Earth; and a
great Piece of the Top of a Rock, which flood about
half a Mile from me Next the Sea, fell down with fuch
a terrible Noife, as I never heard in all my Life. I
perceived alfo, the very Sea was put into a violent Motion by it; and I believe the Shocks were fironger under
the " ater than on the Ifland.
I wasfo amaz'd with the Thing it felf, having never
felt the like, or difcours'd with any one that had, that
I was like one dead or ftupified; and the Motion of
the Earth made my Stomack fick, like one that was
tofs'd at Sea; but the Noife of the falling of the Rock
awaked me, as it were, and routing me from the flupified Condition I was in, fill'd me with Horror, and
I thought of nothing then but the Hill falling upon my
Tent, and all my Houfhold-Goods, and burying all at
once; and this funk my very Soul within me a fecond
time.
After the third Shock was over, and I felt no more
for fome Time, I began to take Courage, and yet I had
not Heart enough to get over my Wall again, fbr fear
of being buried alive, but fat fiill upon the Ground,
greatly cafl down and difconfolate, not knowing what
to do: All this while I had not the leaft ierious religious Thought, nothing but the common, Lord ha'
Mercy upon me; and when it was over, that went away
too.
'kile I fat thus, I found theAir over-caft, and it grew
cloudy, as if it would rain; and in lefs than halfan Hour
it blew a mofl dreadful Hurricane of Wind: The Sea
all on a iudden cover'd with Foam and Froth, the
Shore was cover'd with the Breach of the Water, the
Trees were torn up by the Roots, and a terrible Storm
it was; and this held about three Hours, and then began to abate, and then in two Hours more it was calm,
and began to rain very hard.
All this while I fat upon the Ground very much terrified and deje&fed, when on a fudden it came into my
Thoughts, that theie Winds and Rain being the Confequence of the Earthquake, the Earthquake it felf
was fpent and over, and I might venture into my Cave
again,




( 77)
again: Withthis Thought my Spirits began to revive
and the Rain helping allb to perivade me, I went in
and fat down in mny fent; but the Rain was ib vio.
lent, that my Tent was ready to be beaten down,
with it, and I was forced to go into my Cave, tho'
Very much afraid and uneafy, for fear it ihould fall on
my Head,
This violent Rain forced me to a new Work, vi?. to
cut a Hole thro' my new Fortification like a Sink to let
the Water go out, which would elfe have drown'd my
Care. After I had been in my Cave fome time, and
found fill no more Shocks of the Earthquake follow, I
began to be more compoled; and now, to fupport my
Spirits, which indeed wanted it very much, I went to
my little Store, and took a finall Sup of Rum, which
however I did then and always very iparinglv, knowing I could have no more when that was gone.
It continued raining all that Night, and great part
of the next Day, fo that I could not tir abroad; but
my Mind being more compofed, I began to think of
what I had bell do, concluding, that it the Ifland was
iiubje& to thefe Earthquakes, there would be no living
fbr me in a Cave, but I muft confider of building me
mne little Hut in an open Place, which I might firround with a Wall, as I'liad done here, and to make
my felffecure from wild Beafts or Men; but concluded,
if I flaid where I was, I ihould certainly, one time or
other, be buried alive.. With there Thoughts I refolv'd to remove my Tent
mimRtbe Place where, it food, which was juft under
the ohanging Precipie of the Hill, and which, if it
fhould be fhaken again, would certainly fall upon my
Tent; A'nd r fpent the two next Days, bing the 19th
and 20th of April, in contriving where and how to remove my Habitation.
The Fear of being fwallow'd up alive, made me, that
I never lept in quiet; and yet the Apprehenfon of
lying abroad without any Fence, was almoft equal to
it: But ftill, when I look'd about, and faw how every
thing was put in Order, how pleafantly conceald' I
waend how fafe from Danger, it made me very loth
to remove.

( 79 )
wards the Wreck it felf, I thought it fcemed to l1ie'
higher out of the Water than it ufed to do; I examine&
tihe Barrel which was driven on Shore, and foon found
it was a Barrel of Gun-powder, but it had taken Wa.ter, and the Powder was caked. as hatrd as a Stone
However, I rolled it farther on Shore for the pretent,
and went on upon the Sands, as near as I could to the
Wreck of the bhip to loolk for more.
When I came down to the Ship, I found it ftrange1y removed: The ForecafUte, which lay before buried
in Sand, was heav'd up at leaft ix Foot, and the Stern,
which was broke to pieces, and parted fl or the reif by
the Force of the Sea, foon afier I had left rummaging
of her, was tofi'd as it were up, and cait on one ide,
and the Sand was thrown fo high on that Side next the
Stern, that whereas there was a great Place of Water befre, fo that I could not come within a Quarter of a
Mile of the Wreck without fwimming, I could now
walk quite up to her when the Tide was out. I was
furprized with this at firfi, but ioon concluded it mufi
be done by the Earthquake; and as by this Violence the
Ship was more broken open than formerly, fo many
things came daily on Shore which tile Sea had loofen'd,
and which the -inds and Water rolled by degrees to
the Land., ^
This wholly diverted my Thoughts from the Defign
of removing my Habitation; and I bufied my ielf
mightily that Day efpecially, in fearching whetr I.
could make any way into the hip, but I fiund nothing
was to be expe&ed of that kind, for that all the infide
of the Ship was choak'd up with Sand: However, as I
bad learnt not to defpair of any thing, I refolved to
pull every thing to pieces that I could of the Ship, concluding that every thing I could get from her would be
ef fome Ufe or other to me.
i4ay 3. I began with my Saw, and cut a Piece of a
Beam thro', which I thought held fome of the upper
Part, or Quarter-Deck, together, and wb ei I had cut
it thro', I cleared away the Sand as welt as I could,
from the Side which lay highell; but the Tide coming,
i, I was obliged to give over for that time.
E 4                   Maj




( So )
Mady 4. I went a-fifhing, but caught not one Fhtl that
I duril eat of, till I was weary of my Sport, when
juil going to leave off I caught a young Dolphin. I
had made me a long Line of fome Rope-Yarn, but I
had no Hooks, yet I frequently caught Fifh enough, as
much as I cared to eat, all which I dryed in the Sun,
and eat them dry.
MIay 5. Work'd on the Wreck, cut another Beam
afunder, ani brought three great Fir Planks off from
the Decks, which I tied together, and made fwim on
Shore when the Tide of Flood came on.
May 6. Work'd on the Wreck, got feveral Iron Bolts
out ofher, and other Pieces of Iron Work, work'd very
bard,and came home very much tir'd, and hadThoughts
of giving it over.
May 7. Went to the Wreck again, but with an Intent
not to work, but found the Weight of the Wreck had
broke it ielf down, the Beams being cut, that feveral
Pieces of the Ship feem'd to lye loofe, and the Infide of
the Hold lay fo open, that I could lee into it, but almnof full of Water and Sand.
May 8. Went to the Wreck, and carried an Iron
Craw to wrench up the Deck, which lay now quite
clear of the Water or Sand; I wrench'd open two
Planks, and brought them   on Shore alto with the
Tide: I left the Iron Crow in the Wreck for next Day.
May Q. Went to the Wreck, and with the Crow
made Way into the Body of the Wreck, and felt feveral
%Casksk and loofemd them with the Crow, but could
not break theni up; i felt alfo the Roll of Englijb Led.
and could fir it, but it was tgo heavy to move.
May 1, 11, 12, 13, I4. Went every Day to the
~Wreck, and got a great deal of Pieces of Timber and
Boards, or Plank, and 2 or 300 Weight of Iron.
May 15. I carried two Hatchets to try if I could not
cut a Piece off of the Roll of Lead, by placing the Edge
of one Hatchet, and di iving it with the other but as it
lay about a Foot and a half in the Water, I could not
make any Blow to drive the Hatchet.
May 16. It had blow'd hard in the Night, and the
Wreck appear'd more broken by the Force of the Water; but I flay'd fo long in the Woods to get Pidgeons
for




e


( 8it )
for Food, that the Tide prevented me going to the
Wreck that Day.
May 17. I faw foie pieces of the Wreck blown on
Shore, at a great Difance, two Miles off me, but re-,
folv'd to fee what they were, and found it was a piece
of the Head, but too heavy for me to bring away.
May 24. Every Day to this Day I work'd on the
Wreck, and with hard Labour I loolen'd fome things 1o
much with the Crow, that the firft blowing Tide feveral Casks floated out, and two of the Seamen's
Cheits; but the Wind blowing from the Shore, nothing came to Land that Day,' but pieces of Timber,
and a Hogfhead which had rome Brazil Pork in it, but
the Salt-water and the Sand had fpoil'd.it.
I continue4 this Work every Day to the Irth of
atne, except the Time neceftary to get Food, which I
always appointed, during tlliis Part of my Employment,
tobe when the Tide was up, that I might be ready
when it was ebbd out, and by this Time I had gotten
Timber and Plank, and Iron-Work enough to have
built a good Boat, if I had known how; and alfo I got
at feveral times, and in feveral Pieces, near Ioo Weight
of the Sheet-Lead.
Yune 16. Going down to the Sea-fide, T f6und a Targe
Tortoife or Turtle; this was the firft I had feen, which
it feemis was only mny Misfortune, not any Defe& of
the Place, or Scarcity; for had I happen'd to be on the
other Side of the Ifland, I might have had Hundreds of
them every Day, as I found afterwards; but perhaps
had paid dear enough for them.
June 17. 1 fpent in cooking the Turtle; I found in
her three-fcore Eggs; and her Flefh was to me at that
time the moit favoury and pleafant that ever I tailed in
my ~Life, having had' n Flefh, but of Goats and- Fow.ls)
ince ~ landed in this horrible Place.
sune 18. Rain'd all: Day, and I &ffa'd within. I
thought at this tiie the' Rain felt cold, and I was fomething chilly, which I knew was not ulial in that Latitude..une 19. Very ill, and fEhivering, as if the Weather:
had been cold.

(' 83 )
impoffble for Words to defcribe; when lie itepp'd upon the Ground with his Feet, I thought the Earth
trembled, juft as it had done before in the Earthquake,
and all the Air look'd, to my Apprehenfion, as if it
had been fill'd with Flafhes of Fire.
'He was no fooner landed upon the Earth, but he
moved forward towards me, with a long Spear or Wea- -
pon in his Hand, to kill me; and when he came to a
rifing Gronnd, at fome Diftance, he fpoke to me, or I
heard a Volce fo terrible, that it is impoflible to exprefs
the Terror of it; all that I can fay, I underflood, wasthis, Seeing all tbefe Things have not brought thee to Repentance, now thouf halt die: At which Words, I thought'
he lifted up the Spear that was in his Hand to kill me,
No one that fhall ever read this Account, will expe&that I fliould be able A deferibe the Horrors of my Soul
at this terrible Vifion; I mean, that even while it was
a Dream, I even dreamed of thofe Horrors; nor is itany more poilible to defcribe the Impreitfon that remain'd upon my Mind when I awaked and found irwas but a Drean.a
I had, alas! no divine Knqwledge; what I had received by the good lafru&ion of my Father, was then.;
worn out by an uninterrupted Series, fr 8 Years, of~
Seafearing WickNdhef, andd  conftanit Confervation with.nothiig lu1 fuech as were' like my fel,' wicked and profane toItheaft a Pegree: I do not remebert that I ha4
in all tl:t Time one Thought 'that fo mich as tended
either to looking upwards towards God, or inwards.
towards a Refletion upon my own ways; But a certain Stupidity ofSoul, without Defire of Good,or Confcience of Evil, had entirely overwhelm'd me, and I
was Iall that the mofi hardned, unthinking wickedc
Creatre among our common Sail9rs can be fuppofed to
be, not:litiVng tlh leaft Senfe, either. of the Eear of
God in Daingers$ or of Thankfulnefs to God in.iDeli
verances..
In the relating what is already paffof my Story; this
will be the more eafily believed, when I fhall add, that.::
thro' all the Variety of Miferies that had to this Day
befallen me, I never had fo much as one Thought, ofits.beinghe Hand of Godi or that it.was a juf Punilah
e;nt -




(84)
ifient for my Sin, my rebellious Behaviour againft my
Father, or my pretent Sins, which were great; or fo
much as a Punilhment for the general Courfe of my
wicked Life. When I was on the defperate Expedition on the defart Shores of Africa, I never had fo
much as one Thought of what would become of me,
or one With to God to dire& me whither I ihould go,
or to keep me from the Danger which apparently ifurrounded me, as well from voracious Creatures as cruel
Savages: But I was meerly thoughtlefs of God, or a
Providence, a&ded like a meer Brute from the Principles of Nature, and by the Di&ates of common Senfe
only, and indeed hardly that.
When I was deliver'd and taken up at Sea by the
Portugal Captain, well ufed, and dealt juftly and ho.
hourably with, as well as charitably, I had not the
leaft Thankfulnefs in my Thoughts: When again I was
ihipwreck'd, ruin'd, and in Danger of drowning on this
Ifland, I was as far from Remorfe, or looking on it as
a Judgment; I only faid to my felfoften, that I was
an unfr rtunate Dog, and born to be alwavs miferable.
It is true, when I got on fhore firfE here, and found.
all my Ship's Crew drown'd, and my fel fpared, I
was furpriz'd with a kind of Extafy, and folae Tranft
ports of Soul, which, had the grace ofGod afifted,
might have come up to true Thankfulnes; but it ended where it begun, in a meer common Flight of Joy, or,
as I may fay, being glad I was alive, without the leafl
RefleEion upon the difinguifhing Goodnefs ofthe Hand.
which had vreferved me, and had tingled me out to be,
preferv'd, when all the reft were deftroy'd; or an Enquiry why Providence had been thus merciful to me;
even jut the fame common fort of Joy which Seamen.
generally have after they have got fafe a fhore from a.
Shipwreck, which they drown all in the next Bowl of
Punch, and forget aliofi as loon as it is ever, and all
the reft of my Life was like it.
Even when I was afterwards, on due Confiieration,
made fenfible of my Condition, how I was caft on this
dreadful Place, out of the Reach of human Kind, out
of all Hope of Relief, or Profpe& of Redemption, as
loon as I Law but a Profpet of Lving, and that I
fhould




( 85 )
fhould not flarve and perifh for Hunger, all the Senfe
of my Aflitiion wore off, and I begun to be very eafy,
apply'd my felftothe Works proper ior my Prefervation
and Supply, and was far enough from being afflited at
my Condition, as a Judgment from  Heaven, or as the
Hand of God againft me: Thefe were Thoughts which
very feldom enter'd into my Head.
' The growing up of the Corn, as is hinted in my Journal, had at firft fome little Influence upon me, and
began to affeft me with Serioufnefs, as long as I thought
it had tbmething nmiraculous in it; but as foon as ever
that Part of the Thought was removed, all the Impreffion which was raifed from it wore offalfo, as I have
noted already.
Even the Earthquake, tho' nothing could be more
terrible in its Nature, or more immediately dire&cing
to the vifible Power, which alone dire&s fuch things,
yet no fooner was the firft Fright over, but the lmpreffion it had made went off alfo. I had no more Senfe
of God or his Judgments, much lefs of the prefent Affli&ion of my Circumftances, being from his Hand than
if I had been in the moft profperous Condition o? Life.
But now when I began to be tick, and a leifurely
View of the Miferies of Death came to place it felfbe.
fore me; when my Spirits began to fink under the Burden of a ftrong Diftemper, and Nature was exhaufted
with the Violence of the Fever; Confcience, that had
flept o long, began to awake, and I began to reproach
my felf with my paft Life, in which I had fi evidently,
by uncommon Wickednefs, provoked the Juftice of
God to lay me under uncommon Strokes, and to deal
with me in fo vindiaive a manner.
Thefe Reflections opprefs'd me for the fecond or third
Day of nmy Diftemper, and in the Violence, as well of
the Fever as of the dreadful Reproaches of my Confcience, extorted fome Words from  me, like praying
to God, tho' I cannot fay they were either a Prayer attended with Defires, or with fI-pes; it was rather the
Voice of meer Fright and Difttefs; my Thoughts were
confuted, the Convifions grkat upon my Mind, and
the Horror of dying in fuch a miferable Condition
raifec Vapours into my Head with the meer Appre,
henfions^

(88)
on, he having the fole Power, not of me only, but of

Why has God dfoe this t     W me. What hve I done t be

My Confcience prefently check'd me in that Enquiry,
as if I had blafphem'd, and methought it fpoke to me like
a Voice; WREICH! dfl thou ask what thou haftdne
Look back upon a dreadful mif-fpent Life, and ask thy
felf wfhat thou htqp not done? Ask, Why is it that thou wert

Beafis on the COaft of A frica? Or, drown'd H E RE, when
all the Crew peri h'd but thyjelf  Doft thou ask, What
have I done?
I was ftruck dumb with thefe Refleations, as one aftonifhed, and had not a Ward to fay, no not to anfwer
to my fef, but rofe up penfive and fid, walk'd back to
my-Retreat, and went up ovrf my: Wall, as if I had
'been going to Bed, but my Thoughts were fadly difturb'd, and I had no inclintion to ileep; fo I fat down.
in my Chair, and lighted my Lamp, for it began to be
dark. Now, as the A.pprehenfion of the retumn of my
DEifemper terrifyM  f e very much, itoccurd to my
Thought, that the Bafians take no Phyfick blut their
Tobacco, for almoft all DifAempers -andr  I Iid a Piece
6f a Roll of TobaccQ in one of the Chefs, which was
quite cured,~ anA& biie '-ito thalt was green, and not
quite cured.
I went, dire&ed by Heaven no doubt, for in this.
Cheft I found a Cure both for Soul and Body; I opened the Chefl, and found what I flook'd for, viz. the
Tobaco; and as-the 'few Bbhks I had fav.d layithere,
too, I took out one of' the BiBles which I mentionId
before, and which to this time I had not found Leifure,
or fo much as Inclination to look into; I a y, I took it
out, and brought both that and the Tobacco with me
to the Table.
What Ufe to make of the Tobacco, I knew not, as
to my Diftemper, or whether it was good for it' or no;
bu'ttdrf. feveral- Eperimests with it, as if was re
1ylv'cd




( 8 )
Ablv'd it fhould, hit one Way or other: I firtl took a
Piece of a Leaf, and chew'd it iin my Mouth, which
indeed at firft almoft ftupify'd my Brain, the Tobacco
being green and ftrong, and that I had not been much
us'd to it; then I took Tome and fleeped it an Hour or
two in Rum, and refolv'd to take a Dofe of it when I
lay down; and laftly, I burnt tome upon a Pan of Coals,
and held my Note clofe over the Smoke of it as long
as I could bear it, as well for the Heat as the Virtue
of it, and I held it almoft to Suffocation.
In the interval of this Operation, I took up tlftBible and began to read, but my Head was too much di.
fturb'd with the Tobacco to bear reading, at leafi at that
time; only having open'd the Book cafually, thefirft
Words that occur'd to me were thefe, Call on me in the
Day of Trouble and I will deliver, and thou jhalt glorif
mne.
The Words were very apt to my Cafe, and made
fome Impreflion upon my Thoughts at the Time of reading them, tho' not fo much as they did afterwards; for
as for being deliver'd, the Word had no Sound, as I
may fay, to me; the Thing was fo remote, fo impofible in my Apprehenfion of Things, that I began to fay
as the Children of Ifrael did, when they were promis'd
Fleih to eat, Can God fpread a Table in the Wildernefs?
So I began to to fay, Can God himfelf deliver me from
this Place? And as it was not for many Years that any
Hope appear'd, this prevail'd very often upon my
Thoughts: But however, the Words made a great Im.
preflion upon me, and I muted upon them very often.
It grew now late, and the Tobacco had, as I faid, doz'd
my Head fo much, that I inclin'd to feep; fo I left
my Lamp burning in the Cave, left I fhould want any
thing in the Night, and went to Bed; but before I lay
down, I did what I never had done in all myLife, I kneeled down and pray'd to God to fulfil the Promife to me,
that if I call'd upon him in the Day of Trouble, he
would deliver me; after my broken and imperfe& Prayer was over, I drunk the Rum in which I had fleepd
the Tobacco, which was fo ftrong and rank of the Tobacco, that indeed I could fcarce get it down. Immeliatly upon this I went to Bed, and I found prefently it
flew
