( 91 )
Now I began to conftrue the Words mentioned above, Call on me, and 1 will deliver you, in a different
Senfe from what I had ever done before; for then I had
no Notion of any thing being called Deliverance, but
my being delivered from the Captivity I was in, for
tho' I was indeed at large in the Place, yet the Ifland
was certainly a Prifon to me, and that in the worft
Senfe in the World; but now 4learn' to take it in another Senfe. Now I look'd back- pon my paft Life
with fuch Horror, and my Sins appear'd fo dreadful,
that my Soul fought nothing of God, but Deliverance
from the Load of Guilt that bore down all my Comfort. As for my folitary Life it was nothing; I die
not fo much as pray to be delivered from it, or think of
it j it was all of no Confideration in Comparifon to this;
and I added this Part here, to hint to whoever fhall
read it, that whenever they come to a true Senfe of
things, they will find Deliverance from Sin a much
greater Bleffing, than Deliverance from Afflition.
But leaving this Part, I return to my Journal.
My Condition began now to be, the' not lefs miferabl as to my Way of living, yet much eafier to my
Mind; and my Thoughts being dire&ed, by a confalnt
reading the Scripture, and praying to God, to things of
higher Nature; I had a great deal of Comfort within,
which till now I knew nothing of: Alfo, as my Health
and Strength return, I beftirr'd my fel to furnifh:my
flf with every thing tat I wanted, and make my way
of living as regular as I could.;
From the 4th of luly to the, Inth I was whiefly empoyed in walking about with my Gun in my Hand,
a little and a little at a time, as a Man that was gathering up his Strength after a Fit of Sickmefs: For it
Is hardly to be imagin'd how low I was, and to what
Wbaknefs I was reducd. The Application vwhich I
made ufe of, was perfedly new,,aidi ehaps what had
never cur'd an Ague before; neitleir can I recommend
it to anyoneto pra&ice, by this Exrpperijnt; and tho'
it did carry off the Fit, yet it rather contributedto
weaken




( 93)
weaken me; for I had frequent Convulfions in my
Nerves and Limbs for fome time.
I learnt from it alb this in particular, that being
abroad in the rainy $eafon, was the moft pernicious
thing to my Health that could be, efpecially in thofe
Rains which came attended with Storms and Hurricanes
of Wind; for as the Rain which came in a dry Seafon
was always molt accompanied with fuch Storms, to i
found that Rain was much more dangerous than the
Rain which fell in September and Otlober.
I had been now in this unhappy Ifland above io
Months; all Poflibility of Deliverance from this Condition feem'd to be entirely taken from me, and I firmly
believed, that no human Shape had ever fet Foot upon that Place. Having now fecur'd my Habitation, as
I thought, fully to my Mind, I had a great Defire to
make a more perfe& Difcovery of the Ilfand, and to fee
what other Productions I might find, which yet I knew
nothing of.
It was the X Sth of -7uly that I began to take a more
particular Survey of the Ifland it lelf: I went up the
Creek firit, where, as I hinted, I brought my Rafts on
Shore. I found, after I came about two Miles up, that
the Tide did not flow any higher, and that it was no
more than a little Brook of running Water, and very
freflh and good; but this being the dry Seafon, there
was hardly any Water in fome Parts of it, at leaft
not enough to run in any Stream, fo as it could be
perceiv'd.
On the Bank of this Brook I found many pleafant
Savana's, or Meadows, plain, fmooth, and cover'd with
Grafs; and on the rifing Parts of them next to the
higher Grounds, where the Water, as it might be fuppoled, never overflowed, I found a great deal of Tobacco, green and growing to a great and very ftrong
Stalk: There were divers other Plants which I had no
Notion of, or UnderfIanding about, and might perhaps have Virtues of their own, which I could not
find out.
I Searched for the Caffava Root, which the Indiauss
in all that Climate make their Bread of, but I could
find




(94)
tnA nb.t& Crhw latge Plants of Aloes, bit, did not
then undeorfand them. I                 JQ w feveraln Sugarranes sb.vild, and tfoti' Vat ofiakivtration, i perfi &. If con.

little Ohfervation while I wvas in the Brajils, that I
knew little of the Plants in the Field, at leaft very little
-that mifght 1'rve me to anyj Purpofe now  in my

The next Day, the r6th, I Went up the fame Way a.
gain, and after going fomething farther 'than 1 had

vana's began to ceafe, and the Country became more
woody than before.' In this Part I found differnen
Fruits, and particularly~ I found -Melons upon the
Ground in greqa Abundance, and Grapes upon the
Trees; the Vines had lbread" indd  over tht Trees,
and the Clutlers of Grapes were jaftl now 'iirtbeirPrime;
very ripe and jich. This was a fiarprizing Difcovery,
and I was exceeding glad of them;iii but I was warn'd
by my Experience to. eat flaringly ofthem, rem. embring,
that when I was aihore in Barbar, the eating of'Grapes
kill'd feveral of our Eng0F Men who-were Slaves there,
by throwin~g them into Fluxes and Fevers': Bt, I found
an excellent Lfe for thefre Grapes,  and- that was -to cure
or dry them in the Sun, and keep. them as dry'd Grapes
or Raifins are' kept which I thoughit wou'uld bq, as indeed they were, as who'lefome, and as agreeable to eat,,when no Grapes might be h'ad.
I Fpent all that Evening there, and went not back to
mny Haobitation, which by the way wvas the  Night a'
I might fay, I had lain from Home. In the Nigiht utook

( 96 3
of Grapes, which were fo rich and fine when I gather'd
them, I found them all fpread abroad, trod to Pieces
and dragg'd about, fome here, Come there, and Abundance eaten and devoured:,by this I concluded there
were fome wildCreatures thereabouts, which had done
this; but what they were I knew not.
However, as I found that there was no laying them
up on Heaps, and no carrying them away in a Sack, but
that one Way they would be detroy'd, and the other
Way they would be crufh'd with their own Weight,
I took another Courfe; for I gather'd a large Quantity
of the Grapes, and hung them upon the Out-Branches
of the Trees, that they might cure and dry in the Sun;
and as for the Limes and Lemons, I carry'd as many
back as I could well ftand under.
Wlen I came Home from this Journey, I contemplated with great Pleafure the Fruitfulnefs of that Valley, and the Pleafantnefs of the Situation, the Security
from Storms on that Side the Water, and the Wood,
and concluded that I had pitch'd upon a Place to fix my
Abode, which was by far the worft Part of the Country. Upon the whole, I began to confider of removing
my Habitation, and to look out for a Place equally fafe,
as where I now was fituate, if poffible, in that pleafant
fruitful Part of the Ifland.
This Thought run long in my Head, and I was ex.
ceeding fond of it for Iome Time, the Pleafantnefs of the
Place tempting me; but when I came to a nearer View
of it, and to confider that I was now by the Sea-fide,
where it was at leaft poffible that fomething might happen to my Advantage, and that the tlme ill Fate that
brought me hither, might bring fome other unhappy
Wretches to the fame Place; and tho' it was fcarce probable that any fuch thing fliould ever happen, yet to enclofe my felfamong the Hills and Woods, in the Center of the Ifland, was to anticipate my Bondage, and
to render fuch an Affair not only impropable, but impofible; and that therefore I ought not by any Means
to remove.
However, I was fo enamour'd of this Place, that I
fpent much of my Time there for the whole remaining
Part of the Month of Yuly; and tho' upon fecond
ThouhtI




( 97)
Thoughts I refolv'd as above, not to remove, yet t built
nm  a little kind of a Bower, and furrounded it at a
Dillance wtih a ftrong Fence, being a double Hedge,
as high as I could reach, well ftak'd and fill'd between
with BrqJhvwomd; and here I lay very fecure, foimbtims
two or three Nights together, always going over it with
a Ladder, as betore; ib that I tancy'd now I hadlmy
Country-Houfe, and my Sea-Coafi-Houte: And this
Work took me up to the Beginning of' Aguauf.
I had but newly finili'd my Fence, and began to enjoy my Labour, but the Rains came on, and iade me
Itick clofe to my firft Habitation; for tho' I had made
me aTent like the other, with aPiece of aSail, and fpread
it very well; yet I had not the Shelter of a Hill to keep
me from Storms, nor a Cave behind me to retreat into,
when the Rains were extraordinary.
About the Beginning of Augufi as Ifa!i, I had finifhl'1
my Bower, and began to enjoy my felf. The third of
Augufit, found the Grapes I had hung up were perfetly
dry'd, and indeed, were excellent good Raifins ofthe
Sun; fo I began to take them down from the Trees,
and it was very happy tlat I did ob; for the Rains
which followed would have fpoil'd them, and I had loft
the beft Part of my Winter Food; for I had above
two hundred large Bunc ees of them. No fooner had I
taken them all down and carry'd mof -of them Home
to my Cave, but it began to rain; and from thence,
which was the fourteenth of Atguft, it rain'd more or
lets every Day, till the niddle of Otober; and fometimes fo violently, that I could not flir out of my Cave
for feveral Days.
In this Sealbn I was much furpriz'd with the Increare of my Family: I had been concern'd for the Lots
of one of my Cats, who run away from me, or as I
thought had been dead, and I heard no more Tale or
Tidingsof her, till to my Aftoniflment r he came home
about the End of Auguft, with three Kittens. This
was the more ffrange to me, becaufe tho' I had kill'd
a wild Cat, as I call'd it, with my Gun; yet I thought
it was a quite different Kind fiom our Euroean Cats;
yet the young Cats were the fame kind of Houfe-breed
like the old one i and both my Cats being Females, I
F              thought




( 9S   ):thought it very ftrange: But from thefe three Cats, I
i-terwards came to be fl pefter'd with Cas, that I was
forced to kill them like Vermin, or wild Beafs, and to
driVe them from my Houle as much as poflible.
From the fourteenth of Augufl to the twenty fixth,
inceflant Kain, fo that I could not flir, and was now very caretul not to be much wet. In this Confinement
I began to be ftraitned for Food, but venturing out
twice, I one Day kill'd a Goat; and the laft Day, which
was the twenty-fixth found a very large Tortoitf which
tvas a Treat to me, and my Food ivas regulated thus:
leat a Bunch of Railins for my 13reakfait, a Piece of
the Goat's Flell, or of the Turtle, for my Dinner
broil'd; (for to my great Misfortune, I had no VeIfel
to boil or ftew any thing) and two or three of the Turtlc's Eggs fbr my Supper.
During this Confinement in my Cover by the Rain,
I work'd daily two or three Hours at enlarging my
Cave, and by Degrees work'd it on towards one Side,
till I came to the Outfide of the Hill, and made a Door
or Way out, which came beyond my Fence or Wall,
end fo I came in and out this Way: But I was not perfetly eafy at lying fo open; for as I had manag'd myfelf before, I was in a perfef& Enclofure, whereas now
I thought I lay expos'd, and yet I could not perceive
that there was any living thing to fear, the biggeft
Creature that I had yet feen upon the Ifland being a
Goat.
Septenber the thirtieth, I was now come to the unhappy Anniverfary of my Landing. I caft up the Notches on my Pofl, and found I had been on Shore three
hundred and fixty five Days. I kept this Day as a folemn faft, fetting it apart to Religious Exercife, proftrating my felf on the Ground with the molt ferious
Humiliation, confefling my Sins to God, acknowledging his Righteous Judgments upon me, and praying to
himn to have Mercy on me, thro' Jefus Chrif:; and
having not tafred the leaf Refrefliment for twelve
Hours, even till the going down of the Sun, I then eat
a Bisket-Cake, and a Bunch of Grapes, and went to Bed,
finifhing the Day as I began it.
I had all this time obferv'd no Sabbath-Day; for:..... a




( 99 )
as at firft I had no Senfe of Religion upon my)Mind, and.I
had after ibme time omitted to diftinguill the 9, eeks,
by naking a longer Notch than ordinary tor the -abLath-Day, and bf did not really know what any cf the
Days were; but now having cakf up the Days, as above,
I found I had been there a Year; fo I divided it into
Weeks, and let apart every feventh Day for a Sabbath;
tho' I found at the End of my Account I had loft a Day
or two in my Reckoning.
A little after this my Ink began to fail me, and fo [
contented my felftto ul- it more iparingly, and to write
down only the mnoll remarkable Events ofmny Litf, without continuing a daily MI#ewmorandum of other Things.
The rainy >eafon, and the dry Seafon, began now to
appear regular to me, and I learnt to divide them lo,
as to provide ifr them  accordingly. But I bought all
| ny Experience before I had it; and this I am going
to relate, was one of the molt difcouraging Experiments that I made at all. I have mention'd that I had
av'd the few Ears of Barley and Rice which I had ib
furprizingly found fpring up, as I thought, of themetlves, and believe there were about thirty Stalks of
Rice and about twenty ofBarly; and now I thought it
a proper time to Low it after the Rains, the Sun being in
its Southern Polition going from me.
Accordingly I dug up a Piece of Ground, as well as
I could with my wooden Spade, and dividing it into
two Parts, I iow'd my Grain; but as I was fowing,
it cafually occur'd to my Thoughts, that I would not
low it all at firil, becaule I did not know when was
the proper time for it; {b I fow'd about two thirds
of the Seed, leaving about a Handful of each.
It was a great Comfort to me afterwards, that I did
fo, for not one Grain of that I fow'd this time came to
any thing; for the dry Months following, the Earth having had no Rain after the Seed was Ibwn, it had no
Moilture to afift its Growth, aRd never came up at all,
till the wet Seafon had come again, and then it grew as
if it had been but newly fown.
Finding my firft Seed did not grow, which I eafily
imagin'd was by the Drought, I ibught for a moiAfte
Piece of Ground to make another Trial in, and I dug
F 2                up




( I00    )
up a Piece of Ground near my new Bower, and fow'd
the reft of my Seed in February, a little before the Ver.
nal Equinox; and this having the rainy Months of'March
and April to water it, fprung up very pleafantly, and
yielded a very good Crop; but having Part of the Seed
left only, and not daring to low all that I had yet, I
had but a filall Q.uantity at ladf, my whole Crop not
amounting to above half a Peck of each kind.
But by this Experiment I was made Maifer of my
Bufinefs, and knew exatly when the proper Seafon was
to fbw; and that I might expe& two Seed-times, and
two Harvefts every Year.
While this Corn was growing, I made a little Difcovery, which was of Ufe to me afterwards: As loon as

which was about the Month of November, I made a
Viilt up the Country to my Bower, where tho' I had
not been tome Months, yet I found all things jufa as I
left them. The Circle or double Hedge that I had
made, was not only firm  and entire, but the Stakes
which I had cut off of fomeTrees that grew thereabouts,
were all fhot out, and grown with long Branches, as
much as a Willow.Tree ufually fhoots the firfl Year after lopping its Head. I could not tell what Tree to
call it, that thefe Stakes were cut from.  I was fuirpriz'd, and yet very well pleas'd, to fee the young
Trees grow; and I prun'd them, and led them up to
grow as much alike as I could, and it is fcarce credible
how beautifuil a Figure they grew into in three Years;
fo that tho' the Hedge made a Circle of about twenty
aive Yards in Diameter, yet the Trees, for Luch I might
now call them, loon cover'd it; and it was a compleat
Shade, fuflicient to lodge under all the dry Seafon.
This nmade me refolve to cut fome more Stakes, and
make me a Hedge like this in a Semicircle round my
Wall, I mcan that of my firft Dwelling, which I did;
and placing the Trees or Stakes in a double Row,
at about eight Yards diflance from my firfI Fence, they
grew prefently, ard were at firfl a fine Cover to my
Habitation, and afterward ferv'd for a Defence alfo, as
I flall obierve in its Order.

( II )


I found now, that the Seafons of the Year might fge
nerally be divided, not into Summer and Wintefr, as in
Europe; but into the rainy Seafons, and the dry Seafons,
which were generally thus:
I    HalfFebruary,,
Mal h         the E~dimx.
Half  I a    Raiy, the     being then on or neapril,

The rainy Seafon fometimes held longer or fhorter,
as the Winds happen'd to blow; but this was the general Obfervation I made. After I had found, by Experience, the ill Confequence of being abroad in the
Rain, I took Care to furniih my fel wvith Provifions before-hand, that I might not be oblig'd to go out; and
I fat within Doors as much as poiTible during the wet
Months.
In this Time I found much Employment, (and very
fuitable alfo to the Time) for I found great Occafion
of many things which I had no way to furnifh my
felf with, but by hard Labour and conflant Application; particularly, I tried many Ways to make my felt
a Basket, but all the Twigs I could get for the Purpole
provld fo brittle, that they would do nothing. ivt
prbv'd of excellent Advantage to me now, that when
I was a Boy, I ufed to take great Delight in flanding at
P3                      a




( 102)
*a Bsket-maler' in the Town where my Father liv'd, to,
ice them make their Wicker-ware; and being as Boys
ufually are, very officious to help, and a great Obitrver of the Manner how they work'd thole things,
and ibme:imes lending a Hand, I had by this means
full Knowledge of the Methods of it, that I wanted nothing but the Materials; when it came into my Mind,
thiat the Twigs of that Tree from whence I cut my
Stakes that grew, might poflibly be as tough as the,SallcTs, and WlTills, and Ofters in England, and I re.
folv'd to try.
Accordingly the next Day I went to my CountryHoufe, as 1 call'd it, and cutting fome of the fmaller
Twigs, I found them to my Purpofe as much as I could
defire; whereupon I came the next time prepar'd with
a Hatchet to cut dcwn a Quantity, which I foon found,
for there was great Plenty of' them: Thefe I Let up to
dry within my Circle or Hedge, and when they were
fit for Ufe, I carried them to my Cave; and here during the next Seafon, I employ'd my ftlf in making, as
well as I cculd, a great many Baskets, both to carry
Fa'th, or to carry or lay up any thing as I had occafion;
and tho' i did not finitih them very handfomely, yet I
made them fuffciently ferviceable for my Purpofe; and
thus afterwards I took Care never to be without them
and as my Wicker-ware decayed, I made more, efpecially
I made ftrong deep Baskets to place my Corn in, inflead of Sacks, when I fhould come to have any Quan.
tity of it.
Having mafler'd this Diffculty, and employ'd a
world of Time about it, I beffirr'd my felf to fee, if pop
ible, how to fupply two Wants. I had no Veffels to,
bold any thing that was Liquid, except two Runlets
which were almof full of Rum, and fome Glafs Bottles,
fome of the common Size, and others which were CafeBottles fquare, for the holding of Waters, Spirits, Erc.
I had not fo muwh as a Pot to boilany thing in, except a
great Kettle which I fav'd out of the Ship, and which
was too big for fuch Ufes as I defir'd it for, viz. to make
Broth, and flew a Bit of Meat by it felf. The fecond
Tbing I would fain have had, was a Tobacco-Pipe; but
iA




( 1o3 )
it was impofible to me to make one; however I fbond
a Contrivance for that too at laft.
I employ'd my elf in planting my fecond Rows of
Stakes or Piles, and in this Wicker working all the Sum1
mer, or dry Seafon, when another Butinels took nme up
more Time than it could be iimagin'd I could Ipare.
I mentioned before, that I had a great Mlind to fee
the whole Piland, and that I had travelled up the Brook,
and fo on to where I built mny Bower, and where I had
an Opening quite to the Sea on the other Side of the
Ifland. 1 now refilved to travel quite crofs to the Seafhore on that Side: So taking my Gun, a Hatchet, and
my Dbg, and a larger Q.uantity of Powder and Shot than
utual, with two Bisket-Cakes, and a great Bunch of
Raifins in my Pouch for my Store, I began my Joiurney. When I had pafs'd the Vale where my Bower
ftood, as above, I came within View of the Sea, to the
Weft, and it being a very clear Day, I fairly deflricd
Land, whether an Inand or a Continent, 1 could nottell; but it lay very high, extending from the Weji to
the W. S. W. at a very great Diflance; by my Guy-Is it
could not be lefs than fifteen or twenty Leagues off.
I could not tell what Part of the World this miglht
be, otherwife than that I knew it mull be Fart of Ame-.
rica i and as I conwluded by all my Obfervations, inutiti
be near the Spanifi) Dominions, and perhaps was all inhabited by Savages, where if I fhould have landed, I
had been in a worle Condition than I was now; and
therefre I acquiefced in the Difpofitions of Providence,
which I began now to own, and to believe, order'd every thing for the beft; I fay, I quieted my Mind with
this, alnd left affliiing my felt with fruithlels Wiflies
of being there.
Befides, after forne Paufe upon this Affair, I confider'd, that if this Land was the SpaniJh Coaft, 1 fhould
certainly, one Time or other, fee fome Velel pafs or
re-pafs one Way or other; but if not, then it was the
&aave Coafa between the Spanij Country and Brafis,
which were indeed the worft oftSvages; for they are:

evoux ac thl,tia ha  Bodwies that fal into their Hands, t




( o04 )
With there Confiderations I walk'd very leifurely
forward. I found that Side of the Ifland where I now
was, much pleafanter than mine, the open or Savanna
Fields \weet, adorn'd with Flowers and Grafs, and full
ot very fine Woods. I jaw Abundance of Parrots, and
fain I would have caught one, it poflible, to have kept
it to be tale, and taught it to fpeak to me. I did, afttr tome Pains taking, catch a young Parrot, for I
knock'd it down with a Stick, and having recover'd it,
I brought it home; but it was fome Years before I
could make him fpeak: However, at lafi I taught him
to call me by my Name very familiarly: But'the Accident that tbllow'd, tho' it be a Trifle, will be very
diverting in its Place.
I was exceedingly diverted with this Journey: I
found in the low Grounds, Hares, as I thought them
to be, and Foxes, but they differ'd greatly from all the
other Kinds I had met with; nor could 1 fatisfy my felf
to eat them, tho' I killd feveral: But I had no need to
be venturous; for I had no Want of Food, and of that
which was very good too; efpecially thefe three Sorts,
Vit. Goats, Pidgeons, and I urtle or Tortoife; which,
added to my Grapes, Leaden-HaIl Market could not
have furnifh'd a Table better than I, in Proportion to
the Companr; and tho' my Cafe was deplorable enough,
yet I had great Caule for Thankfulnefs, that I was not
driven to any Extremities for Food; but rather Plenty,
even to Dainties.
I never travelled in this Journey above two Miles
outright in a Day, or thereabouts; but I took To many
Turns and Returns to fle what Difcoveries I could
make, that I came weary enough to the Place where
I refolv'd to fit down for all Night; and then I either
repos'd my felf in a Tree, or furfounded my felf with
a Row of Stakes fet upright in the Ground, either from
one Tree to another, or lb as no wild Creature could
come at me, without waking me.
As foon as I came to the Sea-Shore, I was furprized
to fee that I had taken up my Lot on the worft Side of
the lfland; for here indeed the Shore was cover'd with
innumerable Turtles, whereas on the other Side I had
Jound but three in a Year and half. Here was alfo an
infinit




( I05 )
infinite Number of Fowls of many Kinds, fome of which
I had not feen before, and many of them very good
Meat; but lich as I knew not the Names of, except
thofe call'd Penguins.
I could have fhot as many as I pleated, but was very
fparing of my Powder and Shot; and therefore had
more Mind to kill a She-Goat, if I could, which I
could better feed on: And tho' there were many Goats
here more than on the other Side the Ifland, yet it was
with much more Difficulty that I could come near
them, the Country being flat and even, and they iawv
me much fooner than when I was on the Hills.
I confefs this Side of the Country was much pleafanter than mine, but yet I had not the leafi Inclination
to remove; for as I was fixed in my Habitation, it became natural to me, and I feem'd all the while I was
here, to be as it were upon a Journey, and from Home:
However, I travelI'd along the Shore of the Sea, towards the Eafl, I fuppofe about twelve Miles; and then
letting up a great Pole upon the Shore for a Mark, I
concluded I would go Home again; and that the next
Journey I took, fhould be on the other Side of the Ifland,
Eafl fi-om my Dwellirg, and fo round, till I came to my
'Por again. Of which in its Place.
I took another Way to come back than that I went,
thinking I could eafily keep all the Ifland fo much in
my View, that I could not mifs finding my firft Dwelling by viewing the Country; but I found my felf mifftaken; for being come about two or three Miles, I found
my felf defcended into a very large Valley; but fo furrounded with Hills, and thofe Hills covered with
Woods, that I could not fee which was my Way by any
Direcion but that of the Sun, nor even then, unlefs I
knew very well the Pofition of the Sun at that Time oi
the Day.
It happen'd, to my farther Misfortune, that the
Weather prov'd hazey for three or four Days, while I
was in this Valley; and not being able to fee the Sun, I
wander'd about very uncomfortably, and at laft waX
obliged to find out the Sea-Side, lovk for my Poft, and;
come back the Iame Way I went; and then by eafy
Journeys I turn'd homeward, the Wtather being ex*
F 5               ceeding




( Io6 )
ceiding hot, and mi Gun, Ammunition, Hatchet, aidl
other Things very heavy.
In this Journey my Dog. fHpriz'd a young Kid, and
feiz'd upon it, and I running in to take hold of it,
caught it, and fav'd it alive from the Dog,; I had a
great Mind to bring it home; if I could; for I had often
been muting, whether it might not be poflble to get
a Kid or two, and o raife a Breed of tame Goats, which
might fupply me when my Powder and Shot fhould be
fpent.
I made a Collar to this little Creature, and wiith a
String which I made of fome Rope-Yarn which I always carried about me, I led him along, tho' with fome
Difficulty, till I came to my Bower, and there I enclos'd
him, and left him; for I was very impatient to be at
Home, from whence I had been abfent above a Month.
I cannot exprefs what a Satisfa&ion it was to me, to
come into my old Hutch, and lie down in my Hammock-Bed: This little wandring Journey, without fettled Place of Abode, had been fo unpleafant to me, that
my own Houfe, as I call'd it to my felf, was a perfef
Settlement to me, compar'd to that; and it render'd
every thing about me fo comfortable, that I refolv'd I
would never go a great Way from it again, while it
K tould be my Lot to flay on the fland.
I.repos'd my felf here a Week, to reft and regale my
felf after my long Journey; during which, moft of the
Time.was taken up in the weighty Affair of making a
Cage:for my Poll, who began now to be a meer Domefick, and to be mighty well acquainted with me.
Then I began to think of the poor Kid, which I had
pent in within my little Circle, and refolv'd to go and
itch it Home, or give it fome Food; accordingly t
Went, and foutd it where I left it; for indeed it could
not get out, but was almoft ftarv'd for want of Food _
f went and cut Boughs of Trees, and Branches of fuch.
Shrubs as I could find, and threw it over, and having,
ted it, I ty'd it as I did before, to lead it away; but it
was fo tame with, being htungry, that I bad no need to
have ty'd it; for it follow'd me like a Dog; and as I
continually fed it, the Crature became fo loving, fo,
Ient.e, and fo fond, that it became from that time one

of my Work, and I would immediately fit down and
figb, and look upon the Ground for an Hour or two to,gether; and this was fill worfe to to me; for if I could
Lturlt out into Tears, or vent my felt by Words, it
would go off, and the Grief having exhaufted it felf,
would abate.
But now   I began to exercife my felf with new'
Thoughts; I daily read the Word of God, and apply'd
all the Comforts of itto my prefent State. One Morn.
ing being very fad, I opened the Bible upon thefe Words,
I will never, never leave thee, nr fjrfake thee; immediately it occur'd, that there Words were to me, why
elie ihould they be direted in fuch axManner, juft at
the Moment when I was mourning over my Condition,
as one forfaken of God and Man? Well then, faid I,
it God does not forfake me, of what ill Confequence
can it be, or what matters it, tho' the World fhould
all forfake me; feeing on the other Hand, ifI had all
the World, and fhould lofe theFavour and Blefirng of
God, there would Ie no Comparifon in the Lofs.
From this Moment I began to conclude in my Mind,
that it was potible for me to be more happy in this forfaken, bilitary Condition, than it was probable I fhould
have eVer been in any other particularState in theWorld;
and with this Thought I was going to give Thanks
to God for bringing me to this Place.
I know not what it was, but fomething hockkd amy
Mind at that Thought, and I durft not fpeak the Words:
Blow canft thou be fuch an Hypocrite (faid I, even audihby) to. pretend to be thankful for a Condition, which
however thou may'ft endeavour to be contented with,
thou wouldft rather pray heartily to be delivered from;
o I ftopt there: But tho' I could not fay, I thank'd God
for being there; yet I fincerely gave Thanks to God
for opening my Eyes, by whatever affliting Providences,
to fee the former Condition of my Life, and to mourn
fot my Wckednefs, and- repent. I never open'd the
ible or ihut it, by my very Soul within me blefs'd God
1or dire&ing my Friend in England, without any Order of mine, to pack it up among my Goods; and for
aflifting me afterwards to fave it out of the Wreck of
te Ship.                                   h




( 109 )
Thus, and in this Difpofition of Mind, I began my
third Year; and tho' I have not given the Reader the
Trouble of fo particular an Account of my Works this
Year as the firlt; yet in general it may be obferv'd, that
I was very feldom idle; but having regularly divided
my Time according to the feveral daily Employments
that were before me; fuch as, Firfi, my Duty to God,
and the reading Scriptures, which I contfantly fet apart
ibmos time for, thrice every Day. Secondly, The going
Abroad with my Gun for Food, which generally took
me up three Hours in every Morning, when it did not
Rain. Thirdly, The ordering, curing, prefervilig and
cooking what I had kili'd or catch'd for my Supply;
thefe took up great Part of the Day: Alfo it is to be
confidered, that the Middle of the Day when the Sun
was in the Zenith, the Violence of the Heat was too
great to ftir out; fo that about four Hours in the Evening was all the time I could be fuppofed to work in;
with this Exceptiolln, that fometimes I changed myHours
of Hunting and Working, and went to Work in the
Morning, and Abroad with my Gun in the After.
noon,
To this fhort time allow'd for Labour, I defire may
be added the exceeding Laborioufnefs of my Work, the
mr.ny Hours which for want of Tools, want of Help,
and want of Skill, every thing I did, took up out of my
Time: -For Example, I was full two and forty Days
making me a Board for a long Shelf, which I wanted in
my Cave; whereas two Sawyers with their Tools, and
Saw-Pit, would have cut fix of them out of the fame
Tree in half a Day.
My Cafe was this; it was to be a large Tree which
was to be cut down, becaufe ny Board was to' be a
broad one. This Tree I was three Days a cutting
down, and two more cutting offthe Boughs, and reducing it to a Log, or Piece of Timber. With inexpreffible hacking and hewing I reduced both the Sides of it
into Chips, till it begun to be light enough to move;
then I turn'd it, and made one Side of it finooth, and
flat, as a Board from End. to End; then turning that
fide downward, cut the other fide, till I brought the
Plank to be about three Inches thick, and fiooth on both
Sides




:;.( II0 )
Sides. Any one may judge the Labour of my Hands in
fuch a Piece of Work; but Labour and Patience carry'd
nle thro' that, and many other things: I only obferve
this in particular, to hew the Reafon why to much of
my Time went away with fo little Work, vi. that
what might be a little to be done with Help and Tools,
was a valt Labour, and requir'd a prodigious time to do
alone, and by land.
But notwithlanding this, with Patience and Labour
I went thro' many things, and indeed every thing that
my Circumalnces made neceffary to me to do, as will
appear by what follows.
1 was now in the Months of November and December,
expefting my Crop of Barley and Rice. The Ground
I had manur'd or dug up for them was not great; for
as I obferv'd, my Seed of each was not above the Quantity of half a Peck; for I had loft one whole Crop by
fowing in the dry Seabon; but now my Crop promis'd
very well, when on a fudden I found I was in Danger
of lofingit all again by Enemies of feveral Sorts, which
it was fcarce poffible to keep from it; as firit, the Goats,
and wild Creatures which I call'd Hares, who tafling
the Sweetnefs of the Blade, lay in it Night and Day,
as ibon as it camup, and eat it fo clofe, that it could
get no time to fhoot up into Stalk.
This I faw no Remedy for, but by making an Enclo* fre about it with a Hedge, which I did with a great
4teal of Toil and the more, becaufe it requir'd a grea4
dea of Speed; the Creatures daily fpoilipg my Co rn
HRowever, as my Arable Land was but finall, fuited to
my Crop, I got it totally well fenced in about three
Weeks time; and ihooting fbme-of the Creatures in the
tay-time, I fet my Dog to guard it in the Night, ty*
f   ng him up;to a Stake at the Gate, where he would itand
and barkall Night long; fo in a little time thmee Enemies
frfook the: Place, ai te e'Corn grew very frong an4

( III )
Serts, who flood as it were watching till I ihofuld te
gone. I immediately let fly among them (for I always
bad m'y Gun with me.) I had no f6oner fhot, butthere
role up a little Cloud of Fowls, which I had not feen
at all, from among the Corn it fel.
This touch'd me fenlibly, for I forefaw, that in a
few Days they would devour all my Hopes, that I
fhould be farv'd, and never be able to raiie a Crop
at all, and whatto do I could not tell: However, Irefolv'd not to lole my Corn, ifpoifible, tho' I fiould
watch it Night and Day, In the firft Place, I went among it to lee what Damage was already done, and
found they had fpoil'd a good deal of it; but that as it
was yet too green for them, the lots was not o great,
but that the remainder was like to be a good Crop if
it could be fdv'd.
I flaid by it to load my Gun, and then coming away
I could eafily fee the Thieves fitting upon all the Tiees
about ne, as if they only waited till I was gone away,
and the Event proved it to be fo; for as I walk'd off as,
if I was gone,  was no ifoner out of their Sight, but
they dropt down one by one into the Corn again. I
was fo provok'd, that I could not havy Patience to flay
till more came on, knowing that            at they
eat now, was, as it mightbe
in the Confcquenze; but comin
fired again, and kili'd three ofthe
wifh'd for; fo I took them up, and ferv'  em as
fcrve notorious Thieves in England, ( vi ) Hanged
them in Chains for a Terror to others. It is impoffihle
to imagine almoft, that this fhould have fuch an Effeas it had; for the Fowls would not only not come at
the Corn, but in fhort they forfook all that Part of the
Ifland, and I could never fee a Bird near the Place asi
long as my Scare-Crows hung there.
This I was very glad of, you. may be fure and about
the latter End of Dlecember, which was our fecond Hap
veil ofthe Year, I reaped my Crop.
I was fadly put to it for a Scythe or. a Sickle to cute
it down, and all I could do was no make one as well
as I could out of or e of the broad Swords or Cutlafles,
which I fav'd among  e Ar.a ou.t of the Ship. However




(  '2  )


ever, as my firil Crop was but fmall, I had no great
Difficulty to cut itidown: In fhort, I reap'd it my
way, for I cut nothing off but the Ears, and carry'd it
away in a great Basket which I had made, and ft rubb'd
it out with my Hands: And at the End of all my Harveiling, I found that out of my half Peck of Seed, I had
near two Bufhels of Rice, and above two Bufhels and a
half of Barley, that is to fay, by my Guefa for I had no
Meafure at that time.
However, this was a great Encouragement to me;
and I forefaw that in time, it would pleafe God to ftpply me with Bread: And yet here I was perplex'd again, for I neither knew how to grind or make Meal of
my Corn, or indeed how to clean it and part it; nor
if made into Meal, how to make Bread of it; and if
how to make it, yet I knew not how to bake it. Thefe
things being added to my Defire of having a good
Quantity for Store, and to fecure a conftant supply, I
refolv'd not to tafte any of this Crop, but to preferve it
all for Seed againft the next Seafon, and in the mean time
to employ all my Study and Hours of working to ac.
comnplifh this great Work of providing my felf with Coin
and Brc~
'd  that now I work'd for my
'ldenerful, and what I believe few.:74Kclh upon, (vii.)the lirange Multhingi eceTrar; in the Providing,ProducCuring,  refing, Making and Finifhing this one
Article of Bread.
I that was reduced to a meer State of Nature, found
this to be my daily Difcouragement, and was made
more and more fenfible of it every Hour, even after
^   bI got the firil handful of Seed-Corn, which, as I
have faid, came up unexpe&edly, and indeed to a Surprize.
Firif, I had no Plow to turn up the Earth, no Spade
or Shovel to dig it. Well this I conquer'd, by making
a wooden Spade, as I obferved before; but this did my
Work but in a wooden Manner; and tho' it coil me a
great many Days to make it, yet.for want of Iron it not
only wore out the fooner, but made my Work the harder, and made it be perform'd much worfe,
How



( I3 )
However, this I bore with too, and wascontent to work

great heavy Bough of ai Tree over it, to fcratch the Earth
as it may be calid, rather than Rake or Harrow it.
'' hen it was growing and grown, I have obferv'd already how many things i wanted, to fence it, fecure it,
mow or reap it, cure and carry it Home, thrafh, part
it tiom the Chaff, and live it. Then I wanted a Mill
to grind it, Sieves to drefs it, Yeaft and Salt to make it
into Bread, and an Oven to bake it; and all thefe
things I did without, as fhArl be obferved  and yet
the Corn was an ineftimable Comfort and Advantage to
me too. But all this as I laid, made every thing laborious
and tedious to me, but that there was no Help fotr neitler was my time lb much Lots to me, becaufe I had
divided it, a certain Part of it was every Day appointed to the'e Works; and as I refolv'd to ufe none of the
Corn fbr Bread till I had a greater (Quantity by me, I
had the next fix Months to apply my felf wholly by Labour and Invention to furnilh my felf with Utenfils
proper for the performing all the Operations neceffary

But firt, I was to prepare mor

I did this, I had a Week's Work at leaft   I
Spade, which when it was done, was but a forry one
indeed, and very heavy, and requir'd double Labour to

my Houfe as I could find them to my Mind, and fenc'd
them in with a good Hedge, the -Stakes of which were
all cut of that Wood which I had fet before, which I
knew would grow, fi that in one Year's time I knew I
fliould have a Quick or Living Hedge, that would want
but little Repair. This work was not bo little as to
take me up lefs than three Months, becaufe great Part
of that time was of the wet Seaibn, when I could not
go abroad.


Within




( I4 )


Within Door, that is, when it rained, and I cour3
not go out, I found Employment on the following Occafions, always obferving, that all the while I was at
Work, I diverted my felt with talking:to my Parrot,
and teaching him to Speak; and I quickly learned him
to know his own Name, and at lai to fpeak it out
pretty loud, P O L L, which was the firft Word I ever
heard fpolen-in the Ifland by any Mouth but my own.
This therefore was not my Work, but an Affiftant to
my Work; for now, as I faid, I had a great Employment
upon my Hans, as follows, (vit.) I had long ftudy'd, by
fome Means or other, to make my felf obmn EarthenVetfls, which indeed I wanted forely, but knew not where
to come at them: However, confidering the Heat of the
Climate, I did not doubt but if I could find out any
fuch Clay, I might botchb up fome fuch Pot, as might,
being dry'd in the Sun, be hard enough, and firong
enough to bear handling, and to hold any Thing that
was dry, and required to be kept fo; and as this was
necellary in the preparing Corn, Meal, 'c. which was
the Thing I was upon, I refolved to make fome as large
as I could, and fit, only to fand like Jars to hold what
fhould be put into them,
It would      he Reader pity me, or rather laugh
at                 y aukward Ways I took to raife
milhapen ugly Things I made,
i in, and how many fell out, the
iifF enough to bear its own Weight;
ow many craek'd by the over violent Heat of the Sunbeing let out too haflily; and how nany fell in Pieces
with only removing, as well before as after they were
dry'd; and in a Word, how after having laboured hard
t find the Clay, to dig it, to temper it, to bring it
home and work it, I could not make above two large
Earthen ugly things, I cannot call them Jars, in about
two Months Labour.
However, as the Sun bake4 thefe two very dry and,
hard, I lifted them very gently up, and fet them down,
again in two great Wicker-Baskets, which I had made.
on purpofe forthem, that they;might pot break-; and.
as between the Pot and the Basket there wasna little
ro.o1




( I5 )
room to fpare, I ftuf'd it full of the Rice an Barlejy
Straw, and thefe two Pots being to itand always dry, I
thought would hold my dry Corn, and perhaps th,
Meal when the Corn was bruitid.
Thlo' I mifcarried fo much in my Defign for large
Pots, yet I made feveral fialler things with better Sue.
cefs; fuch as little round Pots, flat Difhes, Fitchers,
and Pipkins, and any thing my Hand turn'd to, and
the Heatof the Sun bak'd them firanpely hard.
But all this would not anfwer my End, which was
toget an Earthen Pot to hold what was Liquid, and
bear the Fire, which none of thefe could do. It happen'd after fome time, making a pretty large Fire for
cooking my Meat, when I went to put it out after I
had done with it, I found a broken Piece of one of my
Earthen-ware Veffels in the Fire, burnt as hard as a
Stone, and red asa Tile. I was agreeably furpriz'd to
fee it, and laid to my felf, that certainly they might
be made to burn whole, if they would burn broken.
This fet me to ftudying how to order my Fire, fo as
to make it burn me rome Pots. I had no Notion of a
"Kiln, fuch as the Potters burn in, or of glazing them
with Lead, tho' I had fome Lead to doit with; but I
plac'd three large Pipkins, and two or three Pots in a
Pile one upon another, and plac'i my Fire-wood all
round it with a great Heap of Etbersunder them;
I ply'd the Fire with frelh Fuel round the Outfide, and
upon the Top, till I faw the Pots in the Infide red hot
quite thro', and obferved that they did not crack at all;
when I faw them clear red, I let them ftand in that
Heat about 5 or 6 Hours, till I found one of them, tho'
it did not crack, did melt or run, for the Sand which
was mix'd with the Clay melted by the Violence of the
Heat, and would have run into Glafs if I had gone on;
fo I flack'd my Fire gradually, till the Pots-began to abate ofthe red Colour, and watching them all Night,
that I Might  ot let the Fire abate to faft, in the Mornilg I had three very good, I will not fay handiome Pipkins, and two 9ther Earthen Pots, as hard burnt as
could be defir'd; and one of them  perfcftly glaz'd:
with the Running of the Sand.
An4




( Ix6 )
After this Experiment, I need not fay that I wanted
no fort of Earthen Ware for my Ufe; but I muff needs
fay, as to the Shapes of them, they were very indifferent, as any one may fuppofe, when I had no Way of
nlaking them, but as the Children make Dirt-Pies, or as
a Woman would make Pies that never learnt to raife
Pafte.
No Joy at a Thing of to mean a Nature was ever
equal to mine, when I found I had made an Earthen
Pot that would bear the Fire; and I had hardly Patience to flay till they were cold, before I fet one upon
the Fire again, with obme Water in it, to boil me fome
Meat, which I did admirably well; and with a Piece
of a Kid I made fome very good Broth, tho' I wanted
Oatmeal, and feveral other Ingredients requifite to make
it ~o good as I would have had it been.
My next Concern was, to get me a Stone-Mortar
to flamp or beat Come Corn in; for as to the Mill, there
was no Thought at arriving to that Perfeftion ofArt,
with one Pair of Hands. To fupply this Want I was
at a great Lofs; for of all Trades in the World I was as
perfe&ly unqualified for a Stone.Cutter, as for any
whatever; neither had I any Tools to go about it with.
I fpent many a Day to find out a great Stone big enough
to cut hollow, and make fit for a Mortar, and could
find none at all, exwpt what was in the folid Rock, and
which I had no Way to dig or cut out; nor indeed
were the Rocks in the fl1and ofHardnefs fufficient, but
were all of a fandy crumbling Stone, which would neither bear the Weight of a heavy Peftle, or would break
the Corn without filling it with Sand: So after a great
deal of Time loll in fearching for a Stone, I gave it
over, and refolv'd too look out a great Block of hard
Wood, which I found indeed much eafier; and getting
one as big as I had Strength to fir, I rounded it, and
form'd it on the Outfide with my Axe and Hatchet, and
then with the Help of Fire and infinite Labour, made
a hollow Place in it, as the Indians in Brafil make their
Cantes. After this, I made a great heavy PeRle or
Beater, of the Wood call'd the Iron-Wood, and this I
prepared and laid by againft I had my next Crop of
Corn,




( I"7)
Corn, when I propos'd to my felf to grind, or rather
pound my Corn into Meal to make my Bread.
1My next Difficulty was to make a Sieve, or Searfe, to
drefs my Meal, and to part it from the Bran and the
Husk, without which I did not fee it poflible I could
have any Bread. This was a molt difficult Thing, io
much as but to think on; for to be fure I had nothing
like the neceffary Thing to make it with; I mean fine
thin Canvas, or Stuff to fearch the Meal through. And
here I was at a full Stop for many Months; nor did I
really know what to do; Linnen I had none left, but
what was meer Rags; I had Goats Hair, but neither
knew I how to weave it or fpin it; and had I known
how, here was no Tools to work it with; all the Remedy that I found for this, was, That at lafl I did remember I had among the Seamens Cloaths which were
fav'd out of the Ship, fomeNeckcloaths of Callicoe or
MIuflin; and with fome Pieces of there I made three
fmall Sieves, but proper enough for the Work; and thus
I made lhift for fome Years; how I did afterwards, I
fliall fhew in its Place.
The baking Part was the next thing to be confider'd,
and  ^ v I Ihould make Bread when I came to have
Corn; or firft I had no Yeafh: As to that Part, as
thereX is no fupplying the Want, fo I did not concern
nyf'elf much about it: But for an Oven, I was indeed
in great Pain. At length I found out an Experiment
for that alto, which was this; I made fome Earthen
Veffels very broad, but not deep; that is to fay, about
two Foot Diameter, and not above nine Inches deep;
thefe I burnt in the Fire, as I had done the other, and
laid them by; and when I wanted to bake, I made a
great Fire upon my Hearth, which I had pav'd with
ibmne fquare Tiles of my own making and burning alfo;
but I fhould not call them fquare.
When the Fire-wood was burnt pretty much into
Embers, or live Coals, I drew them forward upon this
Hearth, fb as to cover it all over, and there I let them
lye, till the Hearth was very hot; then fweeping away
all the Embers, I fet down my Loaf, or Loaves, and
whelming down the Earthen Pot updn them, drew the
Embers all round the Outfide of the Pot, to keep in,
and




( uS )
inda add to the Heat; and thus, as well as in the Left
Oven in the World, I bak'd my Barley-Loaves, and became in little time a meer Paftry-Cook into the- Bargain; fbr I made my felffeveral Cakes of the Rice, and
Puddings; indeed I made no Pies, neither had I any
thing to put into them, iuppofing I had, except the
Flefl either of Fowls or Goats.
It need not be wondered at, it all thefe things took
me up moft Part of the third Year of my Aboad here;
for it is to be obferv'd, that in the Intervals of thefe
Things, I had my new Harveft and Husbandry to manage; for I reap'd my Corn in its Seafon, and carried it
Home as well as I could, and laid it up in the Ear, in
my large Baskets, till I had Time to rub it out; for I
lead no Floor to thrafli it on, or Inffrttment to thralh it
with.
And now indeed my Stock of Corn encreafing, I
really wanted to build my Barns bigger: I wanted a
Place to lay it up in; fbr the Increafe of the Corn now
yielded me fo much, that I had of the Barley about
twenty Bufliels, and of the Rice as much, or more; infemuch, that now I refolved to begin to ufe it cely,
for my Bread had been quite gone a great whilq  r
refolved to fee what Quantity would be fuffil
me a whole Year, and to fow but once a Year.
Opon the whole, I found that the forty Bufl  of
Bafley and Rice was much more than I could con ume
in a Year; fo I refolved to fow juft the fame Quantity
every Year that I fow'd the laft, in hopes that fuch a
Quantity would fully provide me with Bread, )c.
All the while thefe things were doing, you may be,fure my Thoughts run many times upon the Profpe& of
Land which 1 had feen from the other Side of the
Ifland, and I was not without fecret Wifhes that I was
on Shore there, fancying that feeing the main Land, and
an inhabited Country, I might find fome Way or other
to convey my felf farther, and perhaps at laft find foni
Means of Efcape.
But all this while I made no Allowance for the Dangers of fuch a Condition, and how I might fall into the
Hands of Savages, and perhaps fuch as I might have
Reafon to think far worfe than the Lions and Tigers of
C.4i




( I9 )
Africa. Thbt if I once came into their Power, I ihoull
run a Iazard more than a thoufand to one of being
kiW'd, and perhaps of being eaten; for I had heard,
that the People of the Carribean Coafts were Cannibals,
or Men-eaters; and I knew by the Latitude, that I could
not be far off from that Shore. That fuppofe they were
not Cannibals, yet that they might kill me, as many
Europeans who had fallen into their Hand had been ferved, even when they had been ten or twenty together;
much more I that-was but one, and could make little
or no Defence. All there things, I fay, which I ought
to have confider'd well of, and I did caf: up in my
Thoughts afterwards, yet took up none of my Apprehenlions at firif; and my Head run mightily upon the
Thoughts of getting over to that Shore.
Now I wiih'd for my Boy Xury, and the Lonlg-Boat
with the Shoulder of Mutton Sail, with which  i failfd
above a Thouland Miles on the Coaft of a'Jrik; but
this was in vain. Then I thought I would go and look
on our Ship's Boat, which, as I have faid, was blown
up upon the Shore a great Way in the Storm, when we
were firtf caft away. She lay almofl where fhle did at.Af*   t not quite; and was turn'd by the forc of the
i'         'l di s a lmoft Bottom up.a: i, - g; nfl
WY-Water about
aS before.,
If I had had Hands to have ^f    her, and to have
launch'd her into the Water, the Boat would have d<J}
well enough, and I might have gone back into thePeils with her eafily enough; but I might a-veeafily
feen, that I could no more turn her, and ftt her up
right upon herBottomr, than I could remove the Ifland.
However, I went to the Wood and cut Levers and Rollers, and brought them to the Boat, refolv'd to try
what I could do; fuggeffing to my felf, that if I cculd
but turn her down, I might eafily repair the Damage
the had received, and fhe would be a very good Boat,
and I might go to Sea in her very eafily.
I fpared no Pains indeed in this Piece of fruitlefs
Toil, and fpent, I think, three or four Weeks about'
it; at laff finding it impoflible to heave it up with my
little Strength, I fell towdigging away the Sand to undermine




( 120)
dermlne it, an8 fo to make it fall down, fetting Pieces
of Wood to thruft and guide it right in the Fall.
But when I had done this, I was unable to ftir it up
again, or to get under it, much lefs to move it forwards
towards the Water; fo I was forc'd to give it over;
and yet, tho' I gave over the Hopes of the Boat, my
Defire to venture over for the Main increased, rather
than decreafed, as the Means for it feem'd impoflible.
This at length put me upon thinking, whether it was
not poffible to make my felf a Can:e or Periagua, fitih as
the Natives of thofe Climates make, even without Tools,
or, as I might fay, without Hands, vii. of the Trunk
of a great Tree. This I not only thought poflible, but
easy, and pleas'd my felfextreamly with the Thoughts
of making it, and with my having much more Convenience for it than any of the Ncgrses or Indians; hut not
at all confidering the particular Inconveniences which I
lay under, more than the Indians did, vi.. Want of
Hands to move it into the Water, when it was made;
a Difficulty much harder for me to furmount, than all
the Confequences of Want of Tools could be to them:
For what was it to me, that when I had chofen a vaft
Tree in the Woods, I might with great Troublrcut it
-down, ifafter I might be able with ny  toot to hew
and dub the Outfide int        Slhap  f aBoat and
burn or cut out the Inf       it hollow, Co to make
a Boat ofit, if after alt this, I muff leave it iuft there
where I found it, and was not able to launch it into the
Water.
' One would have thought, I could not have had the
taaft Refledion upon my Mird of my Circumftance,
while I was making this Boat, hut I fhould have immediately thought how I filould get it into the Sea;
but my Thoughts were fo intent upon my Voyage over
the Sea in it, that I never once confider'd how I
Ihould get it off of the Land; and it was really in its
own Nature more eafy for me to guide it over forty five
Miles of Sea, than about Forty five Fathom of Land,
where it lay, to fet it a float in the Water.
I went to work upon this Boat the moft like a Fool
that ever Man did, who had any of his Senfes awake.
I pleas'd my felf with the Deign, without determining




( 21 )
ing whether I was ever able to undertake it; not but
that the Difficulty of launching my Boat came often
into my Head; but I put a ltop to my own Enquiries
into it, by this foolifh Anfwer which I gave my felf;
Let mefirf mae it, I' warrant P findfome Way or other
to get it along, when 'tis done.
This was a moft prepofterous Method; but the Eagernefs of my Fancy prevail'd, and to work I went, and
fell'd a Cedar-Tree: I queftion much whether SJlomrn
ever had fuch a one for the Building the Temple at,ferufalem; It was Ave Foot ten Inches Diameter at
the lower Part next the Stump, and four Foot eleven
Inches Diameter at the End of twenty two Foot, after
which it lelfen'd for a while, and then parted into
Branches: It was not without infinite Labour that I
fell"d this Tree: I was twenty Days hacking and hewing at it at the Bottom; I was fourteen more getting
the Branches and Limbs, and the. vaT fpreading Head
of it cut off, which I hack'd and hew'd through with
Axe and Hatchet, and inexpreflible Labour: After this,
it coil me a Month to ihape it, and dub it to a Proportion, and to fomething like the Bottom of a Boat,
that it':ht fwim upright a it ought to do. It cot
me near three Months more to clear the Infide, and:  orkUt~ ol o, as to  e an exa& Boat of it: lhis I
did inieed without Fi  e   re Mallet and Chiffel,
and by the dint of hard LaUBr, till I had brought it
to be a very handfome Periaua and big enough to
have carried fix and twenty MeIn and confquently big
enough to have carried me and all my Cargo.
When I had gone through this Work, was extreme.
ly delighted with it: The Boat was really iuch Nigger than I ever faw a Canoe, or  rtaga, that was made
of one Tree, in my Life; Many a weary Stroke it bad
coft, you nay be fure, for there remained nothing but
to get it into the Water; and had I gotten it into the
Water, I make no queflion, but I fhould have began
the maddeft Voyage and the moll unlikely to be perform'd, that ever was undertaken.
But all my Devices to get it into the Water fail'd me,
though they cof me infinite Labour too; It lay about
one hundred Yards from the Water, and not more, but
G                   the




?                   ( 122 )
t fle firft Inconvenience was, it was up Hill towards th~
Creek: Well, to take away this Difcouragement, I re.
folv'd to dig into the Surface of the Earth, and fo make
a Declivity: This I begun, and it cqtl me a prodigious
deal of Pains; But who grudges Pains, that have their
Deliverance in View?   But when this was worked
through, and this Difficulty manag'd, it was frill much
at one; for I could no more flir the Canoe than I could
the other Boat.
Then I meaflur'd the Diffance of Grdund, and refolv'd
I to cut a Dock, or Canal, to bring the Water up to the
Canoe, feeing I could not bring the Canoe down to the
Water: Well, I began this Work, and when I began to
enter into it, and calculated how deep it was to be dug,
y;      how broad, how the Stuff to be thrown out, I found,
that by the Number of Hands I had, laeing none but my
awn, it mutL have been ten or twelve Years before (
%hould have gone through with it; for the Shore lay
j tigh, fo that at the upper End it muil have been at leafE
twenty Foot deep  fo at length, tho' with great Reifteancy, I gave this Attempt over allo.
This griev'd me heartily, and now I faw, the' too
late, the Folly of beginning a Work before weceount the
Coil, and before we judge rigtly of our own Strength
to go through with it.               " ':   -,
In the middle of this,   I fiiifh'd my fourth
Year in this Place, and: kpt my Anniverfary with the
fame Devotion, and with as much Comfort as ever before; for by a conftant Study, and ferious Application.af the Word of God, and by the Affiftance of his
U3race, I gai'd a different Knowledge from what I had
before: I entertainid different Notions of things; I
look'd now utpon the World as a thing remote, which I
had nothing to do with, no Expeaation from, and ind4eed no Defires about: In a Word, I had nothing in.
deed to do with It, nor was ever like to have; fo I
thought it look'd as we may perhaps look upon it hereafter, vit. as a Place I had lived in, but was come out
of it; and well.mightl fay, as Father Abraham to Divest
'Betwveen me and fbee is agreat Gulph fixed.
In the firft Place, I was removed from all the WicRednefs of the World here; I had neither the ~Zu? ofthb
Flei




eJ^,       ufe  o f the Ee, or the Pride of Lifer  I had
nothing to covet; for I had all that I was now capable.of enjoying: I was Lord of the whole Manor, or if I
pleas'd I might call my felf King, or Emperor over the
whole Country which I had Poflcfiion of: There were
no Rivals: I had no Competitor, none to difpate Sovereignty or Command with me: I might have rais'd
Ship-Loadings of Corn, but I had no Dife for it; fo I
let as little grow as I thought enough for my Occafion
I had Tortoife or Turtles enough; but now and then
one was as much as I could put to any Ufe   I had
Timber enough to have built a Fleet of Ships: I had
Grapes enough to have made Wine, or to have cur'd
into Raifins, to have loaded that Fleet when they had,been built.
But alll could make Ufe of, was All that was vluable: I had enough to eat, and to fupply my Wants,
and what was all the reft to me? If kill'd more Flk
than I could eat, the Dog muft eat it, or the Vermin;
if I fbw'd more Corn than I could eat, it muf befpoil'd:
The Trees that I cut down were lying to rot on the
'Ground, I could make no more Ufi of them than for
Fewel, an that I had no Occafion for, but to drefs my
Food.
Ina Word, the Nature and Experience of Things
tditated to me upon juif Refledion, that all the good
Things of this World, are no farther good to us, thaa
they are for our Ufe; and that whatever we may heap
-up indeed to give others, we enjoy as much as we can
ufe, and no more. The moft covetous griping 'litel
in the World would have been cured of the Vice of Covetoufnefs, if he had been in my Cafe; for I poffefled
infinitely more than I knew what to do with. I had no
room for Defiire, except it was of things which I had
rnot, and they were but Trifles, tho' indeed of great U ie
to me. I had, as I hinted before, a Parcel of' Money,
as well Gold as Silver, above thirty fix Pounds Sterling:
Alas! theret the nafty forry atfeles Stuff lay; I had no
nanrer of Bufines.ffor' i; and I often thought with my
fel, that I would have given a Handful of it for aGrofi,of'TobaccoPipes, or for a Hand-Mill to grind my Corn;
aay, I would have given it all for Sixpenny-wori  of
2                  Zuri




(    )24
Turnip and Carrot Seed out of England, or for a Handful
of Peafe andBeans, and a Bottle of Ink: As it was, I
had not the leaft Advantage by it, or Benefit from it
but there it lay in a Drawer, and grew mouldy with
the Damp of the Cave, in the wet Seafon; and if I had
had the Drawer full of Diamonds, it had been the fame
Cafe; and they had been of no manner of Value to me,
becaufe of no Ufe.
I had now brought my State of Life to be much eafier
in it 1elf than: it was at firft, and much eafier to my
Mind, as well as to my Body: I frequently fat down
to my Meat with Thankfulnefs, and admired the Hand
of God's Providence,' which had thus fpread my Table
in the Wildernefs: I learned to looks more upon the
bright Side of my Condition, and lefs upon the dark
Side; and to confider what I enjoy'd, rather than what
I wanted; and this gave me fonletimes fuch fecret Com.
forts, that I cannot exprefs them; and which I take
Notice of here, to put thole difcontented People in
Mind of it, who cannot enjoy comfortably what God
has given them, becaul.they fee and covet fomething
that he has not given theim: All our Difcontents about
what we want, appeared to nmeto fpring from theWant
of Thankfulnefs for what we have.
Another Refletion was of great Ufeto me, an ttubtlefs would be fo to any one that fhould fall into fuch
Diftrefs as mine was; and this was to compare my prefent Condition with what I at firft expe<fed it fIhould
be; nay, with what it would certainly have been, if
the good Providence of God had not wonderfully order'd the Ship to be calt up nearer to the Shore, where
I not only could come ather, but could bring what I
got out of her to the Shore, for my Relief and Comfort;
without which, I had wanted Tools to work, Weapons for Defence, or Gun-powder and Shot for getting
my Food.
I fpent whole Hours, I may fay whole Days, in reprefenting to my felfin the moft lively Colours, how I
anuft have a&ed, if I had got nothing out of the Ship;
how I could not have fo much as got any Food, except
Fifi and Turtles; and that asit was long beforeI found
any ofthem, I mur have peri&'d firtR: That I thould
have




( 125 )
have liv'd, if I had not periih'd, like a meer Savage:
That ifI had kill'd a Goat, or a Fowl, by any Con.
trivance, I had no way to flea or open them, or part
the Fleth from the Skin and the Bowels, or to cut it
up; but mult gnaw it with my Teeth, and pull it with
my Claws like a Beat.'
Thefe Refleaions made me very fenfible of the Goodnefs of Providence to me, and very thankful for my
prefent Condition, with all its Hardfhips and Misfortunes: And this Part alfo I cannot but recommend to
the ReflefAion of thofe who are apt in their Miferv to
fay, Is any ffliaion like mine? Let them confider, how
much worfe the Cafes of fome People are, and what their
Cafe might have been, if Providence had thought fit.
I had another Refle&ion which aflifted me aloi to
comfort my Mind with Hopes; and this was comparing my prelent Condition with what I had deferv'd, and
had therefore Reafon to expec from the Hand of Providence: I had liv'd a dreadful Life, perfealy deititute
of the Knowledge and Fear of God;   I had been well
intlrua ed by Father and Mother; neither had they been
Wanting to me in their early Endeavours, to infufe a
religious Awe of God into my Mind, a Senfe of my
Duty, and of what theNature and End of my Being
reqtur'd of me; but:las! falling early into the Sea-.fring Life, which of all the Lives is the molt deftitate
of the Fear of God, tho' his Terrors are always before
them; I fay, falling early into the Sea-faring Life, and
into Seafaring Company, all that little Senfe of Reli*
gion which I had entertaind, was ]aught out of meby
my Mefs-Mates, by a harden'd defpifing of Dangers,
and the Views of Death, which grew habitual to me)
by my long Abfence from all manner of Opportunities
to converre with any thing but what was like my felf,
or to hear any thing that was good, or tended towards it.
So void was I of every thing that was good, or ofthe
lea    nfe of what I was, or was to be, that in the
greateft Deliverances I enjoy'd, fh asmy Efcape from
Sallee, my being taken up by the. Prtuguee Mailer of
ths Ship, my being planted fo well in Brafils, my re,

ana after I made a jult Improvement of thefe Things,
I went away and was no more fad.
I had now been here fo long, that many Things which
I brougllt on Shore for my Help, were either quite
gone, or very much wafted and near fpent.
My Ink, as I obferv'd, had been gone for fome Time,
all but a very little, which I eek'd out with Water a littile and a little, till it was fo pale it fcarce left any Ap.
pearance of Black upon the Paper: As long as it lafted
I made afe of it to Minute down the Days of the
Month on which any remarkable Thing. happen'd to
me; and firft by calfing, up Times paft, I remember
that there was a flrange Concurrence of Days, in the various Providences which befel me, and which, if l had
been fuperftitioufly inclin'd to obferve Days as Fatal or
Fortunate, I might have had Reafon to have look'd upon with a great deal of Curiofity.
F irt, I had obfirv'd, that the fame Day that I broke
away from  my Father and my Friends, and run away to Hull in order to go to Sea, the fame Day afterwards I was taken by the Salei Man of War, and made
a Slave.
The fame Day of the Year that I efcap'd out of the
Wreck of that Ship in Tarmotb Roads, that fame Day
of the Year afterwards I made my Efcape from Salleiin
the Boat.
The fame Day of the Year I was born on, (vit.) the,
soth of September, the fame Day I had my Life bo miraculoufly faved 26 Years after, when I was calfton
Shore in this Ifland; fo that my wicked Life and folitary Life began both on a Day.
The next'Thing to my-Ink's being wafted, was that
of my Bread, I mean the Bisket which I brought out of
the Ship. This I had husbanded to the laft Degree,allowing my felf but one Cake of Bread a Day, for above a
Year; and yat I was quite without Bread for a Year before I got any Corn of my own; and great Reafon I had
o be thankful that I had any at all, the getting it being, as has been already obferved, next to miraculous,
My Clothes began to decay too mightily: As to Linnen, I had none a good while, exrcept fome ehecquer'
~hirts which I fotmi i n the Cheftis  t Ot  9the rt StG 4                 men.,




( I28 )
men, and which I carefully preferv'd, beeaure many
Times I could bear no other Clothes on but a Shirt;
and it was a very great Help to me that I had among
all the Mens Clothes of the Ship almoit three Dozen of
Shirts. There were alfo feveral thick Watch Coats of
the Seamens, which were left indeed, but they were too
hot to wear; and tho' it is true, that the Weather
'was to violent hot, that there was no need of Clothes,
yet I could not go quite naked; no, tho' I had been
inclined to it, which I was not, nor could I abide the
Thoughts of it, tho' I was all alone.
One Reafon why I could not go quite naked, was)
I could not bear the Heat of the Sun fo well when
quite naked, as with fbme Clothes on; nay, the very
Heat frequently blifter'd my Skin  whereas with a
Shirt on, the Air it felf made fome Motion, and whifling under that Shirt, was twofold cooler than without
i.: No miore could I ever bring myfelfto go out in the
-Heat of the Sun without a Cap or Hat; the Heat of
the Sun beating with fuch Violence as it does in that
tlace, would give me the Head-Ach prefently,' by darting fo dire&ly on my Head, without a Cap or Hat on;
fo that I could not bear it; whereas if I put on my Hats
it would perfently go away.
Upon thofe Views I began to confider about putting
the few Rags I had, which I call'd Clothes, into fome
Order: I had worn out all the Wafte-coats I had, and
my Bufinefs was now to try if I could not make Jackets
out of the great Watch-Coats which I had by me, and
with fuch other Materials as I had; fo I fet to work a
Tayloring, or rather indeed a Botching; for I made
nmof piteous Work of it. However, I made Ihift to make
twoor three new Waftecoats, which I hoped would ferve
me a great while; as for Breeches or Drawers, I made
but very forry fhiftindeed, till afterward.
I have mentioned, that I faved the Skins of all the
Creatures that I kill'd, I mean four-footed ones and I
had hung them up ftretch'd out with Sticks in the Sun,
by which means fome of them were fo dry and hard
that they were fit for little, but others it feems were
very ufeful  The firft thing I made of there was a
great Cap for my Head, with the Hair on the OUtfide..                *  a*    -                 to




( 29 )
to heot off the Rain; and this I perform'd fo well, that
after this I made a Suit of Clothes wholly of thofe
Skins; that is to fay, a Waftecoat, and Breeches open at
Knees, and both loofe, for they were rather wanting
to keep me coot, than to keep me warm-n  I muft not
omit to acknowledge that they were wretchedly made;
for if I was a bad Carpenter, I was a worfe Taylor
However, they were fuch as I made very good flift
with; and when I was abroad, if it happen'd to Rain;
the Hair ofof the Waftecoat and Capbaing ouermoft,
I was kept very dry.
After this I fpent a great deal of Time and Pains to
make me an Umbrella. I was indeed in great Want of
one, and had a great Mind to make one; I had feem
them made in the Brafils, where they are very ufeful
in the great Heats which are there: And I felt the
Heats every Jot as great here, and greater too, being
nearer the Equinox; befides, as I was obliged to be
muoh abroad, it was a motl ufeiul thing to me, as wet
tor the Rains as the Heats* I took a world of Pains
at it, and was;a great while before I could make any
thing likely to hold; nay, after I thought I had hit
the Way, l fpoilt 2 or 3 before I made one to my Mind
but at lall I made one that anfwer'd indiffrently well >
the main Difficulty I found was to make it tq let down.
I could make it to fpread,. but if it did not lerdown too,
aAtdb'aw in; it would not be portable foe me any Way7
but juil over mjHead, which wouldnot do:: However,
atlat;l as I faid, I made one to anfier, I cover'd it
with Skins, the Hair upwards, fo that it caft off th
Rain like a Pent-houfe, and kept off the Sun fo effectually, that I could walk out in the hotteit of the Weather, with, greater Advantage than I could before in the
eooleit,and when I had no Need of it; I could clofe it
and, caty it under my Arm.
Thus I lived mighty comfortably, my Mind being

throwing my felfwholly upon the Difpl   ofl isoProvidence: This made my Life better-ten fociable; for:
when I began to regret the want ot Conrerfation, I
would ask my felf, whether thes conwerfing& musually
