For this Purpofe, and that I might do every thing, witli
Difcretion and Confideration, 1 fitted up a little Maft
to my Boat, and made t Sail to it out of fome of
the Pieces of the Ship's Sails, which lay in Store, arid of
which I had a great Stock by me.
Having fitted my Maft and Sail, and tried the Boat,
I found the would fail very well: Then I made little
Lockers or Boxes, at either End of my Boat, to put
Provifions, Necefaries, and Ammunition, tSc. into, to
be kept dry, either from Rain, or the Sprye of the Sea;
and alittle long hollow Place I cut in the Infide of the
Boat where I could lay my Gun, making. a Flap to
hang down over it to keep it dry.
I fix'd my Umbrella altb in a Step at the Stern, like
a Maft, to fland over my Head, and keep the Heat of
the Sun off of me like an Auning; and thus I every
now and then took a little Voyage upon the Sea, but
never went far out, nor far from the little Creek- but
at laft being eager to view the Circumference of my
little Kingdom, I refolv'd upon my Tour, and accordingly I viuail'd my Ship for the Voyage; putting in
twvo Dozen of my Loaves, ( Cakes If hould rather callthem) of Barley-Bread; an Earthern Pot full of parchl'c
Rice, a Food Ieat a great deal of; a little Bottle of
Rum, halfa Goat,and Powder with Shot for killing,
more, and two large Watch-coats, of thofe Which, as 1
mention'd before, 1 had fav'd out of the Seamens Cheftsthere I took, one to lie upon, and the other to cover
me in the Nighbt
It was the iixth of November, in the fixth Year ofmy
Reign, or my Captivity, which you pleafe, that I fct
out on this-Voyage, and I found it much longer than I
expe&ed.fortho' the fland itfelfas not very large,
yet when I came to the Eaft Side of it, I found a great
Ledge of Rocks lie out about two Leagues into the Sea,
%ome-above Water, tome under it; and beyond that, a
Shoal ofSand, lying dry half a Leage more  fo that I
wvasoblig'd to go a greatWay Out to Sea to double that
Point.  '
When firttaI difcover'd them I was goingto give over
my Enterprize, and come back again, not knowing..w-fiat-it. ight obHi me to go out to Seai andabove
a.ll




all, doubting how I flquld get baek again; fo I came
to an Anchor, for I hAd made meia kld of an Anchor
with a Piece of a broklp Graplin,' which I got out of
the Ship.
Having fecur'd my Boat, I took my Gun, anid went
on Shore, climbing up upon a Hill, which feem'd to
overlook that Point, where I faw the full Extent of it,
and refolv'd to venture.  c.:
Innmy viewing the Sea fromit liat HiU where I lood,
I perceiv'd a ftrong, and indeed, a moft furious Current, which run to the Eaft, and even came clofe to the
Point; and I took the more Notice of it, becaufe I faw
there might be fome Danger, that when I came into it,
I might be carried out to Sea by the Strength of it,
and not be able to make theitfland again: And indeed,
had I not gotten firft up upon this Hill, I believe it
would hlave been fo; for there was the fame Current on
the other Side the Ifantd, only that it fet off at a farther Diftance; and I faw there was a firong Eddy un'der the Shore; fo I had nothing to do but to get in
out of the firft Current, and 1 1hould prefently be in
an Eddy.
I lay here, however, tro Days; becaufe the Wind
blowing pretty freli at E.S.E. (and that being juft conr
trary to the faid Current) made a great Breach of the
Sea tpeo the Pointi fo that it was not fafe for me to
k!een too clofe to the Shore for the Breach, nor to go
too tar off becaufe of the Stream.
The thlrd Day in the Morning the Wind having
abated over Night, the Sea was clm, and I venture&;
but I am a Warning-Piece again to all rafh and ignorant Pilots; for no lboner was I come to the Point, when
'ven I was not my Boat's Length from the Shore, but. I
'found my felf in a great Depth of Water, and a Current
like the Sluice of a Mill: It carried my Boat along with
it with fuch Violence, that all I could do, could not
keep her fo much as on the Edge of it; but I found
it hurried me farther and farther out from the Eddy,
which was on my Left Hand. There was no Wind
ftirring to help me, and all I could do with my Paddles fignified nothing; and now I began to give my
fel over for loaf for as the Current was on both Sides
the




( 133   )
tre Tfland, I knew in a few Leagues Diffance they
muft join again, and then I was irrecoverably gone;
nor did I fee any Poflibility of avoiding it, fo that E
had no Profpe& before me but ofperifhing; not by the
Sea, for that was calm enough, but of ftarving for Hunger. I had indeed found a Tortoife on the Shore, as
big almoft as I could lift, and had tofs'd it into the
Boat; and I had a great Jar of fiefli Water, that is
to fay, one of my Earthen Pots; but what was all this
to being driven into the vaft Ocean, where, to be fure,
there was no Shore, no main Land, or Illand, for a
thoufand Leagues at leat?
Andnow I faw how eafy it was for the Providence of
God to make the moft mferableCondition that Mankind
could be in, worfe. Now I look'd back upon my defolate folitary fland, as the mot pleafant Place in the
Woa-ld, and all the Happinefs my Heart could wifll for,
was to e but there again: I ftretch'd out my Hands
to it with eager Wiihes; O happy Defart, laid I, I
flall never fee thee more  0 miferable Creature, faid
I, whether am I going! Then I reproach'd my felf
with my unthankful Temper, and how I had repin'd at
my folitary Condition; and now what would I give to
be on Shore there again? Thus we never fee the true
State of our Condition, till it is illuftrated to us by its
Contraries; nor know how to value what we enjoy, but
by the Want of it: It is fcarce poffible to imagine the
Confernation I was now in, being driven from my belovedfland ( for fo it appeared to me now to be ) into
the wide Ocean, almoft two Leagues, and in the utnmof Defpair of ever recovering it again: However I
work'd hard~ till indeed my Strength was almoft ex.
haufed, and kept my Boatas much to the No thwardt
that is, towards the Side of the Current which the Eddy lay on, as pofllbly I could; when about Noon, as
the Sun pafs'd the Meridian, I thought I felt a little
Breeze of Wind in my Face, fpringing up from the
S. SE.B. This chear'd my Heart a little, and efpecially
when in about half an Hour more it blew a pretty
fmall gentle Gale: By this Time I was gotten at a
frightful Diftance from the Ifland, and had the leaft
Cloud or hazy Weather interveln'd I had been und-nie,
another

another Way too; for I had no Compafson Board; and
Ihould never have known how to have fteer'd towards

Weather Continuing clear, I applied my felf to get up
my Maft again, fpread my Sail, faiding away to the
North as much as poffible, to get out of the Current.
Juft as I had fet my Maft and Sail, and tile Boat begn to ftretch away,* I faw even by the Clearnefs of the
Water, fome Alteration of the Current was near; for
where the Current was fo trong, the Water was foul;
but perceiving the Water clear, I found the Current
ahate, and prefently I found to the Eaf/, at about half
a Mile, a Breach of the Sea upon:ome Rocks; thefe
Rocks I found caus'd the Current to part again; and as
the main Strefs ofit ran away more Southerly, leaving
the Rocks to the Nortb-Eaft, fo the other return'd by the
Reppuife of the Rocks, and made a firong Eddy, which
ran back again to the Nortb-Wefl with a very harp

tame to-me, ani fat upon my Thumb, as he u-fed to

as if he had been overjoy'd to fee me again; and 1b I

I had now had enough of rambling to! Sea for tome
time, and had enough to do for many Days to fit ftill,;
and refle& upon the Danger I had been in: I woul&
have been very glad to have had my Boat again on
my Side of the ifland; but I knew not how it was
practicable to get it about: As to the Eaft Side of the
Ifland, which I had gone round, I knew well enough
there was no venturing that Way; my very Heart
would fhrink, and my very Blood run chill but to
think of it: And as to the other Side of the Ialand, I
did not know how it might be there; but fuppofing
the Curr'ant ran with the fame Force againit the Shore
at the Eaft, as it pafs'd by it on the other, I might
run the fame Risk of being driven down the Stream,
and carryld by the Ifland, as I had been before, of being carry'd away from it; fo with there Thoughts I
contended my felf to be without any Boat, tho' it had
been the Produga  of fo many Months tIbour to make
it, and of fo many more to get it unto the Sea.
In this Government of my TemperI remain'd near a
Year, liv'd a very fedate retired Life, as you may well
fuppofe; and my Thoughts being very much compos'd
as to my Condition, and fully comforted in refigning my
felfto the Difpofitions of Providence, I thought 1 lif'&
really very happily in all things, except that of Society.
I improv'd my felf in this Time in all the meehanick
Exercifes which my Neceflities put me upon applying
my felf to, and I believe could, upon Oceafion, have
made a very good Carpenter, efpecially confidering how
few Tools I had.
Befides this, I arriv'd at an unexpeced Perfeaion in
my Earthen Ware, and contrived well enough to make
them with a Wheel, which I found infinitely eafier ant4
better; becaufe I iade Things round and filapeable.
which before were filthy Things indeed to look on;
But I think I was never more vain of my own Performancej




(   38)
mncce or more joyful for any Thing I found out, than
for my being able to make a Tobacco-Pipe; and tho'
it was a very ugly clumfy Thing, when it was done,
and only burnt red like other Earthen Ware, yet as it
was hard and firm, and would draw the Sntoak, I was
exceedingly comforted with it; for I had been always
ufed toSmoak, and there were Pipes in the Ship, but
I forgot them  at firfl, not knowing that there was
Tobacco in the Ifland; and afterward when I fearch'd
the Ship again, I could not come at any Pipes atall.
In my   icker-ware alfo I improved much, and made
Abundance of neceffary Baskets, as well as my Invention
ihew'd me, thoughot very handfom, yet convenient for
miy laying. Things up in, or fetching Things home in,
For Example, if I kill'd a Goat abroad, I could hang
it up in a Tree, flea it, and drefs it, and cut it in Pieces, and bring it home in a Basket; and the like by a
Turtle I could cut it up, take out the Eggs, and a
Piece or two of the Flefh, which was enough for me,
and bring them home in a Basket, and leave the reft
behind me: Alfo large deep Baskets were my Receio
~ers for my Corn, which I always rubb'd out as foon
Ss it was dry,,and cured, and kept it in great Bas.
kets inflead ofa Gramry.
I began now to perceive my Powder abated confiAerably, and this w as a Want which it was impofible
fer me to fipply, and I began ferioufly to confider what
i mui do when I fhould have no more Powder; that
is to fly how I Ithold do to kill any Goats. I had,
as is obfer'd in the third Year of my being here, kept
a young Kid, and bred her up tame, I was in hopes of
getting a He-Goat, but I could not by any means bring
it to pafis till my Kid grew an old Goat; and I could
never find in my Heart to kill her, till the dy'd at lat
of meer Age.
But being now in the eleventh Year of my Refidence,
and, as I have faid, my Ammunition growin low, I
ft my felf to fludy iome Art to trapand Ea re the
oats, to fee whether I could not catch' rome of them
alive, and p   larly I  anted a She.Goat great withXYUg

Itw      oa od  Ifhile betbre they would feed, buit

peaed to ftupply my felf with Goat Fle/h, when I had
no Powder or Shot left, breeding fome up tame was nim
only Way, when perhaps I might have them about my
ioufe like a Flockof Sheep,,
But then it prefently occur'd to me, that I mult keep
thle Tame from;itie Wild, or elfe- they would always
run wild when they grew, up; and the 'only Way for
this was to have fnbme encloied Piece of Ground, well
fenc'd 'either with Hedge or Pale, to keep them up
fo effe&ually, that thofe within might not break out,
or thofe without break in.
This was a great Undertaking for; one Pair of Hands;
yet as I faw there was an, abfolute Neceffity of doing it,
my firft Piece of Work was to find out a proper Piece of
Groupd, viT, wh   ere t Ire was likely to be Herbage for
tllem to eat, Water for them  to drink, and Cover to
)keep them from the Sun.
Thofe who underftand fuch Enclofures will think I
had very little Contrivance, when I pitched upon a
Place very proper for.11 thefe, being a plain open Piece
of Meadow-Land or Savannam  (as our People call it i4
the WetlerniColonies,) which' had two or three little
-rfils of frefh Water in it, and at one end ws very
woody.  I feay they will- fiu!e at my Forecaft,. when $
ihall tell theml I began my enclofing of this Piece o
Ground in fuch a Manner, that my Hedge or Pale muft
have been at leaft two Mile about; Nor was the Madnefs of it fo great as to t hei pompafs, for if' it was ten
lVile about I was like to have timeenough to do it in
But I did not confiderthat my Goats wouldbe as wil
in fo much Conjpafs, as if they had had the whole I'
fland, and I Ihould have Co much Room to chafe them
in, that I Ihould never catch them.
My Hedge was begun and carry'd on, I believe about
fifty Yards, when this Thought occur'd to me; fo I
prefently flopt (hort, and for the firft Beginning I refolv'd to inclofe a piece of about i50 oYards in Lengtbh
and 1oo Yards& in Breadth, which as it would maintain
as many as I 1hould have in any reafonable Time, Co as 1
my Flock e    afe    c I could add more Ground to my. E In lofure.                  "  *  ', (  '.  1 |  -,,1,




(14)
This was a&ing with fome Prudence, and I went to
work with Courage; I was about three Months hedging in the firft Piece, and till I had done it I tether'd
the three Kids in the belt Part of it, and ufed them to
feed as near me as poffible to make them familiar; and
very often I would go and carry them fome Ears ofBarley, or a Handful of Rice, and feed them out' of my
Hand; fo that after my Inclofure was finifh'd, and I
let them loofe, they would follow me up and down,
bleating after me for a Handful of Corn.
This anfwer'd my End, and in about a Year and half
I had a Flock of about twelve Goats, Kids, and all;
and in two Years more I had three and forty, befides
feveral that I took and kill'd for my Food; And after
that I inclofed five feveral Pieces of Ground to feed
them in, with little Penns to drive them into, to take
them as I wanted them, and Gates out of one Piece of
Ground into another.
But this was not all; for now I not only had GoatsPlelh to feed on when I pleas'd, but Milk too, a thing
which indeed in my Beginning I did not to much as
think of, and which, when it came into my Thoughts,
was really an agreeable Surprize; For now I fet up my
Dairy, and had fometimes a Gallon or two of Milk in
a Day. And as Nature, who gives Supplies of Food to
every Creature, dicates even naturally how to make
ufe of it fo I that had never milk'd a Cow, much lels
a Goat, or feen Butter or Cheefe made, very readily
and handily, tho' after a great many Effays and Mifcarriages, made me both Butter and Cheefe at laft, and
never wanted it afterwards.
How mercifully can our great Creator treat his Creatures, even in thofe Conditions in which they feem'd to
be over-whelm'd in Deftrufion! How can he fweeten
the bittereft Providences, and give us Caufe to praife
him for Dungeons and Prifons! What a Table was here
pread for me in a Wildernefs, where I faw nothing at
firft but to perifh for Hunger!
It would have made a Stoick Smile to have feen me
and my lttk Family fit down to Dinner; there was
mYy Mjefty, the Prince and Lord of the whole Ifland:
l ad the Lives of    ll my Subj6ts at my abfolute
Com



142 ):Comand. I eo0d hang, draw, give Life L and Liberty
and take it away, and no Rebels among all my Subjec*s.
Then to i9e how like a King I din'd too, all alone,
attended b  y my Servants; Poll as if he had been my
Favourite, was the only Perfon permitted to talk to
me; my Dog, who was now       grown very old and
xrazy, and found no Species to multiply his Kind up-on, fat always at my Right Hand; and two Cats, one
Qn one Side the Table, and one on the other, expeaing now and then a Bit from my Hand, as a Mark of
fpecial Favour.
But there were not the two Cats which I brought on
Shore at firff, for they were both of them dead, and.bad been interr'd near my Habitation by my own
lHands; but one of them having nmultiply'd ~by I know
not what Kind of Creature, thefe were two which I
had preferv'd tame, whereas the reft run wild in the
Woods, and became indeed troublefome to me at laft
for they would often come into my Houfe, and plunder
me too, till at laft I was obliged to fhoot them, and did
kill a great many; at length they left me with this At
-tendance ' and in this plentiful Manner I liv'd; neither
-could I be faid to want any Thing but Society, and of
that in.fome time after this I was like to have too much.
I was fomething impatient, as I have obferv'd, to
-have the Ufe of my Boat, tho' very loath to run any
4more Hazards; and therefore fometimes I fat contriving Ways to get her about the lilandand at. other times
I fat my felf down contented enough without her. But'
had a itrange Uneafineis in my Mind to go down to
-the Point of' the Ifland, where, as I have laid, inl my
laf Ramble, I went up the Hill to fee how the Shore
lay, and how the Current fet, that I might fee what I
had to do: This Inclination increafed tpon me every
'Day, and at length I refolved to travel thither by
Land; and following the Edge of-the ShoreI did fo::But
had any 'one in England been to meet fiuih a Man as I
was, it muft either have frighted them, or wifed-a great
deal of Laugthter; and as I frequently;Iood..ill to
look at my felf,  could not but fmile at'theotioIn of

' *,. ' ^ *-  '..  ^ 4  '   *,  '.,,!, iil




( '43 )
in fich a Drefs. Be pleated to take a Sketch ofm3
Figure as follows.                     '
I had a great high fhapelefs Cap, made of a Goat's
Skin, with a Flap hanging down behind, as well to
keep the Sun from me, as to fhoot the Rain off from
running into my Neck; nothing being fo hurtful in
thefe Climates, as the Rain upon the FleIh under the
Clothes.
I had a fhort Jacket of Goat-Skin, the Skirts coning
down to about the Middle of my Thighs; and a Pair
of open-kneed Breeches of the fame; the Breeches were
mnade of the Skin of an old He-goat, whofe Hair hung
down fuch a Length on either Side, that like Pantaloons
it reach'd to the Middle of my Legs. Stockings and
Shoes I had none, but I had made me a Pair of fomething, I fcarce know what to call them, like Buskins,
to flap over my Legs, and lace on either Side like Spatterdafhers; but of a moft barbarous Shape, as indeed
were all the reft of my Cloaths.
I had on, a broad Belt of Goat's Skin dry'd, which
I drew together with two Thongp of the fame, inftead
of Buckles, and in a kind of a Frog on either Side of
this, inftead of a SwOrd and a Dagger, hung a little Saw
and a Hatchet, one On one Side, one on the other: I
had another Belt not fo broad, and faften'd in.the fame
manner, which hung over my Shoulder; and at the
End of it, under my left Arm hung two Pouches, both
made of Goat's Skin too; in one of which hung my
Powder, in the other my Shot: At my Back I carried
my Basket, on my Shoulder my Gun, and over my
-ead a great clumly ugly Goat-Skin Umbrello, but
vwhich, alter all, was the moft neceffary thing I had
about me, next to my Gun: As for my Face, the Colour of it was really not lo Moletta like, as one might expe&t from a Man not at all careful of it, and living within 9 or Io Degrees of the Equinox. My Beard I had
once fiffer'd to grow till it was about a Quarter Mia
Yard long but as I had both Scilfars and Razors fufiCient, I had cut it pretty fhort, except what grew oB
my upper Lip, which I had trimm'd into a large Pair of
A hbometan Whiskers, ftch as I had feen worn by oIme
Tzurs, whom I faw at $4Sce for the Moors did uot wear
fuch




( '44).~uch, tho' the Turks did; of there Muflachioes, or Whibs
kers, I will not fay they were long enough to hang my
Hat upon them, but they were of a Length and Shape
monfirous enough, and fuch as in England would have
pafeed for frightful.
But all this is by the by; for as to my Figure, I had
fo few to oblerve me, that is was of no manner of Con,
fequence; fo I fay no more to that Part: In this kind
of Figure I went my new Journey, and was out five or
fix Days. I travell'd firft along the Sea-Shore, dire&f
ly to the Place where I firft brought my Boat to an Anchor, to get up upon the Rocks; and having no Boat
now to take care of, I went over the Land a nearer
Way, to the fame Height that I was upon before; when
looking forward to the Point of the Rocks which lay
out, and which I was oblig'd to double with my Boat,
as I faid above, I was furpriz'd to fee the Sea all fmooth
and quiet, no Rippling, no Motion, no Current, any
more there than in other Places.
I was at a ftrange Lofs to underftand this, and relblv'd
to fpend fome Time in the obferving it, to fee if nothing
from the Sets of the Tide had occafion'd it; but I was
prefently convinced how it was, vi. That the Tide of
Ebb fetting from the Weft, and joyning with the Current of Waters from fome great River on the Shore, muft
be the Occafion of this Current; and that according as
the Wind blew more forcible from the Weft, or from
the North, this Current came near, or went farther
from the Shore; for waiting thereabouts till Evening,
I went up to the Rock again, and then the Tide of Ebb
being made, I plainly faw the Current again as before,
only, that it ran farther off, being near half a League
from the Shore; whereas in my Cafe, it fet clofe upon
the Shore, and hurried me and my Canoe along with it,
which at another Time it would not have done.
This Obfervation convinc'd me, That I had nothing
odo but to oblferve the Ebbing and the Flowing of the
A ide, and I might very eafily bring my Boat about the
Ifand again: but when I began to think of putting it
in Practice, I had fuch a Terror upon my Spirits at
the Remembrance ofthe Danger I had been in, that I
could not think of it again with any Patience j but on
-                     the




(  106 )
tle contrary, I took up another Refolutton, which was
more fafe, though more laborious; and this was, That
I would. build, or rather make me another Teriagua., or
Canoe; and fo have one for one Side of the Ifland, and.
one for'the other.
You are to underrtand, that now I had, as I may call
it, two Plantations in the IWiand; one my little Fortification or Tent, with the Wall abcut it under the
Rock, with the Cave behind me, which by 'this Time
I haa enlarg'd into feveral Apartments or Caves, one
within another. One of thefe, which was the dryef,
and largefl, and had a Door out beyond my Wall or
Fortification; that is to lay, beyond where my Wall
j )ind to the Rock, was all fii'd up with the large Earthen Pots, of which I have given an Account, and with
fourteen or fi'teen great Baskets, which would hold five
or fix Bufhlels each, where I laid up my Stores of Provifion, efpe-ially miv Corn, fome in the Ear cut oft
fhort from the Straw, and the other rubb'd out with
mwy Hand.
As for my Wall made, as before, with long Stakts
or Piles, thofe Pils grew all like Trees, and were by
this Time grown fo big, and fpread io very   niuch.
that there was not the leaft Appearance to aby one's
View of any Hibitation behind them.
Near this Dwelling of'iiine, but a little farther within the Land, and upon lower- Ground, lay hmy two Pieces of Corn-Ground, which I kept duly cultivated
and fow'd, and which duly, yielded me their Harveit in
its Seafon; and whenever 1 had Occafion for more Corn)
I had more Land adjoining as fit as'that.
Befidesthis, I had my Country Seat, and I had now
a tolerable Plantation there alfo; for firtl, I had i,^v
little Bower, as I call'd it, which I kept in Repair;
tb:it is to Nfy, I kept the Hedge which circled it i-n,
cnlf}ntly fitted up to its ufual Height, the Ladder

that they might fpread and grow thick and wild, a~nd
make the more agreeable Shade, which they did effec.
-tually to my Mincd In the middle of this I had my.H                 Tmt




(146)
Tent always flanding, being a piece ofa Sail fpread over
Poles iet up for that Purpotl, and which never wanted
any repair or renewing; and under this I had made me
a Squab or Couch, with the Skins of the Creatures I had
killd, and with-other foft Things, and a Blanket laid
on them, fuch as belong'd to our Sea-Bedding, which I
had faved, and a great Watch-Coat to cover me; and
here, whenever I lad occafion to be abfent from my
chief Seat, I took up my Country Habitation.
Adjoyning to this I had my Enclofures for my Cattle,
that is to fay, my Goats: And as I had taken an inconceivable deal of pains to fence and enclofe this Ground,
fo I was fo uneaiy to fte it kept entire, left the Goats
fliould break thro', that I never left off, till with infinite Labour I had fluck t eDutfide of the Hedge lb full
offmall Stakes, and fo ner to one an another, that it was
rather a Pale than aHedge, and there was fcarce room to
put a Hand thro' between them, which afterwards when
thofe Stakts grew, as they all did in the next rainy
Seafon, made the Enclofure ftrong, like a Wall, indeed
fronger than any Wall.
This will teftify for me that I was not idle, and
that I fpared no Pains to bring to pals whatever appear'd neceffary for my comfortable Support; for I confider'd the keeping up a Ereed of tame Creatures thus
at my Hand, would be a living Magazine of Flefh,
Milk, Butter and Cheefe, for me, as long as I liv'd in the
Place, if' it were to be forty Years; and that keeping
them in my Reach, depended entirely upon my pertecting my Enclofures to fuch a degree, that I might be
fure of keeping them together; which by this Method
indeed I fo effectually fecured, that when thefe little
Stakes began to grow, I had planted them to very thick,
I was forced to pull bonle ofthem up again.
In this Place allb I had my Grapes growing, which I
principally depended on for my Winter Store of Raifins,
and which I never fail'd to preferve very carfully, as the
beft and moft agreeable Dainty of my whole Diet; and
indeed they were not agreeable only, but phyfical, wholefo ne, nourifhing and refrefhing to the laft degree.
As




( I47)
As this was alfo about half way between my other
Habitation and the Place where I had laid up my Boat,
I generally flay'd and lay here in my Way thither;
for I ufed frequently to viiit my Boat, and I kept all
things about or belonging to her in very good Order;
fometimes I went out in her to divert my felf, but no
more hazardous Voyages would I go, nor fcarce ever
above a Stone's Caft or two from the Shore, I was fo apprehenfive of being hurried out of my Knowledge again by the Currents, or Winds, or any other Accident:
But now I come to a new Scene of my Life.
It happen'd one Day about Noon, going towards my
Boat, I was exceedingly furpiz'd with the Print of a
Man's naked Foot on the Shore, which was very plain
to be feen in the Sand: I flood like one Thunder-fcuzk,
or as if I had feen anApparition; I litlen'd, I look'd round
me, I could hear nothing, nor fee any thing; I went
up to a riling Ground to look farther: I went up the
Shore, and down the S.ore, but it was all one, I could
fee no other Impreffion but that one, I went to it again
to fee if there were any more, and to obferveif it might
not be my Fancy; but there was no Room for that, for
there was exactly the very Print of a Foot, Toes,
Heel, and every Part of a Foot; how it came thither
I knew not, nor could irr the leaft imagine  But after
innumerable flattering Thoughts, like a HlVan perfedly
confuted and out of my felf; i came home to my Fortification, not feeling, as we fay, the Ground I went on,
but terrify'd to the laft * degree, looking behind me at
every two or three Steps, milcaking every Bulh and
Tree, and fancying every Stump at a diftance to be a
Man; nor is it poifible to defcribe how many var.ous
Shapes afrighted Imagination reprefented things to me
in; how many wild Ideas were fbnrm'd every Moment
in my Fancy, and what firange unaccountable Whimfies
came into my Thoughts by the Way.
When I came to my Caftle, for lb I think I call'd it
ever after this, I fled into it like one perfued  whether I went over by the Ladder, as firft contriv'd, or
went in at the Hole in the Rock, which I call'd a Door,
Icannot remember; for never frighted Hare fled to
I 2              Cover,




(  148 )
Cover, or Fox to Earth, with more Terror cf MrinI,than I to this Retreat.
I flept none that Night; the farther I was from thb
Occafion of my Fright, the greater my Apprehenfions
were; which is fomething contrary to the nature o'
fhch things, and efpecially to the ulual PraAice of all
Creatures in Fear: Put I was fo embarrafs'd with my
own frightful Ideas of the Thing, tlat I form'd nothing
u tat difinal Imaginations to my felt; even tho' I was now,a great way off it. Sometimes I fancy'd it nmuf be the
Devil; and Realonjoin'd in with me upon this Suppo.
iition: For how fhould any other thing in human Shape
come into: the Place? Where was the Veflel that brought
them? What Marls was there of any other Footiteps?
And how was it poflible a Man flould come there?
But then to think that Satan fhculd take human Shape;upon him in fuch a Place where there could be no man-,ser of Occafion for it, but to leave the Print of his
Foot behind him, and that even for no Furpofe too
( for he could not be fure I fliould fee it ) this was an
Amufement the other Way: I confider'd that the Devil;might have fiund out Abundance of other Ways to have
i;errify'd me, than this of -the fingle Print of a Foot.
That as I lived quite on the otherfide of the Ifland,;he would never have been fo fimple to leave a Mark in;a Place where it was ten Thouland to One whether
I fhould ever fee it or not, and in the Sand too, which
t.he firil Surge of the Sea upon a high Wind would have,defac'd entirely: All this ftenl'd inconfiflent with the
Thing itelf,1 and with all Notions we ufually entertain,.of the Subtilty of the Devil.
Abundance of fuch Things as thefe affilted to argue
jnle out of all Apprehenfions of its b ing the Devil:
And I prefently concluded then, that it muft be fome
more dangerous Creature, vii. That it mult be fome.of the Savages of the main Land over-againft me, who
had wandered cut 'to Sea in their Canoes, and either.driven by the Currents, or by contrary Winds, had
made the Ifland; and had been on Shore, but were gone
awayagain to Sea, being as loth, perhaps, to have ittid
in this defolate fland, as I would have been to have:had ithaem.

ing, or to appear among, the Ireat of his Creatures; that,
H-                        t




(     0 )
to lave feen one of my own Species, would have feem'd
to me a Raifing me from Death to Life, and the greater
BlelTing that Heaven itfelf, next to the fupreme bleffing
of Salvation, could beftow; I fay, that I fhould now
tremble at the very Apprehenfions of feeing a Man, and
was ready to fink into the Ground at but the Shadow, or
iilent Appearance of a Man's having fet his Foot on
the Ifland.
Such is the uneven State of Human Life; and it afforded me a great many curious Speculations afterwards,
when I had a little recovered my firfl Surprize; I
confidered that this was the Station of Life, the infinitely wile and good Providence of God had determin'd
for me; that as I could not forefee what the Ends of
Divine V ifdom might be in all this, fo I was not to
difpute his Sovereignty, who, as I was his Creature, had
an undoubted Right by Creation, to govern and dif.
pofe of me abfolutely as he thought fit; and who, as I
was a Creature who had offended him, had likewife
a judicial Right to condemn me to what Punifliment he thought fit; and that it was my Part to fibmit
to bear his Indignation, becaufe I had finn'd againit
him.
I then refle&ed, that God, who was not only Righteous but Omnipotent, as he had thought fit thus to
punifli and affli& me, fo he was able to deliver me;
that if he did not think fit to do it, 'twas my unqueflion'd Duty to refign nyfelf abfolute and entirely to his
Will: And on the other hand, it was my Duty alfo to
hope il him, pray to him, and quietly to attend the
Ditates and Dire&ions of his daily Providence.
Thefe Thoughlts took me up many Hours, Days,
nay, I may fay, Weeks and Months; and one particular Efrf& of my Cogitations on this Occafion, I cannot
omit, via. One Morning early, lying in my Bed, and
fill'd with Thoughts about my Danger from the Appearance of Savages, I found it difcompos'd me very
much; upon which thofe Words of the Scripture came
into my Thoughts, Call upon me in the Day cf Trouble,
and 1 wil deliver, and tbou Jhalt fl:rify me.
Upon this, riling chearfully out of my Bed, my
Heart was not only comforted, but I was guided and
encourag6...




( 15' )
encouraged to pray earneitlv to God for Deliverasne:
When I had done praying, I took up my Fible, and
opening it to read, the firil Woils that pretented to
me, were, WFait on the Lord, and bbe oj god Cheer, and
he Jall flrengthen thy Heart; wait, ifay, cn the Lord.
It is impoffible to exprefs the Comfort this gave me.
and in return, I thankfully laid down the Book, and was
no more fad, at leaft, not on that Occafion.
In the Middle ofthefe Cogitations, Apprehenflons,
and Refle&ions, it came into my Thoughts one Day.
that all this might be a meer Chimerea of my own,
and that this Foot, might be the Print of my own
Foot, wheV I came on Shore from   my Boat: This
chear'd me up a little too, and I began to perfwade my
flf it was all a Delufion; that it was nothing elie but
my own Foot; and why might not I come that Way
from the Boat, as well as I was going that Way to
the Boat? Again, I confider'd alfo that I could by no
Means tell for certain where I had trod, and where f
had not; and that if at laft this was only the Print of
my own Foot, I had play'd the Part of thofe Fools,
who ftrive to make Stories of Spe&res and Apparitioris, and then are themfelves frighted at them more
than any Body elfe.
Now I began to take Courage, and to peep abroad
again; for I had not ftirr'd out of my Caftle for three
Days and Nights; fo that I began to flarve for Provilion; for I had little or nothing within Doors, but rome
Barley Cakes and Water. Then I knew that my Goats
wanted to be milk'd too, which ufually was my Evening Diverfion; and the poor Creatures were in great
Pain and Inconvenience for want of it; and indeed it
almoft fpoil'd ibme of them, and almoft dry'd up their
Milk.
Heartning my felf therefore with the Beliefthat this
was nothing but the Print of one of my own Feet,
(and fo I might be truly faid to ftart at my own Shadow) I began to go abroad again, and went to my Country-Houfe to milk my Flock; but to fee with what Fear
I went forward, how often I look'd behind me, how I
was ready every now and then, to lay down my Bafket, and run for my Life, it would have made any one
LE 4,               ~hae




( I52 )
have thoughat I was haunted with an evil Conlcience, or
that I had been lat vly moll terribly fiighted  and, ib
indeed 1 had.
Holoever, as I went down thus two orthree Days,
and having leen nothing, I began to be a little bolder,
and to think there was really ncthing in it but my own
I mArination;; bt I could not perfwade my fel 'fully of
this, till I lhould go down to the Shore again, and fee
this Print of a Foot, and meafure it by mly own, and
ice if there was any iimilitade or Fitnefs, that I mipht
Be affured it was my own Foot: But, when I came to.

after I was come home agaip, while the Apprehenfions which had fb over run my Mind were frefh upon

Thus Fear of Danger is ten thoufand times more terrify-.
ing




( 53)
ingthan Danger it felt, when apparent to the Eyes; a.nc

to compofe my Mlind, by crying to God in my Diflrefss

This Confufion of my Thoughts kept me waking all
Night; but in the Morning I fell afeep, and having,
by the AnmufCement of my Mind, been as it were tired
and my Spirits exhrufted, I flept very lbundly, and
wak'd much better compos'd than I had eve,' been before: Andr-now I began to think fedatclv; and upon,
the utmoft Debate with my felt; I concluded, That this
Ifland, which was fo exceeding plealant, fi',iti'ul, and
no farther from the main Land than as I had feen, was
not fo entirely abandon'd as I might imagine: That al
tho' there were no ftated Inhabitants who liv'd on the
Spot; yet that there might ibmetimes come Boats off'
from the Shore, who either with Dcfign, or perhaps.
never, but when they were driven by crofs Winds, might
come to this Place.
That I had liv'd here I 5 Years now, and had not met
with the leaft Shadow or Figure of any People before;
and that if at any Time they fhould be driven here, it
was probable they went away again as foon as ever they
could, feeing they had never thought fit to fix there
upon any Occafion, to this Time.
That the nmoft I could fuggefl any Danger from, was)
fiom any fuch cafual accidental Landing of tliaggling
People from the Main, who, as it was likely if they
were driven hither, were here againft their Wills; 1i
they nmade no flay here, but went off again with all
poflible Speed, feldom fraying one Night on 5hore, left
they fhould not have the Help of thet..ideze and Day.

(   54  )
tight back again; and that therefore I had nothing td
^ do but to confider of Tome fafe Retreat, in Caie I Should

Now I began forely to repent, that I had dug nmy
Cave to large, as to bring a Duor through again, which
Door, as I faid, came out beyond where my Fortification joyn'd to the Rock: Upon maturely confidering
this therefore, I refolv'd to draw me a fecond Fortification, in the fame Manner of a Semicircle, at a Diflance
from my Wall, juft where I had planted a double Row
of Trees about twelve Years before, of which I made
mention  Thete Trees having been planted ib thick before, there wanted but a few Piles to be driven between
them, that they fhould be thicker, and ftronger, and
my Wall would be foon finifh'd.
So that I had now a double Wall, and my outer Wall
Was thickned with Pieces of Timber, old Cables, and
every thing I could think of to make it firong; having
in it feven little Holes, about as big as I night put my
Arm out at. In the Infide of this i thickned my Wall
to about ten Foot thick, with continually bringing
Earth out of my Cave, and laying it at the Foot of the
Wall, and walking upon it; and through the feven
Hbles, I contriv'd to plant the Mufquets, of which I
took Notice, that I got feven on Shore out of the Ship
thefe, I fays I planted like my Cannon, and fitted them
into Frares that held them like a Carriage, that fo I
could fire all the feven Guns in two Minutes time:
This Wall I was many a weary Month a finifhing, and
yet never thought my felf tife till it was done.
When this was done, I fluck all the Ground without
fby Wall, for a great way every way, as full with Stakes
or Sticks of the Ofier-like Wood, which I found fo apt
to grow, as they could well ftand; infomucl, that I be,
lieve I niight fet in near twenty thoufand ofthem, leaving a pretty large Space between them and my Wall,
that I might have Room to fee an Eneiy, and they
mitght hae no Shelter from the young Trees, if they at&
tempted to approach my outer Wall.
Thus in two Years time I had a thick Grove; and in
five or fix Years time I had a Wood before my Dwelli1g, grown lb monftrous thick ahd itrong, that it was
indeed




( T,5   )
Indeed perfeyly impaffable; and no Man, of what kind
foever, would ever imagine that there was any thing
beyond it, much lefs a Habitation: As for the Way
which I propofed to my felf to go in and out, (for I left
no Avenue) it was by fetting two Ladders; one to a Part
of the Rock which was low, and then broke in, and left
room to place another Ladder upon that; fo when the
two Ladders were taken down, no Man living could
come down to me without mifchieving timfel'; and if
they had come down, they were fill on the Outfide of
my outer Wall.
Thus I took all the Meafures human Prudence could
fugger for ny own Prefervation; and it will bee feen at
length, that they were not altogether without juil Reafon; though I forefaw nothing at that time, more than
my meer Fear fuggefted to me.
While this was doing, I was not altogether carelef)
of my other Affairs; for I had a great Concern upoi
me for my little Herd of Goats; they were not only a
prefent Supply to me upon every Occafion, and began
to be fufficient to me, without the Expence of Powder
and Shot, but alfo abated the Fatigue of my Hunting after the wild ones and I was loth to lofe the Advantage of them, and to have them all to nurfe up over
again.
To this Purpofe, after long Confideration, I could
think of but two Ways to preterve them; one was to,
find another convenient Place to dig a Cave under
Ground, and to drive them into it every Night; and
the othewr was to enclofe two or three little Bits of
Land, remote from one another, and as much conceal'd
as I could, where I might keep about halfa dozen young
Goats in each Place; fo that if any Diffter happen'd
to the Flock in general, I might be able to raife thenr
again with little Trouble and Time: And this, tho' it
would require a great deal of Time and Labour, I
thought was the moft rational Defign.
Accordingly, I fpent fome Time to find out the moft
retired Parts of the Ifland; and I pitched upon one which
was as private indeed as my Heart could wifl; for it
was a little damp Piece of Ground in the middle of the
hollow and thick Woods, where, as is obferv'd, I at.
maHn

moit loft my felf once before, endeavouring to corGm

I immediately went to work with this Piece of

miight be fuppofed to be, were well enough fecured in
i. So without any farther Delay, I removed ten She( oats and two He Goats to this Piece; and when they

at more Leifure, and it took me up more Time by a

All tbii Labour I was at the Expgnce ofy purely frorn

now liv'd two Years under thele Uneafinefles, which
indeed made ihy Life much les.comfortable than it was
t'efbre; as may well be imagin'd by any who know
what it is to live in the conftant Snare of the Fear of
Man; and this I muft obferve with Grief too, that the
Pifcompofure -of my Mind had too great nlprtfnions
alfo upon the re-lious Part of my Thoughts; for the
Dread and Teror of faiuing into the Hands of Savages
and Canibals lay fo upon Imy Spirits, that I feldom found

at l'aft not with the fedate Calmnefs and Refignatio.
of 5oul which I was. wont to do: I rather pray'd to

of btfing murther'd and devcur'd before Morning; and
I muil tefrily fiom  my Experience, that a Temper of
-'eace, Thankfulnefs, sLove arid Affition, is much the
more proper Frame for Prayer than that of Terror and
Dircompofure; and that under the Dread of Mifchief
impending, a Man is no amore fit for a comforting Per+                                        - frxngrcee




( I57 )`
fbrmance of the. Duty of praying to God, than he is for
Repentance on a Sick-Bed: For thefe Difcompoiures
affer the Mind as the others do the Body; and the-Difcompofure of the Mind mull neceffarily be as great a
Difability as that of the Body, and much greater, praying to God being properly an Aft of the Mind, not of
the Body.
But to go on; After I had thus fecur'd one Part of
miy little living Stock, I went about the whole fland,
itarching for another private Place, to make fuch another Depofit; when wandring more to the Weft Point
of the Ifland than I had ever done yet, and looking out'
to Sea, I thought I faw a Boat upon the Sea, at a great
Diflance I had found a Perfpedive-Glafs, or two, in
one of the Seamen's Chells, which I fav'd out of our
Ship; but I had it. not about me, and this was fb remote, that I could not tell what to make of it, though
I look'd at it till my Eyes were not-able to hold to look
any longer; whether it was a Boat, or not, I do not
know; but as I defcended from the Hill, I could fee po
more ofit, fo I gave it over; only I refolv'd to go no
more out without a Perfpe&ive-Glafs in my Pocket.
When I was come down the Hill, to the End of the
Ifland, where indeed I had never been before, I was
prefently convinc'd, that the feeing the Print of aMan's
Foot, was not fich a ftrange thing in the Ifland, as I
impagin'd; and but that it was a fpecial Providence
that I was cadl upon the Side of the Ifland, where the
Savages never came, I fllould eafily hbae known, that
nothing was nmre frequent than for the Canoes fiom the
Main, when they happen'd to be a little too far out at
Sea, to fhoot over to that Side of the Ifland for Harbour; likewife as they often met, and fought in their
Canoes, the Vi&ors having taken any Priloners, would
biing them over to this Shore, where, according to their.
dreadful Cuftoms, being all Canibals, they would kilt
and eat them: Of which hereafter.
When I wascome do wn tl$e Hill to the Shore, as I
faid above, being the S.W. Point, of the I land, I was,
perfetly confounded and amaz'd; nor is it poffible for,
ne to exprefs the Horror of my Mind, at. fecing the
Swor; fpread with Skulls, Hands, Feet, and other Bones
of


U




( I58 )
of human Bodies; and particularly I obferv'd a Place
where there had been a Fire made, and a Circle dug in
the Earth, like a Cock-pit, where it is fuppofed the
Savage Wretches had fat down to their inhuman Feaflings upon the Bodies of their Fellow-Creatures.
I was lb aftonifh'd with the Sight of thefe Things,
that I entertain'd no Notions of any Danger to my lelf
from it, for a longe while; all my Apprehenfions were
buried in the Thoughts of fqch a Pitch of inhuman,
hellilh Brutality, and the IHorIor of the Degeneracy of
human Nature; which tho' I had heard of often, yet I
never had fo near a View of before; in fhort, I turned
away my Face fromn the horrid Speftacle; my Stomach
grew fick, and I was jufi at the Point of Fainting, when
Nature difcharg'd the Diforder from my Stomach,
and having vomited with an uncommon Violence, I
was a little relieved; but could not bear to flay in the
Place a Moment; fo I got me up the Hill again, with
all the Speed I could, and walk'd on towards my own
Habitation. '
When I came a little out of that Part of the Ifland,
I flood till a while as amaz'd; and then recovering
my felf, I look'd up with the utmoft Affe6ion of my
Soul, and with a Flood of Tears in my Eyes, gave
God Thanks that had call my firi Lot in a Part of the
World, where I was diftinguifhed from fuch dreadful
Creatures as thefe; and that tho' I had efteem'd my
prefent Condition very miserable, had yet given me fo
many Comforts in it, that I had f1ill more to give
Thanks for, than to complain of; and this above all,
that I had, even in this miserable Condition, been
comforted with the Knowledge of himfelf, and the
Hope of his Bleffing, which was a Felicity more than
fufficiently equivalent to all the Mifery which I had
fufer'd, or could fuffer.
In this Frame of Thankffulnefs, I wert Home to my
Caftle, and began to be much eafier now, as to the Safe.
ty of my Circumftances, than ever I was before; for
I obferv'd that there Wretches never came to this
Ifland in fearch of what they could get; perhaps not
feeking, not wanting, or not expe&ing any thing here;
ind -having often, no doubt, been up in the Icover'd
woody




( I59 )
Woody Part of it, without finding any thing to their
Purpofe: I knew I had been here now almoft eighteen
Years, and never faw the leaft Footfteps of human
Creature there before; and I might be here eighteen
more as entirely conceal'd as I was now, if I did not
difcover my felf to them, which I had no manner of
Occafion to do, it being my only Bifinefs to keep my
felf entirely conceal'd where I was, unlefs I found a
better fort of Creatures than Canibals to make my felf
known to.
Yet I entertain'd fuch an Abhorrence of the favage
Wretches that I have been fpeaking of, and of the
wretched inhuman Clftom of their devouring and eat.
ing one another up, that I continued penfive and fad,
and kept clofe within my own Circle for almoft two
Years after this: When I fay my own Circle, I mean
by it, my three Plantations, vik. my Caftle, my Country-Seat, which I call'd my Bower, and my Encloflre
in the Woods; nor did I look after this for any other
Ufe than as an Inclofure for my Goats; for the Averfion which Nature gave me to there helliih Wretches,
was fuch, that I was fearful of feeing them, as of feeing
the Devil himfelf; nor did I fo much as go to look atter my Boat in all this Time; but began rather to think
of making me another; tor I could not think of ever
making any more Attempts to bring the other Boat
round the fland to me, left I Ihould meet with fome
of thefe Creatures at Sea, in which, if I had happen'd
to have fallen into their Hands, 1 knew what would
have been my Lot.
Time however, and the Satisfa&ion I had, that I
was in no Danger of being difcover'd by thefe People,
began to wear off my Uneafinefs about them; and I began to live juft in the fame compos'd Manner as betore; only with this Difference, that I us'd more Caution, and kept my Eyes more about tme than I did before, left I ihould happen to be feen by any of them;
and particularly I was more cautious of firing my Gumn
left any of them on the Ifland, ihould happen to hear
it; and it was therefore a very good Providence to
me, that I had furnfh'd my felf with a tame Breed
of Goatsi that I needed not bhunt any more about the
Woods




Woods, or ihoot at 'em; and if I did catch any of 'em
after this, it was by Traps and Snares, as I had done
before; fo that for two Years after this, I believe I ne
ver fir'd my Gun once off; tho' I never went out without it; and which was more, as I had iav'd three Piftols
out of the Ship, I always carried 'en out with ma, or
at leaft two of them, tflicking them in my Goat- kin
Belt; I alfo furbifi'd up one oftthe great Cutlafhes, that
I had out of the Ship, and made me a Belt to put it on
alfo; fo that I was now a mofl formidable Fellow to
look at, when I went abroad if you add to the former
Defcription of my felf, the Particular of two Piftols,
and a great broad Sword hanging at my Side in a belt,
but without a Scabbard.
Things going on thus, as I have faid, for fome Time,
I feem'd, excepting thefe Cautions5 to be reduc'd to my
former calm fedate way of Living, all thefe Things
tended to fhlewing me more and more how far my Condition was from being miferable, ccmpared to fume others; nay, to many other Particulars of Life, which it
might have pleafed God to have made my Lot. It pat
me upon refleting, how little repining there would be
among Mankind, at any Condition of Life, if People
would rather compare their Condition with thofe that
are worfe, in order to be thankful, than be always conparing them  with thofe which are better to aliffi their
Murmurings and Complainings.
As in my prefent Condition there were not really
many Things which I wanted; fo indeed I thought that
the Frights I had been in about thefe Savage Wretches
and the Concern I had been in for my own Prelervation, had taken off the Edge of my Invention for my
own Conveniences:; and Ilhad dropt a good Defign,
which I had once bent. my Thoughts upon; and that
was to try if I could not make fotne of my Barley
into Malt, aid then try to brew my ife'fome Beer:
This was really a whimiical Thought, and I reproved
my felf often forthe Simplicity o' it; for I prefeutly
faw there would b2 the Want of feveral Things necefla,
ry to the making my Beer, that it would be impoffible
for me to Iuipply: As Firfl, Casks to preftrve it in,
which was a Thing that, as I have obiCrv'i. already




I could never compafs: no, tho' I fpentlnotmany Days
but Weeks, nay Months, in attempting it, but to 1io
purp;Fie. In the next place, I had no Hops to make it
keep, no Yeaft to make it work, no Copper or Kettle
to make- it. boil; and yet all thefe Things interven'd,
I mean the Erights and Terrors I was in about the Savages, I had undertcken it, and perhaps brought it to
pais too; for I feldonr gave any Thing over without
accomplifhing it, when I once had it in my Head enough
to begin it.
But my Invention now run quite another Way; for.
Night and Day I could think of nothing but how I
might deltroy ibme of thefe Monfters in their cruel
bloody Entertainment, and if pofible, fave the Vietim
they Ihoujd bring hither to deftroy. It would take up
a larger Volume than this whole Work is intended to
be, to fet down all the Contrivances I hatched, or ra.
ther brooded upon in my Thoughts, for the deflroying
1thfe Creatures, or at leaft frighting 'em, fo as to prevent their coming hither. any more; but all was abortive, nothing could be poffible to take Effzct, unlefs I
was to be there to do it my felf;, and what could one
Man do. among, them, when perhaps there might be
twenty or. thirty of them  together, with their Darts,
or their Bows aad Arrows, witlvwhich they, could lhoot
as true to a Mark, as I could with my Gun?
Sometimes I contriv'd to dig a Hole under the Place
twhere they made their Fire, and put in five or fix Pounds
of Gun-powder, which when they kindled tieir Fire,
would confequently take Fire, and blow up all that
was near it; but as in the firft phace I liould be very.
loth to wafte fo much Powder upon 'em, my Store being now within tlie Quantity of a Barrel.; fo neither
could I be lure of its going off, at any certain time,,
when it might furprize them, and at beft, that it vwould
do little more than juft blow the Fire about their Ears,
and fright them, but not fufficient to make them forfake the Place; lb I laid it. afide, and then propos'd,
that I would place my felf in Ambufh, in fome conveni-.
ent Place, with my three Guns, all double loaded; and
io the middle of their bloody Ceremony let fly at 'em,
When I flould be fure to kill or wund perhaps two or
three




( I62 )
three at every fhoot; and then falling in upon them
with my three Piifols, and my Sword, I made no doubt
but that if there were twenty I fould kill them all;
This Fancy pleas'd my Thoughts for fome Weeks,
and I was fo full of it, that I often dreamt of it;
and fometimes, that I was jufi going to let fly at them
in my Sleep.
I went fo far with it in my Imagination, that I employ'd my felffeveral Days to find out proper Places to
put my filfin Ambu}cade, as I laid, to watch for them;
and   went frequently to the Place itlelf which was
now grown more familiar to me and efpecially while
my Mind was thus fill'd with Thoughts of Revenge,
and of a bloody putting twenty or thirty of them to
the Sword, as I may call it; but the Horror I had at the
Place, and at the Signals of the barbarous Wretches
devouring one another, abated my Malice.
Well, at length I found a Place in the Side of the
Hill, where I was fatisfy'd I might fecurely wait, till
I faw any of their Boats coming, and might then,
even betbre they would be ready to come on Shore,
convey myfelf unfeen into Thickets of Trees, in one
of which there was a Hollow large enough to conceal
me entirely; and where I might lit, and obferve all
their bloody Doings, and take my full Aim at their
Heads, when they were ib clofe together, as that it
would be next to impoffible that I fhould mifs my
Shoot, or that I could fail wounding three or four of
them at the firft Shoot.
In this Place then I refolv'd to fix my Defign, and
accordingly I prepar'd two Muskets, and my ordinary
Fowling-Piece. The two Muskets I loaded with a
Brace of Slugs each, and four or five fmller Bullets,
about the Size of Piftol-Bullets; and the Fowling-Piece
I loaded with near a Handful of Swan-Shot, of the
largefl Size; I alfo loaded my Piftols with about four
Bullets each, and in this Pofture, well provided with
Ammunition for a fecond and third Charge, I prepar'd
my filf for my Expedition.
* After I had thus laid the Scheme for my Defign, and
in my Imagination put it in Practice, I continually
made my Tour every Morning up to the Top of the
Hill,




( 163 )
Hill, which was from my Caftle, as I call'd it, about
three Miles, or more, to fee if' I could obferve any
Boats upon the Sea, coming near the Ifland, or ftanding
over towards it; but I began to tire of' this hard Duty, after I had for two or three Months conftantly
kept my Watch; but came always back without any
Diicovery, there having not in all that Time been the
leafi Appearance, not only on, or near the Shore,
but not on the whole Ocean, fo far as my Eyes or Glaffes could reach every Way.
As long as I kept up my daily Tour to the Hill to
look out, bo long alfo I kept up the Vigour of my Defign, and my Spirits feem'd to be all the while in a fuitablc Frame, for fbo outrageous an Execution as the kil.
ling twenty or thirty naked Savages for an Offence
which I had not at all enter'd into a Difcufion of in my
Thoughts, any fiurther than my Paflions were at firft
fir'd by the Horror I conceiv'd at the unnatural Cuftonm of the People of that Country, who it teems had
been fuffer'd by Providence, in his wife Difpofition of
the World, to have no other Guide than that of their
own abominable and vitiated Paflions; and confequently were left, and perhaps had been fo for Ibme Ages, to
a& fuch horrid Things, and receive fuch dreadful Cuftoms, as nothing but Nature entirely abandon'd of Heaven, and ad&ed by fome hellith Degeneracy, could have
run them into: But now when, as I have faid, I began
to be weary ot the fruitlefs Excurfion which I had made
fo long, and fo far, every Morning in vain; fo my Opinion of the A&fion it felf began to alter, and I began
with cooler and calmer Thoughts to confider what it
was I was going to engage in; what Authority or Call I
had, to pretend to be Judge and Executioner upon
thefe Men as Criminals, whom Heaven had thought fit
for tob many Ages to fuffer, unpunifh'd, to go on, and
to be as it were, the Executioners of his Judgments,
upon another: Alfo how far thefe People were Offenders againft me, and what Right had I to engage in the
Quarrel of that Blood, which they lied promifcuoufly
one upon another: I debated this very often with my
felf thus, How do I know what God himfelf Judges in
this




< I72 7
this particular Cafe? It is certain thefe People do not
commit this as a Crime, it is not againft their owiv
Confcieices reproving, or their Light reproaching them.
They do not know it to be an Oftence, and then corn.
mit it in defiance of divine Julice, as we do in almolt
all the Sins we commit. They think it no more a Crimn
to kill a Captive taken in War, than we do to kill an
Ox; nor to eat human F'leh, than we do to eat Multton.
When I Irad confider'd this a little, it follov'd neceffarily, that I was-certainly in the Wrong in it; that theie
People were not Murderers in the Senfe that I had be.
fore condemn'd them in my Thoughts; any more than
thofe Chriitians were Murderers, who often put to
Death the Prifoners taken in Battle, or more frequently,
upon many Occafions, put whole Troops of Men to tht
Sword, without giving Quarter, the' they threw down
their Arms and fubmitted.
In the next place it occur'd to me, that albeit the
Utcage they gave one another was thus bruitiih and inhuman; yet it was really nothing to me: Thefe People:
had done me no Injury: That if they attempted me, or
I faw it neceflary tor my immediate 1frefervation to fall
upon them, fomething might be faid for it; but that
I was yet out of their Power, and they had really no
Knowledg of me, and confequently no Defign upon me;
and theretore it could not be juft for me to fall upon
them. That this would juftify the Condu& of the JSpaniards in all their Barbarities praftis'd in America, where
they deflroy'd Millions of thefe People, who, however
they were Idolaters and Barbarians, and had feveral
bloody and barbarous Rites in their Cuifoms, fuch as
facrificing human Bodies to their Idols, were yet, as to
the Spaniards, very innocent People; and that the
rooting 'em out of the Country, is fpoken of with the
utmoft Abhorance and Deteflation, by even the Spaniards themfelves, atthis Time, and by all other Chriflian Nations of Europe, as a mere Butchery, a bloody
and unnatural piece of Cruelty, unjuffifiable either to
God or Man; and fuch, as for which the very Name
o.f a Spaniard is reckon'd to be frightful and terrible to.
all People of Humanity, or of Chriflian Compaffion:
As




1-7
(      I73 )
As if the Kingdom  of Spain were particularly eminent
for the ProduA of a Race of Men, who were without
Principles of Tendernefs, or the common Bowels of
Pity to the Miferable, which is reckon'd to be a Mark
of a 'generous Temper in the Mind.
'lhefe Confiderations really put me to a Paufe, and
to a kind of a full Stop; and I began by little and little
to be offof my Defign, and to conclud&, I had taken
wrong Meafures in my Refolutions to attack the Savage; that it was not my Bufinefs to meddle with 'em,
untefs they firil attack'd me, and this it was my Bufin:is, if poffible, to prevent; but that if I were dilccver'd, and attack'd, then 1 knew mv Duty.
On the other hand, I argu'd with my felf, That thlis
really was the Way net to deliver my felf, but entirely
to ruin and deftroy my felf; for unlefs I was fure to
kill every one that not only illould be on Shore at that
Time, but that fliould ever come on Shore aiterwards,
if but one of them efcap'd, to tell their Country-People what had happen'd, they would come over again by
Thoufands to revenge the Death of their Fellows and
I fllould only bring upon my felf a certain  )eilruction, which at preeent I had no manner of Occafion
for.
Upon the Whole I concluded, that neither in Princi.
ples nor in Policy I ought one Way or other to concern
my fl-f in this Afftir. That my Bufinels was by all
pcflible means to conceal my felf from them, and not
to leave thelcait Signal to them to gueis by, that tlere
were any living Creatures upon the Ifland; I mean of
human Shape.. eligion join'd in with tllis Prudential, and I was
convinc'd now many Ways, that I was perfectly out of
my Duty, when I was laying all my bloody Schemes
for the DeflruAion of innocent Creatures, I mean innocent as,me: As to the Crimes they were gailty of toowards one another, I had nothing to with therm; they
were National Punifllments to make a juf Retribution
for National Offences; and to bring publick Judgments
-upon thole who offend in a publick Manner, by fuch
Ways as beft pleafe him.
This




(     66 )
This appear'd fo clear to me now, -that nothing was
a greater Satisfa&ion to me, than that I had not been
fuffer'd to do a Thing which I now faw fo much Reafon
to believe would have been no lets a Sin, than that of
wilful Murther, if I had committed it; and I gave mofi
humble Thanks on my Knees to God, that had thus
deliver'd me from Blood-guiltinefs; befeeching him to
grant me the Prote&ion of his Providence, that I
might not fall into the Hands ofBarbarians; or that I
might not lay my Hands upon them, unlefs I had a
more clear Call from Heaven to do it, in Defence of
my own Life.
In this Difpofition I continu'd for near a Year after
this; and fo tar was I from defiring an Occafion for
falling upon thefe Wretches, that in all that Time I never once went up the Hill to fee whether there were
any of them in Sight, or to know whether any of them
had been on Shore there, or not, that I might not be
tempted to renew any of my Contrivances againit them,
or be provoked by any Advantage which might prefint
it felf to fall upon them; only this I did, I went and
removed my Boat, which I had on the other Side the
Ifland, and carried it down to the Eaft End of the
whole Ifland, where I ran it into a little Cove, which
I found under fome high Rocks, and where I knew, by
reafonoftheCurrents, the Savages durft not, at leaft
would not come with their Boats, upon any Acccunt
whatfoever.
With my Boat I carried away every Thing that I
had left there belonging to her, tho' not neceffary for
the bare going thither, via. A Maft and Sail, which I
had made for her, and a Thing like an Anchor, but indeed which could not be call'd either Anchor or Grapling; however, it was the beft I could make ofits kind:
All there I remov'd, that there might not J)e the leaft
Shadow of any Dilcovery, or any Appearance of any
Boat, or of any human Habitation upon the fland.
Befides this, I kept my felf, as I faid, more retired
than ever, and feldom went from my Cell, other than
upon my conftant Employment, via. to mik my SheGoats, and manage my little Flock in the Wood; which,
as it was quite on the other Part of the Ifland, was
quite




( 67 )
quite out of Danger:. For certain it is, that thefe fa.
rage People, who Sometimes haunted this Ifland, never
came with any Thoughts of finding any thing here,
and confequently never wandred off from the Coaft;
and I doubt not, but - they might have been feveral
times on Shore, after my Apprehenfions of them had
made me cautious,, as well as before; and, indeed, I
look'd back with iome Horror upon the Thoughts of
what my Condition would have been, if I had chop'd
upon them, and been difcover'd befbre that, when naked
and unarm'd, except with one Gun, and that loaded
often only with fmall Shot. I walked every where
peeping, and peiring about the Iland, to fee what I
could get; what a 5urprize Ihould I have been in, if,
when 1 difcover'd the Print of a Man's Foot, I had inflead of that feen fifteen or twenty Savages, and found
them purfuing me, and by the Swiftnefs of their Running, no Pofibility of my efcaping them?
The Thoughts of this Sometimes funk my very Soul
within me, and diftrefs'd my Mind fo much, that I
could not foon recover it; to think what I fhould have
done, and how I not only flould not have been able to
refift them, but even thould not have had Prefence of
Mind enough to do what I might have done; much
lefs, what now after fo much Confideration and Preparation I might be able to do: Indeed, after ferious
thinking of thefe Things, I would be very melancholy,
and fometimes it would laft a great while; but I..efolv'd it at lad all into Thankfulnefs to that Providence
w;.ich had deliver'd me from fo many unfeen Dangers,
and had kept me from thofe Mifchiefs which I could
no way have been the Agent in delivering my felffrom;
becaufe I had not the leaft Notion of any fuch Thing
depending, or the leaft Suppofition of its being poft
fible.
This renewed a Contemplation, which often had
come to my Thoughts in former Time, when firft I
began to fee the merciful Difpofitions of Heaven, in the
Dangers we run thro' in this Life: How wonderfully
we are deliver'd, when we know nothing of it. How
when we are in ( a Vuandary, as we call it) a Doubt or
Hefitation, whether to go this Way, or that Way, a
fecret




( I68 )
feCret Hint fhall aire& us this Way, when we ii-tenade
to go that Way; nay, when Senie, our own Inclination, and perhaps Bulinefs has call'd to go the other
Way, yet a firange Impreflion upon the Mind, from we
know not what Springs, and by we know not what'
Power, fhall over-rule us to go this Way; and it ihall
afterwards appear, that had we gone that Way which
we fhould have gone, and even to our Imagination
ought to have gone, we Ihould have been ruin'd and
loft:  Upon thefe, and mn)ny like Reflefions, I afterwards made it a certain Rule with me, That whenever
I found thofe lecret Hints, or Preffings of my Mind, to
doing, or not doing any thing that prefented, or to
going this Way, or that Way, I never fail'd to obly
the fecret Diclate; tho' I knew no other Reafon fbr it,
than that fuch a Preffure, or fuch a Hint hung upon my
Alind: I could give many Examples of the 6uccels of
this Condu& in the Courfe of nimy Life; but more efpe.
cially in the latter Part of my inhabiting this unhappy
Ifland; befides many Occafions which it is very likely
I might have taken notice of, 'if I had feen with the
fame Eyes then, that I faw with now: But 'tis never.too late to be wile; and I cannot but advife all confidering Menl, whofe Lives are attended with futch extraordinary Incidents as mine, or even tho' not lo extras
-ordinary, not to flight fuch fecret Intimations of Providence, let them come from what invifible-Intelligence
they will, thatI fliall not difcufs, and perhaps cannot
account fbr; but certainly they are a Proorof the Converfe of Spirits, and the fecret Communication between
thofe embody'd, and thofe iunembody'd; and fuch a
Proof as can never be withtlood.: Of which I ihall-have
Occafion to give fome very remarkable Inffances in the
Remainder of my folitary Refidence,in this diftial
Place.
I believe the Reader of this will not think ftrange,
if I confets tha't thefe Anxieties, thefe conftant Dangers
I liv'd in, and the Concern that was now upon me,
put an End to all Invention, and to all the Contrivances that I had laid for my future Accommodations
and Conveniences. I had the Care of mY Safety more
now upon my Hands, than that of my Food& I car'd
0ot




( 169    )
not to drive a Nail, or chop a Stick of Wood now, for
fear the Noife I fhould make fhould be heard; much
lets would I fire a Gun, for the fame Reafon; and above
all, I was intolerably uneaiy at making any Fire, left
the Smoak, which is vifible at a great Diftance in the
Day, fhould betray me; and for this Reafon I remov'd
that Part of my Bufinefs which requir'd Fire, fuch as
burning of Pots and Pipes, Uc. into niy new Apartment in the Woods; where, after I had been feme
Time, I found, to my unfpeakable Confolation, a mere
natural Cave in the Earth, which went in a vait way,
and where, I dare fay, no Savage, had he been at the
Mouth of it, would be fo hardy as to venture in, nor
indeed would any Man elfe, but one who, like me, wanted nothing (o much as a fafe Retreat.
The Mouth of this Hollow was at the Bottom of a
great Rock, where, by mere Accident (I would fay,
it I did not fee abundant Reafon to afcribe all fucll things
now to Providence ) I was cutting down Ibme thick
Branches of Trees, to make Charcoal; And before-I go
on, I nmuf obferve the Reafon of my making this Charcoal, which was thus:
I was afraid of making a Smoak about my Habitation, as I faid before; and yet I could not live there
without baking my Bread, cooking my Meat, Cic. fo I
contrived to burn fome Wood here, as I had feen done
in England under Turf, till it became Chark, or dry
Coal; and then putting the Fire out, I preferv'd the
Coal to carry home, and& perform the other Services,
which Fire was wanting for, at home, without Danger
of Smoak.
But this by the by: While I was cutting down rome
Wood here, I perceived that behind a very thick
Branch of low Brufh-wood, or Under-wood, there was
a kind of hollow Place: I was curious to look into it,
and getting with Difficulty into the Mouth of it, I
found it was pretty large, that is to fay, fufficient for
me to ftand upright in it, and perhaps another with
nle; but I muff confefs to you, I made more hafe out
than I did in, when looking further into the Place,
which was perfe&ly dark, I law two broad Ihining Eyes
of fume Creature, whether Devil or Man, I knew not,
I                    which




( 170 ),,^liich twinkled like two Stars, the dim Light from the
Cave's Mouth Ihining dire&ly in, and making the ReP,fleaion.
However, after fome Paufe, I recovered my felf, and
began to call my felf a thoufand Fools, and tell my
felt, that he that was afraid to fee the Devil, was not
fit to live twenty Years in an Ifland all alone; and
that I durft to believe there was nothing in this Cave
that was more frightful than my felf: Upon this, plucking up my Courage, I took up a great Firebrand, and
in I rufh'd again, with the Stick flaming in my
Hand: I had not gone three Steps in, but I was almoft.as much fiighted as I was before; for I heard a very
loud Sigh, like that of a Man in tome Pain, and it was
followed by a broken Noile, as if of Words half exprels'd, and then a deep Sigh again: I flep'd back, and
was indeed ftruck with fuch a Surprize, that it put me
into a cold Sweat; and if I had had a Hat on my Head,
I will not anfwer for it, that my Hair might not have
lifted it off. But fill plucking up my Spirits as well
as I could, and encouraging my fetl a little, with cona
fidering that the Power and Prefence of God was every where, and was able to protee  me; upon this I
ilep'd forward again, and by the Light of the Firebrand, holding it up a little over my Head, I law ly-,
ing on the Ground a molf monilrous frightful old HeGoat, jual making his Will, as we ly, gafping for Life,
and dying indeed of meer old Age.
I ftir'd him a little, to Ifeeji I could get him out,
and he effay'd to get up, but was not able to raife himfelf; and I thought with my felft he might e'en lie
there; for if he had fiighted me fo, he would certainly
fright any of the Savages, if any of them Ihould be
fa hardy as to come in there, while he had any Lite
in him.
I was now recover'd from my Surprize, and began.to look round me, when I found the Cave was but
very finall, that is to fay, it might be about twelve
Foot over, but in no manner of Shape, either round or
quare, no Hands having ever been employed in mak'
ing it, but thofe of meer Nature.: I obferv'd alfo, that
there was a Place at the further Side of it that went in
furthber




( I7I )'
further, but was fo low, that it required me to creep
upon my Hands and Knees to go into if, and whether
it went I knew not; fo having no Candle, I gave it
over for ibme time, but refolved to come again thenext Day, provided with Candles, and a Tinder-Box,
which I had made of the Lock of one. of the Muskets,
with fome Wild-fire in the Pan.
Accordingly, the next Day I came provided with
fix large Candles of my own making, for I made very
good Candles now of Goat's Tallow; and going into
this low Place, I was obliged to creep upon all Fours,
as I have laid, almoft ten Yards; which, by the way,
I thought was a Venture bold enough, confidering
that I knew not how far it might go, or what was beyond it: When I was get thro' the Strait, I found the
Roof rofe higher up, I believe near twenty Foot; but
never was fuch a glorious Sight feen in the Ifland, I
dare fay, as it was, to look round the Sides and Roof
of this Vault or Cave: The Vt alls refle&ed a hundred
thoufand Lights to me from my two Candles; what it
was in the Rock, whether Diamonds, or any other precious Stones, or Gold, which I rather fhppolfd it to
be, I knew not.
The Place I was in, was a nlof delightful Cavity, or
Grotto, of its kind, as could be expected, tho' perfe&ly dark; the Floor was dry and level, and had a fort
off'mnll loofe Gravel upon it; bt that there was no
naufeous or venomons Creature to be feen, neither was
there any Damp or Wet on the Sides or Roof: The
only Difficulty in it was the Entrance, which, however,
as it was a Place of Security, and fich a Retreat as I
vwanted, I thought that was a Convenience; fo that I
was really rejoiced at the-Difcovery,' and refolved,
without any Delay, 'to bring fome of thofe things which
I was moft anxious about, to this Place; particularly,
I refolv'd to bring hither ny Magazine of Powder, and
all my fprye Arms, vi. Two Fowling-Pieces, (for I
had three in all ) and three MIlskets, (for of them I had
tight in all) lo I kept at my Caftle only five, which
ftood ready mounted, like Pieces of Cannon, on my
~ utmoft Fence; and were ready alfo to take out upon
any Expedition.
1 2                Upon




( I72 )
Upon this Occafion of removing my Ammunition;
I was oblig'd to open the Barrel of Powder which I
took up out of the Sea, and which had been wet; and
I found that the Water had penetrated about three or
four Inches into the Powder on every fide, which caking and growing hard, had preferved the Infide like a
Kernel in a Shell; fo that I had near fixty Pounds of
very good Powder in the Centre of the Cask; and this
was an agreeable Dilcovery to me at that time; fo I
carried all away thither, never keeping above two or
three Pounds ot Powder with me in my Cafle, for
fear of a Surprize of any kind: I alfo carried thither all
the Lead I had left for Bullets.
I fancied my felf now like one of the ancient Giants,
which were laid to live in Caves and Holes in tile
Rocks, where none could come at them; for I perfwaded my felf, while I was here, if five hundred
Savages were to hunt me, they could never find me
out; or if they did, they would not venture to attack
me here.
The old Goat, who I found expiring, died in the
Mouth of the Cave, the next Day after I made this
Difcovery; and I found it much eafier to dig a great
Hole there, and throw him in, and cover him with
Earth, than to drag him out: So I interr'd him there,
to prevent Offence to my Nofe.
I was now in my twenty-third Year of Refidence in
this I and, and was fo naturalized to the Place, and
to the Manner of living, that could I have but enjoyed
the Certainty, that no Savages would come to the
Place to dslturb me, I could have been content to
have capitulated for fpending the reft of myTime there,
even to the lafi Moment, till I had laid me down and
