died, like the old Goat in the Cave: I had alfo arriv'd to Ibme little Diverfionsand Amufements, which
nmade the Time pafs more pleafantly with me a great
deal than it did before; at firft, I had taught my Poll,
as I noted before, to fpeak; and he did it lb familiarly, and talk'd tb articulately and plain, that it was
very pleafant to me; and he lived with me no lels
than iix and twenty Years: How long he might live
afterwards, I know not; tho' I know they have a Notion




( 1I73   )
tion in the Brafils, that they live a hundred Years;
perhaps fome of my Pdlls may be alive there flill, calling
after Pt,or Robin Cruj>e to this Day; I wiih no En;gljhbman the ill Lu:k to come there and lear them, but if he
did, le would certainly believe it was the Devil. My
Dog was a very pleafant and loving Comlpanion to me
for no lets than fixteen Years of my Time, and then
died of-meer old Age; as for my Cats, they multiplyed, as I have obferved, to that degree, that I was obliged
to fhoot Ieveral of them at firil, to keep them from de.
vouring me and all I had; but at length, when the
two old ones I brought with me were gone, and after
fome time continually driving them from me, and letting them have no Provifion with me, they all ran
wild into the Woods, except two or three Favourites,
which I kept tame, and whofe Young, when they had
any, I always drown'd, and thefe were part of my
Family: Befides thefe, I always kept two or three
Houfhold Kids about me, which I taught to feed out
of my Hand; and I had alfo more Parrots, which
talk'd pretty well, and would all call Robin Crufoe, but
none like my firft; nor indeed, did I take the Pains
with any of them that I had done with him: I had allb
feveral tame Sea-Fowls, whofe Names I know nut,
which I caught upon the Shore, and cut their 'Wings;
and the little Stakes which I had planted before my Caftle-Wall, being now grown up to a good thick Grove,
thefe Fowls all lived among thefe low  Trees, and bred
there, which was very agreeable to me; lo that, as I
faid above, I began to be very well contented with the
Life I led, if it might but have been fecured from the
Dread of the Savages.
But it was otherwife dire6ted; and it may not be amifs for all People who fhall meet with my Story, to
make this jul Obfervation from it, vid. How frequently,
in the Courfe of our Lives, the Evil which in it felf
we feek mofi to fhun, and which, when we are fallen
into, is the moft dreadful to us, is oftentimes the very
means or door of our Deliverance, by which alone we
can be rais'd again from the Afflifion we are fallen into:
I could give many Examples of this in the Courfe of my.
Unaccountable Life; but in nothing was it more partiI 3              cularly




( I74    )
etlarlv re:ai-a;rdle than in the Circumnltances of my
lalt Years of iolitary Rciidence in this Ifand.
It was now the Month of December, as I faid above,
in my twenty-third Year; and this being the obuthern
Solice, for V, inter I cannot call it, was the particular
Time of my HEarveft, and required my being pretty
muAh abroad in the Fields; when going out pretty
early in the MIorning, even before it w-as thorow Daylight, I was furpriz'd with fecing a Light of fome Fire
upon the Shore, at a diftance tiom me, of about two
Miles, towards the end of'the Ifland, where I had obl
ferved fonie Savages had been, as before; but not on the
cther Side, but to my great Affliaion, it was on my
Side of the Ifland.
I was indeed terribly farpriz'd at the Sight, and flopt
aiort wvithin 1my Grove, not daring to go out left I
might be fitlrpri'd; and yet I had no more Peace within, trom my Apprehenfions I had, that if thefe Savages,
in rambling over the Ifland, fihotld find my Corn
fianding, or cut, or any of ny Works and Improvenients, they would immediately conclude, that there
were People in the Place, and would then never give
ever till they found me out: In this Extremity I went
back direc'ly to my Caftle, pull'd up the Ladder after
le, having made all things without look as wild andnatural as I could.
Then I prepared my felf within, putting my felf in
a Poflure of Defence; I loaded all my Cannon, as I
call'd them; ttb is to fqy, my Mluskets, which were
mounted upon my new Fortification, and all my Piftols
and refolv'd to defend my felf to the laft Gafp; not
forgetting ferioufly to commend my felf to the divine
Prote&ion, and earneftly to pray to God to deliver me
out of the Hands of tlhe Barbarians; and in this Pofture I continu'd about two Ho'rs, but began to be mighty impatient for Intelligence abroad, for I had ro Spiesto fend out.
After fitting a while longer, and mufing what f
fhould do in this Cafe, I was not able to bear fitting in
Jgnorance any longer; fb letting up my Ladder to the
fide of the Hill, where there was a flat Place, as I obferved before, and then ptlling the Ladder up afteIII,




( t75    )
nie, I iAt it up again, and mounted to the Top'of the HlIilI,
and pulling out my Perfpe6eive-Glalh, which I had taken on purpofe, I laid me down flat on nmy Belly on
the Ground, and began to look for the Place: I prefently found there were no leTs than nine naked Savages
fitting round a fnlall Fire, they had made; not to wjrm
them, for they had no need of that, the Weather being
extream hot; but, as I fuppos'd, to drefs iome of their
barbarous Diet of human Flefh, which they    had
brought with them, whether alive or dead, I could not
know.
They had two Canoes with them, which they had
haled up upon the Shore; and as it was then Tide of
Ebb, they feem'd to me to wait for the Return of the
Flood, to go away again; it is nor eafy to imagine
what Confuiion this Sight put me into, efpecially feeing them come on my fide the Ifland, and fo near me
too; but when I obferv'd their coming muft be always with the Current of the Ebb, I began afterwards
to lIe more fedate in my Mind, being fatisfy'd that I
might go abroad with fafety all the Time of the Tide
of Flood, if they were not on Shore before; And having made this Oblfrvation, I went abroad about nmy
Iarveft-Work with the more Compofure.
As I expeCsd, fo it proved, for as foon as the Tide
made to the Weftward, I law them all take Boat; and
row (or paddle, as we call it) all away: I fhould have
obferv'd, that for an Hour and more before they went
off, they went to dancing, and I could eafily difcern
their Poflures and Geftures by my Glaffes: I could not
perceive, by my niceft Obfervation, but that they were
flark naked, and had- not the leaft Covering upon threm
but whether they were Men or Women, that I could
not diflinguifh.
As foon as I faw them fhip'd and gone, I took two
Guns upon my Shoulders, and two lPiflols at my Gir.
dle, and my great Sword by my fide, without a Scablard, and with all the Speed I was able to make, I
went away to the Hill, where I had difcover'd the firit
Appearance of all; As foon as I got thither, which
was not lefs than two Hours, (for I could not go apace
being fo loaden with Arms as I was) I perceiv'd there
I 4                had




(   76)
had been three Canoes more of Savages on that Place }
and looking out further, I faw they were all at Sea-together, making over for the Main.
This was a dreadful Sight to me, efpecially when
going down to the Shore, I could fee the Marks of
Horror which the difmal Work they had been about had
left behind it, vi. the Blood, the Bones, and Part of
the Flefli of human Bodies, eaten and devoured by
thofe Wretqhes, with Merriment and Sport; I was fo
filid with Indignation at the Sight, that I began now
to premeditate tile DeflrlUtion of the next that I law
there, let them be who or how many Ibever.
It fieem'd evident to me, that the Vifits which they
thus made to this lfland, were not very frequent; for it
was above fifteen Months before any more of them
came on Shore there again; that is tofay, I never law
them, or any Footfteps, or Signals of them, in all that
Time; for as to the rainy Sealbns, then they are lure
not to come abroad, at leaft not ib far; yet all this
while I lived unc:mfortably, by reafon of the conflant
A pprehenfions I was in of their coming upon me by
furprize-; from whence I obferve, that the Expe&fation
of Evil is more bitter than the Suffering, efpecially
if there is no room to flake off that Expeaation, or
thofe Apprehenfions.
During all this time, I was in the murthering Humour; and took up moil of my Hours, which Ihould
have been better em'ployed,in contriving how to circumvent and fall upon them the very next time I fllould fee
them; efpecially if they fiould be divided, as they
were the lalf time, into two Parties; nor did I confider at all, that if I kil'd one Party, fitppofe ten or a
dozen, I was ftill the next Day, or Week, or Month,
to kill another, and fb, another, even ad ininitum, till
I thould be at length no leTs a Murtherer than they
were in being Man-eaters, and perhaps much more
fo.
I fpent my Days now in great Perplexity and Anxiety of Mind, expe&ing that I fhould one Day or other fallinto the Hands of thefe mercilefs Creatures;
if I did at any time venture abroad, it was not
without looking round me with the greateft Care and
Caution




( 177 )
Caution imaginable; and now I found to my great
Comfort, how happy it was that I had provided for a
tame Flock or Herd of Goats; for I durft not upon any
account fire my Gun, efpecially near that fide of the
Ifland where they ufually came, left I fhould alarm the
Savages; and if they had fled from me now, I was fure
to have them come back again, with perhaps two or
three hundred Canoes with them  in a few Days, and
then I knew what to expe&t.
However, I wore out a Year and three Months more,
before I ever faw any more of the S avages, and then
I found them again, as I ihall loon obferve: It is true,
they might have been there once or twice; but either
they made no Stay,, or at leaft, I did not hear them;
but in the Month of May, as near as I could calculate,
and in my four and twentieth Year, I had a very ftrange
Encounter with them, of which in its Place.
The Perturbation of my Mind, during this fifteen or
fixteen Months Interval, was very great; I flept unquiet, dreamt always frightful Dreams, and often ftarted out of my Sleep in the Night: In the Day great
Troubles overwhelmed myMind, in the Night I dreamt
often of killing the Savages, and the Reafons why I
might juftify the doing of it: But to wave all this for a
while; it was in the middle of May, on the fixteentll
Day I think, as well as my poor wooden Calendar
would reckon; for I mark'd all upon the Poft flill; I
lay, it was on the fixteenth of May, that it blew a very
great Storm of Wind, all Day, with a great deal of
Lightning and Thunder, and a very foul Night it was
after it: I know not what was the particular occafion
of it; but as I was reading in the Bible, and taken up
with ferious Thoughts about my prefent Condition, [
was furpriz'd with the Noife of a Gun, as I thought,
fiy'd at Sea.
This was to be fure a Surprize of a quite different
Nature from any I had met with before; for the Notions this put into my Thoughts were quite of another
kind: I ftarted up in the greateft Haite imaginable
and in a trice clapt my Ladder to the middle Place of
the Rock, and pulled it after me, and mounting it the
Sicond Time, got to the Top of the Hill; that very Mo.
5                  menr




( T78    )
trent a Flafhi of Fire bid me liften for a fecond Gutrr
which accordingly, in about halt' a Minute, I heard,
and by the Sound knew that it was from that Part of
the Sea where I was driven out with the Current in
13cat.
I immediately confider'd that this muft be fome Ship
in Diftrefs, and that they had fome Comrade, or fome
other Ship in Company, and fir'd thefe Guns for Sig7
nals of Diftr.efs, and to obtain Help: I had this Preience of Mind at that Minute, as to think, that tho'
I could not help them, it may be they might help me;
fo I brought together all the dry Wood I could get at;
hand, and making a good handfome Pile, I let it on
Fire upon the Hill; the Wood was dry, and blaz'd freely, and tho' the Wind blew very hard, yet it burnt
fairly out, fo that I was certain, if there was any fuch
Thing as a Ship, they nmul needs fee it, and no doubt
they did, for as foon as ever my Fire blaz'd up, I heard
another Gun, and after that feveral others, all from the
fame Quarter: I ply'd my Fire all Night long, till
Day broke; and when it was broad Day, and the Air
clear'd up, I faw fomnething at a great Diflance at Sea,
full EaJt of the Ifland, whether a Sail, or a Hull, I
could not diflinguifl, no not with my Glaffes, the
Diflance was fo great, and the Weather Dtill fomething
hazy alfo; at leait it was Co out at Sea.
I look'd frequently at it all that Day, and foon perceiv'd that it di4 not move; fo I prefently concluded
that it was a Ship at an Anchor; and being eager, you
may be fure, to be fatisfy'd, I took my Gun in my
Hand, and ran toward the So&tbh Eafl Side of the Ifland,
to the Rocks where I had formerly been ca ry'd away
with the Current, and getting up there, the 'Weather
by this Time being perfealy clear, I could plainly lee,
to my great Sorrow, the Wreck of a Ship caft away
in the Night upon thofe concealed Rocks which I found
wvhe I was out in my Boat; and which Rocks, as they
check'd the Violence of the Stream, and made a kind
of Gounter-Stream or Eddy, were the Occafion of my
recovering then from the moft defperate hopelefs Condition that ever I had been in i all y Life.
Thus




Thus, what is one Man's Safety, is another Man's
Defirution; for it feems thefe Men, whoever they
were, being out of their Knowledge, and the Rocks being wholly under Water, had been driven upon them
in the Night, the Wind blowing hard at E. and E.N.E.
Had they feen the I fland, as I mufll neceffarily fuppofe
they did not, they mufd, as I thought, have endeavour'd to have fav'd themfelves on Shore by the Help
of' their Boat; but their firing off Guns for Hdp, efpecially when they 1aw, as I imagin'd, my Fire, fillede
me with many Thoughts: Firft I imagin'd, that upon
feeing my Light, they might have put themfelves into
their Boat, and have endeavour'd to make the Shore,
but that the Sea going very high, they might have
been caft away; other times I imagin'd, that they
might have loft their Boat before, as might be the
Cafe many ways; as particularly, by the breaking of
the Sea upon their Ship, which many times obliges
Men to flave, or take in pieces their Boat; and tometimes to throw it over Board with their own- Hands:
Other times I imagin'd, they had t'om other Ship or
Ships in Cotnpany, who, upon the Signals of Diflrefs
they had made, had taken them up and carried them
off: Other whiles I fancied, they were all gone off to
Sea in their Boat, and being hurried away by the
Current that I had been formerly in, were carry'd out
into the great Ocean where there was nothing but Mir
fery and Periffihing; and that perhaps. they might by
this Time think of ftarving, and of being in a Condition to eat one another.
As all thefe were but Conjedeures at bell, fo in the
Condition I was in, I could do no more than look on
upon the Milery of the poor Men, and pity them;
which had ftill this good Effe& on my $ide, that it
ga ve me more and more Caufe to give Thanks to
Cod, who had fo happily and comfortably provided
for me in my defolate Condition and that of two Ships
Cqnmpnpies who were now caft away upon this Part
of the World, not one Life fhould be fpar'd but mine;:
I learnt here again to obtbrve, that it is very rare that
the Providence of God cafts us into any Condition of
Lite fo low, or any Mifery fo grear but we may fee
r *    "    ".                             fOtW



( iSo )fomething or other to be thankful for; and may fee o'
thers in worfe Circumfiances than our own.
Such certainly was the Cafe of thefe Men, of whom
I could not fo much as fee Room to fuppofe any of
them were fav'd; nothing could make it rational, fo
much as to wifl or expeft that they did not all perill
there, except the Poffibility only of their being taken
up by another Ship in Company: And this was but
mere Poffibility indeed; for I faw not the leaft Signal
or Appearance of any fitch Thing.
I cannot explain, by any poffible Energy of Words,
what a ifrange Longing or Hankering of Defires I felt
in my Soul upon this Sight; breaking out fometimes
thus: O that there had been but one or two, nay, or
but one Soul fav'd out of the Ship, to have efcap'd to
me, that I might but have had one Companion, one
iellow-Creature to have fpoken to me, and to have
convers'd with! In all the Time of my folitary Life,
I never felt fo earneft, to ftrong a Defire after the Society of my Fellow-Creatures, or tb deep a Regret at
the Want of it.
There are tome fecret moving Springs in the Affections, wfiich, when they are let a-going by fome Obje& in View, or be it fome Object, though not in View,
yet render'd prefent to the Mind by the Power of Imagination, that Motion carries out the Soul by its Imp)tuofity to fu-h violent, eager Embracings of the Objet, that the Abience of it is infupportable.
Such were there earnet Wifhings, That but one Man
had blen fav'd! 0 that it had been but One! I believe
I repeated the Words, 0 that it had been but One! a
thoufand times; and the Defires were fo nlov'd by it,
that when I fpoke the Words, my Hands would clinch
together, and my Fingers prefs the Palms of my Hands,
that if I had had any loft Thing in my Hand, it wouold
have crulfh'd it involuntary; and my Teeth in my Head
would ftrike together, and fet againft one another fo
firong, that for fome time I could not patt them
again.
Let the Naturalifts explain thefe Things, and the
Reafon and Manner of them; all I can fay of them, is,
to defcribe the Fa&, which was eyes furprizing to me
when




( i8I )
when I found it, tho' I knew not from what it flouldc
proceed; it was doubtlefs the Effeft of ardent Withes,
and of firong Ideas form'd in my Mind, realizing the
Comfort which the Converfation of one of my FellowChriftians would have been to me.
But it was not to be; either their Fate, or mine, or
both, forbid it; for till the laf Year of my being on
this lfWand, I never knew, whether any were fav'd out
of that Ship or no; and had only the Affliiion folne
Days after, to fee the Corps of a drown'd Boy come
on Shore, at the End of the Ifland, which was next
the Shipwreck: He had on no Cloaths, but a Seaman's
Waftcoat, a Pair of open knee'd Linnen Drawers, and
a blue Linnen Shirt; but nothing to dire& me fo much
as to guefs what Nation he was of: He had nothing in
his Pocket but two Pieces of Eight and a TobaccoPipe; the laft was to me of ten times more Value than
the firft.
It was now calm, and I had a great Mind to venture
out in my Boat to this Wreck; not doubting but I
might find fomething on Board, that might be uf{tul
to ma; but that did not altogether prefs me fo much,
as the Poflibility that there might be yet fome living
Creature on Board, whole Life I might not only fave,
but might, by faving that Life, comfort my own' to
the laft Degree; and this Thought clung fo to nW
Heart, that I could not be quiet, Night or Day, but
I mull venture out in my Boat on Board this Wreck;
and committing the reft to God's Providence, I thought
the Impreffion was fo firong upon my Mind, that it
could not be refilled, that it muft come from fome vifible Dire&fion, and that I fhould be wanting to my
felf, it I did not go.
Under thePower of this Impreffion, I haften'd back
to my Caftle, prepar'd every Thing for my Voyage,
took a Quantity of Bread, a great Pot for frefil Water, a Compafs to fleer by, a Bottle of Rum, ( for I had
ftill a great deal of that left) a Basket'full ofRaifins:
And thus loading my felf with every thing neceffary, I
went down to my Boat, got the Water out of her, and
got her afloat, loaded all my Cargo in her, and then
went Home again for more; My fecond Cargo was a
great




( I82.  )
great Bag full of Rice, the Umbrella to fet up over nmy
Hlead for Shade, another large Pot full of frefh Water,
and about two Dozen of my fmall Loaves, or Barley
Cakes, more than before, with a Bottle of Goat's Milk,
and a Cheefe; all which, with great Labour and Sweat,
I brouight to my Boat, and praying to God to direA
my Voyage,. I put out, and rowing or paddling the.
Canoe along the Shore, I came at lalt to the utnoft
Point of the Ifland, on that Side, ( vi. ) N. E. And
now I was to lunch out into the Ocean, and either
to venture, or not to venture; I look'd on the rapid.
Currents which ran conftantly on both Sides of theIffand, at a Diftance, and which were very terrible to
me, from the Remembrance of the Hazard I had been
in before, and my Heart began to fail me; for I forefaw that if I was driven into either of thofe Currents,
I ihould be carried a vaft Way out to Sea, and perhaps
out of my Reach, or Sight of the Ifland again; and that
then, as my Boat was but fmall, if any little Gale of
Wind fhould rife, I fhould be inevitably loft.
Thefe Thoughts fo opprefs'd mv vlind, that I began to give over my Enterprize, and having haled my
Boat into a little Creek on the Shore, I ftept out, and
fat me down upon a little rifing hit of Ground, very
penfive and anxious, between Fear and Deiire about
my Voyage; when, as I was mufing, I could perceive
that the Tide was turn'd and the Flood came on, Upon
which my going was for fo many Hours impral&icable: Upon this prefently it occur'd to me, that I
ihould go up tothe higheil Piece of Ground I coulc
find, and obterve, if I could, how the Sets of the Tide
or Currents lay, when the Flood came in, that I might
judge whether, if I was driven one Way out, I might
not expe& to be driven another Way home, with the
fame -Rapidnefs of the Currents:, This Thought was Po
fooner it my Head, but I caft my Eye upon a little
Hill, which fuificiently overlook'd the Sea both ways}
and: from whence I had a clear View of the.Currents,
or Sets of the Ti4e, and which Way I was to. guide
my felf in my Return: Here I found, that as the Curl
rent of the Ebb fet out clofe by the South Point of the
lAd,Mn, fo te  r w urent io tl^-l! o.d f in4 clofe by tl~s:                                           hort




'(   83 ))
fcre of the North Side, and that I had nothing. to do
Ibut to keep to the North of the Inland in my Return,
and I fiould do well enough.
Encourag'd with this Oblervation, I refolv'd the next
Morning to fet out with the firft of the Tide; and repofing my felf for that Night in the Canoe, under the
great Watch-Coat I mention'd, I launch'd out: I made
ihrf a little out to Sea full North, till I began to feel
the Benefit of the Current, which fet Eaftward, and
which carried me at a great Rate, and yet did not fo
hurry me as the Southern Side Current had done before,
and fo as to take from me all Government of the Boat;
but having a frong Steerage with my Paddle, I went,
Jjay, at a great Rate, dire&ly for the Wreck, and in lets
than two Hours I came up to it.
It was a difmal Sight to look at: The Ship, which
by its Building was spanijh, (tuck faft, jaum'd in between two Rocks; all the Stern and Quarter of her was
beaten to Pieces with the Sea; and as her Forecatle,
which {luck in the Rocks, had run on with great Violence, her Mainmaft and Foremaft were brought by the
Board, that is to fay, broken fhort off;, but her Boltfprit was found, and the Head and Bow appear'd firm:
When I came clofe to her, a Dog appear'd upon her,
who feeing me coming, yelp'd and cry'd, and as Loon
as I call'd him, jump'd into the Sea, to come to me,
and I took him into the Boat, but found him almoft
dead for Hunger and Thirft: I gave him a Cake of
my Bread, and he eat it like a ravenous Wolf, that had
been flarving a Fortnight in the Snow: I then gave the
poor Creature fome freth Water, with which, ifIl would
have let him, he would have burft himfelf.
After this I went on Board; The firft Sight I
met with, was two Men drown'd! the Cook-Room,
or Forecaftle of the Ship, with their Arms fadl about
one another: I concluded, as is indeed probable, that
when the Ship truck, it being in a Storm, the Sea
broke lo high, and fo continually over her, that the
Men were not able to bear it, and were ftrangled with
the conflant rufhing in of the Water, as much asif they
had been under Water: Befides the Dog, there was
nothing left in the Ship that had Life, nor any Goods
that




( 184 )
that I could fee, but what were fpoil'd by the Water
There were fome Casks of Liquor, whether Wine or
Brandy, I knew not, which lay lower in the Hold, and
which, the Water being ebb'd out, I could fee, but
they were too big to meddle with: I faw feveral Chefts,
which I believ'd belong'd to fome of the Seamen, and
I got two of them into the Boat, without examining
what was in them.
Had the Stern of the Ship been fix'd, and the Forepart broken off, I am peritaded I might have made a
good Voyage; for by what I found in thefe two Chefis,
I had room to fuppofe the Ship had a great deal of
Wealth on Board; and if I may guefs by the Courfe
fhe fleer'd, Ihe mull have been bound from the Buenos
Aires, or the Rio de la iPlata, in the South-Part of America, beyond the Brafils, to the Havana, in the Gulph
of Mexico, and fo perhaps to Spain: She had, no doubt,
a great Treafiire in her, but of'no Ufe at that time to
any Body; and what became of the reft of her People,
I then knew not.
I found, befides there Chefts, a little Cask full of
Liquor, of about twenty Gallons, which I got into my
Boat, with much Difficulty: There were feveral Muskets in a Cabbin, and a great Powder-Horn, with about four Pounds of Powder in it; as for the Muskets, I
had no occafion for them, fo I left them, but took the
Powder-Horn: I took a Fire-fhovel and Tongs, which
I wanted extremely; as alfo two little Brafs-Kettles, a
Copper-Pot to make Chocolate, and a Gridiron; and
with this Cargo, and the Dog, I came away, the Tide
beginning to make home again; and the fame Eve.
ning. about an Hour within Night, I reach'd the Ifland
again, weary and fatigu'd to the laft Degree.
I repos'd that Night in the Boat, and in the Morning I refolv'd to harbour what I had gotten in my new
Cave, not to carry it home to my CatIle: After refreihing my felf, I got all my Cargo on Shore, and began to examine the Particulars: The Cask of Liquor I
found to be a kind of Rum, but not fuch as we had at
the Brafils; and in a Word, not at all good; but when
I came to open the Chefts, I found feveral things of
great Ufe to me: For Example, I found in one a fine
Cafe




(,85 )
Care of Bottles, of an extraordinary kind, and fill'&
with. Cordial Waters, fine, and very good; the Botties held about three Pints each, and were tip'd with
Silver: I found two Pots of very good Succades, or
Sweetmeats, fo faften'd alto on Top, that the falt Water had not hurt them; and two more of the fame,
which the Water had fpoil'd: I found fome very good
Shirts, which were very welcome to me, and about a
dozen and a half'of Linnen white Handkerchiefs, and
colour'd Neckcloths; the former were alfo very welcome, being exceeding refilefhing to wipe my Face in a
hot Day; betides this, when I came to the Till in the
Chefls, I found there three great Bags of Pieces of Eight,
which held about eleven hundred Pieces in all; and in
one of them, wrapt up in a Paper, fix Doubloons of
Gold, and fonte fiuall Bars or Wedges of Gold; I fuppofe they might all weigh near a Pound.
The other Chefl I found had fome Cloaths in it, but
of little Value; but by the Circumtfances it muff have
belong'd to the Gunner's Mate, tho' there was ro Powder in it, but about two Pounds offine glaz'd Powder,
in the three finall Flasks, kept, I. fuppofe, for charge
ing their Fowling-pieces on occafion: Upon thewhole,
I got very little by this Voyage, that was of any ufl
to nme; for as to the Money, I had no manner of occalion for it; 'twas to me as the Dirt under my Feet; and
I would have given it all for three or four Pair of
EngliJb Shoes and Stockings, which were things I greatly wanted, but had not had on my Feet now tor many
Years: I had, indeed, gotten two Pair of Shoes now,
which I took off of the Feet of the two drown'd Men,
who I faw in the Wreck; and I found two Pair more
in one of the Chefis, which were very welcome to me;
but they were not like our Englijh Shoes, either for
Eafe or Service, being rather what we call Pumps than
Shoes: I found in this Seaman's Cheff about fifty
Pieces of Eight in Royals, but no Gold; I fuppofe this
belong'd to a poorer Man than the other, which feem'dl
to belong to fome Officer.
Well, however, I lugged this Money home to my
Cave, and laid it up, as I had done that before, which
1 brought from our own Ship; lnt it i was great Pity,
** ~~ '




(   86)
4 I faid, that thb other Part of this Ship had not come
to my Share, for I am fatisfied I might have loaded my
Camoe feveral times over with Money, which, if I had
ever efcap'd to England, would have lain here fafe
enough till I might have come again and fetch'd it.
Having now brought all my Things on Shore, and
fecur'dthem, I went back to my Boat, and row'd or
paddled her along the Shore to her old Harbour, where
I laid her up, and made the beft of my Way to my
old Habitation, where I found every Thing fare and
quiet; fo I began to repofe myfelf, live after my old
}afilion, and take care of my Family Affairs; and for
a while I lived eafy enough; only that I -was more vigilant than I us'd to be, look'd out oftner, and did not
go abroad fo much; and if at any time I did flir with
any Freedom, it was always to the Eaft Part of the
lfland, where I w:as pretty well Iatisfy'd the Savages
never came, and where I could go without fo many
Precautions, and fuch a Load of Arms and Ammunition,
as I always carry'd with me, if I went the other Way.
I liv'd in this Condition near two Years more; but
my unlucky Head, that was always.to let me know it
W as born to make my Body miferale, was all thofe two
Years fill'd with Projeas, and Defigns how, if it were
| poffible, i might get away from this Ifland'; forf iome
times I was for making another Voyage to the Wreck,
tho' my Reafon told me that there was nothing left there
worth the Hazard of- my Voyage: Sometimes for a
Ramble one way, fometimes another; and I believe verily, if I had had the Boat that I went from Salee iw:
I fliould have ventur'd to Sea, bound any where, I
knew not whether.
I have been, in all my Circumftanees, a- Memento
to thofe who are totch'd with that general Plague of
Mankind, whence, for ought I know, one halfof their
Miferies flow; i mean, that of not being fatisfy'd with
the Station wherein God and Nature hath plac'd them;
for not to look back. upon my primitive Condition, and
the excellent Advice of my Father, the Oppofition to
which was, as I may call it, my Original Sin, my lubfequent Mifakes of the fame kind had been the means of
mny coininito this niiferable Condition  for had that
*,'Pro,




( 187 )
Providence, which ib happily had feated me at the Brafits, as a Planter, blefs'd me with confin'd Defires, and I
could have been contented to have gone on gradually,
I might have been by this Time, 1 meanin the Time
of sy being in tLis JIland, one of the moil confiderable
Planters in the Brafls; nay, I am  perfuaded, that by
the Improvements I had made in that little time I liv'd
there, and the Encreafe I fhould probably have made,
if I had ftay'd, I might have been worth an hundred
tboufand loydores; and what Bufinefs had I to leave
a fettled Fortune, a well-flock'd Plantation, improving and increafing, to turn Supra Cargo to Guinea, to
fetch Negroes, when Patience and Time would have
fo encreas'd our Stock at Home, that we could have
bought them at our own Door, from thofe whofe Buinels it was to fetch them? And though it had coil us
fonething more, yet the Diference of that Price was
by no Meanls worth faving at fo great a Hazard.
But as this is ordinarily the Fate of young Heads,
fo Refleaion upon the Folly of it, is as ordinarily the
Exercife of more Years, or of the dear-bcught Experience of Time; and fo it was with me now; and yet
fo deep had the Mitfake taken Root in my Temper,
that I could not fatisfy my felf in my Station, but was
continually poring upon the Means and Poflibility of
my Efcape from this Place; and that I may with the
greater Pleafire to the Reader bring on the remaining
Part of my Story, it may not be improper to give fome
Account of my firft Conceptions on the Subjet of this
foolilh Scheme for my Efcape and how, and upon what
Foundation I aCted.
I am now to be fuppos'd retir'd into my Caftle,
after my late Voyage to the Wreck, my Frigate laid
up, and fecur'd under Water as ufual, and ny Condition reflor'd to what it was before: I had more Wealth,
indeed, than I had before, but was not at all the richer,
for I had no more Ufe for it, than the Indians of Peru
had beforethe Spaniards came there.
It was- olle of the Nights, in the rainy Seafon in
March, the four and twentieth Year of my firft fetting
Foot in this Ifland of Solitarinefs, I was lyingin my
Bed, or Hammock, awake, very well in Health, ha&
no




( i88 )
no Pain, no Diftemper, no Uneafiefs ofBody, no, nor anyUneafinefs of Mind,more than ordinary; but could by
no means clofe my Eyes; that is, fo as to fleep; no,
not a Wink all Night long, otherwife than as follows':
It is as impoffible as needlefs, to fet down the innumerable Crowvd of Thoughts that whirl'd through that
great Thorowfair of the Brain, the Memory, in this
Night's Time:    run over the whole Hiftory oi my
Lite in Miniature, or by Abridgment, as I may call it,
to my coming to this Iland; and allb of that Part of
my Life fince I came to this IWland; in ny Refleftions
upon the State of my Cafe, fince I came on Shore on
this Ifland, I was comparing the happy Pofture of my
Afzairs, in the firft Years of my Habitation here, compar'd to the Life of Anxiety, Fear, and Care, which I
had liv'd in ever fince I had feen the Print of a Foot
in the Sand; not that I did not believe the Savages
bad frequented the Ifland even all the while, and might
have been feveral Hundreds of them at Times on Shore
there; but as I had never known it, and was incapable
of any A pprehenfions about it; my Satisfa&ion was perfe&, tho' my Danger was the fame; and I was as happy
in not knowing my Danger, as if I had never really been
expos'd to it; this furnifh'd my Thoughts with many
very profitable Refle6tions, and particularly this one,
how infinitely good that Providence is, which has provided in its Government of Mankind fuch narrow
Bounds to his Sight and Knowledge of Things; and tho'
he walks in the midft of fo many thoufand Dangers,
the Sight of which, if difcover'd to him, would diftraa his Mind, and fink his Spirits, he is kept ferene
and calm, by having the Events of Things hid from
his Eyes, and knowing nothing of the Dangers, which
furround him,
After there Thoughts had for fome Time entertained
me, I came to refle&t erioufly upon the real Danger I
had been in for fo many Years in this very Ifland; and
how I had walk'd about in the greateft Security, and
with all poflible Tranquillity, even when perhaps nothing but a Brow of a Hill, a great Tree, or the cafual
Approach of Night, had been between me and the worft
kind of Detrution, viy. That of falling into the Hands
ot




( I89 )
of Canibals and Savages, who would have feiz'd on mi
with the fame View, as I did of a Goat or a Turtle,
and have thought it no more a Crime to kill and devour me, than I did of a Pidgeoni or a Curlieu; I
fhould unjuilly flader my felt, if I flould fay I was
not fincerely thankful to my great Preferver, to whofe
fingular Prote&ion I acknowledged, with great Humi.
lity, that all thefe unknown Deliverances were due;
and without which I ihould inevitably have fallen into
their mercilefs Hands.
When thefe hlloughts were over, my Head was for
fonle time taken up in confidering the Nature ofthefe
wretched Creatures, I mean, the Savages; and how it
came to pafs in the World, that the wife Governour of
all Things fhould give up any of his Creatures to fuch
Inhumanity; nay, to iomething fo much below even
Brutality it felf, as to devour its own Kind: But as
this ended in fome (at that Time fruitlets) Specula.
tions, it occur'd to me to enquire, what Part of the
World thefe Wretches liv'd in; how far off the Coaft
was from whence they came; what they ventur'd over
fo far from Home for; what kind of'Boats they had;
and why I might not order my fel, and my Bufinefs
lo, that I might be as able to go over thither, as they
were to come to me.
I never fo much as troubled my felf to confider what
I fhould do with my felt when I came thither; what
Ihould become of me, if I fell into the Hauds of the
Savages; or how I fliould efcape froln them, if they
attempted me; no, nor fo much as how it was poflible for me to reach the Coaft, and not be attempted by
fome or other of them, without any Poffibility of
delivering nly felf; and if I fhould not fall into their
Hands, what I fhould do for Provifion, or whither
I fhould bend my Courfe; none of' there Thoughts,
I fay,'to much as came in my Way; but my Mind
was wholly bent upon the Notion of my pafling
over in my Boat to the main Land: I look'd back
upon my prefent Condition, as the moft miferable that
could pofibly be; that I was not able to throw myfelf
into any thing but Death that could be call'd worfe;
that




that if'I reach'd the Shore of the Main, I might;
perhaps, meet with Relief, or I might coaff along, as
I did on the Shore of Arick, 'till I came to fonie inhabited Country, and where I might find.ome Relief;
and after all, perhaps I might iall in with fome ChriIlian Ship that might take me in; and if the worit
came to the worif, I could but die, which would put
an End to all thtfe Miferiesat once: Pray Note, All
this wasthe Fruit of a difturb'd Mind, an impatient
Temper, made as it were defperate by the long Continuance of my Troubles, and the Difappointments I had
met in the Wreck I had been on board of, and where
I had been fo near the obtaining what I fo earneflly
long'd for, viO. fome Body to fpeak to, and to learn
fome Knowledg from, of the Place where I was, and
of the probable Means of my Deliverance; I fay, I
was agitated wholly by thefe Thoughts: All my Calm
of Mind in my Refignation to Providence, and waiting the Iffue of the Difpofitions of Heaven, feem'd to
be fufpended, and I had, as it were, no Power to
turn my Thoughts to any Thing, but the Proje& of a
Voyage to the Main, which came upon me with fuch
Force, and fuch an Impetuofity of Defire, that it was
not to be refifted.
When this had agitated my Thoughts for two Hours,
or more, with fach Violence, that it fet my very Blood
into a Ferment, and my Pulfe beat as.high as if I had
been in a Fever, merely with the extraordinary Fervour of my Mind about it Nature, as if I had been
fatigu'd and exhaulted with the very Thought of it,
threw me into a found Sleep: One would have thought
I lhould have dreamt of it; but I did not, nor of any
thing relating to it; but I dreamt, that as I was going
out in the Morning, as ufual, from  my Caftle, I faw
upon the Shore two Canoes, and eleven Savages coming
to Land, and that they brought with them another Savage, who -they were going to kill, in order to eat him;
whten, on a fudden, the Savage, that they were going
to kill, jump'd away, and ran for his Life; then I
thought in my Sleep, that he came running into my
-little thick Grove, betfre my Fortification, to hide
hiimtelf and -thatl feeing him alone, and not perceivazz




( '9'.nfg that the other fought him that way, flietwd my e
to him, and fmiling upon him, encourag'd him: That
he kneel'd down to me, teeming to pray me to affift
him; upon which I fhew'd my Ladder, made him go
up, and carried him into my Cave, and he became
my Servant; and that as foon as I had gotten this Man,
I laid to my felf, Now I may certainly venture to the
Main Land; for this Fellow will ferve me as a Pilot,
and will tell me what to do, and whither to go fbr
Provifions; and whether not to go for fear of being
devoured, what Places to venture into, and what to
efcape. I wak'd with this Thought, and was under
fuch inexpreffible Imprefiions of Joy at the Proflpe& of
my Efcape in my Dream, that the Difappointments
which I felt upon coming to my fel; and finding it
was no more than a Dream, were equally extravagant
the other way, and threw me into a very great Dcjection of Spirit.
Upon this, however, I made this Conclufion, That
my only way to go about an Attempt for an Efcape,
was, if poffible, to get a Savage into my Poffeilion;
and, if poffible, it ihould be one of their Prifoners,
whom they had condemn'd to be eaten, and ihould
bring thither to kill; but thefe Thoughts frill were
'attended with this Difficulty, that it was iinpoffible
to effe& this without attacking a whole Caravan of
them, and killing them all; and this was not only a
very defperate Attempt, and might mifcarry; but, on
the other hand, I had 'greatly fcrupl'd the Lawtulnefs of
it to me, and my Heart trembled at the Thoughts of
fhedding fo much Blood, tho' it was for my Deliverance. - mneed not repeat the Arguments which occur'd
-to me againil this, they being the iame mention'd before: But tho' I had other Reafons to offer 'now, vit.
That thofe Men were Enemies to my Life, and would
devour me, if' they could, that it was Self-prefervation in the highelt Degree, to deliver my felf from this
Death of a Life, and was a5ting in my own Defence, as
much as if they were a&ually affaulting me, and the
like: I fay, tho' there things argued for it, yet the
Thoughts of' fhedding human Blood for my Deliverance, were very terrible to me, and fuch as could by
no Mleans reconcile my felf to a great while.  How



R' owever, at lafd, after many fecret'Difputes witl
myfelf, and after great Perplexities about it, (for all
thefe Arguments, one way and another, ftruggled in
my Head a long time) the eager prevailing Delire
of Deliverance at length mafter'd all the reft, and I refolv'd, if potfible, to get one of thefe Savages into my
Hands, coft what it would: My next thing then was
to contrive how to do it; and this indeed was very
difficult to refblve on; But as I could pitch upon lo
probable Means for it, fo I refolv'd to put myfelf upon
the Watch, to fee them when they came on Shore, and
leave the reft to the Event, taking fuch Meafures as the
Opportunity fliould prefent, let be what would be.
With theie Refolutions in my Thoughts, I fet myfelf
upon the Scout, as often as poffible, and indeed to often
till I was heartily tired of it; for it was above a Year
and a half that I waited, and for great Part of that Time
'went out to the Weft-End, and to the South-Weft Corner of the Ifland almoft every Day, to fee for Canoes,
but none appear'd: This was very difcouraging, and
began to trouble me much; tho' I can't fay that it did
in this Cafe as it had done Come time before that, vit.
wear off the Edge of my Defire to the thing,.but the
longer it feem'd to be delay 'd, the more eager I was for
it: In a Word, I was not at firft more careful to fhun the
Sight of thefe Savages, and avoid being feen by them,
than I was now eager to be upon them.
Betides, I fancied myfelf able to manage one, nay,
two or three Savages, if I had them, fo as to make them: entirely Slaves to me, to do whatever I fhould dire&
them, and to prevent their being able at any time to do
me any Hurt: It was a great while that I pleas'dmyfelf with this Affair; but nothing ftill prefented; all
my Fancies and Schemes came to nothing, for no Savages came near me for a great while.
About a Year and half after I had entertain'd thefe
Notions, and, by long muting, had as it were refolv'd
them all into nothing, for want of an Occafion to put
them in Execution, 1 was furpriz'd one Morning early,
with feeing no lefs than five Canoes all on Shore together on my Side the Ifland, and the People who belong'd to them all landed, ard out of my Sight: The
Num



(   93   )
Number of them broke all my Meafures  F for feeing fo
many, and knowing that they always came four, or lix,
or rometimes more, in a Bqft, I could not tell what to
think of it, or.how to take my Meafures, to attack
twenty or thirty Men fingle-handed; lo I lay ftill in
my Cafile, perplex'd and aifcomforted; however I put
my felfinto all the fame Poffures for an Attack, that
I had formerly provided, and was juft ready for Adion,
if any thing had prefented: Having waited a g5od
while, liftening to hear if they made any Noile, at length
being very impatient, I let my Guns at the Foot of my
Ladder, and clamber'd up to the Top of' the Hill by
my two Stages, as ufual; franding Xo however, that
my Head did not appear above the Hill; fo that they
could not perceive me by any Means: Here I obferv'd,
by the help of' my Perfpe&ive-Glafs, that they were
no lets than thirty in Number, that they had a Fire had
kindled, and that they had had Meat dreis'd; how they
cooked it, that I knew not, or what it was, hut they
were all dancing, in I know not how many barbarous
Geflures and Figures, their own Way, round the Fire.
While I was thuslooking on them, I perceiv'd by my
Perfpe&ive two miferable Wretches drag'd fiom the
Boats, where, it feems, they were laid by,:and were
now brought out for the Slaughter  I perceived one of
them immediately fell, being.knock'd down, I fuppofe
with a Club or wooden Sword, for that was their Way,
and two or three others were at work irmmediately, cutting him  open for their Cookery, while the other Vidim was lett ftanding by himfelt; till they thould be
ready for him: In that veryMoment this poor Wretch feeing himfelf a little at Liberty, Nature infpir'd him with
Hopes of Life, and he flarted away from them, and
ran with -incredible Swiftnefs along the Sands dire&ly
towards me, I mean, towards that Part of the Coafl
where my Habitation was.
I was dreadfully frighted (that I muff acknowledge)
when I perceiv'd him to run my Way; and efpecially$
when, as If thought, I tawt him purfued by the whole
Body; and now I expe&ed that Part of my Dream was
coming to pars, and that he would certainly take ihelter
in my Grove but I could not depend by any means

(   94)
upon my Dream for the reft of it, vit. that the other
Savages would not purfie him thither, and find him
there: However, I kept my Station, and my Spirits began to recover, when 1 found tthat there was not above
tlhree,en that follow'd him; and ifll more was I encouraged, when I found that he outflript them exceedingly in running, and gain'd Ground of them, fo that if
he could but hold it for halt an Hour, I faw eafily he
would fairly get away from them all.
There was between them and my Caftle the Creek
wtich I mention'd often at the firft Part of my Story,
when I landed my Cargoes out of the Ship; and this I
knew, he nuftl neceflarily fwim iover, or the poor
Wretch would be taken there; But when the Savage efl
caping came thither, he made nothing of it, tho' the
Tide was then up  but plunging in, iwvam thro' in about thirty Strokes, or thereabouts, landed, and ran on
with exceeding Strength and Swiftnefs; when the three
Purfuers came to the Creek, I found that two of' them
could fwim, but the third could not, and that he tlanding
on the other Side, look'd at the other, but went no
further; and fbon after went foftly back again, which,
as it happen'd, was very well for him in the Main.
I obferv'd, that the two who vfam, were yet more
than twice as long fwimming over the Creek, than the
PXellow Was that fled from them: It came nov very
warmly upon my Thoughts, and indeed irrefiflibly,
that now was my Time to get me a Servant, and perhaps a Companion, or Affifant, and that I was call'd
plaiidly by Providence to fave this poor Creature's
Life;  I immediately gat down the Ladders with all poffible Expedition, fetch'd my two Guns, for they were
both at the Foot of the Ladders, as I obferv'd above;
and getting up again with the fame hafte, to the Top
of the Hill, I crois'd toward the Sea; and having a very fhort cut, and all down Hill, clap'd my felf in the

his Enemy, and at one Blow cut off his Head as cleverly,
no Executioner in Germany could have done it fooner
or better; which I thought very ftrange, for one, who
I had reafon to believe, never faw a Sword in his Life
before, except their own wooden Swords; however, it
feems, as I learn'd afterwards, they make their wooden
Swords fo fharp, fo heavy, and the Wood is fl hard,
that they will cutoff Heads even with them, ay and
Arms, and that at one Blow too: W' hen he had done

fore me.
But that which afloniih'd him moft was, to know how
I had kill'd the other Indian fo far off; fo, pointing to
him, he made Signs to me to let him go to him ~   So I
bad him go, as well as I could; when he came to him,
he flood like one amaz'd, looking at him, turn'd him firft
on one fide; then on t'other, look'd at the Wound the
Bullet had made, which it ieems was juft in his Breaft,
where it had made a Hole, and no great Quantity of
Blood had follow'd,.but he had bled inwardly, for he was
quite dead: Then-he took up his Bow and Arrows, and
cameback; fo I turn'd to go away, and beckon'd to
him to follow me, making Signs to him that more might
come after them.
Upon this he fign'd to me, that he fhould bury them
with Sand, that they might not be feen by the refl if
they follow'd; and ft I made Signs again to him to do,fo; he fell to work, and in an Inftant he had fcrap'd a
Hole in the Sand with hlis Hands, big enough to bury
the firft in, and then drag'd him into it, and cover'd
bim, and did fo allo by the other; I believe he had,               bury'd




(  t97   )   "
bury'd them both in a Quarter of an Hour; then eai
ling him  away, I carry'd him  not to my Caftle, Lut
quite away to lmy Cave, on the further Part of the Iiland; fo I did not let my Dream come to pals in thkit
Part, vie. That he came into my Grove Jor Shelter.
Here I gave hin Bread, and a Bunch of Raifins to
eat, and a Draught of Water, which I found he was in.
deed in great Dittrefs tor, by his running; and laving
recrefi'd him, I made Signs tor him to go lie down and
eep, pointing to a Place where I had laid a great Parcel of'Rice Straw, and a Blanket upon it, which I ufed
to lleep upon my elf fometimes; ib the poor Creatulre
laid down and went to fleep.
He was a comely handlome Fellow, perfeEly well
made, with ftrait long Limbs, not too large, tall, ande
well ihap'd; and, as I reckon, about twenty-fix Years
of Age. He had a very good Countenance, not a fierce
and lurly Al'pc&, but ieem'd to have fomething very
manly in his Face, and yet he had all the Sweetnefsand
Softnels of an Eurcpean in his Countenance too, efpe.
cially when he finii'd: Tis Hair was long and black,
not curi'd like Wool; his Forehead very high, and large,
and a great Vivacity and fparkling Sharpnels in his Eycs.
The Colour of his Skin was not quite black, but very
tawny, and yet not of an ugly yellow naufeous Tawny,
as the Brafilians, and Virginians, and other Natives otf
America are, but of a bright kind of a dun Olive Co.
lour, that had in it fomething very agreeable, tho' not
very eafy to defcribe. His Face was round and plumpi
his Nole fmall, not flat like the Negroes, a. vry good
Mouth, thin Lips, and his Teeth fine  well fet, and
white as Ivory: After he- had flurbec'd, rather than
flept, about half an Hour, he wak'd again, and comes
out of the Cave to me, for I had been milking my Goats,
which I had in the Enclofure ju l by. When he efpy'd
me, he came running to me, laying himfelf down again
uporn the Ground, with all the poflible Signs of an humble thankful Difpofition, making a many antick Gelures.
to lhow it: At laft helays his.Head flat upon thGround,
cloe to my Foot, and fetsmy other Foot upon his Head4
as he had done before;,nd after this, made all th.

(  199 )
fuller Intelligence of them: When I came to the Place,
my very Blood ran chill in my Veins, and my Heart
funk within me at the Horror of the Spe&acle: Indeed
it was a dreadful Sight, at lealt it was to to me, tho'
Friday made nothing ot it: The Place was cover'd with
human Bones, the Ground dy'd with their Blood,
great Pieces of Fleth left here and there, half eaten,
mangled and fcorch'd; and, in fhort, all the Tokens of
the triumphant Feaft they had been making there, after a Vitory over their Enemies: I faw three Skulls,
five Hands, and the Bones of three or four Legs and
Feet, and abundance of other Parts of the Bodies; and
Friday, by his Signs, made me underfiand, that they
brought over four Prifoners to feaft upon; that three of
them were eaten up, and that he, pointing to himfielt
was the fourth: That there had been a great Battel between them and their next King, whofb Subje6& it
teems he had been one of; and that they kad taken a
great Number of Prifoners, all which were carried to
feveral Places by thofe that had taken them in the
Fight, ill order to feaft upon them, as was done here by
thefe Wretches upon thofe they brought hither.
I caus'd Friday to gather all the Skulls, Bones, Flefl,
and whatever remain'd, and: lay them together on a
Heap, and make a great Fire upon it, and burn them
all to Alfes: I found Friday had frill a hankering Stomach after fome of the Flefh, and was till a Cannibal in
his Nature, but I difcover'd fo much Abhorrence at
the very Thoughts of it, and at the leaft Appearance cf
it, that he durfi not difcover it; for I had, by fone
means, let him know that I would kill him if he offer'd it.
When we had done this, we came back to our Caflel
and there I fell to work for my Man Friday; and firft
bf all I gave him a Pair of Linen Drawers, which I hc.d
out of the poor Gunner's Cheft I mention'd, and which
I found in the Wreck; and which, with- a little Altiatin, fitted him very well; then I made him a* Jer;
kin of Goat's-Skin, as well as my Skill would allow
anl I was now grown a     tolerable good Taylor; and I
gave li m a Cap, which I had made of a Hare-Skif,
very convenient and falhionable enough; and thus he
K 4                  was




( 200    )
was drefs'd, for the prefent, tolerably well, and nighty
well was he plcas'd to fee himlflfalmofi as well cloath'd
as his Mafler: It's true, he went aukwardly in thefe
things at firit; wearing the Drawers was very aukward
to him, and the Sleeves of the Waiftcoat gall'd his
Shculders, and the Infide of his Arms; but a little
iafing them, where he collplain'd they hurt him, and
ufing hinlelfto them, at length he took to them very
well.
The next Day after I came Home to my Hutch with
him, I began to confider where I fhould lodge him; and
that I might do well for him, and yet be perfetly eafy
my felt: I made a little Tent for him in the vacant
Place between my two Fortifications, in the Infide of
the laff, and in the Outfide of the firfl: And as there
was a Door or Entrance there into my Cave, I made
a formal fram'd Door.Cafe, and a Door to it of Boards,
and fet it up in the PafIage, a little within the Entrance;
and caufing the Door to open on the Infide,  barr'd it
up in the Night, taking in my Ladders too; fo that
Friday could no way come at me in the Infide of my
innermoll Wall, without making fo much Noife in getting over, that it muft needs awaken me; for my firft
Wall had now a compleat Roof over it of long Poles,
covering all my Tent, and leaning up to the Side of
the Hill, which was again laid crols with fmall Sticks
inftead of Laths, and then thatch'd over a great Thicknets with the Rce-Straw, which was frong like Reeds;
and at the Hole or Place which was left to go in or out
by the Ladder, I had plac'd a kind of Trap-Door, which
if it had been attempted on the Out. fide, would not
have open'd at all, but would have fallen down, and
made a great Noife; and as to Weapons, I took them
all into my Side every Night.
But I needed none of all this Precaution; for never?Man had a more faithful, loving, fincere Servant than
Friday was to me; without Pafions, Sullenefs, or Defigns perfeAly oblig'd and engag'd; his very Affteiions
were ty'd to me, like thofe of a Child to a Father; and
i dare aIy, he would have facrific'd his Life for the faving mine, upon any Occafion whatfoever: The nany
'eftimonies be gave me of this, put it out ofdoubt

and fuon convilncd me., that I needed to ufe no "Precaw'l

(204). to my Man, who feen'd very glad of it, and lik'd it
very well; but that which was fdrangefi to him, was
to fee me -at Salt with it: He made a Sign to me, that
the Salt was nct good to eat, and putting a little into
his own Mouth, he feem'd to nauieate it, and would
Ipit and fputter at it, wafiing his Mouth with fref
Water after it i on the other hand, I took fome Meat
in my Mouth without Salt, and I pretended to fpit and
Sputter for want of Salt, as fafl as he had done at the
Salt; hut it would not do, he would never care for
Salt with Meat, or in his Broth; at leaft, not a great
while, and then but a very little.
Having thus fed him with boil'd Meat and Broth, I
was refolv'd to feaft him the next Day with roafing a
Piece of the Kid; this I did by hanging it before the
Fire in a String, as r had feen marry People do in England, fetting two Poles up, one on each fide the Fire,
and one crots on the top, and tying the String to the
crofs Stick, letting the Meat turn continually: This,
Friday admir'd very much; but when he came to tafle
the Fleih, he took fo many ways to tell me how well he
lik'd it, that I could not but underlfand him; and at
afi he told me he would never eat Man's Flefh any
more, which I was very glad to hear.
The next Day I fet him to work to beating fomne Corn
out, and fifting it in the manner I ufed to do, as I obifer'd before; and he loon underftoed how to do it as
well as I, efpecially, after he had feen what the Meanpng of it was, ande that it was to make Bread of; for
after that I let him fee me make my Bread, and bake it
too; and in a little Time Friday was able to de all the
Work for me, as well as I could do it my felf.
X began rtow:to confider, that having two Mouths to
feed initead of one, I muft provide more Ground for
my Harveft, and plant a larger Quantity of Corn than
I tfed to do  fo I mark'd out a larger Piece of Land,
*Anil began the Fence in the fane manner as before, in
which Friday not only worked very willingly and very
tard, but did it very chearfully; and I' todt him what
it was for, that it was for Corn to make more Bread,
becaufe hewas now with me, and that I might have
cough. for him ahd my felf tao: He appear'd very fen-.ible




( 205 )
fible ofthat Part, and let me know, that he thought I
had much more Labour upon me on his Account, than
I had for my felf; and that he would work the harder
for me, if' would tell him what to do.
This was the pleafanteft Year of all the Life I led in
this Place: Friday began to talk pretty well, and tun
derltand the Names of almoft every Thing I had Occalion to call for, and of every Place I had to fend him to,
and talk a great deal to me; f that, in fhort, I began
now to have fome ufe for my Tongue again, which in.
deed I had very little Occafion for before; that is to
fay, about Speech: Befides the Pleafure of talking to
him, I had a fingular Satisfaation in the Fellow himfelf;
his fimple unfeign'd Holnefy appear'd to me more and
more every Day, and I began really to love the Crea.
ture; and on his Side, I believe he tov'd me more
than it was pofible for him ever to love any thing before.
I had a mind once to try if he had any hankering Inclination to his own Country again; and having learn'd
him Englifh fo well, that he could anfwer me alnoft any.ueftions, I ask'd him whether the Nation that he
belong'd to never conquer'd in Battle? At which he
fmil'd and faid, Yes, yes, we always fight the better;
thatis, he meant always get the betterin Fight, and fo w;
began the following Difcourfe. You always fight the better, faid I, How came you to be taken Priibner then
Friday?
Friday. My Nation beat much, for all that.
Malter. How beat; if your Nation beat them, how
came you to be taken?
Friday. They more than my Nation in the Place
where me was; they take one, two, three, and me: My
Nation over-beat them in the yonder Place, where me
no was, there myNation take one, two, great ThJufand
Mlafiter. But why did not your Siderecover yId ar&
the Hands of your Enemiesthen?
friday. They run one; two, three, and me, and:rfake
go in the Canoe; my Nation have no Canoe that Time.
Mafler. Welt, FridaY, and what does your Nationi dB
with the Men they take? Do they a'rry them awad
a4 eat them  as thiefe id?           '

of the World to be worfhip'd inftead of God, and as God;
and the many Stratagems he made ufe of; to delude
Mankind to their Ruin X how he had a fecret Accefs to
our Pairons, and to our Affe&ions, to adapt his Snares
fo to cur Inclinations, as to caufe us even to be our own
Tempters, and to run upon our own DeftruAion by our
own Choice.
I found it was not fo eafy to imprint right Notions in
his Mlind about the Devil, as it was about the Being of
a God: Nature affifted all my Arguments to evidence
to him even the Necefity of a great firft Caufe, and
over-ruling governing Power, a iecret, dire&ting Providence, and of the Equity and Juftice of paying Homage to him that made us, and the like: But there appear'd nothing of all this in the Notion of an evil Spirit, of his Origil;al, his Being, his Nature, and above
all, of his Inclination to do Evil, and to draw us into
do fo too: And the poor Creature puzzled me once in
luch a manner, by a Queftion merely natural and innocent, that I fcarce knew what to fay to him: I had
been talking a great deal to him of the Power of God,
his Omnipotence, his dreadful Averiion to Sin, his being a confuming Fire to the Workers of Iniquity; how,
ashe had made us all, he could deftroy us and all the
World in a Moment; and he liften'd with great Serioufnefs to nle all the while.
After this, I had been telling him how the Devil
was God's Enemy in the Hearts of Men, and us'd all
his Malice and Skill to defeat the good Defigns of Providence, and to ruin the Kingdonl of Chrift in the
World, and the like: Well, fays Friday, but you fay,
God is ob ftrong, fo great, is he not much ftrong, much
might as the Devil? Yes, yes, fays I, Friday, God is.
fronger than the Devil,God is above theDevil,and there
fore we pray to God to tread him under our Feet, and
enable us to refift his Temptations, and quench his fie.
ry Darts. But, fays he again, if God muc/h frong, muc
mwgbt as the Devil, why Gcd no kill the Devil fi  make
him no more wticked?
I ws ftrangely fiirpriz'4 at his Queftion, and after all,
tho' I was now an old Man, yet I was but a young
Do4tor and ill enough qualified for a Cafiaift, or a Sol-,
vet




vor of Difficulties: And, at firfl, I could not tell what
to lay; fo I pretended not to;hear him, and ask'd him
what he laid. But he was too earneft for an Antfwer to
forget his Qteftionr; fo that he repeated it in the very
fmhe broken Words, as above. By this time I had recover'd myfelf a little, arid [ faid, God will at laf puwjifb
him feverely, he is referv'd for the Judgment, and is to
be ca/t into the bottomlefs Pit, to dwell with everlafling

me, repeating my Words, Referve at Laft, me no underfiand, But wby not kill fhe Devil now, not kill great a.
go? Ycu may as well ask Me, faid I, why God does not
kill you and L; when we do wicked things here that offend him: We are prefermed to repentand be pardon'd.
He mufies a while at this; Well, we/l, lays he, mighty
- affe&ioately tbat well foyu, I, Devil, all wicked, all
preferve, repen. Godpardon al: Here I was run down
again by him to the laft degree, and it was a Teftimony to me, how the mere Notions of Nature, tho' they
will guide reafonable Creatures to the Knowledge of a
God, and of a Worihip or Homage due to the Supreme
Being of God, as the Confequence of our Nature; yet
xathing but Divine Revelation can form the Knowledge
of Yejbs Cbrift, and of a Redemption purchas'd for us;
of a Mediator ofa new Covenant, and of an Intereefl
for, at the Footftool of God's Throne; I fay, nothing
but a Revelation from  Heaven can form thefe in the
Soul) and that therefore theGo4pel of our Lord and
Saviour Tefs Chrift, I Imean, the Word of God, and
the Spirit of God, promifed for the Guide and San&ifier of his P'eople, are the abfolutely neceflary Inftru&ors
oftheSouls of M e in the faving Knowledge of God,
and the msans of Salvation.

In this thankful Frame I continued all the Remainde
of my Time, and the Converfation which employ'd th
Hours between Friday and I, was fuch, as made the
three Years which we liv'd there together, perfe6ly
'and compleatly happy, if any fSuc Tbzng as crmpleai.lappinefs can be frm'd in a fublunary State: T he Sa
age was now a good Chriflian, a much better than I
'thO' I have Reaion to hope, and blefs God for it, that
we were equally penitent, and comforted reftored Pe
nitents: We had here the Word of God to read, and nc
farther off from his Spirit to inftru&, than it we had
been in England.
I always apply'd me felf to reading the Scripture, and
to let him know, as well as I could, the Meaning of what
I read; and he again, by his ferious Enquiries and
Quefiions, made me, as I laid befjre, a much better
Scholar in the Scripture-Knowledge, than  i fhould ever
have been by my own private meer reading: Another
thing I cannot refrain fron obferving here alfo from Experience, in this retired part of my Life, vi(. How infilite and inexprefible a Blefing it is, that the Ktnowledge of God, and of the Dcgtrine of Salvation byChrift
YeJus, is fo plainly laid down in the UWord of God, fo
eaty to be rcceiv'd and underftood,, that as the bare
reading the Scripture made me capable of underfianding enough of my Duty to carry me dire&tly on to the
great,Work of fincere Repentance for my Sins, and laying hold of a Saviour for Life and Salvation, to a fiated
Retbrmation in Pratice, and Obedience to all God's.Commands, and this without-any Teacher or Inftruftor
(I mean, human) fo the fame plain infiru4ti  lufI fideritly ferv'd to the enilghtning this lavage Creature,
and bringing him to be:fuch a Chrifian, as I have
known few equcl to him in my Life.
As to the Difputes, Wranglings, Strife, and Contention, which has happen'd in the World about Religion,
whether Niceties in Doctrines, or Schemes of ChurchGovernment, they were all perfce&ly felefs to us, as for
ought I ean yet fee, they iave been to all the ret in
the World: We had thefre Guide to Heaven, vit the
Word of God   and we had, ble14d be OCd, comfortable
iews of the Spirit of God, teaching and inftru6ing us
rI




(   13 )
by his Wora, leading us- into all Truth, aen  making us
both willing and obedient to the Inftrudion ot his
Word   and I cannot fee the leaft Uie that the greateft
Knowledge of the difpated Points in Religion, which
have made fuch Confufions in the World, would have:
been to us, if we could have obtained it: But I mufl
go on wfth the'Hiftorial Part of Things, and take every
Part in its Order.
After Friday and I became more intimately acquainted, and that he cculd underftand altmofl all I laid to
him, and fpeak fluently, tho' in broken Englifj, to me;
I acquainted him with my own Story, or at leaft fo
much of it as related-to my coming into the Place, how
I had liv'd there, and how long: I let him into the
Myflery ( for fuch it was to him) of Gunpowder and
Bullet, and taught him how to ioot: I gave him a
Knife, which he was wonderfully delighted with, and
I made him a Belt, with a Frog hanging to it, fuch as
in England we wear Hangers in; and in the Frog, intlead ofa Hanger, I gave him a Hatchet, which was
not only as good a Weapon in bome Gafes, but much
more ufeful upon many Occafions. -
I defcrib'd to him the Countrys of Europe, and partiCularly England, which I came from; how we liv'd,
how we worfhip'd God, how we behav'd to one another; and how we traded in Ships to all the Parts of
the Wbrld: I gave him an Account of the Wreck which
1 had been on board of, and ilew'd him as near as I
cold the Place where fhe lay; but fhe was all beaten
in Pieces long before, and quite gone.
I fhew'd him the Ruins of our Boat, which we kht
when we-fcapd,, and which I could not ftir with nmy
whale Strength then, but was now fallen almoft all to
Piects: Upon feeing this Boat, Friday ftood muting a
great while, and faid nothing; I askd. him what it
was he fludied upon; at laft, Iays he, me fre fuc Boat
like come ts Place at my Naticn.
I did not uhderfalnd him a good while; but at laf,
when I had examin'd further into it, I underftood by
him, that a Boat, fuch as that had been, came on Ihore
Kpon te Country where he liv'd, that is, as he explain'd it, was driven thither by Strefs of Weather: I
prefent.

-( 2I5 )r
I obferv'd an extraordinary Senle of Pleafure appear'l
in his Face, and his Eyesfparkled, and his Countenance
difcover'd a itrange Eagernefs, as if he had a Mind to
be in his own Country. again; and this Oblervation of
mine put a great many Thoughts into me, which made
me at firit not fo eafy about my new Man Friday, as I
was before; and I made no doubt, but that if Friday
could get back to his own Nation again, he would not
only forget all his Religion, but all his Obligation ti
me; and would be forward enough to give his Coun.
trymen an Account of me, and come bck perhaps,
with a Hundred or two of them, and make a Feaft upon
me, at which he might be as merry as he ufed to be
with thofe of his Enemies, when they were taken in
War.
But I wrong'd the poor honeC Creature very much,
for which I was very forry afterwards: However as
my Jealoufy increas'd, and held me fome Weeks, I was
a little more circumfpe&, and not fo familiari and kind
to him as before; in which I was certainily in thex wrong
too, the honeft grateful Creature having no Thought
about it, but what confifted with the beit Principle,
both as a religious Chriftian, and as a grateful Friend,
as appear'd alterwards to my full Satisfa&ion.
While my Jealouly of him lafted, you may.be fure I
was every Day pumping him to fee if he would;diiiwver any ofthe new Thoughts, which I fufpe&ed were
in him; but I fbund, every thing he faid was fo honeft,
and fo innocent, that, I could lind nothing to nqurilh
my Sufpicion; and, in fpite of all my lineafinefs, be
made me at laft entirely his own again; nor did he
in the leaft perceive sthat I -was uneafy, and therefore
I could not fulpea: him of Deceit.
One Day, walkirng tp th  ae me Hill, but the Weather being hazy at 5ea, fI that we could not fiee the
Continent, I all'd to him, and aid, Friday, do not
you wifh your Itlf in yqur own Country, your Own

turn wild again, eat Mens Flefi again, and be a Savage as you were before?  He,look'd full of Concern,

( 216 );ve good, tell them to pray God, tel them to eat Corn.

would go back to them? He linil'd at that, and told

would tell them how I had killed his Enemies, and.fav'd

lie told me, as well as he could, how kind they were to
fcventeen white Men, or bearded Men, as he oall'd

From this Time, I confefs, I had a mind to venture
over, and fee if I could poffibly join with thefe bearded Men, who, I made no doubt, were Spaniards or PIrtugueJf; not doubting but, if I could, we might find
fome Method to efeape from thence, being upon the
Continent, and a good Company together, better than
I could from an liand forty Miles off the Shore, and alone without help: So, faster fome Days, I took Friday
to work again, by way of Diifourfe; and told him, I
would give him a Boat to go back to his own Nation;
and accordingly I carry'd him to my Frigate, which
lay on the other Side of the Ifland, and having clear'd
it of Water ( for I always kept it funk in the Water) I

I found he was a moft dextrous Fellow at managing

Friday, fiall we go to your Nation? He look'd very
'dull at my faying fc, which, it feems, was becaufe he

I could not get into the Water; he faid that was big
enough   but then, as I had taken no Care.of it, and it
had




( 217     )
had lain two or three and twenty Years there, the Suh

Friday told me, iuch a Boat would do very well, and

Upon the Whole, I was by this Tine fo fix'd upon

that I told him we would go and make one as big as

I ask'd him what he meant; I told him I was not angry with lain at all: No anry! N2 angry! fays he, repeating the Words feveral times, Why fend Friday bhme

him from me, fo If found all the Foundation of his Delire to go to his own Country, was laid in his ardent

( 219   )
a farther Defign that he knew nothing of, and that

like what we call in England, a Shoulder. of-tMuttonSail, to go with a Boom at Bottom, and a little ihort

Boat too and.again in the Sea by the Rudde:, and how

little cloudy Weather, and feldom or never any Fogs in
thole Parts, there was the lets Occafion for a Compafs, teeing the Starls wtere always to be feen by Night,
and the Shore by Day, except in the rainy Sealons,
and then no Body cared to fir abroad, either by Land
or Sea.
I was now enter'd on the feven and twentieth Year
of my Captivity in this Place; though the three laft
Years that I had this Creature with me, ought rather
to be left out of the Account, my Habitation being
quite of another kind than in all the refi of the Time.
kept the Anniverfary of my landing here with the
tiahe Thankfulnefs to God for his Mercies, as at firft;
and if I had inch Caufe of Acknowledgment at firft,
I had much more fo now, having fuch additional Te1fimonies of the Care of Providence over me, and the
great Hopes I had of being effcAually and fpeedily deliver'd; for I had a-l invincible Impreffion upon my
Thoughts, that my Deliverance was at hand, and that
I ihould not be allother Year in this Place: However,
I went on with my Husbandry, digging, planting,
fencing, as ufial; I gather'd and cur'd my Grapes, and
did every neceffary Thing, as before.
The rainy Seafon was -in the mean time upon me,
when I kept more within Doors than at other Times;
fo I had fIow'd our new Veffel as fecure as we could,
bringing her up into the Creek, where, as I faid in
the Beginning, I landed my Rafts from the Ship, and
haling her up to the Shore, at high Water Mark, I
made my Man Friday dig a little Dock, juft big enough
to hold her, and juft deep enough to give her Water
enough to float in; and then, when the Tide was out,
we made a ftrong Dam crofs the End of it, to keep
th: Water out; and fi Ihe lay dry, as to the Tide,
from




( 21     )  -
firom the Sea;and to keep theRain offwe laid a great many Boughs of Trees to thick, that Ihe wasas well thatched as-a Houie; and thus. we waited for the l1onth of
November and December, in which I defign'd to make
my Adventure.
When the fettled Seafon began to come in, as the
Thought of'my Deiign return'd with the fair Weather,
I was preparing daily for the Voyage; and the firft.'hing I did, was to lay by a certain (Quantity ot' Proviiions, being the Stores for our Voyage; and intended,
in a Week or a Fortnighlt's Time, to open the Dock,
and launch out our Boat:  was bul)' one Morning upon fomething ofthis kind, when I cill'd to Friday, and
bid him go to the Sea-fhore, and lee if he could find a

once a Week, for the fake ot the Eggs, as vell as the
Fitel; Friday had not been long gune, when hecame
running back, and flew over my outer Wall, or Fence,
like one that felt not the Ground, or the Steps he fet his

I faw the poor Fellow was molt terribly fcared; for nothing ran in his Head but that they were come to look
for him, and would cut him in Pieces, and eat him;
and the poor Fellow trembled fo, that I fcarce knew
what to do with him: 1 comforted him as- well asicould, and told him I was in as much Danger as-he,
and that they woulld eat, me as well as him; but, fays

( 222 )
When he had drank it, I made him take the two Fowling-l-ieccs which we always carry'd, and load then

Vi hen I had thus prepar'd my felf, I took my Per.

Pri'oners, and threeCanoes;and that their whole Bufinefs
e:emed to be the triumphant Banquet upon thefe three

Wood came clofe almofd down to the Sea: This, with

down again to Ftiday and told him, I -was refolved.to r.to dewy to them, and kill them;all; and ask'd him if:
'the would ftand by me? He was now gotten over his

Dram I had given him, he was very chearful, and told
me, as before, be would die, when 1 bid die.
In this Fit of Fury, I took firft and divided the
Arms which I had charg'd, as before, between us: I
gave Friday one Piftol to ftick in, his Girdle, and three
Guns upon his Shoulder; and I took one Pifol, and

out: i took a fmall Bottle of Rum in my Pocket, and

and as to Orders, I charg'd him to keepclofe behind me,
and notto ftir,or fhoot, or do any thing,tillI bid hini;and
in the mean time, not to fpeak a Word: In this Pofture
I fctch'd a Compafsto my Right Hand of near a; Mile,
