fo that I might come within fhot of them before I ihould
be difcover'd, which I had fcen by my Glafs it was eafy
to do.                                      Wh




( 223 )
While I was making this March, my former Thoughts
returning, I began to abate my Rlfolution; I do not
mean, that I entertain'd any Fear of their Number; for
as they were naked, unarm'd Wretches, 'tis certain I
was luperior to them; nay, though I had been alone;
but it occur'd to my Thoughts, What Call? What Occation? much lets, What Neceffity, I was in to go and
dip mny Hands in Blood, to attack People, who had
neither done or intended me any Wrong? Who, as to
me were innonent, and whofe barbarous Cufloms were
their own Difafter, being in them  a Token indeed of
God's having left them, with the other Nations of that
part of the World, to ifchl Stupidity, and to Tu:h inhtman Colurles; but did not call me to take upon me to
be a Judge of their A&ions, much lefs an Executioner
of his Juitice; that whenever he thought fit, he would
take the Caufe into his own Hands, and by National
Vengeance punihl them   for National Crimes; but
that, in the mean Time, it was none of my Bufinefs;
tllhat it was true, Friday might juftify it, becaufe he was
a declar'd Enemy, and in a tate of War with thofe very particulat People, and it was lawful for him to attack them; but I could not fay the fame with refpect
to nme  Thefe Things were ib warmly prels'd upon
my Thoughts all the Way as I went, that I relblv'd I
would only go place my felf near them, that I mightl
oblerve their barbarous Feaft, and that I would ab
then as God flould dire&; but that unlefs fonething
offer'd that was more a Call to me than yet I knew ot,
I would not meddle with them.
With   this Refolution I entered. the Wood, and
with all, poffible Warynefs and Silence (Friday following
clole at my Heels) I march'd till I came to the Skirt
of the Wood, on the Side which was next to them; only
that one Corner of the Wood lay between me and thenm
Here I call'd foftly to Friday, and fhewing him a great
Tree, wlich was juft at the Corner of the Wood, 1 bad
him go to the Tree, and bring me word if he could feq
there plainly what they were doing; he did fo, and
came immediately back to me, and told me they might
be plainly view'd there y that they were all about thQ

(     24)
Fire, eating the Flefl of one of their Prifbners; and
that another lay bound upon the Sand., a little from

not one of their Nation, but one of the bearded Menl,
who he had told me of; that came to their Country in

plainly, by my Glafs, a white Man, who lay upon the
Beach of the iea, with his Hands and his Feet ty'd with
Flags, or T hins like Rutfhes, and that he was an European, and had Cloaths on.

where I was, which, by going a little way about, I faw

within half Shot of them; lo I with-held my Parlion,
though I was indeed enrag'd to the higheft Degree, and
going back abbut twenty Faces, I got behind fome Bufhes,
which held all the way, till I came to the other Tree, and
then I came to a little rifing Ground, which gave me a
tull View of them, at the Dittance ofabout eighty Yards.
I had now not a Moment to lofe; for nineteen of
the dreadful Wretches fate upon the Ground all clofe
huddled together, and had jutt lent the other two to
hutcher the poor Chrflian, and bring him perhaps Limb
by Limb to their Fire; and they were ftoop'd down to
untie the Bands at his Feet I turn'd to Friday, now,

then, F. iday, fays i, do exatly as you fee me do, fail
in nothing; fo I fet down one of the Muskets and the
Fowling- Piece upen the Ground, and Friday did the
like by his; and with the other Musket I took my Aim.
at the Savages, bidding him do the like; then asking
him, if he was ready? he faid, Yes; then fire at them,
fLid I; and the farne Moment I fir'd alfo.
Friday took his Aim fo much better than I, that on
the fide that he fhot, he kill'd two of them, and wounded three more; and on my fide, I kil'd one, and wounded two: They were, you may be fure, in a dreadful Confernation; and all of 'em who were not hurt, jump'd up
upon their Feet immediately, but did not know which
Way




( 225 )     -
Way to run, or which Way to look; for they knew not
from whence their Deftru&ion came: Friday kept his
Eyes clofe upon me, that as I had bid him, he might

made, I threw down the Piece, and took up the Fowling-Piece, and Friday did the like; he fee me cock, and

faid I; yes, fays he; let fly then, fays I, in the Name
of God, and with that I fired again among the amaz'cd
Wretches, and fo did Friday; and as our Pieces were nowloaden wvith what I call'd Swan-Shot, or fmall Piflol
Bullets, we found only two drop; but to many were
wounded, that they ran about yelling and skreaming
like mad Creatures, all bloody, and milerably wounded,
toofl of them; whereof three moure fell quickly after,,
though not quite dead.

which by the way was not very fai, being loaden with Arms:

who, was, as I faid, lying upon the Beach, or Shore,

a terrible Fright to the Sea-fide, and hAd jtimp'd into aCanoe, and three more of the reftl made the fame Way::

about forty Yards to be. near them, he fhot at them,
and I thought he had kill'd them. all: for I faw them all
fall of a Heap into the Boat; though I faw two of them
up again quickly: However, he kill'd two of.them, and
wounded the third, fo that he. lay d6wn in the Bottomi
of the Boat, as if he had been dead.

( 226 )
ask'd him in the.Prtugaefe Tongue, What he was? He

as I could make up, we will talk afterwards, but we
muft fight now; if you have any Strengt! left, take
this Piltol and Sword, and lay about you: He took
them very thankfully, and no fooner had he the Arms
in his Hands, but as if they had put new Vigour into
him, he flew upon his Murderers like a Fury, and had
cut two of them in Pieces in an Inftant; for the Truth
is, as the whole was a Surprize to them, fo the poor
Creatures were lb much fiighted with the Noi e of our
Pieces, that they fell down for meer Amazement and
Vear, and had no more Power to attempt their own Ef.
cape, thau their Flefh had to refilt our Shot; and that
Was the Cafe of thofe five that Friday fhot in the Boat;
fbr as three of then fell with the Hurt they receiv'd,
o the other two fell with the Fright.
I jept my Piece in my Hand ffill, without firing, begn willing to keep myCharge ready, becaufe I had given
the Spaniard my P'iiol and Sword; fo I call'd to Friday,
And bad him run up to the Tree froml whence we firft
fir'd, and fetch the Arms which lay there, that had
been difcharg'd, which he did with great Swiftnefs;
and then giving him my Musket, I fat down my felf
to load all the reft again, and bad them come to me
when they wanted: While I was loading there Pieces,
there happened a fierce Engagement between the Sp ani4rd and of one the Savages, who made at him with one of
their great wooden Swords, the fame Weapon that was
6o have kill'd him before, if I had not prevented it:
The Spaniard, who was as bold and as brave as could
be'imagin'd, tho' weak, had fought this Indian a good
while, and bad cut him two great Wounds on his
Head; but the Savage being a flout lulty Fellow, clo*                        fing




227)'..
fing in with him, had thrown him down (being faint)
and was wringing my Sword out of his Hand, when:the Spaniard, tho' undermoil, wifely quitting his Sword,
drew the Fitol from his Girdle, flot the Savage through
the Body, and kill'd him upon the Spot, befbre I, who
was running to help. him, could come near him.
Friday being now left at his Liberty, purfu'd the flying Wretches with no Weapon in his Hand, but his
Hatchet; and with that he difpatch'd thofe three, who
as faid before, were wounded at firit and fallen, and
all the reft he could come up with; and the S3aniard
coming to me for a Gun, I gave him one of the Fowling-Pieces, with which he purfu'd two of the Savages,
and wounded them both; but as he was not able to run,
they both got from him into the Wood, where Friday
purfu'd them, and kill'd one of them; but the other was
too nimble for him; and tho' he was wounded, yet had
plung'dinto the Sea, and fwam with all his Mightoff
to thofe two who were left in the Cance, which three
in the Cance, with one wounded, who we know not
whether he dy'd or no, were all that efcap'd our Hands
of one and twenty. The Account of the reft is as
follows;
3 Kill'd at our firft Shot from the Tree.
2 Kill'd at the next Shot.
'2 Kill'd by Friday in the Boat.
2 Kiild byDitto, of thofe at firtt wounded
x Ki'd by Ditto, in the Wood.
3 Killed by the Spaniard.
4 Kill'd, being found dropt here and there of their
Wounds, or kill'd by Fiday in his Chace of them.
4 Efcap'd in the Boat, whereof one wounded, if
not dead..
2l In all.
Thofe that were in the Canoe, work'd hard to get out

( 228 )
and purfued them; and indeed I was very anxicus about

People, they fhould come back, perhaps, with tx.o or

Multitude; fo I contented to purf'ue them by Sea; and
running to one of their CUanes, I jump'd in, and bad
Friday follow me; but when I was in the Cance, I was
furpriz'd to find another poor Creature lie there alive,
bound Hand and Foot, as the Spaniard was, for the
Slaughter, and almoft dead with Fear, not knowing
what the matter was; for he had not been able to look
up over the Side of the Boat, he was tied fo hard,
Neck and Heels, and had been tied fo long, that he
had really little Life in him.
I immediately cut the twilled Flags, or Rufhes,
which they had bound him with, and would have help'd
him up; but he could not {land, or [peak, but groan'd
moft piteoufly, believing, it feems, fill that he was only
unbound in order to be kill'd.
When Friday came to him, I bad him fpeak to him,
and tell him of his Deliverance, and pulling out my
Bottle, made him give the poor Wretch a Dram,
Which, with the News of his being deliver'd, revived.
him, and he fat up in the Boat; but when Friday came
to hear him fpeak, and look'd in his Face, it would
have moved any one to Tears, to have feen how Friday
kifs'd him, embraced him, hugg'd him, cry'd, laugh'd,
hollow'd, juip'd about, danced, fung, then cry'd again, wrung his Hands, beat his own Face and Head,
and then fung, and jump'd about again, like a diftrafed
Creature: It:was a good while, before I could make
him fpeak tmnie, or tell me what was the matter; bit
when he came a little to himfelt, he told me that it was
his Father.
It is not eafy for me to exprefs how it moved me
to fee what Extafy and filial Affeiion had work'd in
this poor Savage, at the Sight of his Father, and of his
being deliver'd from Death; nor indeed can I defcribe
hailf th Extravagances of his Affte6ion after.this; for
he went into the Boat ana out of the Boat a great many

to his Bofom, half an Hour together, to nour ih it;

This Ation put an End to our Furfuit of the Canoe,
with the other Savages, who were now gotten almoIt

To remedy this, I went to work in my Thought,

while he came to me, I foon made a kind of Hand-Barrow to lay them on, and Friday and I carried them up
both together upon it between us: But when we got
them to the Out fide of our Wall, or Fortification, we
were at a worfe Lols than before; for it was impoffible
to get them over; and I was reoblv'd not to break it'
down: So I fet to Work again; and Friday and I, in
about two Hours Time, made a very handiome Tent,
cover'd with old Sails, and above that with Boughs of
Trees, being in the Space without our outward Fence,
and between thit and the Grove of young Wood whichi
I had plante4: And here we made them'two Beds of
fuch Things as I had, viz. of good Rice-Straw, withBlankets laid upon it to lie on, and another to cover
them on each Bed.
My fland was now peopled, and I thought my felf
very rich in Subjecs; and it was a, merry Refleaion/.
which I frequently made, How like a King I olopk'd
Firft of all, the whole Country was nly own meer
Property; fo that I had an undoubted Right of Domi
nion. 2dty, My People were perfeAly fubijeted: t
ws aboilute Lord and Lawgiver; they all ow'd theiy
Lives to me, and were ready to lay down their Lives;
if there bad been Occafion of it, for me: It was remarabe too, I had but three Subje&ts and they were of
three




( 232 )2
three different Religions, My Man Friday was a Pro;
teftant; his Father wasa Pagan     and a Cannibal; and
th.bSpaniad was aPapift: However, I allow'd Liberty ofConfcience throughout my Dominions: But this
is by the way.
As foon as I had fecur'd my two weak refcued Prifoners, and given them Shelter, and a Place to reft them

them: And the firft Thing I did, I order'd Friday to
take a yearling Goat, betwixt a Kid and a Goat, out ot'
my particular Flock, to be kill'd: Then I cut off the
hinder Quarter, and chopping it into finall Pieces, I
fet Friday to Work, to boiling and Hewing, and made
them a: very good Difh, I affure you, of Fleih and

Broth; and as I cook'd it without Doors, ( for I made
no Fire within my inner Wall, fo I carried it- all into
the new Tent; and having feta Table there for them,
I fat down and eat my own Dinner alib with them,, and,
as wellas I could, chear'd them and encourag'd them;
Friday being my Interpreter, efpecially to his Father,
and, iideed, to the Spaniard too; for the Spaniard fpoke
the Language of the Savages pretty well.
After we had dined, or rather fipped, I order'd'
Friday to take one of the Canoes, andgo and fetch our
Muskets and other Fire-Arms, which for wantof Time
we had left upon the Place of Battle; and the next
Day I order'd him to go and bury the dead Bodies.of
the Savages, which- lay open to the Sun, and would
prefently be offenfive; and I alfo order'd him to bury
the horrid Remains of their barbarous Feaft, which [
knew were pretty much, and which I could not think
of doing my felf; nay, I could not bear to fee them, if
I went that Way: All which he. puntually perform'd,
Tnd defac'd the very Appearance of the Savages being
there; fd that when I went again, I could fcarce know
where it was, otherwife than by the Corner of the
Wood pointing to the Place.
I then began to enter into a little Converfation with
my two new Subijes; and firft I fet Friday to enquire
of his Father, what he thought of the Efcape of the
$oawges in that Canoe, and whether we might expea a

( 233 )
Return of them with a Pewer too greafior us to refiff?'
His firt Opinion was, that the Savages in the Boat never conld live out the Storm  which blew that Night
they went off, but mufi of Neceflity be drown'd or
driven Soutbh t thofe other Shores, where they were as
fure to be devour'd as they were to be drowned it they
were caft away; but as to what they would do if they
came fafe on Shore, he faid he knew not; but it was
his Opinion that they were fo dreadfully frighted with
the manner of their being attack'd, the Noife and the
Fire, that he believ'd they would tell their People, they
were all kill'd by Thunder and Lightning, not by the
Hand of Man, and that the two which appear'd, (vii.)'
Friday and me, were two Heavenly Spirits or Furies
come down to deflroy them, and not Men with Weapons: This he faid he knew, becaufe he Heard them all
cry cut fo in their Language to one another; for it was
impoffible to them to conceive that a Man could dart
Fire, and fpeak Thunder, and kill at a Diftance, without litting up the Hand, as was done now: And this old
Savage was in the right; for, as I underfiood fince by
other hands, the Savages of that Part never attempted to
go over to the Ifland afterwards; they were fo terrified
with theAccounts given by thofe fourMen, (for it feems
they did efcape the Sea ) that they believ'd whoever
went to that enchanted Ifland, would be defroy'd with
Fire from the Gods.
This however I knew not, and therefore was under
continual Apprehenfions for a good while, and kept
always upon my Guard, me and all my Army; for-as
we were now four of us, I would have ventur'd upon a
hundred of them fairly in the open Field at any time.
In a little time, however, no more Canoes appearing, the Fear of their coming wore off, and I began to
take my former Thoughts of a Voyage to the Main into
Confideration, being likewife affur'd by Friday's Father, that I might depend upon good U fage from their
Nation on his Account, if I would go.
But my Thoughts were a little fu'pended, when I
had a ferious Difcourfe with the Spaniard, and when I
underflood that there were fixteen more of his Countryiten and Portugefe, who having been caf away, and

( z34 ).
made their Efcape to that fide, liv'd there at Peace indeed with the Savages, but were very lore put to it for
Neceffaries, and indeed for, Life: 1 ask'd- him all the

Spanilh Ship, kound from the Rio de l Plqta, to the Havan, being directed to leave their Loading there, which
was chiefly Hides and Silver, and to bring back what
European Goods they could. meet with there; that they
had five Portugefe Seamen on Board, whom they took
out of another Wreck; that five of their own Men were
drown'd when firfl the Ship was loft, and that thefle efcap'd thro' infinite Dangers and Hazards, and arriv'd almoft flarv'd on the Cannibal Coaft, where they expected
to have been devour'd every Moment.
He told me, they 'ad fome Arms with them, but they,
were perfe&ly ufeleis, for that they had neither Pow.
der or Ball, the Wafhiig of the Sea having fpoil'd all
their Powder, but a little, which they ul'ed at their firlt
Landing to provide themfelves fome Food.
I ask'd him what he thought would become of them
there, and.if they had form'd no Defign of making any
Efiape: He faid, They had many Confultations about
it,' but that having neither Vefel, nor Tools to build
one, or Provifions of any Kin,.their Coplifels alwayis
ended int Tears and Defpair  '.
I ask'd him how he thought they would receive a
Propofal from me, which might tend towards an Efcape:
And whether, if they were all here, it might not be
done? I told him with Freedom, I fear'd moftly their
Treachery and ill- Ulage of me, if I put mj ife in their
Hands; for that Gratitude was no inherent Virtue in
the Nature of Man; nor did Mlen ailw;as fquare trheir
Dealings by the Obligations they had receiv.'d fo much
as they did by the Advantages they expeaed: I told;
him, it would be very hard, that I hould be the In,
ftrument of their Deliverance, and that they filould afterwards make me their Prifoner in New-Spain, where,
an Englihman was certain to be made a Sacrifice, what
Neceffity, or what Accident fbever, brought.himthither: And thatI had rather. be deliver'djlp to the Savages, and: be-devour'd alive, tban.fall intOathe mer<ilefs Clawsofthe Priets,= and be carry'd into!thse! qi:
ition.




( 235    )
Ftion. I added, That otherwife I was perfwaded, if
they were all here, we might, with fo many Hands,
build a Bark large enough to carry us all away, either to
the Brafils Southward, or to the Iflands or Spanijh Coatt
Northward: But that if in Requital they Should, when
I had put Weapons into their Hands, carry me by Force
amlong their own People, I might be ill uled formy
Kindnefs to them, and make my Cafe worfe than it was
before.
He anfwver'd with a great deal of Candor and Ingenuity, That their Condition was fo miferable, and they
were fo fenfible of it, that he believed they would abhor
the Thought of ufing any Man unkindly that ihould
contribute to their Deliverance; and that, if I pleafed,
he would go to them with the old Man, and difcourfe
with them about it, and return again, and bring me
their Anlwer: That he would make Conditions withl
them upon their folemn Oath, That they would be abfolutely under my Leading, as their Commander and
Captain; and that they ihould fwear upon the Holy
Sacrameunts and Gofpel, to be true to me and to go to
fuch Chriftian Country as I fhould agree to, aned
no other; and to bedireded Iwholly and abfolutely by
my Orders, till they were landed fafely in fuch Country
as I intended; and that he would bring a Contrat from
them under their Hands for that Purpofe.
Then he told me, he would firfi fwear to me himfelf
That he would never flir from me as long as he liv'd,
till I gave him Orders; and that he would take my
Side to the laft Drop of his Blood, if there ihould happen the leaft Breach of Faith among his Countrymen.
He told me, they were all of them very civil honeft
Men, and they were under the greateft Diftrefs imaginable, having neither Weapons or Cloths, nor any Food,
but at the Mercy and Difcretion of the Savages; out of
all Hopes of ever returning to their own Country; and
that he was fure, if I would undertake their Relief, they
wou'd live and die by me.
Upon the1e Affurances, I refolv'd to venture to relieve them, it poflible, and to fend the old Savage and
this Spaniard over to them to treat: But when he had
gotten all Things in a Readinefs to go, the Spaniard himfelf




C   3,6 )
flftfrtred an Objecion, which had fo much Prudence
in it on one Hand, and fb much Sincerity on the other
Hand,, that I could not but be very well fatisfy'd in it;
and, by his Advice, put off the Deliverance of his Conlrades for at leaft half a Year. The Cafe was thus.
He had been with us now about a MIonth; during
which. Time I had let him lee in what Manner I had
provided, with the Altitfance of Providence, for my
Support; and he taw evidently what flock of Corn and
Rice I had laid up; which, as it was more than iilflicient for my felt, bo it was not fufficient, at leafi without good Husbandry, for my Family, now it was encreas'd to Number four: But much lefs would it be futf
ficient, if his Countryman, who were, as he laid, fourteen flill alive, fliould come over; and leaft of all would
it he fufficient to vic6ual our Veflel, if we fliould build
one, for a Voyage to any of the Chrifian Colonies of
America. So he told me, he thought it would be more
advilable, to let him and the two other dig and cultivate rome more Land, as much as I could pare Seed to
Tow; and that we ihculd wait another Harveft, that
we might have a Supply of Corn for his Country-men
when they ihould conae; for Want might be a Temptation to theni to difagree, or not to think themfelves de.
liver'd, otherwife than out of one Difficulty into another: You know, fays he, the Children of Ijrael, though
they rejoic'd at firfi at their being deliver'd out of Egypt,
yet vebeU'd even againft God himfelf that deliver'd
them, when they came to want Bread in the Wildernels.
His Caution was fo feafonable, and his Advice fo good,
that I could not but be very well pleas'd with this Propafal, as well as I was fatisfy'd with his.Fidelity; So
we fell to digging all four of us, as well as the wooden
Tools we were furnifhbd with permitted; and in about
a Month's Time, by the End of which it was Seed-time,
we had gotten as nmuch Land cur'd and trimm'd up,. as
we fbo'd 22 Bufhels of Barley on, and I6 Jarrs ofRice,
which was, in ihort, all the Seed we had to fpare; nor
indeed did we leave our felves Barley fufficient for our
owvn Food, fbr the fix Months that we had to expe& our
Chop, thal is-to. ay, reckoning from' the Time we tit
our




(237    )
tcur Seed afide for fowing; for it is not to be fuppos'd ft
is iix Months in the Ground in the Country.
Having now Society enough, and our Number being
fufficientto put us out of Fear of the Savages, if they
had come, unlefs their Number had been very great,
we went freely all over the Ifland, where-ever we found
Occafion; and as here we had our Efcape or Delivexance upon our Thoughts, it was inpoflible, at leaft for
me, to have the Means of it out of mine; to this Purpole, 1 mark'd out teveral Trees, which I thought fit
for our Work, and I fet Friday and his Father to cutting
them down; and then I caus'd the Spaniard, to whom I
imparted ny Thought on that Affair, to overfee and direCt their VVork:  ihew'd them with what indefatigable Pains I had hew'd a large Tree into tingle Planks,
andI caus'd them to do the like, till they had made about a Dozen large Planks of good Oak, near two Foot
broad, 35 Foot long, and from two Inches to four Inches thick: what prodigious Labour it took up, any
one may imagine.
At the fame Time I contriv'd to encreafe my little
Flock of tame Goats as much as I could; and to this Purpofe I made Friday and the Spaniard go out one Day,
and my felf, with Friday, the next Day, for we took
our turns: And by this Means we got about 20 young
Kids to breed up with the reft; for when-ever we fhot
the Dam, we fav'd the Kids, and added them to our
Flock: But above all, the Seafon for curing the Grapes
coming on, I caus'd iun:h a prodigious Qitantitv to be
hung up in the Sun, that I believe, had we been at Alicant, where the Raifins of the Sun are cured, we could
have fill'd 60 or So Barrels; and thefe, with our Bread,
was a great Part of our Food, and very good Living too,
I affure you; for it is an exceeding nourifhing Food.
It was now Harveft, and our Crop in good Order;
it was not the moft plentiful Encreafe I had feen in the
Ifland, but however it was enough to anfwer our End;
for from our 22 Buihels of Barley; we brought in and
threfhed out above 220 Buihels, and the like in Propbrtion of the Rice, which was Store enough for our Food
to the next Harvefl, tho' all the 16 Spaniards had been
oa Shore with me; or if we had been ready for a Voyage,




( 238 ) I


ge, it.woulcld ery plentifully have vifuall'd our Slhp,
to have carry'd us to any Part of the World, that is to,fay, of America. When we had thus hGus'd and fecur'd
'.our Magazine of Corn, we fell to Work to make more
Wicker-Work, v~. Great Baskets in which we kept
it, and the Spaniard was very handy and dexterous at
this Part, and often blam'd me that I did not make
fome Things for Defence,of this Kind of Work; but I
faw no Need of it: And now having a full Supply of
Food for all the Guefsexpe&ed, 1 gave the the Spaxiard Leave to go over to theiMain,to fee what he could
do with thofe he had left behind him there: I gave
him a tlri& Charge in Writing, not to bring any Man
with him, who would not firit fwear in the Vrefence of
himfelf and of the old Savage,That he would no Way injure, fight with, or attack the Perfon he fhould find in
the fland, who was oi kind to fend for them in Order
to their Deliverance; but that they would ftand by-and
defend him againf all ifch Attemps, and where-ever
they went, would be entirely under, and fubj&ted t6 his
Command; and that thisfhould be put in Vv riting, and
fign'd with their Hands: How we were to have this
done, when I knew they had neither Pen or Ink, that,
indeed, was a Qiueftion which we never ask'd.
Under thefe lnitru&ions, the Spaniard, and the old
Savage (the Father of Friday) went away in one of the
Canoes, which they might be laid to come in, or rather
were brought in, when they came as Prilbners to be devour'd by the Savages.
I gave each of them a Musket with a Firelock on it
and about eight Charges of Powder and Ball, charging thenm to be very good Husbands of both, -and not to
ufe either of them but upon urgent Occafion.
This was a cheariul Work, being the firft Meafures
ufed by me in View of my Deliverance for now 271
Years and fome Days: I gave them Provifions of Bread,
and of dryd Gra ps, fuificient for thenifelves for many:Days, andgfuflicient for all their Country-men for about
eight Days time; and' wilhing them a good Voyage, I
fee them goi agreeing with them about a Signal they
&tould hang outat. their Return by which I Thuuld kno\v
them again, when they came back, at afDiitance,:before
t hey came on Shore.                          They




( 239 )
They went away with a fair Gale on the]Day.that
the Moon was at Full;:by my Account in the MoRith
of October; but as for an exa&t Reckoning of Days, a:
ter I had once loft it, I could never recover it again;
nor had I kept even the Number of Years bo puntually; as to be lure that I was right, tho', as it prov'd,
when I afterwards examin'd my Account, I found I had
kept a true Reckoning of Years.
It was no lefs than eight Days I had waited for them,
when a ftrange and untorefeen Accident interven'd, of
which the like has not, perhaps, been: heard of in Hiftory. I was fail afleep in my Hutch one Morning,
when my Man Friday came running in to me, and call'd
aloud, iiafler, Mafter, they are come, they are come.
I jump'd up, and, regardlefs of Danger, I went out
as blon as I could get my Clothes on, thro' my little
Grove, which ( by the Way ) was by this Time grown
to be a very thick Wood: I fay, regardlels of Danger,
I went without my Arms, which was not my Cufton
to do; but I was furpriz'd, when turning my Eyes to
the Sea, I prelently taw a Boat at about a League and
Half's Diftance, tanding in for the Shore, with a
Sbhulderf 4Mtdttcn-Sail, as they call it, and the \ ind
blowing pretty fair to bring them in: Al'o I obferv'd
prelently, that they did not come from that Side which
the Shore lay on, but firom the Southermofi End of the
Ifland - Upon this I call'd Friday in, and bid him lye
cloft, for thefe were not the Feople we look'd for, and
that we might not know ytt whether they were Friends
or Enemies.
In the next-Place, I went in to fetclh n'yPerfpe&iveGlafs, to fee-what I could make of thlem; and having
taken the Ladder out, I climb'd up to the Top of the

(240)
I cannot exprers the Confufion I was in, tho' the:Joy
of feeing a Ship, and one whom I had Reafon to believe
was Mann'd by my own Country-men, and confequently Friends, was fucla as I cannot defcribe; but yet I
had fome becret Doubts hung about me, I cannot tell
ornm whence they came, bidding me keep upon my
Guard: In the firft Place, it occur'd to me, to Conifaer what Bufinefs an Eng ijh Ship could have in that
Part of the World, fince it was not the Way to, or
from any Part of the World, where the EngliJh had any
Traffick; and I knew there had been no Storms to drive
them in there, as in Diftrefs; and that if they were
'Egzlijh really, it was mofl probable that they were here
upon no good Defign; and that I had better continue
as I was, than fall into the Hands of Thieves and Mur-:therers.
Let no Man defpife the fecret Hints and Notices of
Danger, which fometimes are given him when he may
think there is no Pouflbility of its being real: That
fuch Hints and Notices are given us, I believe few that
have made any Obfervations of Things can deny; that
they are certain Difcoveries of an invifible World, and
a Converfe of Spirits, we cannot doubt; and if the
Tendency of them feems to be to warn us of Danger,
why fhould we not fuppofe they are from fome friendly Agent, ( whether fupreme, or inferior and fuburdinate, is not the Queftion) and that they are given for
our Good?
The prefent Quefion abundantly confirms me in the
Juflice of this Reafoning; for had I not been made
cautious by this ftcret Admonition, come it from whence
it will, I had been undone inevitably, and in a far
worfe Condition than before, as you will fee prefently.
I had not kept my felf long in this Pofture, but I
law the Boat draw near the Shore, as if they look'd for
a Creek to thruft in at for the Convenience of Landing; however, as they did not come quite far enough,
they did not fee the little Inlet where I formerly landed
my Rafts; but run their Boat on Shore upon the Beach,
at about half a Mile from ine, Which was very happy
for me; for otherwife they would have landed jufi, as
I may fay, at my Door, and would foon have beaten

All this while I kept my felf very clofe, not once daring to llir out of my Caftle, any farther than to my

very glad I was, to think how well k was fortify'd -
I knew it was no lefs than ten Hours before the Boat

kets: My Figure, indeed, was very fierce; I had my
formidable Goat-skin Coat on, with -the great Cap I
mentioned, a naked Sword, two Piftols in my Belt, and
a Gun upon each Shoulder.
It was my Defign, as I faid above, not to have made

The poor Man, with Tears running down his Face,

your Cafe?

Well, fays I, let us retreat out of their View or Hearing, left they awake, and we will refolve farther; fi>
they willingly went back with me, till the Woods cover'd us from them.
Look you, Sir, laid I, if I venture upon your Deliverance, are you willing to make two Conditions with
me; lie anticipated my Propofals, by telling me, that
both he and the Ship, if recover'd, fiould be wholly
direled and commanded by me in every thing; and if
the Ship was not recover'd, he would live and die with
me in what Part of the World foever I would fend
him; and the two other Men faid the fame.
Wtell, fays I, rmy Conditions are but two. I. TLat

your Hands, you will upon all Occafions give them up

Ifland, and in the mean time be govern'd by my
Orders.
2. That if the Ship is, or may be recover'd, you will

He gave me all the Ajfurances that the Invention
and Faith of Man could devife, that he would comply
with thefe modt realbnable Demandsand befides would

with Powder and Bal;l tell me next what you think is
proper to be done: He fhew'd all the Teftimony of hi.

Gratitude that he was able; but olfer'd to be wholly

one of them was kill'd on the Spot, and the other very
ruch wounded; but not being dead, he ftarted up

but the Captain flepping to him, told him, 'twas too

his Villainy, and with that Word knock'd him down
hith the Stok of his Musket fo that he never fpokt
more

Captain told them, he would fpa'-e their Lives, if they

and Foot while they were upon tlhe Ifland.
While this was doing, I itct lFiday with the Captain's Mate to the Boat, with Orders to fecure her, and

pleat.
It now remain'd, that the Captain and I fhould en*

and told him my whole Hiftory, which he heard with
an Attention even to Amazement, and particularly at
the wonderful Manner of my being furnifh'd with Pro,
vifions and Ammunition; and indeed, as ny Story is
a whole Colle&ion of Wonders, it affeted him deeply;
but when he refle&ted from thence upon himfelf, and
how I feem'd to have been preferv'd there on purpofe
to fave his Life, the Tears ran down his Face, and he
could not fpeak a Word more.
After this Communication was at an End, I carry'd
him and his two Men into my Apartment, leading them
in juf where I came out, vit. at the Top of the Houfg,
where I refrefh'd them with fuch Provifions as I had,
and few'd them all the Contrivances I had made, dur,
mng my, ong, long, inhabiting that Place.
All I ihew'd them, all I faid to thenm, was perfetl
amazing  but above all the Captain admir'd my For*
M  4                 tifica



( 248 )    >
tification, and how perfetly I had conceal'd my Retreat with a Grove of Trees, which having been now
planted near twenty Years, and the Trees growing
much ialfer than in EIggand, was become a little Wood,
and b thick, that it was unpafiable in any Part of it;
but at that one Side, where I had rekerv'd my little
winding PflTage into it: This, I told him, was my Caffle
and my Reficience; but that I had a Seat in the Count-y, as molt Princes have, whither I could retreat upon
Occafion, and I would fhew him that too another Time;
bat at prefent our Buiinefs was to confider, how to recover the Ship: He agreed with me as to that; but
told me, he was perftelly at a Lofs what Meafures to
take  for that there were flill fix and twenty Hands on
Board, who having enter'd into a curfed Confpiracy,
by which they had all forfeited their Lives to the Law,
would be harden'd in it now by Defperation; and would
carry it on, knowing that if they were reduc'd, they
fhculd be brought to the Gallows as foon as they came
to Enqland?, or to any of the Eglijbi Colonies; and that
thtrefole there would be no attacking them with ft
imhall a Number as we were.
I muted for fome time upon what he had faid, and
found it was a very:rational Conclufio, and that
therefore fomething was to be refolved on very fpeedily,
as well to draw the Men on Board into fome Snare for
their Surprize, as to prevent their Landing upon us,
and deflroying us: Upon this it prefently occur'd to
me, that in a little while, the Ship's Crew wondering
what was become of their Comrades, and of the Boat,
would certainly come on Shore in their other Boat, to
fee for them, and that then perhaps they might come
arm'd, and be too ltrong for ts: This he allow'd was
rational.
Upon this I told him, the firft Thing we had to do,
was to flave -the Boat, which lay upon the Beach, fo
that they might not carry her off; and taking every
thing out of her, leave her fo far ufelefs as not to be fit
to fwim; accordingly we went on Board, took the Arms
which were left on Board, out ofher, and wjlaterei
etif we found there, which was a Bottle of Brandy, and
another of Runi a few;Bisket Cakes, a Horni of Pow*

fays Rohinfon; fo he asked the Captain, and the Captain him{elf then calls out, You Smit/b, you know my

Upon this, Will. Atkins cry'd out, For God's fake,

neither; for it feems this Will. Atkins was the firfl Man
that laid hold of the Captain, when they firft mutiny'd,
and uied him barbaroufly, in tying his Hands, and giving him injurious Language: However, the Captain
told him he muft lay down his Arms at Difcretion,
an4oruft to the Governour's Mercy, by which he meant
me; for they all call'd me Governour.
In a Word, they all laid down their Arms, and begged their Lives; and I fent the Man that had parley'd
with then,, and two more, who bound them all; and
then my great Army of 50 Men, which particularly
with thofe three, were all but eight, came up and feiz'd
upon them all, and upon their Boat, only that I kept
my felf and one more out of Sight, for Reafons of State.
Our next Work was to repair the Boat, and to think
of feizing the Ship; and as~ for the Captain, now he had
Leifuire to parley with them, he expoftulate&w.ith them

and how certainly it mulf bring them to Mifery andi
Diftrefs in the End, and perhaps to the Gallows.
They all appear'd very penitent, and begg'd hard
for their Lives: As for that, he told them they were,
none of his Prifoners, but the Commander's of the
Ifland; that they thought they had fet him on Shore iw
a barren uninhabited Ifland, but it had pleas'd God fo
to direa them, that the I4and was inhabited, and that

Any one may guews how readily fich a Propofal wouldc

deepeil Imprecations, that they would be faithful to
him to the laft Drop, and that they fliould owe their

as long as they liv'd.
Well. fays the Captain, I muftt go and tell the Go.

him to content to it: So he brought me an Account of
the Temper he found them in; and that he verily believed they would be faithful.
However, that we might be very fcure, I told hium
he thould go back again, and chuie out five of them, and.

left them Iut to accept it; and it was now the Bufinefs
of the Prifuners, as much as of the Captain, to perfwade the other five to do their Duty.
Our Strength was now thus order'd for the Expedition. i. The Captain, his Mate, and Pa ffnger. 2,s

( 260 )
ask'd the Captain, If he was willing to venture

and may Man Friday, I did not think it was proper for

Employment enough for us to keep them afunder, and
fupply them with ViEtuals.
As to the five in the Cave, I refolv'd to keep them
faft; but Friday weht twice- a Day to them, to ftup
ply them  with Neceffaries; and I made the other two
carry Provifions to a certain Diftance, where friday

When I lhew'd my felF to the two Hoflages, it was

the Governour had;rder'd to look after them, and that

fhould be fetch'd into the Cafile, and be laid in Irons;
fo that as we never utffer'd them to fee me as Governour, fo I now appear'd as another Perfon, and fpoke of
the Governour, the Garribon, the Caftle, and the like,
upon all Occafions.
The Captain now had no Difficulty before him, but
to furnilh his two Boats, ftop the Breach of one, and
Man them; He made his Paffenger Captain of one,
with four other: Men; and himfelft and his Mate, and

Bufinefs very well; for they came up to the Ship about
Midnight: As foon as they came within Call of the

brought ol the Men and the Boat, but that it was a
long Time before they had found them, and the like;
holding them in a Chat, till they came to the'Ship's

with.their Arms; immediately knock'd down the Second Mate and Carpenter with the But-end of their

they fecur'd all the reft that were upon the Main and

down 'into the Cook-Room, making three Men they

When this was done, and all fafe upon Deck, the
Captain order'd the Mate with three Mllen to break into
the Round-Houfe, where the new Rebel Captain lay,
and, having taken the Alarm, was gotten up, and with
two Men and a Boy had gotten fire-Arms in their
Hands; and when the Mate with a Crow fplit open
the Door, the new Captain and his Men fir'd boldly
among them, and wounded the Mate with a MusketBall, which broke his Arm, and wounded two more of
the Men, but kill'd no body.
The Mate calling for Help, rufh'd however into the
Round-Houfe, wounded as he was, and with his Fiftol
ihot the new Captain though the Head, the Bullet entering at his Mouth, and came out again behind one of
his Ears; fo that he never fpoke a Word; upon which
the reft yielded, and the Ship was taken effe&ually,
without any more Lives loft.
As foon as the Ship was thus fecur'd, the Captain order'd feven Guns to be fir'd, which was the Signal agreed
upon with me, to give me Notice of his Succels, which
you may be fure I was very glad to hear, having fat
watching upon the Shore for it, till near two of the
Clock in the Morning.
Having thus heard the Signal plainly, I laid me down;
and it having been a Day of great Fatigue to me, I flept
veiy found, till I was fomething furpriz'd with the
Noife of a Gun; and prefently ftarting up, I hearda a
Man call me by the Name of Governour, Governour
and prelently I knew the Captain's Voice, when climbing up to the Top of the Hill, there he flood, and pointing to the Ship, he embrac'd me in his Arms, AMy dear
Friend and Delieverer, fays he, there's your Skip, fjorJke
is all yours, and fo are woe and all that belong to.her: I
caft my Eyes to -the Ship, and there fhe rode within
little more than half a Mile of the Shore; for they had
weigh'd her Anchor as foon as they were Mafters of her;
and the Weather being fair,,had brought her to an Anchor juft againft the Mouth of the little Creek; and.
the Tide being up, the Captain had brought the Pinpace




2( 262 )
mace in near dte Place where I firit landed my Rafts, arl
fo landed juft at my Door.
I was at irit ready to fink down with the Surprize:
For I faw my Deliverance indeed vifibly put into my
Hands, all Things eafy, and a large Ship juil ready to
carry me away whither I pleafed to go,- At firi, for
fome Time, I was not able to anfwer hinm one Word;
but as he had taken me in his Arms, I held faft by him,
or I fliould have fallen to the Ground.
He perceiv'd the Surprize, and immediately pulls a
Bottle out of his Pocket, and gave me a Dram of Cordial, which he had brought on purpofe for me; after I
drank it, I fat down upon the Ground, and though it
brought me to my feli, yet it was a good while before
I could fpeak a Vv ord to him.
All this while the poor Man was in as great an Extafy
as, only not under any Surprize, as I was; and he
faid a thoufand kind tender l hings to me, to compote
and bring me to my felf; but fuch was the Flood of Joy
in my Breaft, that it put all my Spirits into Confufion;
at laft it broke out into Tears, and in a little while alter
1 recover'd my Speech.
Then I took my Tarn, and embraced him as my De
liverer; and we rejoyc'd together: I told him, I look'd.upon him as a Man fent from H-eaven to deliver me,
and that the whole Tranfa&ion feem'd to be a Chain of
Wonders; that fuch Things as thefe were the Teflimonies we had of a fecret Hand of Providence govern.
ing the World, and an Evidence, that the Eyes of an
infinite Power could fearch into the remoterf Corner of
the World, and fnd Help to the Miferable whenever
he pleafed.
I forgot not to lift up my Heart in Thankfulnefs to
Heaven; and what Heart could forbear to blets him,
who had not only in a miraculous Manner provided for
one in fuch a Wildernefs, and in fuIh a defolate Condition, but from whom every Deliverance m uft always be
acknowledged to proceed!
When we had talk'da while, the Captain told me,
lie had brought me fome little Refrethments, fuch as the
Ship afforded, and fuch as the Wretches who had been fo
iong his Maiters had not plunder'dehim  of; Upon this
be




263 )
ie call'd aloud to the Boat, and bid his Men bring the
Things a-ihore that were for the Governour; and in.
deed it was a Prefent, as if I had been one, not that was
to be carry'd along with them, but as if I had been
to dwell upon the Ifland ftill, and they were to go with-.out me.
Firft he had brought me a Cafe of Bottles full of excellent Cordial Waters, fix large Bottles of Mlade? a Wine;
the Bottles held two Quarts a-piece; two Pound of
excellent good Tobacco, twelve good Pieces of the Ship's
Beef; and fix Pieces of Pork; with a Bag of Peafe, and;about a hundred Weight of Bisket.
He brought me allb a Box of Sugar, a Box of Flow-.er, a Bag full of Lemons, and two Bottles of Lime-juice,
and abundanceof other Things; But befides thefe, and
what was a thouland times more ufeful to me, he brought
me fix clean new Shirts, fix very good Neckcloths,
-two Pair of Gloves, one Pair of Shces, a Hat, and one
Pair of Stockings, and a very good Suit of Cloaths of
his own, which had been worn but very little: In a
Word, he cloathed nme from Head to Foot.
It was a very kind and agreeable Prelert, as any one.may imagine, to one in my Circurftances: But never
wvas any thingin the World of that Kind fo unplealant,,awkard, and uneafy as it was to me to wear fach Cloaths.at their firft putting on.
After theie Ceremonies pail, and after all his good
Things were brought into my little Apartment, we 1egan to confult what was to be done with the Pril(ners
'we had; for it was worth confidering, whether we.might venture to take them away with us or no, efpecially two of them, whom we knew to be inctrrigible
and refa&ory to the laft Degree; and the Captain faid, he
Aknew they were fuch Rogues, that there was no obliging them, and if he di4 carry them away, it mulftbein
Irons, as Malefa&ors, to be deiver'd over to Jufaice at
the firft Englihj Colony he could come at; and I found
that the Captain himlelf was very anxious about it.'
Upon this, I told him, that it he defir'a it, I durft
tendertake to bring the two Men he fpoke of, to make
it their own Requeft that he fnould leave them upon the
Ifland: I Jhould be very glad of that, fays the Captain,.vitb "all my 'eart.                         Wlle

Well, fetys, I will fend for them up, and talk wvith

for they were now difcharg'd, their Comrades having

were, to the Bower, and keep them there till I came. i
After fome Time, I came thither drefs'd in my newv
Habit, and now I was call'd Governour again; being
all met, and the Captain with me, I caus'd the Men to
lie brought befbre me, and I toldthem, I had had a fulll
Account of their villainous Behaviour to the Captain,
and how they had run away with the Ship, and were
-preparing to commit farther Robberies, but that Pro.
vidence had enfnar'd them in their own Ways, and that
they were fallen into the Pit which they had digged
for others.
I let them know, that by my Direfion the Ship had,been feiz'd, that fhe lay now in the Road, and they might
fee by-and-by, that their new Captain had receiv'd the
Reward of his Villainy; for that they might fee him
hanging at the Yard-Arm.
That as to them, I wanted to know what they had to
fay, why I ihould not execute them as Pirates taken in
the Fa&, as by my Commiffion they could not doubt i
had Authority to do.
One ofthem anfwer'd in the Name oflthe reft, That
they had nothing to fay but this, That when they were
taken, the Captain promis'ed them their Lives, and they.humbly implor'd my Mercy: But I told them I knew
not what Mercy to ihew them; for, as for my felf, I
had refolv'd to quit the Ifland with all my Men, and
had taken Paffage with the Captain to go for England:
And as for the Captain, he could not carry them to
England, other than as Prifoners in Irons to he try'd for
Mutiny and running away with the Ship; the Confe-quence of which, they muft needs know, would be the
Gallows; fo that I could not tell which was bef for
them, unlefs they had a Mind to take their Fate in thtI
fland; if they defir'd that, I did not care, as I had
Liberty to leave it I had fome Inclination to give themn
4heir Lives, ifthey:thought they could ihi-ftn Shore.., 1  *.., ',..  T hey




( 65 )
They feem'd very thankful for it, -faid they would
much rather venture to flay there, than to be carry'd to
England to be hang'd; ib 1 left it on that Illue.
However, the Captain feem'd to make lome Difficulty of it, as-if' he durit not leave them there: Upon this
I feem'd a little angry with the Captain, and told him,
That they we'e my -'rilfners not his; and that feing
I had offer'd them to mul.h Favour, I would be as good
as my Word; and that if he did not think fit to content
to it, I would fet them  at Liberty as I found them;

he could catch them.
Upon this they appeared very thankful, and I accordly iet them at Liberty, and bad them retire into the
Woods, to the Place whence they came, and I would
leave them fbme Fire Arms, Ibme Ammunition, and
fome Dire6aions how they fhould live very well, if they
thought -it.
Upon this, I prepar'd to go on Board the Ship, but
told the Captain, that I would flay that Night to prepare my Things, and defir'd him to go on Board in the
mean Time, and keep all right,in the Ship, and fend
the Boat on Shore the next Day for me; ordering 'him,
in the mean time, to caufe the new Captain who was
kill'd, to be hang'd at the Yard-Arm, that thef Men
might fee him.
When the Captain was gone, I fent for the Men up
to me to my Apartment, and entered ferioufly into Difcourfe with them of their Circunmfances: I told them,
I thought they had m-ade a right Choice; that if the
Captain carry'd them away they would certainly be
hang'd: I fliewed them the new Captain hanging at the
Yard-Arm of the Ship, and told them they had nothing
left to expe&.
When they had all declar'd their willingnefs to flay,
I then told them, I would let them into the Story of
my living there, and put them into the Way ofmaking
it eafy to them: Accordingly I gave them the whole
Hiftory of the Place, and of my coming to it; fhew'd
them my Fortifications, the way I made my Bread, planted my Corn, cured my Grapes; and in a Word, all that
was neceCary to make them eafy: I told them the StoN                  ry




( 266 )
Try alfo of the fixteen Spaniards that were to be expe&ed;
for whorml I left a Letter, and made them promile to.treat them in common with themfeves.
I left them my Fire-Arms, vii. Five Muskets, three
Fowling-Pieces, and three Swords: I had about a
Barrel of Powder left; for after the firtl Year or
two, I ufed but little, and wafted none: I gave them a
Defcription of the Way I managed the Goats, and Direations to milk and fatten them, and to make both Butter and Cheefe.
In a Word, I gave them every Part of my own Story;
and I told them, I would prevail with the Captain to
leave them two Barrels of Gun-Powder more, and fome
Garden-Seeds, which I told them I would have been.
vrery glad of; alfb I gave them the Bag of Peafe which.the Captain had brought me to eat, and bad them be
iiire to low and encreate them.
Having done all this, I left them the next Day, and.went on board the Ship: We prepar'd immediately to
fail, but did not weigh that Night: The next Morning early, two of the five Men catie fwimming to the
Ship's Side, and making a molt lamentable Complaint of
the other three, begg'd to be taken into the Ship, for
God's Sake, for they fhould be murder'd and begg'd the
Captain to take them on Board, tho' he hang'd them
immediately.
Upon this, the Captain pretended to have no Power
without me; but.after fbme, Difficulty, and after their
~olemn Prormiles of Amendment, they were taken on
Board, and were fane time after foundly vvhipp'd and
pickled; after which they prov'd very honeft and quiet
Fellows.
Some time after this, I went with the Boat on Shore,
the Tide being up, with the Things promifed to the
Men, to which the Captain, at my lnterceffion, caus'd
their CheRts and Cloaths to be added, which they took,
and were very thankful for:. I alfo encourag'd them,
iby telling them, that if it lay in my Way to fend any
~eflel to take them ini, I would not forget them.
When I took Leave ofthis lfland, I carry'd pn Board&
for Reliques the great Goat's Skin Cap I had made, my
l.ubrella, and one of my Parrots; alfo I frgot pn.
to




I  I         -- 1,1  1 z


( 267 )
to take the Money I formerly menti)n'd, which had lain
by me fo long ufelefs, that it was grown rufty, or tarniflh'd, and could hardly pafs for Silver, till it had been
a little rubb'd and handld; as alfo the Money I found
in the Wreck of the Spanijh Ship.
And thus I left the Ifland the Nineteenth of Decemw
sr, as I found by the Ship's Account, in the Year 1 S6,,
-after I had been upon it eight and twenty Years, twvo
Months, and nineteen Days; being deliver'd from the
*fecond Captivity the fallme Day of the Month that I firf
made my Efcape in the Barco-Longo, from among the
Mocrs of Salleo.
In this VefIel, after a long Voyage, I arriv'd in England, the Eleventh of yune, in the Year 1687, having
been thirty and five Years abfent.
When I came to England, I was a perfe& Stranger to
all the World, as if I had never been known there
My Benefaaor and faithful Steward, whom I haid left
in Truft with my Money, was alive, but had had great
iisfortunes in the World, was become a Widow the
fec.pnd Time, and very low in the World: I made her
eafy as to what fhe ow'd me, afiuring her, I would give
her no Trouble; but on the contrary, in gratitude te
her former Care and Faithfulnefs to me, I reliev'd her,
as my little Stock would afford, which at that Tinme
wouid indeed allow me to do but little for her; but I
affur'd her, I would never forget her former Kindnefs to
me; nor did I forget her, when I had fufficient to help
her;,as fhall be obferv'd in its Place.
I went down afterwards into Torklhire; but my Father was dead, and my Mother, and all the Family extin&; except that I found two Sifters, and two oftlie
Children of one of my Brothers; and as I had been long
ago given over for dead, there rad been no Provifion
made for me, fo that, in a Word, I found nothing to
relieve orafiftl me; and that little Mconey I had, would
not do fo much fbr me, as to fettling in the World.
I met with one Piece of Gratitude indeed, which I
did not expeL&; and this was, That the Mafter of:the
Ship, whom I had fo happily deliver'd, and by the fame
Means lav'd the Ship and Cargo, having given a very.
handfole Account to the Owners, ofthe Manner how I
N 2                had




( 268 )
had fav'd the Lives of the Men, and the Ship, they invited me tu meet them, and fome other Merchants concern'd, and all together made me a very handfome

two hundred Pounds Sterling.
But after making feveral Refle&ions upon the Circumltanccs of my Life, and how little M ay this wculd
go towards fettling me in the World, I refolv'd to go to.LsbSn, and fee it 1 might not come by fome Information of the State of my Flantation in the Brafils, and
of what was become of my Partner, who I had Realon
to fuppole had fome Years now, given me over for dead.
With this View I took Shipping for Lisbon, where I
arriv'd in April following; my Man Friday accompanying me very honelily in all thefeRamblings, and proving a mofl taithful Servant upon all Occafions.
W hen I came to Lisbon, I fbund out, by Enquiry, and
to my particular Satisfaaion, my old Friend the Captain of the Ship, who firfl took me up at Sea, off of the
Shore of' rick: He was now grown old, and had left
Oft the Sea, having put his Son, who was far from a
young Man, into his Ship; and who ftil ufed the Brafil Trade.  The old Man did not know me, and, indeed, I hardly knew himn; but I foon brought my felf
to his Remembrance, when I told him who I was.
After!ome paflionate Exprelfions of our old Acquaintance, I enquire', )you may be fure, after my Plantation
and my Partner: The old Man told me, he had not
been in the Brafils for about nine Years; but that he
could allure me, that when he came away, my Partner
was living, but the Truflees who I had join'd with him
to take Cognizance of my Part, were both dead; that
however, he believ'd that I would have a very good
Account of the Improvement of the Plantation; for
that upon the general Beliefof my being caft away and
drown'd, my Truflees had given in the Account of the
Produce of my Part of thePlantation, to the Procurator
Pifcal; who had appropriated it, in Cafe I never came
to claim it, one Third to the King, and two Thirds to
the Monaltery of St. A4gufii, to be expended for the
Benefit of the Poor, and for the Converfion of the Indians to the Catholick Faith; but that if I appear'd,

( 269 )
or any one for me, to claim the Inheritance; it floulct

or Steward of the Monaftery, had taken great Care all
along, that the Incumbent, that is to fay, my Partner,
gave every Year a faithful Accolun ot the Produce, of
which they receiv'd duly my Moiety.
I ask'd him, If he knew to what tHeight of Improvement he had brought the Plantation? And, whether
he thought it might be worth looking after? or whether, on my going thither, I fhould meet with no ObftruAtion to my polfetfing my juft Right in the Moiety?
He told me, he could not tell exatly to what Degree the Plantation was improv'd; but this he knew,
that my Partner was grown exceeding rich upon the
enjoying but one Half of it; and that, to the heft of
his Remembrance, he had heard, that the King's Third
of' my Part, which was, it feems, granted away to
fome other Monaftery, or Religious Houte, amounted
to above two hundred Moldores a Year; that as to my

Survivors of my two Truftees, were very fair honeft

their Hands, for my Account; being the Produce of
the Farm, while their Fathers held the Truft, and before it was given up, as above, which, as he remenber'd, was for about twelve Years.
I ihew'd my felf a little concern'd, and uneafy at this

have dy'd.

Providence of Heaven, which difpofes all Things, it

thole Veffels I had been made miferable, and in which

going to Paris only; fo that we were in all fix ofus, and
five Servants; the two Merchants, and the two PortugueJf contenting themfelves with one Servant between
two, to fave the Charge; and as for me, I got an EngliJb Sailor to travel with me as a Servant, betides my
Man Friday, who was too much a Stranger, to be capable of fupplyingthe Place of a Servant upon the Road.
In this Manner I let out from Lisbon: And our Company being all very well mount'd and arm'd, we made a
little Troop, whereof they did me the Honour to call
me Captain, as well becaufe I was the oldeft Man, as
becaufe I had two Servants, and, indeed, was the Original of the whole Journey.
As I have troubled you with none of my Sea Journals: fo I ihall trouble yQu now with none of my Land
Jour,




(. 278 )
Journal: But fbme Adventures that happen'd to us in
this tedious and difficult Journey, I mult not omit.
When wecame to Marid, we being all of us Strangers
to Spain, were willing: to flay tome Tims rto fee the
Court of Spain, and to fee what was worth obferving;
but it being the latter Part of the Summer, we haften'd
away, and let out from  M14adrid about the Middle of
toober: But when we came to the Edge of Navarre, wve
were alarm'd at feveral Towns on the Way, with an
Account, that fo much Snow was fallen on the French
Side of the Mountains, that feveral Travellers were oblig'd to come back to Pampeona, after having attempted at an extreme Hazard, to pafs on.
When we came to Pampeluna it felf, we found it fo
indeed; and to me that had been always ufed to a hot
Climate, and indeed to Countries where we could fcarce
bear any Cloaths on, the Cold was unfufferable; nor,
indeed, was it more painful than it was furprizing, to
come but ten Dajs before out of the Old Caflile, where
the Weather was not only warmln.but very hot; and
imnmediately to feel a Wind from the Pyrennsan Mountains, ib very keen, fo feverely cold, as to be intollerable,
andto endanger benumming and perifhing of our Fingers and Toes was very itrange.
PoorFriday was really frighted when he faw the Mountains all cover'd with Snow, and felt coldWeather, which
he had never feen or felt bcfore in his Life.
To mend the Matter, after we came to PafpelJua,
it continu'd Snowing with fo much Violence, and fo
long, that the People laid, Winter was come before its
Time, and the Roads, which were difficldt before, were
now quite impaffable; in a Word, the Snow lay in
fome Places too thick for us to Travel; and being not
hard frozen as is the Cafe in Northern Countries, there
was no going-without being in Danger of being bur.y'd
tive every Step: We laid no leIs than twenty Days
bt Pampeluna when (fecing the Winter coming on, and
ho likelyhopd of its being better, for it was the fevereat
Winter all over Eurcpe that had been known in many
Years) J propofed that we.ihould all go awvay to Fo. ie.
rabia, and there take Shipping for Bourdeaux, which
was a very little Voyage.




1-              1  I,  -   -  3,, I   W


( 79 )
But while we were confidering this, there came -in
four French Gentlemen, who having been flopped on the
French fide of ths Pafies, as we were on the Spanijb, had
found out a Guide, who traverfing the Country near the
Head, ofLanguedVc, had brought them over the Mountains by fuch Ways, that they were not much incoinm
moded with the Snow; and where they met with Snow
in any Quantity, they faid it was frozen hard enough
to bear them and their-Horfes.
We lent for this Guide, who told us, he would undertake to carry us the fame Way, with no Hazard from
the Snow, provided we were arm'd fufficiently to proted us from wild Beads; for, he faid, upon thefe great
Snows, it was frequent for fome Wolves to fhow themfelves at the Foot of the Mountains, being made ravenous for want of Food, the Ground being cjver'd with
Snow: We told him we were well enough prepared for
fuch Creatures as they were, it he would. erftre us
firom a Kind of two legged Wolves, which we were told
we were in moft Danger from, efpecially on the Fren/b
Side of the Mountains.
He fatisfy'd us there was no Danger of that Kind in
the Way that we were to go: So we readily agreed to
follow him, as did alfo twelve other Gentlemen, with
their Servants, tome French, fome SpanifJ, wlo, as I
faid, had attempted to go, and were oblig'd to come
bick again.
Accordingly we all fet out for Pampeluna, with oir
G6ide, on the fifteenth of November; and indeed, I
was furpriz'd, when inftead of going forward, he came
diretly baek with us, on the fame Koad that we came
from  Madrid, above twenty Miles; when being pafs'd
two Rivers, and come into the plain Country, we- ound
ourfelves in a warm Climate again, where the Country
was pleafant, and no Snow to be feen; but on a fudden,
turning to the Left, he approach'd the Mountains another Way; and tho' it is true, the Hills and Precipices
look'd dreadful, yet he made fo many Tours, fitel Meanders, and led us by fuch winding Ways, we were infenfibly pafs'd the Height of the Mountains, without being
much incumber'd with the Snow; and all on a fudden
"he afew't us the 2leafant fruitful Provinces of.Lang-.) as

doc and Gafccign, all green and flourihhing; tho'indeed

We were a little uneafy however, when we found it
fnow'd one whole Day, and at Night, fo faft, that we
could not travel; but he bids us be eat3y, we fhould lbon
be palt it all: We found, indeed, that we began to defcend every Day, and to come more North than before,
and fo depending upon our Guide, we went on.
It was about two Hours before Night, when our
Guide being fomething before us, and not juff in Sight,
out rufl'd three nlonitrous Wolves, and after them a
Bear, out of a hollow Way, adjoining to a thick Wood';
two of the Wolves flew upon the Guide, and had he
been halfa Mile before us, he had bee.n devour'd indeed,
before we could have help'd him: One of them taften'd
upon his Horfe, and the other attacked the Man with
that Violence, that he had not Time, or not Prefence of
Mind enough to draw his Piftol, but hollowed and cry'd
out to ts molt luftily; my Man Friday being next to me,
I bid him ride up, and fee what was the Matter: As
foon as Friday came in Sight ofthe Man, he hollow'd as
loud as t'other, 0 Mafier! 0 Aafler! But like a bold
Fellow, rode dire6ly up to the poor Man, and with his
Piftol fhot the Wolf that attacked him into the Head.
It was happy for the poor Man, that it was my Man
Friday; for he hlaving been uied to that kind of Creatuee,in his Country, had no Fear upon him; but went clofe
upto him, 'and fhot him, as above; whereas any of' us
Would have fir'd at a farther Diftance, and have perhaps either mifs'd the Wolf; or endangered fhooting the
Man.
But it was enough to have terrify'd a bolder Man than
I, and indeed it alarm'd all our Company, when with.
the Noife of Friday'sPiftol, we heard Xn both Sides the
difimlleft howling of Wolves, and the Noife redoubled
by the Eccho of the Mountains, that it was to us as if

'perhaps indeed, there was not fuch a few, as that we hd
no Caufe of Apprehenfions.
However, as F? iday had killed this Wolf, the other,
that had faflen'd upon the Horfe left. him inmediatel,

( 28I )
and fled, having happily faften'd upon his Head, where

twice, once on the Arm, and the other Time a little above his Knee; and he was jutt as it were tumbling
down by the Diforder of the Horfe, when Friday came
up and hlot the Wolf.
It is ealy to fuppofe, that at the Noife of Friday's Pitol, we all mended our Pace, and rid up as faft as the
Way (which was very difficult) would give us Leave,
to fee what was the Matter; as foon as we came cleat
of the Trees, which blinded us before, we faw plainly
what had been the Cafe, and how Friday had difengaged
the poor Guide; though we did not presently difcern
what Kind of Creature it was he had killed.
But never was a Fight manag'd fo hardily, and in fuch
a furprizing Manner, as that which follow'd between
Friday and the Bear, which gave us all (though at firit
we were furpriz'd and afraid for himn.the greateft Diveriion imaginable: As the Bear is a heavy, clumfey
Creature, and does not gallop as the Wolf does, who is
fwift and light;fo he has two particular Q)ualities, which
generally are the Rule of his A&ions; Firfl, As to Men,
who are not his proper Prey, I fay, not his proper Prey,
becaufe, tho' I can't fay what excefive hunger might do,
which was now their Cafe, the Ground being all cover'd with Snow; yet as to Men, he does not ufually
attempt them unlefs they firft attack him: On the contrary,if you meet him in theWoods,tho'if you don't meddle with him, he won't meddle with you; yet then you
muft take care to be very civil to him, and give him the
Road, for he is a very nice Gentleman, he won't go a
flep out of the Way for a Prince; nay, if you are really
afiaid, your beft way is to look another Way, and keep
going on; for fometimes, if you ftop, and fand ftill
and look ftedfaftly at him, he takes it for an Affront;
but if you throw or tofi any thing at him, and it hits
him, though it were but a Bit ot Stick as big as your
Finger, he takes it for an Affront, and fets all his other
Bufinefs afide to purfie his Revenge, for he will have
Satisfaeion in Point of Honour, that is his firft Quality:




( 282 )
The next is, That if he be once affronted, be will never
leave you, Night or Day, till he has his Revenge, but
follow, at a good round Rate, till he overtakes you.
My Man Friday had deliver'd our Guide, and when

This was, indeed, a good Diverfion to us; but we

of W'olves run much in my Head; and indeed, except
the Noife I once heard on the Shore of A'rica, of which
I have faid fomething already, I never heard any thing
that fill'd me with fo much Horror.
Thefe things, and the Approach of Night, called us
off, or elfe, as Friday would have had us, we lhould
certainly have taken the Skin of this monftrous Creature off, which was worth faving; but we had three
Leagues to go, and our Guide haffen'd us, fo we left
him and went forward on our Journey.
The Ground was ftill cover'd with Snow, tho' not
ib deep and dangerous as on the Mountains, and the
ravenous Creatures, as we heard afterwards, were come
down into the Foreft and plain Country, prefs'd by
Hunger to feek for Food; and had done a great deal of
Yifchiefin the Villages, where they furpriz'd the Country-People, kili'd a great many of their Sheep and
Horfes, and rome People too.
We had one dangerous Place to pafs, which our
Guide told us, if there were any more Wolves in the
Country, we fhould find them there; and this was a
fmiallPlain, furrounded with Woods on every Side,
and a long narrow Defile or bane, which we were to
pats to get through the Wood, and then we 1hould come
to the Village where we were to lodge.
It was within half an Hour of Sun-fet when we enter'd the firtt Wood; and a little after Sun-let, when,ve came into the Plain, we met with nothing in the
firft Wood, except that in a little Plain within the
Wood, which was not above two Furlongs over, we
faw five great Wolves crois the Road, full Speed one
after another, as if they had been in Chafe of fome
Prey, and had it in View, they took no Notice of us,
and were gone, and out of our Sight in a few Moments.
Upon -this our Guide, who by the Way was a
wretched faint-hearted Fellow, bid us keep in a ready
Pofture;




( 286 )
pofture for he believ'd there were more Wolves a
coming.
We kept our Arms ready, and our Eyes about us,
but we law no more Wolves, 'till we came thro' that
Wood, which was near half a League, and enter'd the
Plain; -as foon as we came into the Plain, we had Occation enough to look about us; the firft Objef we met
with, was a dead Horfe; that is to fay, a poor Horfe,
which the Wolves had kill'd, and at leaft a Dozen of
them at Work; we could not fay eating of him, but
picking of his Bones rather; for they had eaten up all
the FleIh before.
We did not think fit to diffurb them at their Feaft,
neither did they take much Notice or us: Friday would
have let fly at them, but I would not fuffer him by
any Means; for I found we were like to have more Bufinefs upon our Hands than we were aware of; We
were not gone half over the Plain, but we began to
hear the Wolves houl in the Wood on our Lett, in a
frightful Marner; and prefently after we Law about a
hundred coming on diretly towards us, all in a Body,
and mofft o them in a Line, as regularly as an Army
drawn up by experienc'd Officers: I fcarce knew in
what Manner to receive them; but found to draw ourfelves in a clofe Line, was the only way: So we form'd
in a Moment: But that we might Iiot have too much
Interval, I order'd, that only every other Man fhould
ire, and that the others who had not fir'd, would fland
ready to give them a fecond Volley immediately, if
-they continued to advance upon us, and that then thofe
'who had fir'd at firft, fhould not pretend to load their
Fuzees again, but ftand ready with every one a Piflol,
fot we were all arm'd with a Fuzee, and a Pair of Piflols each Man; to we were by this Method able to fire
fix.Volleys, halfof us at a time; however, at prefent
we had no Neceflity, for upon firing the firft Volley,
thie Enemy made a full Stop, being terrified as well
with the Noife, as with the Fire  four of them being
4hot into the Head, dropp'd; feveral others were wounda   ~ed, and went bleeding off, as we could fee by the Snow:
I found they ftopp'd, but did not immediately retreat;
Whereqpon -rgeembring -that I had been told, that the,fierceRf




( 287    )
fierceRf Creatures were terrify'd at the Voice of a Many
I caus'd all our Company to hollow as loud as we could;
and I found the Notion not altogether miftaken, for
upon our Shout, they began to retire, and.turn about;
then I or.dr'd.a fecond Volley to be fir'd, in their Rear,
which put them to the Gallop, and away they went to,the Woods.
This gave us leifure to charge our Pieces again, and
that we might lofe no Time, we kept going; but we
had but little more than loaded our Fuzees, and put
our felves into a Readinefs, when we heard a terrible
Noiie in the fame Wood, on our Left, only that it wvas
farther onward the fame Way we were to go.
The Night was coming on, and the Light began to
be dusky, which made it the worfe on cur Side but the
Noife encreafing, we could eafily perceive that it was
the howling and yelling of thofe hellifih Creatures and
on a fudden, we perceiv'd two or three Troops of
Wolves, one on our left, one behind us, and one on cur
Front; fo that we feem'd -tobe furrounded with them;
however, as they did not fall upon us, we kept our
Way forward, as faft as we could make our Horits go,
which the Way being very rough, was only a good
large Trot; and in this manner we came in View of
the Entrance of a Wood, thro' which we were to pals,
at the farther Side of the Plain; but we were greatly
furpriz'd, when coming near the Lane, or Pals, we law
a oonfus'd Number of Wolves ltanding juft at tLe Entrance.
On a fudden, at another opening of the Wood, we
lieard the Noife of a Gun; and looking that Way, outruih'd a Horfe, with a Saddle, and a Bridle on him,
Rlying like the Wind, and fixteen or feventeen Wolves
after him, full Speed; indeed, the Horfe had the Heels
of them; but as we fuppos'd that he could not hold it
at that rate, we doubted. not bt~ they would get up.

there lay a Gun jufl by him fir'd off; but as to the Man,

This fill'd us with Horror, and we knew not what

and I verily believe there were three hundred of them:
It happen'd very much to our Advantage, that at the
Entrance into the Wood, but a little Way from it,
there lay fome large Timber Trees, which had been
cut down the Summer before, and 1 fuppofe, lay there
for Carriage: I drew my little Troop in among thofe
Trees, and placing our felves in a Line, behind one long
Tree, I advis'd them all to Light, and keeping that
Tree before us, for a Breafl-Work, to ftand in a Triangle, or three Fronts, enclofing our Horfes in the
Center.
We did fo, and it was well we did; for never was a
more furious Charge than the Creatures made upon us
in this Place; they came on us with a growling kind of
a Noifeand mounted the Piece of Timber, (which as I
faid, was our Break-Work, as if they were only rufhing
upon their Prey; and this Fury of theirs, it feems, was
principally occafion'd by their feeing our Horfes behind
us, which wvas the Prey they aimed at: I order'd our
Men to fire as before, every other Man; and they took
their Aim fo fure, that indeed they kill'd feveral of the
Wolves at the firIt Volley  but there was a Neceflity to
keep a continual Firing; for they came on like Devfls,
thofe behind, puffing on thofe before.
When we had fir'd our fecond Volley of our Fuzees,
we thought they flopped a little, and I hop'd they
would have gone off, but it was but a Moment,+ for
others came forward again; fo we fir'd two Volleys of
our Piflols, and I believe in thefe four Firings, we killed feventeen or eighteen of them, and lam'd twice as
many; yet they came on again.

about we,, the Bills of Excliange whicl I brought wish
