Mty principal Guide, and IPrivy-Counfellor, was my, good ancient Widow, who in Gratitude for the MAoney
I had Lent her, thought no Pains too much, or Care
too great, tp employ Ior me; and I trufted her lb entire)l wi'th ev&ry Th'ing, thatI was perfe&tly ea{5 as to the;+ecuriyo(f X my Eff'fts; and indeed,, was very happy
from niy Beginning, and now to the End, in the unipottes Integrity of this good Gentlewoman.
And'now I began to think of leaving my Effeas witjl
this Woman, and fetting out for Lisbon, and. lb to the
Brafls:.But now another Scruple came in my Way, and,that was Religion; for as I had entertain'd Lome Doubts
aout \the Roman, Religion, even while I was abroad,
ifpedially in my State of Solitude; fo I knew there w~s
n9 going to the Brafils for me, much lefs going to fettle
}Ither~, unlefs I refolv'd to embrace the Roman Cathalick Religion, without any Referve; except on the other
hand, I refolv'd to be a Sacrifice to my Principles, be
a Martyr for Religion, andI die in the Inquifition; fo
I retolv'd to flay at Home, and if I could find Means
Tor it, to difpofe of my Plantation... To this Purpofe I wrote to my old Friend at Lisbon,.
wIvho in Return gave me' Notice, that he could eafily
difpofe of it there: But that. if I thought fit to give
him Leave to offer it in my Name to the two Merchants,
the Survivors of my Truftees who liv'd in. the Brafils,
'who muft fu.lly underftand the Value of it, who liv'dc
juft upon the Spot, and who I knew were very rich,
lb that he believ'd they would be fond of buying it; he
aid not doubt, but I fhould make 4 or 5oQo Pieces of
Eight the more of it.:..
Accordingly I agr6ed, gave him Order to offer it to
thMm, and ie did fo; and in about eight Months more,
tlie Ship being then return'd, he Lent me an Account,
that they had accepted the Offer, and had remitted
3300o Pieces of Eight, to a Correfpondent of theirs at
Lisbcn, to pay for it.
In Return, I figned! the InfIrument of Sale in the
Form, which they lent from Lisbon~ and fent it to my
old Man, who fent ime Bills of Exchange for 328co
' 0 2                      '"      'Piees




1'ieces of Eight  for the Eftate; refervipg - the'ayxnent of too Moidores a - Year to him, thee 'd Miti,
during his Lif&, anld 5o Moidores afterwards to' his
Son for his Life, whiclh I had promis'd them; and: which
the; Plantationwas to make good as a Rent-Charge.
And thus I have' given the firfL 1art of a Life Of
Fortune and Adventure, a ife of' Providence's Ch equer-Work, and of a Variety which the WOirld will
feldom b* able to thew the like of:, Beginning fooliihly, hut clofing much more happily than.ay at of it
ever gave me Leave fo much as to hope for.,
Any one would think, that in this State of. compli.
cated good Fortune, I was paft runningiany niore Hazards; and fo indeed I had been, if other Circumftances.
had concurred, but I was innured to a wandering itge,
bad no Family, -nor many Relations,4 nor, however rifch
had i       eonera&e  much' Acquaintance; and through i hid
fold my Eflate in the Brafils, yet I qould not keep tAt
Country out of my Head, and had a great Mind ti to'eupon the Win again, Ifpqciall y T could nor relifl'thie
ironig Inclination I had to fee my lIand, and to know
if the poor spdniards were in Being there, and how~' le
Rogues I left there) had ufed thenm.,
My true Friend the Widowea r  1ieftlly adifwadd  me
froon' it, alnd -'I frpre4 irai  with' me, that for' allizhft
even Yearis R-lhte preenteld 'my running abroad; di
which Time, I todk xiy tw6 Nephews, the ClAIdrn t
one of' my Brothers, into my Care. The eldenf havihg'
fomething of bis ow n I bred uup as a Gentlemban and
gave him a Settlement of' fome Addition to  s h fiate,
after my D)eceafe; the other I put out to a Captain ofa Ship; -and after 1filV  Years, fnding him anfl~,
bold, enterprzing young Fellow, I put hini into a good
Sh~rip, a  tnd oera himto: And thbs young Fellow afterwards -drew me in' as ~4d as I was, ta ftrther AdIie.
tures my felf.
In the mean time, I in part fettled my felf here; for
~drfl of all I maarry'd, and that not either to miy Difadvantage or Dilfatisfiaion, and had three Children, twVo
Sons and one Daughters But my Wife dyini, -and my.
Nephew c    ng Home with 9god SEef fro    a Voy.
age to S9aiz, nm Inclination to go-abroad, andr;his finPortunity,




(2    3 )
portunity, prevailed and ehgag'd me to gb in his Ships
as a private, Trader to the Ef-lndies: This was in the
'Year 1694.
In this Voyage I vifited my new Colony in the Ifland,
faw my Succeofrs the Spaniards, had the whole Story
of theit Lives, and of the Villains I left there, how at.,irft they infulted the poor Spaniards, how they afterwards agreed, difagreed, united, feparated, and how at
laft the Spaniards were oblig'd to uife Violence with
them i how they were fubjected to the Spaniards  how
honefHy the Saniards us'd them; a Hiftory, if it were
enter'd into, as full of Variety and wonderful Accidents, as my own Part, particularly alfo as to their Battles with the Carribeans, wh6 landed feveral times upon
the Ifland, and as to the ImproVement they made upon
the ISland itfelf, and how five of them made-an Attempt
upon the main Land, and biught away eleven Men and
five Women Prilbners, by which, at my coming, I found
about twenty young Children on the Iland.
Here I flay'd about 2o Days, left them Supplies of all
neceffary Things, and particularly of Arms, Powder,
Shot, Cloaths, Tools, and two Workmen, which I
brought from England with n, viz.- a Carpenter and a
Smith:.
Befides this, I fhar'd the Ifland into Parts with 'em,
referv'd to myfelf the Property of the whole, but gate
thefi fiuch Parts, refpefRively as they agreed on; and.
having fettled all Things with thenm, and engaged them
not to leave the Place, I left them there.
From thence I touch'd at the Brails, from whence I
fent a Bark, -which I bought there, with more People,
to the Iflahd, and in it, befides other Supplies, I int
feven Women, being fuch as I found proper for Setvice, or for Wives to fiuch as would take them: As to
the Exglblj Men, I promis'd themi to fend them fotm
Women from England, with a good Cargo of Neceffaries,if they would apply themfelves to Planting, which I
afterwards could not perform: The Fellows prov'd very
honeft and diligent, after they were mafter'd, and had
their Properties fet apart for them. I Lent them alfo
from the Brts five Cows three of them being bi
-               with




(  294 )
itvh Calf, fQme Sheep, and foe Mgs, which,. when
I came again, Were confiderably epcreas4.
~ But all there Things, With an Account' how 3o0 Ckribbes canme and invaded them, and ruin'd their Plantations, and how. they fought with that whole Number
twice, and were. at firi. defeated, and one of thegi
* Mkill'd; but at laft a Srorm deftlroying their Enemics c<noes, they fanifh'd or deflroy'd almoft all the reff, aad
renew'd and recover'd the PofIeffion oftheir Plantation,
and fill liv'd upon the fland.
All thefe Things, wvith fome very furprizing Incidents in fome new Adventures of my own, for ten Years
more, I may perhaps give a farther Account of hereafter.
